PAGE: 1
HEADING: FRESENIUS

*Fresenius, [Johann Baptist] Georg [Wolfgang] (1808-1866), German physician and
botanist, born 25 Sep 1808 in Frankfurt am Main where he went to school, from 1826 at
Heidelberg Univ. studying medicine, and later at Würzburg and Giessen, Dr. med. 1829
Giessen, practiced in Frankfurt am Main but greatly interested in botany, dir. of the Botanic
Garden and lectured 1831-1866 for the Senckenbergische naturforschende Gesellschaft and
the Medicinische Gesellschaft, died 1 Dec 1866 of pneumonia in Frankfurt. (<em>Fresen</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: FR (some destroyed). – <em>Exsiccatae</em>: Fresenius contributed to G.L.
Rabenhorst, <em>Algen Europa's</em>, see TL-2/4: 465, exsiccata (15).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: ADB 7: 352-353; Ainsworth p. 176; Andrews p. 265; APN
p. 210; Backer p. 650; Baillon 2: 644; Barnhart 2: 8; Biol.-Dokum. 6: 72.250-72.263; BM
2: 618; Bossert p. 133; CSP 2: 717, 6: 661, 7: 710; De Toni 1: xlix, 2: l; Frank 3(Anh.): 32;
GR p. 78; Hawksworth p. 182; Herder p. 451 (index); Hortus 3: 1193; IH 2: 208; Jackson
p. 347, 350; Kelly p. 251; Kew 2: 338; LS 9173-9185; Mägdefrau p. 310 (index); NAF 1(1):
158, 2(2): 157; NDB 5: 405; Nordstedt p. 15; Portr. 3: 450; PR ed. 1: 3362-3364, ed. 2:
3045-3052; Quenstedt p. 148; Rehder 5(index): 297; Sarjeant p. 1043; Stevenson p. 1242;
TL-1: 158; TL-2/1: 875-876, 2/4: 1171 (index); Tucker 1: 262; Zander ed. 10: 661, ed. 11:
752, ed. 17: 948.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bot. Zeitung (Berlin) 25: 7-8. 1867; Flora 50: 14. 1867; Senckenberg.
	Naturf. Ges. Jubiläumsband I: 281-285?. 1992. (biogr.)
Bay, J.C., 1910. Flora Gesamt-Register 26-100: 11.
Blum, J., 1901. Ber. Senckenberg. Naturf. Ges., Wiss. Abh. 1901: 7, 13-14.
Candolle, A.L., 1880. Phytographie: 412.
Conert, H.J., 1967. Senckenberg. Biol. 48(C): 17-23. (portr. p. 27)
Conert, H.J., 1987. Ber. Deutsch. Bot. Ges. 100: 200-203.
De Bary, H.A., 1867. Bot. Zeitung (Berlin) 25: 7-8.
Engelmann, W., 1846. Bibl. Hist.-Nat.: 677. (index)
Schmidt, A., 1998. Mycoses 41, Suppl. 2: 89-91. (n.v.)
Schmidt, A. &amp; D.I. Schmidt, 1999. Contr. Microbiol. 2: 1-4. (biogr.) (n.v.)
Urban, I., 1906. <em>In</em>, C. Martius, Fl. Bras. 1(1): 173.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: (additional) <em>Fresenia</em> Fuckel (1866).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: (1) The entry for <em>Beitr. Fl. Abyssin.</em> ... 1836-1845 (TL-2/1, nr. 1858) can be cor-
rected as follows:

	Anon., Flora 20(Lit.): 184. 28 Dec 1837 (rev. 3).

form editions: (a) <em>Microfilm</em>: Chapel Hill, North Carolina (Univ. of North Carolina Library,
Photographic Service), 1960, 1 reel (35 mm). <em>Copy</em>: (n.v.). (b) <em>Microfiche</em>: Zug, Switzer-

(Meckler/Chadwyck-Healey Publishing), [1987?], 3 microfiches (Plant taxonomic lit. mi-
crofiche coll.). <em>Copy</em>: MO (n.v.).

*Frey [-Stauffer], Eduard [Édouard] (1888-1974), Swiss biology teacher and lichenolo-
gist, born 3 Nov 1888 in Meiringen (Oberhaslital) where he grew up, taught at a primary
school 1909-1911 and a girls' school in Bern 1914-1939, Dr. Sci. Nat. 1922, taught biology
at a teachers' college 1939-1956, died 23 Apr 1974 in Langenthal (Kt. Bern), "the grand old
man of European lichenology ..." (<em>teste</em> Almborn, 1971). (<em>Frey</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: G (40,000 Lich. transfered from BERN), duplicate material B,
BCC, CHUR, LD, M, RUEB, SIGMA, W.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 210; Barnhart 2: 9; BFM p. 284 (index); Chris-
tiansen p. 315 (index); GR p. 631-632, <em>pl</em>. [<em>21</em>]; GR cat. p. 63; Hirsch p. 89; IH 2: 208; Kew
2: 338; Kleppa p. 321 (index); LS suppl. 8927-8940; MW p. 129; Portr. 1: 62 (index), 3:
450; Roon p. 41; SBC p. 120; TL-2/1: 876-877, indices 2/4, Suppl. 3.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Intl. address book botanists: 328. 1931.
Almborn, O., 1971. Bot. Not. 124: 522. (on Frey's "Flechten" 1969)
Clerc, Ph., 1998. Meylania 14: 14-19.
Clerc, Ph., 2001. Meylania 20: 17-22. [transfer of Frey's crypt. herb. to G]

HEADING: FREY

Welten, M. &amp; K. Ammann, 1976. Rev. Bryol. Lichénol. 42: 1011-1015. (bibl., phot.)

<sm>OUTSIDE OUR PERIOD</sm>: (1) <em>Botanique</em> ... 1949, French "adaptation" by René Baumgartner
of a school text book.
(2) Die <em>Flechtenflora</em> und -<em>vegetation</em> des <em>Nationalparks</em> im <em>Unterengadin</em> ... 1952-1959,
2 vols.
(3) <em>Flechten</em>: <em>Unbekannte Pflanzenwelt</em> ... In series, Hallwag Taschenbücher, Bd. 89. 1969.
<em>Copy</em>: US; and its French transl., <em>Lichens: un monde végétal méconnu</em> ... Petits atlas Payot
Lausanne no. 62. 1970. <em>Ref</em>.: Almborn, O., Bot. Not. 124: 522. 1971 (brief rev. of <em>Flechten</em>).

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) One of a number of co-authors with J. Braun-Blanquet, <em>Veget.-
entw. Schweiz. Nat.-park</em> ... 1931, see TL-2/Suppl. 3, nr. 22.668.
(2) Contributed "Cladoniaceae ... Umbilicariaceae" to <em>Rabenh. Krypt.-Fl. ed. 2</em> ... Band 9,
Abt. 4, I. Hälfte, 1932-1933 (see TL-2/4, nr. 8450); this part of the larger work also avail-
able as a reprint: 1971 ... New York [etc.] (Johnson Reprint). <em>Copy</em>: (n.v.).
(3) A. Zahlbruckner acknowledged the collaboration of Frey and J[ózef]. Motyka (1900-
1984) in publishing A. Zahlbruckner &amp; L. Hauman, <em>Les Lichens des hautes altitudes au
Ruwenzori</em> ... (1936), see TL-2/7, nr. 18.544.
(4) One of the editors of <em>Herzogia</em> (1968-1974); vol. 1(2) of 1969 was dedicated to Frey on
the occasion of his 80th birthday.

HEADING: FREYN

Freyhold, [Ferdinand] Edmund [Joseph Karl (Carl)] von (1845-x), German botanist
(morphologist), born 26 Dec 1845 in Sommerfeld (Frankfurt an der Oder), taught at sec-
ondary school in Eupen, Dr. ès-sciences naturelles 1875 Strassburg, prof. at Freiburg in
Breisgau 1884 [listed at Pforzheim in 1886, 1887 and 1891]. (<em>Freyhold</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 9; BM 2: 619; CSP 7: 711, 9: 928; Jackson p.
91, 104; Kew 2: 338; Morren ed. 10: 25; Rehder 1: 115.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Dörfler, I., 1896. Botaniker-Adressbuch: 15; 1909. Id., ed. 3: 34.
[Engelmann, W.], 1891. Botanisches Adressbuch: 154.

35.517. Ueber <em>Symmetrieverhältnisse</em> und Zygomorphismus der <em>Blüthen</em> ... Separatabdruck
aus dem 1874er Herbstprogramm der höheren Bürgerschule zu Eupen ... Eupen (Buch-
und Steindruckerei von Jul. Mayer) 1874. Qu. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 1874 (Bot. Zeitung (Berlin) 27 Nov 1874, Flora 11 Dec 1874), p. [1]-33. <em>Copies</em>: G, K, U.
<em>Ref</em>.: Anon., Bull. Soc. Bot. France 22(RBC-D): 168-169. 1875 [i.e. Jan-Feb 1876] (rev).

35.518. <em>Beitraege zur Pelorienkunde</em>. Botanische Inaugural-Dissertation, der mathema-
tischen und naturwissenschaftlichen Facultät der Universität Strassburg zur Erlangung der
Doktorwürde vorgelegt ... Eupen (Druck und Lithographie von Wwe. J. Emonds) 1875.
Oct. (<em>Beitr. Pelorienkunde</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1875, p. [i-ii], [1]-69, [70], <em>1 pl</em>. (uncol. lith). <em>Copies</em>: FH (n.v), G, MO (n.v).

35.519. Ueber <em>Blüthenbau</em> und <em>Verstäubungsfolge</em> bei <em>Tropaeolum pentaphyllum</em> ... Dresden
(Druck von E. Blochmann und Sohn) 1876 [i.e. 1877]. Qu. (<em>Blüthenbau Tropaeolum</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1876 (submitted 5 Sep 1876), t.p., p. [2, blank], [3]-32, <em>pl. 1</em> (uncol. draw). <em>Copies</em>:
	BM (n.v), NY (n.v), U. – Issued as Nova Acta Acad. Caes. Leop.-Carol. German. Nat.
	Cur. 39(1): 1-32, <em>pl. 1.</em> 1876 [i.e. 1877].

*Freyn, Josef [József, Joseph] Franz [František] (1845-1903), Austrian civil engineer and
amateur botanist, born 7 Dec 1845 in Prague (now Czech Republic), where he attended
gymnasium 1856-1862 and became interested in botany, attended technical high school,
Prague 1862-1865, engineering school, Vienna 1865-1867, employed in the construction of
railways in Hungary and studied the Hungarian flora, later employed in Istria 1874-1878,
returned to Bohemia 1878 and then Prague 1881 where he owned a construction business,
died 16 Jan 1903 in Prag-Smichow. (<em>Freyn</em>).

<sm>HERBARIA</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: B, BP, BRNM, F, GB, GE, GOET, IBF, L, LE, MANCH, MJ, OXF,
W. – Some corr. GH (Archives, Jane Loring Gray Autograph Collection).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 4: 26, 27, 12(1): 262, 12(3): 393; APN p. 210; Backer
p. 223, 650; Barnhart 2: 9; Biol.-Dokum. 6: 72.789-72.807; BJI 1: 20; BM 2: 470, 656, 6:
345; BN p. 173; Bossert p. 133; Clokie p. 168; CSP 7: 711, 9: 928, 12: 252, 15: 128; DTS 1:
72-73, 6(4): 139; Frodin ed. 2: 556; Futak-Domin p. 208; Hegi 5(2): 1409, 6(1): 100, 6(2):
1227; Herder p. 323; Hortus 3: 1193; IH 2: 209; Jackson p. 267; Kew 2: 338-339; Klášterský
p. 81; Lenley p. 174; Maiwald p. 277 (index); Morren ed. 10: 33; MW p. 129; NDB 5: 424;
ÖBL 1(4): 360; Portr. 3: 450; Rehder 5(index): 298; Saccardo 1: 76, 179, 2: 51, 122, cron.
xxii; Strid p. 119, ed. 2: 165; TL-2/1: 877, indices 2/4, 2/5; Tucker 1: 262; 2: xvi; Urban-
Berl. p. 346; Wagenitz p. 58; Zander ed. 10: 66, ed. 11: 752; ed. 17: 948.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Deutsche Bot. Monatsschr.: 44-45. 1903.
Barbey, W., 1903. Bull. Herb. Boissier, sér. 2, 3: 160.

PAGE: 6
HEADING: FREYN

Dörfler, I., 1896. Botaniker-Adressbuch: 112; 1902. Id., ed. 2: 151.
[Engelmann, W.], 1891. Botanisches Adressbuch: 49.
Franks, J.W., 1973. Manchester Mus. Publ., new ser., no. NS.1.73: 3, 14.
Hackel, E., 1903. Oesterr. Bot. Z. 53: 99-104. [also as a 5 p. reprint]
Schiffner, V., 1904 [i.e. 7 Jul 1905]. Ber. Deutsch. Bot. Ges. 22: (15)-(21). (bibl.)

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) Contributed Ranunculaceae, at least, to F. Buchenau, <em>Reliquiae
rutenbergianae</em> ... 1880-1889, see TL-2/4: 1008.
(2) Contributed <em>Hieracium</em> (p. 336-354) to J. Velenovsky, <em>Fl. Bulg.</em> ... 1891, see TL-2/6, nr.
15.982, where Freyn is not mentioned.

35.520. <em>Beitrag</em> zur <em>Flora Ober-Ungarns</em> ... 1872. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 1872 (p. [341] "Vorgelegt in der Sitzung vom 1. Mai 1872"), p. [341]-354. <em>Copy</em>: HH.

*Friche-Joset, François [b. François Joset] (1799-1846), French-born Swiss horticulturist,
born 27 Mai 1799 in Courfaivre (Mont-Terrrible, France, now Ct. Jura, Switzerland), suc-

PAGE: 10
HEADING: FRICKHINGER

cessively at Soleure, Delémont, Porrentruy 1832-ca. 1841 and Altkirch where he died on 14
Dec 1846. (<em>Friche-Joset</em>).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 210; Barnhart 2: 10; BL 2: 560; BM 2: 620, 6: 346;
Jackson p. 344; PR ed. 2: 3056; Rehder 5(index): 298; TL-2/1: 878; Tucker 1: 262.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Charpin, A. &amp; G.G. Aymonin, 1999. J. Bot. Soc. Bot. France 10: 13.
Charpin, A. &amp; G.G. Aymonin, 2003. J. Bot. Soc. Bot. France 21: 68.
Kirschleger, F., 1858. Fl. Alsace 2: lxxxvi-lxxxvii.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: The entry for the posthumously published <em>Syn. fl. Jura</em> ... 1856 (TL-2/1, nr. 1860)
can be amended as follows:
<em>Editor and, in part, co-author</em>: Montandon, F[rédéric?]. Jules (Père) (fl. 1856).
<em>Ed. 1</em>: Dec 1856, ... <em>Copies</em>: BM (n.v.), G, HH, LC (n.v.), NY. <em>Microfiche</em>: Westport, Conn.
	(Meckler/Chadwyck-Healey Publishing), [1987?], 5 microfiches (Plant taxonomic lit.
	microfiche coll., "1684C5-1688F1"). <em>Copy</em>: MO.
<em>Ed. 2</em>: 1868, as <em>Guide du botaniste</em> dans le <em>Sundgau et</em> les lisières du <em>Jura</em> badois, balois, so-
	leurois, bernois et dubisien, &amp;c. ... new t.p. and pref. (Friche-Joset's name suppressed),
	added to a reissue of the old sheets ... <em>Copies</em>: BM (n.v.), K (n.v.), NY.

Frickhinger family. Prof. Karl Mägdefrau kindly provided F.A. Stafleu (in litt., 15 Sep
1979) data on this Bavarian family that may help others sort out its four generations of
botanists (and naturalists):
1st generation: (1) Christian Albert (Adalbert) Frickhinger (pharmacist, b. 16 Jan 1818
	in Nördlingen, d. 20 Mar 1907 in Nördlingen). – In 1848, published on vegetation with
	Adalbert Schnizlein (A. Frickhinger's brother-in-law), see TL-2/5, nr. 10.967.
2nd generation: (1) Hermann Adalbert (Albert) Frickhinger<em>*</em> (pharmacist, b. 8 Jan 1851
	in Nördlingen, d. 4 Mai 1940 in Nördlingen, see TL-2/1: 878). – Published on vascular
	plants 1905-1926, incl. <em>Gefässkrypt. &amp; Phanerogamenfl. Ries.</em> ... 1911, see TL-2/1, nr.
	1861. (2) Karl Frickhinger (medical doctor, president of Munich Red Cross, b. 3 Mai
	1863).
3rd generation: (1) Ernst Christoph Frickhinger (botanist, b. 3 Oct 1876 in Nördlingen, d.
	10 Oct 1940 in Nördlingen), son of H.A. Frickhinger. – Thesis on plants of the Rieses 1904,
	1922, 1926. (2) Hans Walter Frickhinger, son of Karl Frickhinger (wrote on nature, incl.
	plant diseases, b. 18 Sep 1889 in Nördlingen, d. 25 Jan 1955 in Geisenhausen?).
4th generation: (1) Karl Albert Frickhinger (pharmacist and paleontologist who published
	on fossil fishes, b. 1924, d. 28 Mai 2003, see Archaeopteryx: Jahreszeitschrift der Freun de
	des Jura-Museums Eichstätt 21: 69. 2003).

Frickhinger, Ernst Christoph (1876-1940), German botanist and pharmacist, born 3 Oct
1876 in Nördlingen, doctorate 1904 Erlangen, died 10 Oct 1940 in Nördlingen. (<em>E. Frickh.</em>).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Son of Hermann Adalbert Frickhinger (1851-1940), see TL-2/1: 878.

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: BFM p. 284 (index); NDB 5: 435; TL-2/5: 1030 (index).

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Dörfler, I., 1909. Botaniker-Adressbuch, ed. 3: 34.
Frickhinger, H., 1907. Genealogie der Familie Frickhinger in Nördlingen ..., Nördlingen
	(C.H. Beck): iv, 89 p. (n.v.)

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: Co-author with A. Schnizlein, <em>Veg.-Verh. Jura- Keuperform.</em> ... 1848,
see TL-2/5, nr. 10.967.

PAGE: 11
HEADING: FRIDERICHSEN

35.546. Die <em>Gefässpflanzen</em> des <em>Rieses</em>. Ein Beitrag zur pflanzengeographischen Durch-
forschung Süddeutschlands. Inaugural-Dissertation zur Erlangung der Doktorwürde der
hohen philosophischen Fakultät der kgl. Bayer. Friedrich-Alexanders-Universität Erlangen
... Nördlingen (C.H. Beck'sche Buchdruckerei) 1904. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 1904, cover-t.p., p. [1]-53, Lebenslauf [unpaged], map (uncol. fold.). <em>Copy</em>: HH.
<em>Note</em>: Inaugural-Dissertation, Erlangen.

*Friderichsen, [Peter] Kristian [Nikolaj] (1853-1932), Danish pharmacist and botanist
(esp. interested in <em>Rosa</em> and <em>Rubus</em>), born 24 Jan 1853 in Copenhagen, worked from 1870
in a hometown pharmacy, asst. examination 1874 and Cand. pharm. 1876, lived in Jutland
from 1880-1898 at Haderslev and Højer, pharmacist in Gudumholm 1899-1908 and from
1908 in Kjellerup where he died 31 Mar 1932. (<em>Frid</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: C (esp. <em>Rubus</em>), DBN. – <em>Exsiccatae</em>: (1) Friderichsen &amp; O.C.L.
Gelert, <em>Rubi exsiccati Daniae et Slesvigiae</em> (I-II, Ribe, nos. 1-60, 1885-1887) (<em>Rubi Exs.
Daniae Slesv.</em>): A, B, C, GH, IBF, JE, K, LD, MANCH. (2): Id. (III, Horsens, nos. 61-101,
1888).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 6(1): 483; APN p. 210; Backer p. 650; Barnhart 2: 10;
BN p. 173; Christiansen p. 314; CSP 15: 131; IH 2: 209; Kew List p. 24; Rehder 5(index):
298; TL-2/1: 878; Tucker 1: 263, 3: 112.

Fridtz, Randor Eretius (1845-1921), Norwegian amateur botanist and plant collector,
born 29 Nov 1845 in Kristianssand, trained as a teacher 1862-1864, studied mathematics,
physics and chemistry at the Univ. of Kristiania from 1880, amanuensis at the chemistry
lab. 1887-1918, studied the flora of s. Norway, esp. during summer holidays and made ex-
tensive collections, died 15 Feb 1921 in Kristiania (Oslo). (<em>Fridtz</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: B, C, GB, O, TROM.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: BL 1: 462, 656; BM 6: 346; IH 2: 209; Kleppa p. 322
(index); TL-2/2: 953 (index); Urban-Berl. p. 346.

Holmboe, J., 1979. <em>In</em>, E. Bull &amp; E. Jansen (eds.), Norsk Biografisk Leksikon 4: 269.
Nuland, J., 1977 [i.e. 1979]. Kristians. Mus. Årb. 1977: 33-39. (portr.) [Abstract in Ex-
	cerpta Bot., A, 34(2): 128. 1980]

Friedrich, Paul Alexander (1856-1918), German paleobotanist, born 4 Jun 1856 in Kreipa
bei Halle, attended gymnasium in Halle and Eisenach, studied mathematics and natural
sciences in Halle from 1875, Dr. phil. 1878 Halle, went to Berlin to study tertiary plants of
Saxony, then to Lübeck as teacher at the Katharineum 1882, died 3 Feb 1918 in Lübeck.
(<em>P.A. Friedrich</em>).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Not to be confused with Paul Friedrich (1927-x), a linguist who published on trees.

Friend, Hilderic (Rev.) (1852-1940), English Methodist minister, born 6 Nov 1852 in High
[Great] Wigsell (Kent), but raised in Hastings (Sussex), entered the Wesleyan College in
Richmond 1874, left two years later as missionary to China, lost an eye in 1880 and re-
turned to England, lived in Newton Abbot (Devonshire), began study of English worms
(annelids) 1890, retired 1914, died 7 Feb 1940 in Solihull, Birmingham. (<em>Friend</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BIRA, NH.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 11; BL 2: 656 (index); BM: 2: 621; Desmond

Tucker 1: 263, 3: 112.

	145: 414. 1940.

	crofiche, 11×15 cm (Opie collection of children's literature). <em>Copy</em>: (n.v.).

Fries family. As there is much confusion about this Swedish family that produced so many
well known botanists, we thought it wise to incorporate here a small chapter on their "bo-
tanical" genealogy. This is useful as several members of this family received the same given
names and often published using only part of their names. A more complete genealogy can
be found at Elias Fries Ättlingar (an electronic resource).
1st generation: The first and best known botanist in the Fries family was Elias Magnus
	Fries (1794-1878) (better known as Elias Fries). Elias Fries had eight children among
	which three sons continued his interest in botany, viz. (1) Theodor [Thore] M[agnus].
	Fries (1832-1913); (2) Elias Petrus Fries (1834-1858); and (3) Oscar [Oskar] Robert
	Fries (1840-1908) (a.k.a. Robert Fries, which often causes confusion with Robert E.
	Fries of the next generation).
2nd generation: The eldest son of Elias Fries, Theodor M. Fries (1832-1913), also had
	three sons interested in botany, viz. (1) Klas Robert Elias Fries (1876-1966) (better
	known as Robert E. Fries); (2) Thoralf Gustaf Elias Fries (1882-1963) (better known
	as Thoralf Fries, and almost unknown to botany); and (3) Thore Christian Elias Fries
	(1886-1930) (a.k.a. Thore Fries). The wife of Thore Fries, Fennia Maria Fries (née
	Rosberg) (1897-1987), painted and collected plants.
	The second son of Elias Fries, Elias Petrus Fries (1834-1858), died at only 24 years of
	age without issue.
	The third son of Elias Fries, Johan Otto Fries (1838-1931), was a surveyor and did not
	contribute to botany.
	The fourth son of Elias Fries, Oscar Robert Fries (1840-1908), had nine children of which
	one son, Elias Theodor (Thore) Fries (1875-1951), made his living as a physician but
	also was active in botany.
3rd generation: Klas Robert Elias Fries (1867-1966), the second son of Theodor M. Fries
	(1832-1913), had one son, Carl Magnus Elias Fries (1917-1987) (a.k.a. Magnus Fries),
	who was a docent in botany at Uppsala Univ.
	Thoralf Gustaf Elias Fries (1882-1963), the seventh child of Theodor M. Fries (1832-
	1913), had one son, Nils Thorsten Elias Fries (1912-1994) (a.k.a. Nils Fries), who was
	a prof. of fungal physiology at Uppsala Univ.
The following entries will treat members of the Fries family in alphabetic order, using their full
given names, thus e.g. Rob. E. Fries will be alphabetized as (Klas) Robert Elias Fries, etc.

*Fries, Elias Magnus (1794-1878), Swedish botanist (a founder of taxonomic mycology),
born 15 Aug 1794 in Femsjö (Småland), the first botanist of a family of renowned Swed-
ish botanists (see the <em>Fries family</em> above), attended school at Växjö, went to Lund 1811 and
studied under E. Acharius, docent and Ph.D. 1814 Lund (20 years old!), adjunct in botany
1819, royal prof. 1824, prof. agricultural economics, Uppsala 1834, prof. of botany and ag-
ricultural economics and head of the Botanical Garden 1851-1859, Commander of the North
Star 1856, retired as prof. 1859 and as garden dir. 1863, died 8 Feb 1878 in Uppsala. (<em>Fr</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: UPS (orig.). – <em>Exsiccatae</em>: See IH 2: 209 and TL-2/1: 878 (also
contributed fasc. 13 to C. Stenhammer, <em>Lichenes Sueciae exsiccati</em> ...).

PAGE: 17
HEADING: FRIES

<sm>POSTAGE STAMPS</sm>: On 7 Oct 1978, the Swedish Post issued a booklet of 6 stamps valued
1.15 kr. with mushrooms (yv. 1201-1026). The cover of the booklet shows a portrait of Elias
Magnus Fries as this issue commemorated the centenary of his death.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) Co-author with C.A. Agardh, <em>Disp. alg. suec.</em> ... Pars 3, 15 Mai
1812 (see TL-2/1, nr. 36).
(2) Assisted J.H. Wallman in editing the cryptogams in S. Liljeblad, <em>Utkast Sv. fl.</em> ... ed. 3,
1816 (see TL-2/3, nr. 4528).
(3) Contributed text to A. Afzelius, <em>Reliq. afzel.</em> ... 1860 (see TL-2/1, nr. 34).

*Fries, Elias Petrus (1834-1858), Swedish botanist, born 14 Oct 1834 in Femsjö (Små-
land), student at Uppsala 1853, Dr. 1857, died 17 Dec 1858 in Uppsala. (<em>E.P. Fr.</em>).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Second son of Elias Magnus Fries (1794-1878) (see the Fries family and above).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: UPS.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 211; Barnhart 2: 11; BM 2: 625; KR p. 215-216; PR
3114; Rehder 5(index): 299; TL-2/1: 888-889.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bot. Not. 1858: 205-206. 1858.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: His thesis, <em>Anteckn. svamp. geogr. utbred.</em> ... (1857) (TL-2/1, nr. 1897) is available
in microfiche:
<em>Microfiche</em>: Westport, Conn. (Meckler/Chadwyck-Healey Publishing), 1987, 1 microfiche
	(13 fr.) (Plant taxonomic lit. microfiche coll., "1725C3-1725E3"). <em>Copy</em>: MO (n.v.).

Fries, Elias Theodor [Thore] (a.k.a. Theodor Fries of Visby) (1875-1951), born 9 Jul 1875
in Göteborg, studied medicine in Uppsala (license 1908), published on the flora of Gotland,
died 11 Oct 1951 in Visby. (<em>E.Th. Fr.</em>).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Son of Oscar Robert Fries (1840-1908) (see the Fries family and below).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Chiefly Gotland (±1891-1951): A, E, GB (6400 Phan.; 300 zooce-
cidia (galls)), GH, LD.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 11; IH 2: 209; KR p. 216.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Dörfler, I., 1896. Botaniker-Adressbuch: 135; 1909. Id., ed. 3: 264.
Hedge, I.C. &amp; J.M. Lamond (eds.), 1970. Index collectors Edinburgh Herb.: 81. (as "Fries,
	E.T.")
Lange, Th., 1951. Bot. Not. 1952(4): 442-445. (bibl., portr.)

35.574. <em>Basidiobolus myxophilus</em>, en ny <em>Phycomycet</em> ... Bihang till K. Svenska Vet-Akad.
Handlingar ... 1899. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 1899 (Nat. Nov. Dec (2) 1901, read 8 Feb 1899), p. [1]-15, [16], <em>pl. 1-2</em> (uncol.
	lith.). <em>Copies</em>: B, BM (n.v.), U; IDC 7670/2, mf. 465-466. – Issued as Bihang K. Svenska
	Vetensk.-Akad. Handl. 25(Afd. III). No. 3. 1899.

*Fries, (Klas) Robert Elias (1876-1966), Swedish botanist, born 11 Jul 1876 in Uppsala,
began his studies in Uppsala, fil. kand. 1898, fil. lic. 1901, accompanied Swedish Chaco-
Cordillera Exped. 1901-1902, Dr. Phil. and docent in botany 1905, on the Swedish Rhode-
sia- Kongo Exped. 1911-1912, biology lecturer at Uppsala 1913 and Prof. Bergianus at the
Bergianska trädgården in Stockholm 1915, esp. known for his studies in the Annonaceae,
returned with his younger brother (T.C.E. Fries) to Africa (Mt. Kenya and the Aberdares)
in 1921-1922 and again in 1953, died 29 Jan 1966. (<em>R.E. Fr.</em>).

PAGE: 22
HEADING: FRIES

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Eldest son of Theodor Magnus Fries (1832-1913) (see below), older brother of Thore
Christian Elias Fries (1886-1930) (see below) and grandson of Elias Magnus Fries (1794-
1878) (see the Fries family and above).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Mainly UPS and S, duplicates B, BR, CORD, G, K, M, PH (Ar-
gentina), US. – A few letters in GH (Archives).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Ainsworth p. 259, 260; APN p. 211; Barnhart 2: 11; Biol.-
Dokum. 6: 73.698-73.723; BL 1: 40, 50, 233, 296, 2: 509, 565; BM 2: 625, 6: 347; BN p.
21, 173; Bossert p. 134; Ewan Pap. p. 73; Frodin ed. 2: 321; GR p. 489; Hirsch p. 90; Hortus
3: 1193; IF suppl. 2: 35, 4: 354; IH 2: 209; Kelly p. 251; Kew 2: 342-344; KR p. 216-220,
581; Langman p. 293-294; Lenley p 174; LS 9302-9307 (except for 9305), 33.440-33.445;
LS suppl. 8958-8962; Moebius p. 105, 197; MW p. 129, suppl. p. 69; NAF 1(1): 159; Portr.
1: 62 (index), 3: 452; SMK 2: 609-610; SO p. 222 (index); Stevenson p. 1242; TL-2/1: 889,
indices 2/7, Suppl. 2; Tucker 1: 263; Urban-Berl. p. 347; Zander ed. 10: 661, ed. 11: 752,
ed. 17: 948.

	1951 (portr.); Taxon 2: 33. 1953; Taxon 15: 128. 1966; Svenska Dagbladet [newspaper]

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: (additional) <em>Friesodielsia</em> Steenis (1948); <em>Klarobelia</em> Chatrou (1998; derived
from Kla[s]+Rob[ert]+Elia[s]).

<sm>OUTSIDE OUR PERIOD</sm>: (1) Determined Anonaceae for R.-H. Chodat &amp; E. Hassler, <em>Pl. Hassl.</em>
... 1904 (see TL-2/2, nr. 2475).
(2) First author with his younger brother T.C.E. Fries, <em>Phytogeographical researches on Mt.
Kenya and Mt. Aberdare, British East Africa</em> ... 1948.
(3) A short <em>history</em> of <em>botany</em> in <em>Sweden</em> ... [with contributions by Karl Vilhelm Ossian
Dahlgren (1888-x) et al.], 162 p., 2 maps (fold. col.) 1950, which was prepared for the
Seventh Intl. Bot. Congr., held in Stockholm in 1950.

ries initiated and, at first, solely edited by the latter botanist, see <em>Beiträge</em> zur <em>Kenntnis</em> der
<em>Flora</em> des <em>Kenia, Mt. Aberdare</em> und <em>Mt. Elgon</em> ... 1923-1930 (sub T.C.E. Fries, below).

PAGE: 31
HEADING: FRIES

Fries, Oscar Robert (1840-1908), Swedish physician and botanist (mycologist), born 5
Apr 1840 in Uppsala, studied at Uppsala from 1858, med. kand. 1863, med. lic. 1867, Dr.
med. 1868 and docent at Uppsala, at Göteborg 1869-1898, died 18 Jun 1908 in Uppsala.
(<em>O.R. Fr.</em>).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Son of Elias Magnus Fries (1794-1878) (see above) and brother of Theodor Magnus
Fries (1832-1913) (see the Fries family and below).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

*Fries, Theodor [Thore, Thorel] Magnus (1832-1913), Swedish botanist, born 28 Oct 1832
in Femsjö (Småland), studied at Uppsala from 1851, Dr. Phil. and docent for botany 1857, asst.
for botany and agricultural economics 1862, "Borgströmiansk" Prof. in botany 1862, dir. of
Botanical Garden 1877-1899, rector of Uppsala Univ. 1893-1899, retired 1899, specialist on
the history, life, publications and letters of Linnaeus, died 29 Mar 1913 in Uppsala. (<em>Th. Fr.</em>).

PAGE: 32
HEADING: FRIES

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Eldest son of Elias Magnus Fries (1794-1878) (see above), brother of Elias Petrus
Fries (1834-1858) (see above) and Oscar Robert Fries (1840-1908) (see above), and father
of (Klas) Robert Elias Fries (1876-1966) (see above) (see also the Fries family).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: See IH 2: 210. – Some corr. FH (William Gilson Farlow papers).

*Fries, Thore Christian Elias (1886-1930), Swedish botanist, born 2 Nov 1886 in Uppsala,
fil. kand. 1908, fil. lic. 1912, D.Phil. 1913 and docent, all Uppsala Univ., collected with his
brother R.E. Fries in E. Africa (Mount Kenya and the Aberdares) 1921-1922, appointed
prof. of botany and dir., Bot. Museum, Univ. of Lund 1927, organized an exped. to S. Africa
and Rhodesia with N.T. Norlindh and A.H. Weimarck 1930-1931, but died 31 Dec 1930 in
Umtali (now Mutare), S. Rhodesia (now Zimbabwe) of pneumonia. (<em>T.C.E. Fr.</em>).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Youngest son of Theodor Magnus Fries (1832-1913) (see above), brother of (Klas)
Robert Elias Fries (1876-1966) (see above) and grandson of Elias Magnus Fries (1794-
1878) (see above). Fennia Maria Fries (née Rosberg) (1897-1987), the wife of T.C.E. Fries,
collected and painted plants. (See also the Fries family).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: See IH 2: 209-210, 603; additional material at M.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 211; Barnhart 2: 11; BL 1: 40, 296, 2: 79, 532, 656;
Biol.-Dokum. 6: 73.759-73.760; BN p. 21, 173; Bossert p. 134; GR p. 489; GR cat. p. 63;

PAGE: 36
HEADING: FRIES

Hirsch p. 90; Hortus 3: 1193; IH 2: 209-210, 603; Kew 2: 344-345; Kleppa p. 322 (index);
KR p. 228-229; LS suppl. 8963-8973; Portr. 3: 452; SMK 2: 610 (portr.); TL-2/1: 889-891,
indices 2/3, 2/5, 2/6, Suppl. 1, 6; Tucker 2: xvi, 3: 112.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bull. Misc. Inform. Kew 1931(3): 158. 1931; J. Bot. 69: 56. 1931.
Dörfler, I., 1909. Botaniker-Adressbuch, ed. 3: 264.

	1927.
<em>Note</em>: This is a fourteen part series that Fries alone (Parts I-III) and then in collaboration
	with his brother R.E. Fries (Parts IV-XIV) edited. All of the parts were published in No-
	tizbl. Bot. Gart. Berlin-Dahlem, vols. 8-11. 1923-1930. Authorship varies (even within
	a part) and some of the contributions have been treated earlier under the names of col-
	laborators (e.g. Carl Christensen, Part VI, see TL-2/Suppl. 4, nr. 26.238). We have seen
	offprints only of the first and tenth part, but offer the following summary of the paging
	and dates for the entire work:
"Thore C. E. Fries" (ed.):
<em>Part I</em>: Notizbl. Bot. Gart. Berlin-Dahlem 8(76): 389-423, <em>pl. 5-6.</em> 15 Jun 1923; <em>II</em>, Id.
	8(77): 475-504. 15 Aug 1923; <em>III</em>, Id. 8(78): 547-573. 15 Sep 1923.
"Rob. E. und Th. C. E. Fries" (eds.):
<em>Part IV</em>: Id. 8(80): 661-704 (15 Feb 1924); <em>V</em>, Id. 9(81): 16-36 (1 Jun 1924); <em>VI</em>, Id.
	9(83): 173-189 (30 Dec 1924); <em>VII</em>, Id. 9(85): 299-333 (15 Jun 1925); <em>VIII</em>, Id. 9(87):
	485-522 (25 Feb 1926); <em>IX</em>, Id. 9(90): 113-135 (25 Mar 1927); <em>X</em>, Id. 10(91): 69-101
	(10 Jul 1927); <em>XI</em>, Id. 10(93): 266-272 (30 Mar 1928); <em>XII</em>, Id. 10(96): 594-621 (30
	Mar 1929); <em>XIII</em>, Id. 10(99): 897-917 (30 Mar 1920); <em>XIV</em>, Id. 11(101): 20-47 (30 Dec
	1930).

Friese, Johann Nepomuk [Nepomuck] (1792-1866), Austrian physician and naturalist,
born 2 Jan 1792 in Komotau (now Czech Republic), studied medicine and natural history in
Vienna, Dr. med. 1817 and Dr. Phil. 1827 Innsbruck, dir., Innsbruck Univ. Botanic Garden
1819-1848, prof. natural history and agron., Univ. of Innsbruck 1827-1847, later at Vienna
where he died on 14 Sep 1866 of cholera. (<em>J.N. Friese</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

PAGE: 40
HEADING: FRIESNER

35.678. <em>Grundriss</em> der <em>Phytognosie</em> ... Innsbruck (gedruckt mit Rauch'schen Schriften)
1836. Oct. (<em>Grundr. Phytognosie</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1836 (Flora 28 Nov 1836), p. [i]-xii, [1]-267. <em>Copies</em>: BM, NY (n.v.). <em>Microfiche</em>:

	II Monographs). <em>Copy</em>: (n.v.).

Friesner, Ray Clarence (1894-1952), American plant taxonomist and ecologist, born 8 Feb
1894 in Bremen, Ohio, A.B. 1916 Ohio Wesleyan Univ., Delaware, Ohio, Ph.D. 1919 Univ.
of Michigan, Ann Arbor, asst. prof. 1919, assoc. prof. 1922, prof. 1925, "Head" 1920-1952,
Dept. of Botany, and dean 1947-1952, College of Liberal Arts and Sciences, all Butler
Univ., Indianapolis, Indiana, secretary1926-1935 and president 1936, Indiana Academy of
Science, Dr. h.c. 1951 Ohio Wesleyan Univ., died 1 Dec 1952 in Indianapolis (buried in
Bremen, Ohio). (<em>Friesner</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BUT (25,500, incl. field books), duplicates CAS, DS, DUKE, F,
GH, IA, ILL, ISC, KSC, LAS, MO, NH, NY, OKLA, POM, TEX, U, WAB (now NY),
WS, WVU. – Some corr. at HU.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Amer. Men Sci., ed. 8: 837; APN p. 211; Barnhart 2: 12;
Hirsch p. 90; IF suppl. 4: 322, 324; IH 2: 210 (excluding Colombia); Pennell p. 607; Tucker
3: 112.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Intl. address book botanists: 470. 1931; Butler Univ. Bot. Stud. 11: 103-111.
	1954. (bibl.: 47 entries; portr.)
Bowman, H.H.M. et al., 1953. Ohio J. Sci. 53: 251. (obit.)
Burgess, R.L., 1996. Huntia 10: 44.
Dolan, R.W., 1991. Brittonia 43: 54-56. (Friesner Herb.)
Edington, W.E., 1953 [1954]. Proc. Indiana Acad. Sci. 63: 32-34. (obit., portr.)
Jones, J.J., 1954. Butler Univ. Bot. Stud. 11: 103-104 (portr. on p. [ii]), 107-110. (bibl.)
Masson, V.J., 1994. Brittonia 46: 220. (herb.)
Potzger, J.E., 1945. Butler Univ. Bot. Stud. 7: 6.
Potzger, J.E., 1954. Castanea 19: 126-127. (obit., portr.)
Stieber, M.T. &amp; A.L. Karg, 1984. Huntia 5: 193 [=157].

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: Friesner Herb. (BUT), Butler Univ., Indianapolis, Indiana.

<sm>FESTSCHRIFT</sm>: Butler Univ. Bot. Stud. 11(papers 8-17): 103-209. Nov. 1954 (with portr. on
p. [ii]) "dedicated to the memory of Dr. Ray C. Friesner by the former majors in the Botany
Department of Butler University (1920-1952) and by his collegues on the faculty of Butler
University" (see also Anon., 1954 above).

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: Editor, <em>Butler University Botanical Studies</em>, vols. 2-10 (1931-1952).

35.680. <em>Indiana</em> as a <em>critical botanical area</em> ... Reprinted from the Proc. Indiana Acad. Sci.

PAGE: 41
HEADING: FRIREN

	Acad. Sci. 46: 28-45. 1937.
<em>Note</em>: Based on a Presidential address delivered 6 Nov 1936.

Frimmel, Franz von (a.k.a. Frimmel von Traisenau and Frimmel-Traisenau) (1888-1957),
Austrian botanist and plant breeder, born 6 Apr 1888 in Vienna, Dr. phil. 1912 Univ. of
Vienna, demonstrator of botany, Univ. of Vienna 1911-1913, asst. "Fürst-Liechtenstein-
Pflanzenzüchtungs-Institut", Eisgrub 1914-1918 and dir. from 1918, docent at the German
technical school in Brünn (i.e. Brno, Czechoslovakia) 1926-1928 and prof. from 1928, died
19 Nov 1957 in Olomouc (now Czech Republic). (<em>Frimmel</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 12; BM 2: 625; Bossert p. 134; Futak-Domin
p. 210, 570; Hirsch p. 90; NDB 5: 614; Portr. 3: 452.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Intl. address book botanists: 63. 1931.
Sitan, L.J., 1958. Der Züchter 28: 97-99. (bibl., portr.)

Friren, Auguste [Marie Joseph] (Abbé) (1837-1916), French priest interested in geology
and bryology, born 24 Oct 1837 in Thionville (Moselle), studied in Nancy and then at the
Seminary in Metz, among other positions was chaplain ("aumônier") of the Pensionnat des
Dames du Sacré-Coeur in Montigny-lès-Metz (Moselle) 1865-1873, and prof. of math-
ematics and physics at the Petit Séminaire of Sainte-Constance from 1873, retired 1915,
died 18 Apr 1916 in Metz (Moselle). (<em>Friren</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: PC (Bryoph.)?, Société d'Histoire Naturelle, Metz (not located).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 12; BFM p. 284 (index); BL 2: 183, 656; CSP
12: 254, 15: 141; DBF 14: 1303-1304; IH 2: 210; Kew 2: 346; LS 33.448; Tucker 1: 263.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Charpin, A. &amp; G.G. Aymonin, 1999. J. Bot. Soc. Bot. France 10: 50.

Frisch, Alban Immanuel (1856-1934), German journalist and amateur botanist, born
21 Oct 1856 in Dresden, attended schools there and later the Gymnasium Albertinum in
Freiberg and the Leipzig Gymnasium until 1877, studied law and politics in Leipzig but
became a journalist and studied the local flora around his home in Annaberg, died 28 Mar
1934 in Dresden. (<em>A.I. Frisch</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 12; CSP 15: 142.

Doctorwürde ... Annaberg (Druck von C.O. Schreiber) 1897. Oct. (<em>Veget.-Verh. Pöhlberg-
Gebietes</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1897 (Bot. Centralbl. 30 Dec 1897, Nat. Nov. Jan (1) 1898), cover-t.p., p. [1]-92,
	[93, index, 95-96, vita]. <em>Copies</em>: G, HH, NY (n.v.), US, WU.
<em>Ref</em>.: Roth, E., Bot. Centralbl. 74(17-18): 136-138. 21 Apr 1898 (rev.).
<em>Note</em>: This was his doctoral dissertation.

Frisendahl, Arvid (1886-1965), Swedish botanist, born 24 [25?] Jun 1886 in Piteå, fil.
kand. 1907, fil. lic. 1910 and Dr. phil. 1912, all Uppsala Univ., adjunct for biology and
chemistry in Göteborg 1917, lector in 1919, died 29 Jan 1965 in Uppsala. (<em>Frisendahl</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Czechoslovakia (1936): GB.

HEADING: FRISTEDT

*Fristedt, Robert Fredric [Frederic, Fredrik] (1832-1893), Swedish pharmacologist
and botanist, born 19 Jun 1832 in Stockholm, studied at Uppsala Univ. from 1851, fil.
mag. 1857, med. kand. 1859, med. lic. 1861, adjunct for natural history and chemistry at
Uppsala 1861 and prof. pharmacology 1877, died 16 Feb 1893 in Tomtebo nr. Uppsala.
(<em>Fristedt</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: C, E, GB, M (Lich.), S, UPS (orig?). – <em>Exsiccatae</em>: <em>Sveriges phar-
maceutiska växter med pharmakologiska upplysningar</em> ... Upsala (Edquist &amp; Berglund
[fascs. 1-7], Ed. Berling [fasc. 8]) ... 1863-1872 (<em>Sver. Pharm. Växt.</em>); Fascs. 1-8, nos.
1-740: A, GB, H, L, M, S, UPS.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 211; Barnhart 2: 12; BL 2: 517, 656; BM 2: 626;
BN p. 22, 174; CSP 2: 728, 7: 717, 9: 935, 15: 143; GR p. 489; IH 2: 210; Jackson p. 485;
Kew 2: 346; Kleppa p. 322 (index); KR p. 230-231; Morren ed. 10: 107; PR ed. 2: 3123;
Rehder 1: 355; Saelan p. 548; SMK 2: 621-622 (portr.); TL-2/1: 891; TR p. 87 (as "R.J.");
Tucker 1: 263.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bot. Not. 1893: 85-86. 1893. (b. "19 Nov 1832")
[Engelmann, W.], 1891. Botanisches Adressbuch: 67.
Hedge, I.C. &amp; J.M. Lamond (eds.), 1970. Index collectors Edinburgh Herb.: 81.
Hertel, H. &amp; A. Schreiber, 1988. Mitt. Bot. Staatssamml. München 26: 141.
Pfister, D.H., 1985. Mycotaxon 23: 113.
Sayre, G., 1969. Mem. New York Bot. Gard. 19: 24-25.
Wittrock, V.B., 1903. Acta Horti Berg. 3(2): 40; 1905, Id. 3(3): 13, <em>pl. 101.</em> (portr.)

<sm>OUTSIDE OUR PERIOD</sm>: Edited <em>Ioannis Franckenii Botanologia nunc primum edita</em>, prae-
fatione historica, annotationibus criticis, nomenclatura Linnæana illustrata ... Upsaliae
(Typis descripsit Ed. Berling) 1877. Qu.

Fritel, Paul-Honoré (1867-1927), French paleobotanist (and paleozoologist), born 19 Aug
1867 in Evreux (Eure), asst. dir., paleobotanical lab., Muséum natl. d'Histoire naturelle,

PAGE: 47
HEADING: FRITSCH

Fritsch, Carl [Karl] (1812-1879), Austrian scientist, born 16 Aug 1812 in Prague (now
Czech Republic), where he studied law 1833-1836, but being more interested in astronomy,
became an asst. at the Prague observatory 1851, adjunct and eventually vice-dir., Central-
Anstalt für Meteorologie und Erdmagnetismus, Vienna, well known for his phenological
observations on plants and animals, retired and moved to Salzburg in 1871 where he died
on 26 Dec 1879. (<em>C. Fritsch</em>).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Not to be confused with his son Karl Fritsch (1864-1934) (see below).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 12; BM 2: 626 (as "Karl"); CSP 2: 729-730,
7: 717-719, 9: 936, 12: 254; DTS 1: 74-78, 6(4): 45; Futak-Domin p. 211-212; IH 2: 210 (as
"Karl ... Sr."); Jackson p. 83, 268, 270; Kew 2: 347; Maiwald p. 82, 204, 205; NDB 5: 626
(as "Karl"); ÖBL 1: 370; PR ed. 2: 3124-3125; Rehder 5(index): 300; Saccardo 2: 122.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Alman. k. Akad. Wiss. Wien 30: 162-172. 1880. (bibl., biogr.); A catalog
	of the Edward L. Greene collection: 130. 1986. (as "Karl")
Fritsch, K., 1880. "Carl Fritsch" [Selbstbiographie] Meterolog. Zeitschr. p. 105-119.
Gilbert, P., 1977. A compendium of the biographical literature on deceased entomologists:
	128.

35.707. Über die <em>periodischen Erscheinungen</em> im <em>Pflanzenreiche</em> ... Prag (Druck der k.k.
Hofbuchdruckerei von Gottlieb Haase Söhne) 1845. Qu. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 1845, p. [1]-89, 1 schema (part. col.). <em>Copy</em>: BM. – Issued as Abh. Königl. Böhm.
	Ges. Wiss., ser. 5, 4. 1845.

35.708. <em>Kalender</em> der <em>Flora</em> des <em>Horizontes</em> von <em>Prag</em>. Entworfen nach zehnjährigen Vegeta-
tions-Beobachtungen ... Als Anhang zum Jännerhefte ... [Sitzungsberichte K. Akad. Wiss.
Wien] ... 1852. Oct. (<em>Kalender Fl. Prag</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1852 (p. [1] dated Jan 1852), p. [1]-110. <em>Copies</em>: BM, HH, K (n.v.), LC, NY (n.v.). –
	Issued as suppl. to Sitzungsber. Kaiserl. Akad. Wiss., Math.-Naturwiss. Cl. 8. 1852.

35.709. <em>Phänologische Beobachtungen</em> aus dem <em>Pflanzen</em>- und <em>Thierreiche</em> ... Wien (Aus
der Kaiserlich-Königlichen Hof- und Staatsduckerei) 1869. Qu. (<em>Phänol. Beob. Pfl.- Their-
reiche</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 29 Oct 1869 (date on p. [i]), p. [i]-iv, 1-180, 2 maps (1 col., 1 uncol.). <em>Copies</em>: G, LC
	(n.v.). – Issued by Kaiserl. Akad. Wiss. as viii. Heft. Jahrgang 1857.
<em>Note</em>: (1) This publication is Heft 8 of 1857, the text on p. [i] reads: printing finished 19 Jun
	1860, issued 29 Oct 1869 [sic]. (2) There are more publications by Carl [Karl] Fritsch
	with the same title 1851-1857 and 1866, but not seen by us.

*Fritsch, Felix Eugen[e] (1879-1954), British algologist of German ancestry, born 26
Apr 1879 in London (Hampstead), B.Sc. 1898 Univ. College, Univ. of London, went to
Germany where he worked as an asst., Botany Dept., Ludwig-Maximilians Univ., Munich
1899-1901, where he also received a Ph.D., briefly worked at Jodrell Lab., Kew, then as
a lecturer, Botany Dept., Univ. College 1902-1906, D.Sc. 1905 Univ. College, asst. prof.
1906-1911, prof. 1924 and head 1911-1948, all Dept. of Botany, Queen Mary College (then
called East London College), Univ. of London, retired 1948, F.L.S 1903 and president Lin-
nean Society 1949-1952, F.R.S. 1932, Darwin Medal 1950, D.Litt. h.c. 1953 Univ. of Lon-
don, Corr. Member, B.S.A., died 23 Mai 1954 in Cambridge. (<em>F.E. Fritsch</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: S. Africa: B; diatoms: BM; other plants: QMC (transfered to
NMW), TUB? <em>Note</em>: About 1912, Fritsch began to collect illus. of freshwater algae and at

PAGE: 48
HEADING: FRITSCH

his death he had accumulated ca. 20,000. His widow gave this collection to the Freshwater
Biological Association (now in Ambleside, Cumbria, United Kingdom). <em>The Fritsch Col-
lection of Illustrations of Freshwater Algae</em> now contains over 500,000 illus. IDC has is-
sued a microfiche edition with supplements (see also TL-2/1: 891, and Taxon 22: 308-309.
1973); basic collection (1964), and Suppl. 1 (1972), 2 (1978), 3 (1982), 4 (1987), 5 (1992)
and 6 (1996). A genus index to the basic collection and supplements was compiled by Pertti
Eloranta, Prof. of Limnology, Univ. of Helsinki.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 211; Barnhart 2: 12; BM 6: 349; Bossert p. 134;
Desmond p. 240, ed. 2: 265; DNB 21: 51-52. 2004; GR p. 398; Hirsch p. 90; IH 2: 210;
Kew 2: 346-347; Langman p. 294; LS 9349; Moebius p. 68; NAF ser. 2(6): 63; Nordstedt
suppl. p. 7; Portr. 1: 62 (index), 3: 453; TL-2/1: 891-892, indices 2/5, 2/7, Suppl. 4; Tucker
1: 264.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Intl. address book botanists: 181. 1931; Nature 162(4119): 562. 1948 [re-
	tirement]; Times [London] [newspaper]: 24 Mai 1954.

<em>Note</em>: Fritsch was sole author of parts I-II, V.

*Fritsch, Karl [Carl] (1864-1934), Austrian botanist, born 24 Feb 1864 in Vienna, studied
natural history in Innsbruck 1882-1883 and Vienna 1883-1886, Dr. phil. 1886 Vienna, volun-
teer at the Naturhistorischen Hofmuseum, Vienna 1889, habilitation 1890, demonstrator of
systematic botany, Inst. of Plant Physiology 1892 and prof. 1896, Univ. of Vienna, moved to
Univ. of Graz 1900 where he became full prof. 1905, died 17 Jan 1934 in Graz. (<em>Fritsch</em>).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Son of Carl Fritsch (1812-1879) (see above).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Europe: GZU, also E. – <em>Exsiccatae</em>: <em>Flora exsiccata Austro-
Hungarica</em>, a museo botanico universitatis vindonbonensis edita (Wien, nos. 2801-3600,
1898-1902) (<em>Fl. Exs. Austro-Hung.</em>): BP, C, LE, M, W (orig.); see also TL-2/2, nr. 3598.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) Nomenclatural proposals by Fritsch were included in R. von Wett-
stein, <em>Neuere Bestrebungen auf dem Gebiete der botanischen Nomenclatur</em> ... 1892, see
TL-2/7, nr. 17.339.
(2) Contributed "Bot. Mus. &amp; Gard." to R. von Wettstein (ed.), <em>Bot. Anst. Wiens</em> ... 1894,
see TL-2/7, nr. 17.345.
(3) Contributed fascs. 8, 1899 and 9, 1902 to A. Kerner von Marilaun, <em>Sched. fl. exs. austro-
hung.</em> ... 1881-1913, see TL-2/2, nr. 3598.
(4) One of many collaborators contributing to A. Zahlbruckner, <em>Plantae Pentherianae</em> [I]
... 1900, see TL-2/7, nr. 18.507.
(5) Editor of A. Pokorny, <em>Illustrierte Naturgeschichte des Pflanzenreiches</em> ... ed. 22, 1903
&amp; ed. 28, 1921, at least, see TL-2/4: 326 (sub (2)).
(6) Ad (a) <em>Gesneriaceae</em> add: Nachtr. II-IV, 3: 317-319. Feb 1908.
Ad (b) <em>Columelliaceae</em> add: Nachtr. II-IV, 3: 320. Feb 1908.
Ad (c) <em>Caprifoliaceae</em> add: Nachtr. II-IV, 3: 330-332. Feb 1908.
Ad (d) <em>Adoxaceae</em> add: Nachtr. II-IV, 3: 332. Feb 1908.
(7) Editor, <em>Mitteilungen des Naturwissenschaftlichen Vereines für Steiermark</em> (1906-1910).
(8) Contributed name changes to G. Tischler, <em>Allg. Pfl.-Karyol.</em> ... 1921-1922, see TL-2/6,
nr. 14.593.

Fritsch, Karl [Carl] Wilhelm Georg (Freiherr) von (1838-1906), German vulcanologist
and paleontologist, born 11 Nov 1838 in Weimar, visited Teneriffe 1862, died 9 Jan 1906 in
Halle (on the Saale River). (<em>K.W.G. Fritsch</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 12; BM 2: 626-627; NDB 5: 623 (d. "Goddula
b. Merseburg"); Sarjeant p. 1047.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Boettger, O., 1906. Ber. Senckenberg. Naturf. Ges. Frankfurt 1906: 27*-29*.
Luedecke, O., 1906. Leopoldina 42: 44-53. (portr.) (n.v.)

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: Edited the serial <em>Leopoldina</em> (Jena).

Fröderström, Harald August (1876-1944), Swedish physician (psychiatrist) and botanist,
born 11 Mai 1876 in Goteborg, med. kand. 1901 Lund, med. lic. 1907 Stockholm and med.
dr. 1913 Uppsala. (<em>Fröd</em>.).

11: 753, ed. 17: 948.

Frödin, John Otto Henrik (1879-1960), Swedish geographer and specialist in plant ge-
ography, born 16 Apr 1879 in Uppsala, fil. cand. 1901 and fil. lic. 1906, both at Uppsala,
Dr. fil. 1914 and docent in geography at Lund, Prof. of Geography, Univ. of Uppsala 1929-
1952, died 23 Oct 1960. (<em>Frödin</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

Suppl. 6: 515 (index).

Charpin, A. &amp; J. Timbal, 2007. Acta Bot. Gallica 154: 449.
Hjulström, F., 1961. K. Vet.-Soc. Ärsb. 17-19. (portr.) (n.v.) [also as Meddel. Uppsala Univ.
	Geogr. ser. A, no. 171. (n.v.)]

Fröhlich, Anton[ín] (1882-1969), Czech botanist, born 1 Jun 1882 in Hradišti (Moravia)
where he attended gymnasium and studied natural sciences, Dr. fil. 1911, prof. in gymna-
sium in Mikulově 1920-1944, died 18 Feb 1969 in Znojmo (Moravia). (<em>A. Fröhl.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: B, BRNU, GZU, KIEL, M.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 211; Bossert p. 134; Futak-Domin p. 212-213; IH
2: 211; Kew 2: 348; Klášterský p. 81-82; Portr. 3: 453; Urban-Berl. p. 347.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Intl. address book botanists: 63. 1931.
Švestka, F., 1962. Preslia 34: 307-308. (bibl., portr.)

<em>Note</em>: This publication was Fröhlich's thesis.
<em>Ref</em>.: Krause, K., Bot. Jahrb. Syst. 48(Lit.): 18. 27 Aug 1912 (rev.).

Froehner, Albrecht (fl. 1896-1898), German botanist, born in Dresden, studied <em>Coffea</em>
under A. Engler at the Berlin Botanical Museum, Dr. thesis at Rostock. (<em>A. Froehner</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

Froelich, Carl Fr. (fl. 1850-1857), Swiss artist and botanist living in Teufen. (<em>C. Froel.</em>).

Fron, Georges (1870-1957), French agronomist and mycologist, born 20 Feb 1870 in Paris,
agron. engineer 1891, at the Jardin colonial in Nogent-sur-Marne, Dr. ès-sciences 1899
Paris, served in W.W.-I, and after demobilization returned to the Paris Inst. Agronomique
1921, prof. of plant pathology, then of applied botany, president of the Société Botanique de
France and the Société Mycologique de France, died 15 Dec 1957 in Paris. (<em>Fron</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: P.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 212; Barnhart 2: 14; BL 2: 101-102, 656; CSP 15:
153; DBF 14: 1373-1374; Hirsch p. 90; IH 2: 211; Kelly p. 86; Kew 2: 350; LS 33.461-33.465;
LS suppl. 9026-9034; Rehder 5(index): 301; Stevenson p. 1242.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Intl. address book botanists: 108. 1931.
Charpin, A. &amp; J. Timbal, 2007. Acta Bot. Gallica 154: 449. (d. "1958")
Davy de Virville, A., 1954. Hist. bot. France: 139.
Dörfler, I., 1909. Botaniker-Adressbuch, ed. 3: 108.
Lavaud, S., 1955. Cat. thèses de Doctorat ès Sciences nat. soutenues à Paris de 1891 à 1954: 27.

HEADING: FROST

Fronius, Franz Friedrich [Friedrich Franz] (1829-1886), Hungarian evangelical clergy-
man and botanist, born 9 [4?] Jan 1829 in Nadesch (Szász Nádos, Siebenbürgen; now
Romania), attended elementary school in Nadesch and gymnasium in Schässburg, studied
theology and natural history at Univ. of Leipzig 1847-1849, teacher at the gymnasium of
Schässburg (Segesvárott), minister in Arkeden 1859, from 1868 at Agnetheln (Sz.-Agothän,
Siebenbürgen) where he died 14 Feb 1886. (<em>Fronius</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: B, L.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 14; BM 2: 628 (as "Friederich"); CSP 2: 735,
12: 256; IH 2: 211; Kanitz nr. 267; ÖBL 1: 374; PR ed. 2: 3133; Rehder 5(index): 301;
Urban-Berl. p. 347.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Bieltz, E.A., 1887. Mitth. Siebenbürg. Vereins Naturwiss. Hermannstadt 37: 1-5.

35.787. <em>Flora</em> von <em>Schässburg</em>. Ein Beitrag zur Flora von Siebenbürgen ... Kronstadt (Druck
und Verlag von Johann Gött) 1858. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 1858, p. [1]-95, 1 schema (uncol., fold.). <em>Copy</em>: BM.
<em>Note</em>: (1) The schema evidently consitutes p. 83-84. (2) The author signed this work as
	"Friedrich Fronius".

Frost, Charles Christopher (1805-1880), American shoemaker and self-taught natural-
ist, born 11 Nov 1805 in Brattleboro, Vermont, worked as a shoemaker throughout his life
except in the winter months of a few years in his early manhood when he taught school,
otherwise spent his leisure hours studying astronomy, geology, mineralogy, meteorology
and botany (esp. mycology), hon. A.M. Dartmouth and Middlebury colleges, died 16 Mar
1880 in Brattleboro, "the learned shoemaker of Brattleboro". (<em>Frost</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Fungi &amp; Lich.: VT-Frost Herb. (orig.; "... in the small dry-goods
boxes left over from Frost's primary employment as a shoemaker"), duplicates BUF, FH,
NYS; New England: NEBC. – Some corr. in [Edward] Tuckerman Botanical papers, 1816-
1886 (Amherst College Archives and Special Collections, Amherst, Mass.), also FH, GH,
NY and VT.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 212; Barnhart 1: 14; Bossert p. 134; CSP 7: 722;
Ewan Pap. p. 74; GR p. 217; IH 2: 211; Jackson p. 361; Kelly p. 86; Lenley p. 134; NAF 7(15):
1064, 9(6): 436; Portr. 3: 453; Rhodora, index p. 328; TL-2/6: 897 (index); Tucker 1: 265.

Frost, Frederick Hazard (1902-1973), American paleobotanist and paper-industry scien-
tist, born 11 Jan 1902 in Hanover, New Hampshire, B.S. (Geology) 1923 Univ. of Chicago,
Ph.D. 1927 Univ. of Calif., Natl. Research Council Fellow, Harvard Univ., Cambridge,
Mass. 1927-1929, vice-president and dir. of research, S.D. Warren Co. (a paper company),
Portland, Maine 1929-ca. 1966, vice-president 1953, Techn. Assn. Pulp &amp; Paper Industries in
Maine, died 20 Aug 1973 in Portland, Maine. (<em>F.H. Frost</em>).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: First son of astrophysicist Edwing Brant Frost (1866-1935).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: UC (orig.).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Amer. Men Sci. ed. 12: 1989; Ewan Pap. p. 74; IH 2: 211.

Ewan, J. (ed.), 1969. Short hist. bot. U.S.: 51.

	ogr. of F.H. Frost's father, some family details]

HEADING: FRYE

Fry, Edward (Sir) (1827-1918), British lawyer, judge and cryptogamic botanist also inter-
ested in archeology, astronomy and geology, born 4 Nov 1827 in Bristol (Gloucs.), edu-
cated at Bristol College 1841-1842 and Univ. College, London from 1843, B.A. 1851 in
classics and physiology, called to the bar 1854, Queen's Counsel 1869, appointed Judge of
the High Court of Justice 1877-1883, Lord Justice of Appeal 1883-1892, published also to-
gether with his daughter Agnes Fry (1868-1957), knighted 1877, F.R.S. 1883, G.C.B. 1907,
LL.D. Edinburgh, died 18 Oct 1918 at "Failand House" nr. Bristol. (<em>E. Fry</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown. – Mss.: Family papers in Cambridge Univ. Library
(England).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 224; Barnhart 2: 15; BB p. 117; BM 2: 629 (as
"Rt. Hon. Sir Edward"), 6: 350; BN p. 174; Bossert p. 135; CSP 15: 158; Desmond p. 240,
ed. 2: 265-266; DNB 1912-1917: 200-203, 21: 90-92. 2004; Ewan Pap. p. 74; LS 9375; LS
suppl. 9042-9046; Portr. 3: 443.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., New York Times [newspaper]: 7. 20 Oct 1918; Bull. Misc. Inform. Kew
	1919: 84-85. 1919; Rep. Bot. Soc. Exch. Club Brit. Isles 5(3): 354-355. 1919.

Kennedy, Lord Justice, 1907. J. Soc. Comparative Legislation, ser. 2, 8(2): 171. (portr.)
Lister, G., 1919. Proc. Linn. Soc. London 1918-1919: 53-54.

*Frye, Theodore Christian (1869-1962), American cryptogamic botanist, born 15 Sep 1869
on a farm nr. Washington, Illinois, B.S. 1891 Univ. of Illinois, taught school for seven years
in Illinois, Ph.D. 1902 Univ. of Chicago (under John M. Coulter), prof. of biology, Morn-
ingside College, Sioux City, Iowa 1902-1903, prof. and chair, Botany Dept. 1903-1941, and
dir., Puget Sound Biological Station (forerunner of Friday Harbor Laboratories) 1914-1930,
Univ. of Washington in Seattle 1903-1950, died 5 Apr 1962 in Seattle. (<em>Frye</em>).

PAGE: 66
HEADING: FRYE

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: WTU (orig.); see also IH 2: 211 (and add OSC, TRTC). – <em>Exsic-
catae</em>: (1) <em>Moss exsicc</em>., Seattle, Washington, nos. 1-60, 1942. <em>Set</em>: NY. (2) <em>Hepaticae</em>:
<em>Distributed by Clark &amp; Frye</em>, Seattle, Washington?, nos. 1-?, 1940. <em>Sets</em>: CAS, PH, UPS.
– Mss. in Univ. of Washington Libraries (Dept. of Botany Records, 1902-2000) and a tape-
recorded interview in the archives of the Seattle Historical Society.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Amer. Men Sci. ed. 9: 378; APN p. 212; Barnhart 2: 15;
BL 1: 162, 296; Bossert p. 135; Ewan ed. 1: 212, ed. 2: 80; Ewan Pap. p. 74; Hirsch p. 91;
Hortus 3: 1193; IH 2: 211; Kew 2: 351; Lenley p. 175; LS 33.470; NW p. 46 (index); Portr.
1: 62 (index), 3: 454; Roon p. 41; SBC p. 120; TL-2/1: 894, indices 2/2, Suppl. 4.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) Contributed "The Kelp beds of Southeast Alaska" to Frank Ken-
neth Cameron (1869-1958) (ed.), <em>Potash from kelp</em> ... U.S.D.A. Off. Secr. Rep. no. 100 ...
1915.
(2) Co-author of a number of papers on Hepaticae by L. Clark:
(a) <em>Liverworts Northw</em>. ... 1928, see TL-2/Suppl. 4, nr. 26.460;
(b) <em>Hepaticae northwestern states</em> ... 1931, see TL-2/Suppl. 4, nr. 26.461;
(c) <em>Liverworts Wyoming Washington</em> ... 1931, see TL-2/Suppl. 4, nr. 26.462;
(d) <em>Liverworts Northwestern States</em> ... 1934, see TL-2/Suppl. 4, nr. 26.463;
(e) <em>Hepaticae California</em> ... 1937, see TL-2/Suppl. 4, nr. 26.464; and
(f) <em>Extension ranges northwestern Hepaticae</em> ... 1937, see TL-2/Suppl. 4, nr. 26.465.
(3) Editor, <em>Puget Sound Marine Station Publications</em>, vol. 1 (1915-1916), and its retitled
successor <em>Puget Sound Biological Station Publications</em>, through vol. 7 (1931). Subesquent
to Frye's editorship the serial became <em>University of Washington Publications in Oceanog-
raphy</em>.

35.802. <em>Northwest flora</em> ... Seattle (University Bookstore, Univ. of Washington) [1912]. Oct. (<em>Northw. fl.</em>).

<em>Co-author</em>: Rigg, George Burton (1872-1961), see TL-2/4: 791-792 and IH 2: 762.
<em>Publ</em>.: 12 Sep 1912 (see Note (1)), p. [1]-453. <em>Copies</em>: Harriman, HH (n.v.), USDA (n.v.).
<em>Note</em>: (1) There is no internal evidence for a date. However, T.C. Frye evidently told H.M.
	Hall in 1921 that the flora was published on 12 Sep 1912 (<em>fide</em> IPNI sub "Northw. Fl.").
	(2) This volume is a precursor to <em>Elem. fl. Northwest</em> (see nr. 35.804 below) and derived,
	in turn, from <em>Laboratory exercises in elementary botany; based on plants of the Pacific
	slope</em> (1909, 1911) by the same authors.

35.803. The <em>ferns</em> of <em>Washington</em>[.] Illustrated ... [Port Richmond, New York] 1913-1914. Oct. 

<em>Co-author</em> [and principal illus.]: Jackson, Mabel McMurry (fl. 1913-1914), a student of
	T.C. Frye.
<em>Publ</em>.: 1913-1914 (p. [1] signed 20 Mar 1913, cover-t.p. gives dates of serial publications in 4
	parts), cover-t.p., p. [1]-59, <em>pl. 1-20</em> (mostly draw., some uncol. phot.). <em>Copy</em>: HH. – Reprinted
	and to be cited from Amer. Fern J. [1] 3(3): 65-83, <em>pl. 1-4</em> (uncol. draw.). 30 Aug 1913, [2] Id.
	3(4) 97-108, <em>pl. 6-8</em> (uncol. draw.). 30 Dec 1913, [3] Id. 4(1): 7-14, <em>pl</em>. <em>9-14</em> (uncol. phot. &amp;
	draw.). 30 Mar 1914, [4] Id. 4(2): 41-57, <em>pl. 15-21</em> (uncol. phot. &amp; draw.). 9 Jun 1914.
<em>Note</em>: (1) Cover p. 3 is advert. (2) Plates included in the paging (in both reprint and serial).
	(3) There is no <em>pl. 5</em> in the serial, which lead to a confusing renumbering of plates in the
	reprint: <em>pl. 1-4</em>, <em>15-18</em> are the same in both versions; <em>pl. 6-14</em>, <em>20-21</em> in the serial are <em>pl.
	5-13</em>, <em>19-20</em>, respectively, in the reprint; and <em>pl. 19</em> in the serial is <em>pl. 14</em> in the reprint!

*Fryer, Alfred (1826-1912), British botanist, born 25 Dec 1826 in Chatteris (Cambs.), at-
tended school in Leicester where he formed a friendship with Henry Walter Bates, friendly
with several of the founders of the Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood, returned to his home in
1848, aimed to publish a flora of Huntingdonshire in 1883 but focused mainly on <em>Pota-
mogeton</em>, F.L.S. 1898, died 26 Feb 1912 in Chatteris ("He grew up an unpractical man, fond
of poetry and general literature ..." <em>fide</em> Druce, 1913, p. 196). (<em>Fryer</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Potamogetonaceae: BM (orig.), duplicates BEL, CGE, K, LIV,
MANCH, NMW, PH, WAR, YK. – Mss. materials in the Natural History Museum (Lon-
don), Oxford Univ. (Dept. of Plant Sciences) and Yale Univ. Library, New Haven, Conn.
(Fryer family papers).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 212; Barnhart 2: 15; BB p. 117; Blunt ed. 2: 268;
BM 2: 629, 6: 350; Bossert p. 135; Clokie p. 168; CSP 2: 737, 15: 158, 176; Desmond p. 241,
ed. 2: 266; DNB 21: 116-117. 2004; GFB p. 95; IH 2: 212; Kent p. 54, ed. 2: 145; Kew 2:
351; Kew List p. 24; NI 2: 63; Portr. 3: 454; TL-1: 159-160; TL-2/1: 894, 2/3: 948 (index).

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Babington, C.C., 1897. Memorials: 472.
Bennett, A., 1912. Proc. Linn. Soc. London 124: 46-47.
Bridson, G.D.R. et al., 1980. Nat. hist. manuscript resources British Isles: 402. (index)
Dörfler, I., 1902. Botaniker-Adressbuch, ed. 2: 106; 1909. Id., ed. 3: 156.
Druce, C.C., 1913. Rep. Bot. Exch. Club Soc. Brit. Isles 3: 195-201. (bibl.)
Evans, A.H. &amp; J. Britten, 1912. J. Bot. 50: 105-110. (portr.)
Franks, J.W., 1973. Manchester Mus. Publ., new ser., no. NS.1.73: 2, 14.
Gibson, J.A. &amp; E.C. Nelson, 2001. Cumulative index Archives Nat. Hist.: 58.
Gilbert, J.L., 1972. Ann. Rep. Huntingdon. Fauna Flora Soc. 24: 12-13. (<em>fide</em> Kew Record)
Mears, J.A., 1981. Proc. Acad. Nat. Sci. Philadelphia 133: 150.
Preston, C.D., 1988. Arch. Nat. Hist. 15: 15-33. (bibl., portr.)
Preston, C.D., 1988. Watsonia 17: 23-35. (bibl., analysis of F.'s <em>Potamogeton</em> taxa)

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Fryer's principal contribution, <em>Potamoget. Brit.</em> ... [1898]-1915 (TL-2/1, nr. 1908),
was treated earlier but the entry can be amended as follows:
<em>Co-authors</em>: Bennett, Arthur (1843-1929), see TL-2/Suppl. 2: 72-73 and IH 2: 67-68; Evans, Ar-
	thur Humble (1855-1943), see TL-2/Suppl. 6: 434-435 and IH 2: 187 (as "Arthur Armble").
<em>Microfiche</em>: Westport, Conn. (Meckler/Chadwyck-Healey Publishing), [1987?], 3 micro-
	fiches (Plant taxonomic lit. microfiche coll., "1733A3-1735D2"). <em>Copy</em>: MO.

Fuchs, Max (1861-x), German geographer, born 7 Jan 1861 in Bromberg, attended gym-
nasium in Bromberg, studied history and geography in Berlin from 1880, went to Halle
1882, doctorate 1885 Halle, worked at a bank 1885-1893, dir. of archives, Deutsche Bank
in Berlin 1893-1929. (<em>M. Fuchs</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 16; BM 2: 630; Langman p. 295: Rehder 2:
814; Tucker 1: 266.

und der philosophischen Facultät der vereinigten Friedrichs-Universität Halle-Wittenberg zur
Erlangung der Doktorwürde ... Halle a/S. (Druck v. Metzger &amp; Wittig i. Leipzig) 1885. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 31 Oct 1885 (thesis defense; J. Bot. Dec 1885), p. [1]-32 [32=vita]. <em>Copies</em>: B-S,
	HH (n.v.), MO.
<em>Note</em>: This thesis is not the complete publication by Max Fuchs, see the following entry
	(nr. 35.821).

*Fuckel, [Karl Wilhelm Gottlieb] Leopold (1821-1876), German pharmacist and mycologist,
born 3 Feb 1821 in Reichelsheim (Hessen-Nassau), owned a pharmacy in Oestrich (Rheingau),
died 8 Mai [Mar?] 1876 in Vienna of typhus on his way back from a trip to Italy. (<em>Fuckel</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: G (orig.), duplicates BR, CWU, K (Fungi), L, M, STR, W, WIES.
– <em>Exsiccatae</em>: (1) <em>Fungi Rhenani Exsiccati a Leopoldo Fuckel collecti</em> ... (nos. 1-2700,

PAGE: 72
HEADING: FÜNFSTÜCK

1863-1874): BM (list), BPI (1-2697), FH (complete set), G (complete set), HBG, S, UPS.
(2) The status of the following as an exsiccata is unclear: <em>Enumeratio fungorum Nassoviae
a Leopoldo Fuckel collectorum</em>, Ser. I ... (Wiesbaden) (1860): M.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: ADB 8: 176 (as "Gottlieb Wilhelm Carl Leopold"); AG
6(1): 596 (d. "8 Mar 1876"); Ainsworth p. 342 (index); Ainsworth &amp; Bisby's Dict. p. 197;
APN p. 213; Barnhart 2: 16; Biol.-Dokum. 6: 75.175-75.184; BM 2: 630; BN p. 174; CSP 2:
739, 6: 663, 7: 726, 9: 947; DTS 1: 80 (d. "8 Mar 1876"); Frank 3(Anh.): 33; GR cat. p. 63;
Hawksworth p. 182; Hegi vi/2: 1229; Herder p. 247; Hist. Coll. BMNH p. 150; IH 2: 212;
Jackson p. 164, 225, 307; Kelly p. 86, 251; Kew 2: 352; Kew List p. 24; Kleppa p. 322 (index);
LS 3370, 9381-9396; Moebius p. 107; Morren ed. 2: 8; NAF 1(1): 159, 7(15): 1064, ser. 2(13):

*Fünfstück [Fuenfstueck], [Leberecht] Moritz (1856-1925), German botanist (lichenolo-
gist), born 23 Mar 1856 in Dittelsdorf (Saxony), attended Johanneum at Zittau until 1875,
studied mathematics and natural history (esp. botany) at the universities of Leipzig, Würz-
burg, Tübingen and Berlin, Dr. sci. 1884, at the Technische Hochschule in Stuttgart 1885,
extraord. prof. 1895 and prof. of botany and pharmacognosy 1900, died 18 Feb 1925 in
Stuttgart. (<em>Fünfstück</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: B (500 Lich.), some duplicates in M (herb. Arnold). In addition,
a large collection of Lich. from the estate of M. Fünfstück went to STU but was destroyed
in W.W.-II.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 213; Barnhart 2: 16; Biol.-Dokum. 6: 75.253-
75.258; BM 2: 630; CSP 12: 257, 15: 164; DTS 1: 80, 4: xliv-xlv; GR p. 79, <em>pl</em>. [<em>18</em>]; GR
cat. p. 34; Herder p. 257; IH 2: 213; Kelly p. 86, 251; Kew 2: 353; LS 9400-9407; Moebius
p. 112, 113; NI Suppl. p. 34; Portr. 3: 457; Rehder 5(index): 302; TL-2/1: 896-897, indices
2/2, 2/5; Tucker 1: 266.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Dörfler, I., 1896. Botaniker-Adressbuch: 15; 1902. Id., ed. 2: 16; 1909. Id., ed. 3: 34.

PAGE: 73
HEADING: FÜNFSTÜCK

[Engelmann, W.], 1891. Botanisches Adressbuch: 26.
Hertel, H. &amp; A. Schreiber, 1988. Mitt. Bot. Staatssamml. München 26: 141, 145, 156.
Lakon, G., 1925. Ber. Deutsch. Bot. Ges. 43: (39)-(44). (bibl., portr)
Lakon, G., 1926. Bot. Arch. 15: 1-4. (bibl.)

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: Fünfstück initiated and edited the serial <em>Beiträge zur wissenschaftli-
chen Botanik</em>, Bd. 1-5 (1897-1906); vol. 1 published in Stuttgart by E. Nägele, vols. 2-5 by
A. Zimmer.

Fuentes Maturana, Francisco (1876-1934), Chilean botanist, born 19 Apr 1876 in San
Fernando, chief, Phanerogam section, Santiago Museum 1912, died 6 Feb 1934 in Aysén.
(<em>Fuentes</em>).

HEADING: FUJII

Fuisting, Wilhelm [Guilelmus] (1839-1870), German lichenologist, born 18 Jul 1839 in
Münster and attended Gymnasium there until 1858, studied law in Bonn but switched to
natural history in Münster after two years, went first to Munich and in 1864 to Berlin, Dr.
Sci. 1865 Berlin, returned to his home in Münster because of heart problems, died 17 Nov
1870. (<em>Fuisting</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: B, additonal material at HBG, M.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: ADB 8: 191-192; APN p. 213 (as "Füisting"); Barnhart 2:
17; BM 2: 231; CSP 7: 726; GR p. 79; IH 2: 212; Kew 2: 353; LS 9417-9419; PR ed. 2: 3156;
SBC p. 120; Urban-Berl. p. 286, 299; Zep.-Tim. p. 50.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Hertel, H. &amp; A. Schreiber, 1988. Mitt. Bot. Staatssamml. München 26: 157.
Kuhn, M., 1871. Verh. Bot. Vereins Prov. Brandenburg 12: 30.

35.835. <em>De</em> nonnullis <em>apotheci lichenum evolvendi rationibus</em> ... Dissertatio inauguralis
quam consensu et auctoritate amplissimi philosophorum ordinis in alma litterarum univer-
sitate Friderica Guilelma ad summos in philosophia honores rite capessendos die ix. M.
Augusti A. MDCCCLXV. H.L.Q.S. publice defendet ... Berolini (Typis expressit Gustavus
Schade) [1865] Oct. (<em>De apoth. lich. evolv. ration.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 9 Aug 1865 (date of thesis defense), p. [i, iii], [1]-59, [60, vita], [61, theses]. <em>Copies</em>:
	BM, FH (n.v.), G, K (n.v.), LC (n.v.), NY (n.v.), WU.

Fujii, Kenjiro (1866-1952), Japanese botanist and cytologist, born 5 Oct 1866 in Kanazawa
(prov. Kaga), B.Sc. ("Rigakushi"), also studied at Univ. of Munich 1903-1904, prof. of plant
morphology and genetics, Tokyo Imperial Univ., 1903-ca. 1927, died 11 Jan 1952. (<em>Fujii</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 213 (as "Fujii, K. (fl. 1909)"); Barnhart 2: 17;
Biol.-Dokum. 6: 75.525-75.526; BM 6: 351; Bossert p. 135; Kew 2: 353; MW p. 129; Portr.
1: 62 (index), 3: 455; Rehder 5(index): 303; TL-2/6: 897 (index); Tucker 1: 266, 2: xvi,
3: 112.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Intl. address book botanists: 248. 1931.
Dörfler, I., 1896. Botaniker-Adressbuch: 264; 1902. Id., ed. 2: 210; 1909. Id., ed. 3: 295.
Mortlake, G.N., 1911 (1912, 2nd ed.). Love-letters of a Japanese, London (Stanley Paul &amp;
	Co.): 247, [5] p. [letters by Marie Charlotte Carmichael Stopes and Kenjiro Fujii under
	the pseudonyms of Mertyl Meredith and Kenrio Watanabe] (n.v.)

	the 25th year (jubilee) of his professorship [and his 70th birthday; issue includes Y. Ku-
	wada (p. 297-301) on "Professor K. Fujii's Contributions to Botanical Science" (bibl.)]
Wittrock, V.B., 1905. Acta Horti Berg. 3(5): 182, <em>pl. 150.</em> (portr.)

641-1604. 31 Aug 1937 (portr., frontisp.).

ties of cretaceous plants</em> ... 1910, see TL-2/6, nr. 13.207.
(2) Editor, <em>Cytologia</em> (International Journal of Cytology), vols. 1-16 (Aug 1929-Nov 1951,
except when publication suspended Dec 1945-Feb 1949).

Fukuyama, Noriaki [Nuruyuki] (1912-1946), Japanese botanist, student of G. Masamune,
specialized in the orchids of Taiwan, the Ryukyus and Micronesia, died in Taiwan. (<em>Fukuy</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: KPM (remnants of private herb. acquired via G. Masamune), TAI.
– Some mss. materials in KPM (via G. Masamune).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 213; Barnhart 2: 18; MW p. 131, suppl. p. 72.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Inoue, K. et al., 1998. J. Jap. Bot. 73: 199-230. (orchid types)
Walker, E.J., 1976. Fl. Okinawa S. Ryukyu Isls.: 1095.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: G. Masamune, <em>Short fl. Formosa</em> ... 1936 (TL-2/3, nr. 5576) acknowl-
edges the cooperation of Fukuyama.

<sm>OUTSIDE OUR PERIOD</sm>: <em>Contribution to the orchid flora of the Ryukyu archipelago</em>: i-ii ...
Contr. Lab. Syst. Bot., Kanazawa Univ., nos. 7-10 ... 1952, was published posthumously.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: <em>Studia Orchidacearum Japonicarum</em> ... I-X (1934-1938) was seen at HH-Ames, but
all nine parts were detached from journals; see MW (p. 131, suppl. p. 72) for details.

Fulford, Margaret Hannah (1904-1999), American botanist (bryologist and lichenologist),
born 14 Jun 1904 in Cincinnati, Ohio, B.A. 1926, B.E. 1927 and M.A. 1928, Univ. of Cincin-
nati, Ph.D. 1935 Yale Univ., New Haven, Conn., instructor of botany 1927-1940, curator of the
herb. 1927-1974, asst. prof. 1940-1946, assoc. prof. 1946-1954 and prof. of botany 1954-1974,
all Univ. of Cincinnati, B.S.A. Merit Award 1979, died 28 Nov 1999 in Cincinnati. (<em>Fulford</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: CINC (orig.), duplicates MICH, NY. – Letters in Cornell Univ.,
Ithaca, New York (Albert Leroy Andrews corr.), FH (Geneva Sayre papers) and NY
(Donald P. Rogers records).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Amer. Men Sci. ed. 20: 1496; APN p. 213; Barnhart 2: 18;
Bossert p. 135; Ewan ed. 1: 165 (index); Ewan Pap. p. 74; GR p. 217; IH 2: 212; Kew 2: 355;
Lenley p. 175; Portr. 1: 62 (index), 3: 456; Roon p. 41; SBC p. 120.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Bischler-Causse, H., 2000. Cryptog. Bryol. 21(1): 91.
Burk, W.R., 2002. Ohio J. Sci. 102: 133.
Ewan, J. (ed.), 1969. Short hist. bot. U.S.: 94, 95.
Gradstein, S.R., 2000. Bryol. Times, Issue 100: 15. (n.v.)
Greene, H.C. &amp; J.T. Curtis, 1955. Bibl. Wisconsin vegetation: 74. (index)
Ogilvie, M. &amp; J. Harvey (eds.), 2000. Biographical dict. woman in science: 477-478.
Stotler, R.E., 1988. Bryologist 90: 285-286. (portr.) ["Margaret H. Fulford Dedication Issue"]

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: Margaret H. Fulford Bryophyte Herb. (CINC) and Library, Univ. of Cincinnati.

<sm>OUTSIDE OUR PERIOD</sm>: (1) <em>The genus Bazzania in Central and South America</em>, Waltham
[Mass.] (Chronica Botanica Company). – Issued as Ann. Cryptog. Phytopathol. 3: xvi, 175
p. 1946. Suppls. were issued in Bull. Torrey Bot. Club 86. 1959.

Fuller, Albert Morse (1899-1981), American botanist, born 3 Mai 1899 in Kinnickinnic
(St. Croix Co.), Wisconsin, State Teacher's College (now Univ. of Wisconsin-River Falls),
River Falls, Wisconsin 1918, asst. principal, high school, Red Granite, Wisconsin 1918-
1919, B.A. 1923 Univ. of Wisconsin at Madison, asst. 1923-1930, assoc. 1931-1933 and
curator of Botany from 1933, all Milwaukee Public Museum, Milwaukee, Wisconsin, M.S.
1948 Marquette Univ., Milwaukee, died Jan 1981 in Wisconsin. (<em>A.M. Fuller</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: AMES, MICH, MIL (esp. <em>Rubus</em>), WIS.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 213; Barnhart 2: 18; Ewan Pap. p. 74; IH 2: 212;
Portr. 1: 62, 3: 456; Rhodora, index p. 328.

HEADING: FULLMER

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Intl. address book botanists: 470. 1931.
Greene, H.C. &amp; J.T. Curtis, 1955. Bibl. Wisconsin vegetation: 74. (index)

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: Co-author with William N. Steil, <em>Ferns and fern allies in Wisconsin</em>,
Parts [I]-II ... 1929 (reprinted from: [I] Amer. Fern J. 18(4): 105-114. 4 Dec 1928, II, Id.
19(1): 1-10. 10 Feb 1929).

Fullmer, Edward Lawrence (1870-x), American mycologist, born 30 Jul 1870 in Defiance
(Defiance Co.), Ohio, B.S. 1897 and M.S. 1898 Ohio State Univ., Columbus, Prof. of Biol-
ogy 1903-1940, Baldwin-Wallace College, Berea (Cuyahoga Co.), Ohio, member, Ohio
Academy of Science. (<em>Fullmer</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: OS. In several articles he also mentioned an herb. at Cedar Point
(i.e. Sandusky, Ohio) but this has not been traced.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Amer. Men Sci. ed. 7: 614; Barnhart 2: 19; IH 2: 212.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Intl. address book botanists: 470. 1931.
Dörfler, I., 1909. Botaniker-Adressbuch, ed. 3: 330.

Funk, Georg (1886-1958), German algologist and dendrologist, born 15 Mai 1886 in Bens-
heim (Hesse), Inaugural Dissertation 1912 Ludwigs-Univ., Giessen, appointed, marine bot-
any dept., Stazione Zoologica, Naples, Italy 1912, also prof. of botany, Ludwigs-Univ., died
24 Jan 1958 in Naples. (<em>Funk</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 213; Barnhart 2: 19; Biol.-Dokum. 6: 75.673-75.696;

Funke, George Lodewijk (1896-1946), Dutch botanist, born 29 Mai 1896 in Amster-
dam, attended elementary school and gymnasium in Amsterdam, in 1915 began biology
at Utrecht, Ph.D. 1922 Utrecht, teacher at gymnasium in Schiedam 1924, at Bogor (Indo-
nesia) 1927-1928, lecturer 1934, then prof. 1937, Univ. of Ghent, Belgium (but forced by
Germans to return to The Netherlands during W.W.-II), died 15 Dec 1946 from complica-
tions after an appendectomy. (<em>Funke</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Ainsworth p. 130, 327; Barnhart 2: 20; Biol.-Dokum. 6:
75.708; JW 1: 442, 2: 190, 4: 385; Kew 2: 356; LS suppl. 9133-9140.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Intl. address book botanists: 262. 1931.
Oye, P. van, 1946. Koninkl. Vlaam. Acad. Wetensch. ... Belgie Jaarb. 1946: 209-216. (bibl.,
	portr.)
Oye, P. van, 1947. Nature 159: 327. (b. "The Hague")

<sm>OUTSIDE OUR PERIOD</sm>: Funke published posthumously <em>Waterplanten</em> ... Gorinchem (J.
Noorduijn) 1951. – In series, Noorduijn's wetenschappelijke reeks 38.

Furrer, Ernst (1888-1976), Swiss botanist (plant geographer), born 29 Nov 1888 in Elsau
(Kt. Zürich), visited Bormio 1910-1911, Dr. Sci. 1914 Zürich (under Prof. H. Schinz),

PAGE: 80
HEADING: FURRER

studied the phytogeography of the Abruzzes in Italy and advocated protection of nature in
Switzerland, worked in Zurich where he died on 6 Sep 1976. (<em>Furrer</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Z. – Phot., at least, Stadtarchiv Schaffhausen, Switzerland.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 12(2): 65; Barnhart 2: 20; BFM p. 284 (index); BL 2:
367, 560-561, 585, 656; BM 6: 351; Hirsch p. 91; Kew 2: 357; TL-2/Suppl. 3: 545 (index).

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Intl. address book botanists: 328. 1931.
Fornaciari, G., 1978 ["1976-1977"]. Ann. Bot. (Rome) 35-36: 369-372. (bibl.)
Landolt, E., 1977. O.P.T.I.M.A. Newsl. (5): 17.
Landolt, E., 1977. Vierteljahrsschr. Naturf. Ges. Zürich 121: 370-371. (portr.) (b. "28
	Nov")
Pignatti, S., 1977. Inform. Bot. Ital. 9: 104-106. (bibl. re. Italy)
Uehlinger, A., 1976. Natur &amp; Mensch 18: 300-303. (n.v.)

<sm>OUTSIDE OUR PERIOD</sm>: Furrer wrote a book on Swiss wildflowers entitled <em>Blumen am Wege</em>
... Zürich (Silva-Bilderdienst) 1950, with water-color illus. by Hans and Otto Baumberger;
transl. into French by Robert Matthey and issued as <em>Fleurs sur ton chemin</em>, Zurich (Silva)
1950, and into Italian by Giacomo Gemnetti and issued as <em>Fiori sul tuo cammino</em>, Zurigo
(Edizioni Silva) 1950.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) Co-author with J. Braun-Blanquet, <em>Sur l'étude des associations</em> ...
1913, see TL-2/Suppl. 3, nr. 22.652.
(2) Edited a Festschrift in honor of Hans Shinz (1858-1941), which appeared in Viertel-
jahrsschr. Naturf. Ges. Zürich 73. 1928, see TL-2/5: 176.

Furtado, Caetano [Cajetano] Xavier dos Remedios (1897-1980), Indian botanist, born 14
Oct 1897 in Merces, Goa, studied agriculture at the Agricultural College in Poona, B.Sc.
1921, worked in Burma (now Myanmar) for a short time as asst. botanist, joined the Singa-
pore Botanic Garden in 1923 as field asst., later as botanist, Dr. Sci. 1940 Univ. of Bombay,
retired 1952 but rehired until 1960, specialist in palms, Araceae and nomenclature, died 13
Jun 1980 in Singapore. (<em>Furtado</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: A, B, BM, BO, K, LAS, NY, SING.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 213; Backer p. 650; Barnhart 2: 20; Biol.-Dokum.
6: 75.743-75.749; Bossert p. 136; Hortus 3: 1193; IH 2: 213; Kew 2: 357-358; MW p. 131,
suppl. p. 72; Portr. 3: 458; Roon p. 42; SK 1: cl (handwr.), 183 (portr.), 4(2): xciv (portr.),
cxxxvii, 8: xxxvii; Zander ed. 17: 949.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Intl. address book botanists: 313. 1931.
Alphonso, A.G., 1980. Gard. Bull. Singapore 33: 301-302. (portr.)
Beaman, J.H. et al., 2001. The plants of Mount Kinabalu 4: 22. [Furtado's Kinabalu collec-
	tions generally bear Clemens nos.]
Holttum, R.E. &amp; J. Dransfield, 1981. Fl. Males. Bull. 34: 3543-3544. (d. "12 Jun")
Johnson, D.V. &amp; Eng Pin Tay, 1999. Gard. Bull. Singapore 51: 141-150. (palm bibl.,
	portr.)
Jones, G.N., 1966. An annotated bibl. Mexican ferns: 72.
Kiew, R., 2005. Gardenwise 24: 16. (biogr., portr.)

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Furtadoa</em> M. Hotta (1981).

ture</em>. Gard. Bull. Singapore 12(2): 311-377. 7 Dec 1949.
(2) Furtado, C.X. &amp; Srisuko Montien, <em>A revision of Lagerstroemia</em> L. (<em>Lythraceae</em>). Gard.
Bull. Singapore 24: 185-335. 9 Aug 1969.

Futterer, Wilhelm [Friedrich] (1871-x), German pharmacist, born 19 Jan 1871 in Stock-
ach (Kreis Constanz), attended Gymnasium in Heidelberg, studied pharmacy and passed
the state examination for pharmacist 1895, Dr. Sci. 1896 Heidelberg, asst., Botanical Inst.,
Marburg Univ. (<em>W. Futterer</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.
