Fyson, Philip Furley (1877-1947), Japanese-born British teacher and sometime botanist,
born 17 Apr 1877 in Niigata, Japan of missionary parents, educated in Scotland, attended
Cambridge, succeeded Alfred Gibbs Bourne (1859-1940) as prof. of biology 1904-1912 and
then prof. of botany 1912-1920, Presidency College, Madras, India, inspector of schools
for Vishakapatnam and Ganjam 1920-1925, returned to the Presidency College as principal
1925-1932, F.L.S., retired 1932 and settled in England, died 26 Dec 1947 in Rushwick
(Worcs.) after being struck by a car while bicycling. (<em>Fyson</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: FRC, K, PCM.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 213; Barnhart 2: 21; BM 6: 352; Frodin ed. 2: 721;
IH 2: 213; Kew 2: 359; NI 2: 64; Tucker 2: xvi, 3: 113.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Intl. address book botanists: 228. 1931; [Last will and testament, 12 Dec
	1947]: <em>Copy</em>: K; Evening News and Times (Worcester) [newspaper]: 27 Dec 1947, Id.: 30
	Dec 1947, Id.: 2 Jan 1948; [certified copy birth certificate, dated 24 Mar 1997]: <em>Copy</em>: K.
Matthew, K.M., 1997. J. Swamy Bot. Club 14: 94-97. (portr.)
Matthew, K.M., 1998. Frontline (India's Natl. Magazine) 15(5): 88. (portr.)
Matthew, K.M., 1998. Shola no. 21: 278-279. (portrs. Fyson &amp; wife)
Matthew, K.M., 1999. Huntia 10(2): 130-131. (portr.)
Matthew, K.M., 2001. Shola no. 27: 326-327.
Purushothaman, T.R., 1932. The Presidency College (Madras) Magazine 7(2-3): 134-137.
	(portr.)

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Fysonia</em> Kashyap (1923).

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: Instrumental in initiating the <em>Journal of Indian Botany</em> (Madras), vols.
1-2 (1921-1923), which was superseded by the <em>Journal of the Indian Botanical Society</em>,
vols. 3-x (1924-x).

Kodaikanal ... Madras (Printed by the Superintendent, Government Press) 1915[-1920].

Gacogne, [Pierre Joseph] Alphonse (1814-1879), French teacher, entomologist and bota-
nist, born 3 Jan 1814 in Senlis, prof. of literature and history in Paris, and then in Lyon, died
26 Dec 1879 in Lyon. (<em>Gacogne</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: "herbier donné à la Soc. Bot. de Lyon" (Magnin, 1907).

Gadd, Pehr [Petrus] Adrian [Adrianus] (1727-1797), Finnish chemist, economist and
naturalist, born 12 Apr 1727 in Birkkala, student 1742 and later Prof. of Chemistry, Univ.
of Åbo (Turku) 1761, died 11 Aug 1797 in Åbo. (<em>Gadd</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown. – Corr. of Linnaeus.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 22; Collander p. 120 (78 works); Collander hist.
p. 155 (index); CSP 2: 752; Dryander 5: 244-245 (index); Herder p. 385; KR p. 235; PR ed. 1:
3455-3464; Rehder 5(index): 305; Saelan p. 119-128; Sarjeant p. 1056; SMK 3: 4; TR p. 88.

Hintikka, T.J., 1923. Valvoja-Aika 1: 405-419. (n.v.)

Gadeceau, Émile [Jules Arthur] (1845-1928), French botanist esp. interested in the flora of
Brittany, born 7 Feb 1845 in Nantes and was to succeed his father in business but devoted
himself to botany, died 18 Mai 1928 in Neuilly (Seine). (<em>Gadeceau</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BM (orig. by purchase), duplicates: CGE, E-GL, K, MPU.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 22; BL 2: 102, 172, 182, 657; BM 2: 633,
6: 352; Bossert p. 137; CSP 7: 729, 12: 258, 15: 180; DBF 15: 22-23; IH 2: 214; Kew 2:
360-361; Kew List p. 25; MW p. 131; Portr. 3: 459; Rehder 2: 254; TL-2/3: 948 &amp; Suppl.
2: 459 (indices); Tucker 1: 267, 774, 3: 113.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Arch. Bot. Caen Bull. Mens. 2: 136. 1928; J. Bot. 66: 302. 1928.
Charpin, A. &amp; G.G. Aymonin, 2003. J. Bot. Soc. Bot. France 21: 69.
Charpin, A. &amp; J. Timbal, 2007. Acta Bot. Gallica 154: 450.
Davy de Virville, A., 1954. Hist. bot. France: 254, 261, 263, 267, 268.
Dörfler, I., 1896. Botaniker-Adressbuch: 58; 1902. Id., ed. 2: 75; 1909. Id., ed. 3: 108.
Font Quer, P., 1928. Cavanillesia 1: 119.
Hedge, I.C. &amp; J.M. Lamond (eds.), 1970. Index collectors Edinburgh Herb.: 82.
Perrein, Ch., 1995. Émile Gadeceau ... phytoécologue et biohistorien. Thèse, Nantes: 1-
	260. (n.v.)

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) Published J. Lloyd, <em>Fl. Ouest France</em> ... ed. 5, 1898 (see TL-2/3, nr.
4904), which also included an appendix (p. 455-459) by Gadeceau.
(2) Co-author with D. Bois, <em>Végétaux</em> ... 1909, see TL-2/Suppl. 2, nr. 21.869.

Gadow, Hans Friedrich [Friedrick] (1855-1928), German-born British zoologist whose
knowledge of birds, reptiles, amphibians and plants contributed to systematics, evolution
and biogeography, born 8 Mar 1855 in Krakow Schlawe (now Alt-Krakow bei Schlawe),
Farther Pomerania, where his father was Inspector of the Prussian Royal Forests, from
1875 studied natural science at Berlin Univ., Ph.D. 1878 Jena (under E. Haeckel), research
asst. in zoology, BMNH 1880, trustee and curator of the Strickland Foundation for Birds,
Zoology Museum, Cambridge Univ. 1882, naturalized 1884, lecturer, King's College, Cam-
bridge 1884, F.R.S. 1892, visited Mexico with his wife 1904, reader in vertebrate morphol-
ogy, King's College 1920, died 26 [16?] Mai 1928 nr. Cambridge, England. (<em>Gadow</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BM (ca. 200). – Mss. in the Amer. Philos. Soc (Hans Gadow pa-
pers) and in the Natural History Museum, London.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Biol.-Dokum. 6: 75.953-75.965; BM 2: 633, 6: 353; CSP 9:
952, 15: 180-181; Hirsch p. 92; IH 2: 214; Kew 2: 361; Langman p. 296; NDB 6: 14 (d. "16
Mai"); Tucker 1: 267, 3: 113.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Adler, K., 1989. Contr. hist. Herpetology: 154; 2007. Id., vol. 2: 109-110. (handwr.,
	portr.) (d. "16 Mai")
Bridson, G.D.R. et al., 1980. Nat. hist. manuscript resources British Isles: 402. (index)
G., J.S., 1928. Nature 121: 874. (obit.)
Jones, G.N., 1966. An annotated bibl. Mexican ferns: 72.
Knobloch, I.W., 1983. Phytologia Mem. 6: 29.
McVaugh, R., 1972. Contr. Univ. Michigan Herb. 9(3): 235-236.
P[almer]., T.S., 1928. Auk 45: 538-539.
Thorpe, W.H., [1976]. The early Cambridge Bird Club: recollections of ornithologists and
	other naturalists, [Cambridge] (Cambridge Bird Club): 16 p. (ined.) (n.v.)
W[atson]., D.M.S., 1931. Proc. Roy. Soc. London, ser. B, 107: i-iii. (portr. facing p. i.) (d.
	"16 Mai")
Wright, A.H., 1949. Herpetologica 5, Suppl. 1: 19. (as "Friederick")
Wynne, O.E., 1969. Biogr. key-names birds of the world: 71.

PAGE: 91
HEADING: GAERTNER

<em>Publ</em>.: 15 Feb 1909 (in journal, read 18 Jun 1908), p. [429]-440. <em>Copy</em>: K. – Reprinted and

	uncol. phot.), 1 map (uncol., fold.). <em>Copies</em>: BM, HH (n.v.), K, LC (n.v.), MO(2) (n.v.),

<em>Ref</em>.: M.I.N., Geogr. J. (London) 77(3): 283-284. Mar 1931 (rev.).
	Diels, L., Bot. Jahrb. Syst. 64(Lit.): 31. 26 Oct 1931 (rev.).

Gaerdt, Heinrich (1813-1893), German horticulturist and landscape architect, born 7 Nov
1813 in Drebkau (Brandenburg), head gardener of August Borsig, a factory owner 1854,
later dir. of the Königlicher Gartenbau in Berlin, died 14 Nov 1893. (<em>Gaerdt</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart p. 22; Herder p. 104; Rehder 5(index): 305;
TL-2/4: 1171 (index).

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Wittmack, L., 1893. Gartenfl. 43: 3-6. (portr.)

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Gaerdtia</em> Klotsch (1855).

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: One of many contributing editors ("Unter Mitwirkung von ...") to the
serial <em>Gartenflora</em>, vols. 36-39; see TL-2/4, nr. 8775.

35.910. Die <em>Winterblumen</em>. Anleitung für Gärtner und Gartenliebhaber zur Winterkultur
der für den Schmuck der Wohnräume und Glashäuser, für Bouquets, Vasen und andere
Arrangements geeigneten einheimischen und ausländischen Blumen und Blattpflanzen ...
Berlin (Verlag von Paul Parey) 1884. Oct.

Ed. 2 [Neue Ausg.]: 1886, p. [i]-xvi, 1-735, <em>9 pl</em>. (chromolith.). Co<em>py</em>: USDA (n.v.).

*Gaertner [Gärtner], Carl [Karl] Friedrich (von) (1772-1850), German physician and bota-
nist, born 1 Mai 1772 in Calw (some say St. Petersburg, others Göppingen), son of Joseph
Gaertner, dissertation 1796 Göttingen (on phosphorous in urine), returned to Calw and from

PAGE: 92
HEADING: GÄUMANN

there began traveling (Paris, London, The Netherlands), returned again to Calw in Mar 1803
and then went to Tübingen, knighted 11 Mai 1846, died 1 Sep 1850 in Calw. (<em>C.F. Gaertn.</em>).

An important dissertation on Gaertner not cited in TL-2/1:
Graepel, P.H., 1978. Carl Friedrich von Gärtner (1772-1850). Familie—Leben—Werk. Ein
	Beitrag zur Geschichte der Sexualtheorie und der Bastarderzeugung im Pflanzenreich.
	Marburg (Vorgelegt von Peter Hartwig Graepel): p. [i]-xii, 1-445, [Lebenslauf]. (portrs.).
	<em>Copies</em>: BM, MO, US. – See also: S[tafleu]., F.A., Taxon 29: 175. 1980 (short rev.).

*Gäumann, Ernst Albert (1893-1963), Swiss mycologist and plant pathologist, born 6
Oct 1893 in Lyss (Kt. Berne), attended Gymnasium in Biel, Ph.D. 1917 Bern (under Edu-
ard Fischer), in Indonesia 1919-1922, prof., Dept. of Special Botany, Swiss Federal Inst.
of Technology, Zürich &amp; dir., Bot. Museum 1927-1963, specialized in parasitic fungi and
mosses, Dr. h.c. Bonn, Bordeaux, Montpellier and Paris, Corr. Member B.S.A., died 5 Dec
1963 in Zürich. (<em>Gäumann</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BERN; Rust fungi: ZT, Indonesia: BO.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Ainsworth p. 342 (index); Ainsworth &amp; Bisby's Dict. p.
202 (as "Ernest"), 227; APN p. 221; Barnhart 2: 22; BFM p. 284 (index); BN p. 28; Bossert
p. 140 (as "Gaumann"); GR p. 640; Hawksworth p. 182; Hirsch p. 92; IH 2: 219; Kelly p.
88; Kew 2: 362; KR p. 251; LS suppl. 9399-9436; Mägdefrau p. 310 (index); Moebius p.
107; Portr. 1: 62 (index); SK 1: 184; TL-2/1: 903-904.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Intl. address book botanists: 328. 1931; Death announcement, Zürich. 6
	Dec 1963. <em>Copy</em>: K.

Gage, Andrew Thomas (1871-1945) (Major, later Lieut.-Col.), Scottish soldier, physician
and botanist, born 14 Dec 1871 in Aberdeen, M.A. and LL.D. Aberdeen Univ., asst. to prof.
of Botany, Aberdeen Univ. 1894-1895, Indian Medical Service 1897-1898, herb. curator,
Calcutta Botanic Gardens 1898-1905, then superintendent and dir. of the Botanical Survey

PAGE: 95
HEADING: GAGE

of India 1906-1925, prof. of Botany, Medical College, Calcutta, librarian and asst. secretary
of the Linnean Society (London) 1924-1929, F.L.S. 1901, died 21 Jan 1945 in Strathpeffer
(Ross). (<em>A.T. Gage</em>).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Not to be confused with Sir Thomas Gage (1781-1820), who specialized in Lich.
(see IH 2: 214) and for whom the genus <em>Gagea</em> Salisb. (1806) was named.

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: India: A, B, CAL, DBN, DD, E, K, L, LE, U. – Letters and mss.
materials in the archives of GH, Glasgow Univ. (Frederick Orpen Bower corr.), K and
Linnean Society (London).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 650; Barnhart 2: 22; BM 6: 353; Desmond p.
242, ed. 2: 268; Frodin ed. 2: 1025 (index); IH 2: 214; LS 9460; MW p. 131; Portr. 3: 460;
TL-2/2: 953 (index); Tucker 1: 267, 3: 113; Urban-Berl. p. 347.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Biswas, K. (ed.), 1942. 150th Anniv. Vol. Royal Bot. Gard. Calcutta: 6-7. (portr.)
Cowan, J. McQ., 1945. Proc. Linn. Soc. London 157: 105-109. (portr.)
Desmond, R., 1992. European discovery Indian flora: 346. (index)
Dörfler, I., 1902. Botaniker-Adressbuch, ed. 2: 106, 206; 1909. Id., ed. 3: 290.
Hedge, I.C. &amp; J.M. Lamond (eds.), 1970. Index collectors Edinburgh Herb.: 82.
Nelson, E.C., 1980. Glasra 4: 47. (specimens at DBN)
Riddick, J.F., 1998. Who was who in British India: 136.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: Author of the final part (i.e. no. 26) of Sir G. King, <em>Mat. fl. Malay
Penins.</em> ... Sep 1936, see TL-2/2, nr. 3655.

PAGE: 97
HEADING: GAGNEPAIN

*Gagnepain, François (1866-1952), French botanist, born 23 Sep 1866 in Bois-de-Raveau
nr. La Charité-sur-Loire (Nièvre), began collecting plants when 11 years old, school teacher
in various villages of Nièvre 1886-1900, "préparateur des hautes études" 1909, then asst.
dir. of the lab. of phanerogamic botany 1909, both Muséum natl. d'Histoire naturelle, Paris,
major contributor to <em>Flore générale de l'Indochine</em> 1907-1950, which was initiated by Prof.
H. Lecomte, Légion d'honneur 1923, died 20 Jan 1952 in Cannes. (<em>Gagnep</em>.).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: The death notice in Bot. Centralbl. (119: 256. 1911) was erroneous.

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: P.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 215; Backer p. 226, 650; Barnhart 2: 23; BL 1:
122, 297, 2: 184, 200-201, 657; BM 6: 353; BN p. 174; CSP 15: 184; DBF 15: 44; Frodin ed.
2: 818; Hortus 3: 1193; IH 2: 214; Kelly p. 86; Kew 2: 363-364; Langman p. 276; Lenley
p. 176; LS suppl. 9197; MW p. 119, 131-133, suppl. p. 73; Portr. 1: 62 (index); Rehder 5(in-
dex): 306; RS p. 84; Strid p. 123, ed. 2: 170; TL-2/1: 904-905, indices 2/2, 2/4, 2/5, Suppl.
4; Tucker 1: 267, 3: 114; Zander ed. 10: 603, ed. 17: 949.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Intl. address book botanists: 108. 1931; Rev. Int. Bot. Appl. Agric. Trop.
	32: 303-305. 1952.
Charpin, A. &amp; G.G. Aymonin, 2003. J. Bot. Soc. Bot. France 21: 69-70.
Charpin, A. &amp; J. Timbal, 2007. Acta Bot. Gallica 154: 450.
Chevalier, A.J.B., 1944. <em>In</em>, P.H. Lecomte, Fl. Indochine, tome prél.: 41. (portr.)
Davy de Virville, A., 1954. Hist. bot. France: 186, 187, 264, 346, 352, 366.
Dörfler, I., 1896. Botaniker-Adressbuch: 58; 1902. Id., ed. 2: 75; 1909. Id., ed. 3: 108.
Gagnepain, F., 1908. Notice sur les travaux botaniques de F. Gagnepain, Mâcon (impr. de
	Protat frères): 14 p. (n.v.)
Gagnepain, F., 1930. Titres et travaux scientifiques, Villeneuve-Saint-Georges ("L'Union
	typographique"): 1-39, incl. 8 p. illus. (bibl. of 270 publ.)
Humbert, H., 1952. Notul. Syst. (Paris) 14(4): 221-229. (portr.) [fasc. also dedicated to FG]
Jacquet, P., 2001. Orchidophile 32(147): 137-142. (portr.) (n.v.)
Jaussaud, P. &amp; Éd. R. Brygoo, 2004. Du Jardin au Muséum en 516 biographies, Paris: 235-
	236.
Lancaster, R., 1989. Roy Lancaster travels in China: a plantsman's paradise, Woodbridge
	(The Antique Collectors' Club): 27.
Reed, C.F., 1969. Bibl. Fl. SE Asia: 66-77. (bibl.)
Wittrock, V.B., 1905. Acta Horti Berg. 3(3): 102, <em>pl. 143.</em> (portr.)

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) A major contributor to H. Lecomte, <em>Fl. Indo-Chine</em> ... (see TL-2/2,
nr. 4275) for which Davy de Virville (1954: 187) noted "Gagnepain en assuma la publica-
tion, rédigeant, à lui seul, 69 familles représentant 4.865 pages".
(2) Co-author with A.E. Finet, <em>Contributions à la flore de l'Asie orientale</em> ... 1905-1907, 2
vols., which reprints 11 articles published earlier in the Bull. Soc. Bot. France (1903-1904)
and Mém. Soc. Bot. France (1905-1906).
(3) Contributed to K. Rechinger, <em>Botanische und zoologische Ergebnisse einer wissen-
schaftlichen Forschungsreise nach den Samoainseln</em> ... Part 5, 1913 (TL-2/4, nr. 8726).
(4) Contributed to C.S. Sargent (ed.), <em>Pl. wilson.</em> ... 1913-1917, 3 vols. (TL-2/5, nr. 10.303).
(5) Co-author with Aug. Chevalier, <em>Genre nouveau de Saxifragacées</em> ... 1927 (TL-2/Suppl.
4, nr. 25.853).
(6) Posthumously, with Jules E. Vidal (1914-x), contributed Sabiacées to <em>Flore du Cam-
bodge, du Laos, et du Vietnam</em> ... 1960; this flora being a continuation of the <em>Fl. Indo-Chine</em>
(TL-2/2, nr. 4275).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: There is almost an infinity of Gagnepain reprints at NY, more than 373 [through

PAGE: 98
HEADING: GAGNEPAIN

1950], often only a few pages long, apparently numbered by Gagnepain and many sent to
E.D. Merrill; some undoubtedly detached from periodicals.

*Gaillard, Albert (1858-1903), French pharmacist and mycologist, born 5 Sep 1858 in Neuilly-
sur-Seine nr. Paris, curator of the Lloyd herbarium, Angers (Maine-et-Loire), collected in Ven-
ezuela 1887, Lauréat de l'Institut de France (Paris), died 28 Jul 1903 in Angers. (<em>Gaillard</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Venezuela (fungi): B, BM, BPI, FH, NY, P (phan.), PC?; France: BPI.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 215; Barnhart 2: 23; BM 2: 634; BN p. 174; CSP
15: 185-186; IH 2: 214; LS 9465-9497, 20.128, 33.503-33.505; Kelly p. 86-87; Lenley p.
176; NAF 9(6): 445 (sub Patouillard) TL-2/1: 905, 2/4: 1171 (index); Urban-Berl. p. 275.

PAGE: 103
HEADING: GAILLARD

Charpin, A. &amp; J. Timbal, 2007. Acta Bot. Gallica 154: 450.
Dörfler, I., 1896. Botaniker-Adressbuch: 58; 1902. Id., ed. 2: 75.
Harshberger, J.G., 1899. The botanists of Philadelphia: 267. [sub Ellis, J.B.]

	Editorial Acta Científica Venezolana): 28, 163.

follows:

	fiches (Plant taxonomic lit. microfiche coll., "1813F1-1815G1"). <em>Copy</em>: MO (n.v.).

	Périsporiacées: le genre Meliola: anatomie, morphologie, systématique ... Lons-le-
	Saunier (Imprimerie &amp; Lithographie Declume), p. [1]-163, [i, printer's mark], <em>pl. 1-24</em>
	(uncol. lith.). <em>Copy</em>: NY.

Gain, Louis (1883-1963), French naturalist (ornithologist and algologist) and meteorolo-
gist, naturalist aboard the <em>Pourquoi Pas?</em> on Jean-Baptiste Auguste Étienne Charcot's 2nd
Exped. to the Antarctic 1908-1910, also sailed (1911-1912) on the <em>Hirondelle II</em>, which
had been built for oceanographic research by Prince Albert I (1848-1922) of Monaco, Dr.
ès-sciences 1912 Paris, "préparateur" to the Prof. of Comparative Anatomy, Muséum natl.
d'Histoire naturelle, Paris 1913, after W.W.-I employed as a meteorologist becoming asst.-
dir., national office of meteorology, retired 1952. (<em>Gain</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Antarctic: PC.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 215; Barnhart 2: 23; BM 6: 354; IH 2: 214; Kew
2: 235.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: [Albert Ier de Monaco], 1934. Résultats des campagnes scientifiques accomplies
	sur son yacht par Albert Ier, prince souverain de Monaco ... vol. 89: 458-459, <em>pl. 4</em>, figs.
	20, 22. (portrs.)
Charcot, J., 1911. The voyage of the 'Why not?' in the Antarctic ... [English version], New
	York, London (Hodder and Stoughton): 311 (index). (portrs., facing p. 24 &amp; 200)
Charpin, A. &amp; J. Timbal, 2007. Acta Bot. Gallica 154: 450.

Gaiser, Lulu Odell (1896-1965), Canadian plant cytologist and taxonomist, born 1 Jun 1896
in Crediton, Ontario, A.B. 1916 Univ. of Western Ontario, London, Ontario, A.M. 1921 and
Ph.D. 1927 Columbia Univ., New York, New York, asst., Dept. of Botany, Barnard College,
New York, New York 1921-1923, Junior Pathologist, U.S.D.A., Washington, D.C. 1924-1925,
lecturer then Prof. of Biology, McMaster Univ., Hamilton, Ontario 1925-1949, Gray Herb.,
Harvard Univ., Cambridge, Mass. 1949-1954, died 7 Apr 1965 in Crediton. (<em>Gaiser</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: DAO, GH (few), OAC. – Corr. in a number of collections, a.o. Ralph
Erskine Cleland papers (1892-1971), Lilly Library, Indiana Univ., Bloomington, Indiana; Fran-
cis Marion Ownby papers (1934-1974), Washington State Univ. Libraries, Pullman, Washing-
ton; and Orland E. White papers (1902-1968), Univ. of Virginia, Charlottesville, Virginia.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 215; Barnhart 2: 24; Ewan Pap. p. 75; Hirsch p. 92;
Hortus ed. 2: 1193; Kew 2: 365; Langman p. 296-297; Lenley p. 176; Portr. 3: 46; Rhodora,
index p. 329.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Intl. address book botanists: 44. 1931.
Cody, W.J. et al., 1986. Systematics in Agriculture Canada at Ottawa 1886-1986. Historical
	Ser. 28: 79 (English index), 81 (French index).
Greene, H.C. &amp; J.T. Curtis, 1955. Bibl. Wisconsin vegetation: 74. (index)
Moore, R.J. &amp; W.F. Grant, 1965. Canad. J. Genet. Cytol. 7: 361-362. (bibl.)

<sm>OUTSIDE OUR PERIOD</sm>: (1) <em>The genus Liatris</em> ... Rhodora 48: 165-183, 216-263, 273-382, 393-
414. 1946.
(2) <em>Chromosome studies in Kuhniinae</em> (<em>Eupatorieae</em>). <em>I</em>. <em>Brickellia</em> ... Rhodora 55: 253-267,
269-288, 297-321, 328-345. 1953.
(3) <em>Studies in the Kuhniinae</em> (<em>Eupatorieae</em>) <em>II</em>. ... J. Arnold Arbor. 35: 87-133. 1954.
(4) Raymond J[ohn]. Moore (1918-1988) compiled <em>A survey of the vascular plants of Lamb-
ton County, Ontario</em> ... 1966, which was based on a survey from 1957-1964 by Gaiser.

*Galeotti, Henri-Guillaume (1814-1858), French-born Belgian (naturalized 28 Feb 1843)
geologist, botanist and horticulturist, born 10 Sep 1814 in Paris, the son of a Milanese father,

PAGE: 106
HEADING: GALEOTTI

moved with his family in childhood to Brussels, studied natural history at the Établissement
Géographique de Bruxelles, awarded gold medal in science for work in geology, Belgian
Royal Acad. Sci. 1835, traveled in Mexico Dec 1835-Jun 1840, returned to Europe and es-
tablished an horticultural firm in the suburbs of Brussels, revisited Mexico 1840-1841, dir.,
botanical garden, Brussels 1853 until his death on 14 Mar 1858 in Brussels. (<em>Galeotti</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BR (orig.), duplicates in B, BR, C, E, F, FI, G, GENT, GH, K, L,
LE, LG, LV, M, MANCH, NY, OXF, P, P-JU, PC, TUB, U, UC, US, W.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 216; Barnhart 2: 24; BM 2: 635; Clokie p. 169; CSP
2: 758-759; Ewan Pap. p. 75 (as "Henri"); Herter p. 357; Hortus 3: 1193; IF suppl. 4: 354; IH
1 (ed. 6): 358(index), 2: 214; Jackson p. 548 (index); Kew 2: 366; Kew List p. 25; Langman p.
297-298; Lasègue p. 205, 209-211, 304, 315; MW p. 134; PR ed. 1: 6548, ed. 2: 5850 &amp; p. 116;
Quenstedt p. 153; Rehder 5(index): 306; Sarjeant p. 1058; TL-2/1: 906; TL-2/3: 948, 2/4:
1171 (indices); Tucker 1: 267; Urban-Berl. p. 299, 348; Zander ed. 10: p. 603, ed. 17: p. 949.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Amer. J. Sci. Arts, ser. 2, 27: 443. 1859.
Bommer, J.E., 1858. J. Hort. Prat. Belg. 2: 94-96.
Candolle, A.L., 1880. Phytographie: 414.

Hedge, I.C. &amp; J.M. Lamond (eds.), 1970. Index collectors Edinburgh Herb.: 82.
Hemsley, W.B., 1887. Biol. Centr. Amer. 4: 125-126.
Jones, G.N., 1966. An annotated bibl. Mexican ferns: 292-293. (index)

	publications 1830-1880, vol. 2: 94, 616 (sub M. Martens).

	sciences, Amsterdam (Koninklijke Nederlandse Akademie van Wetenschappen): 84-85.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) Co-author with M. Martens:
(a) <em>Mém. foug. Mexique</em> ... 1842, see TL-2/3 no. 5486.
(b) <em>Notice sur les plantes des familles des Vacciniées</em> ... 1842, see TL-2/3, nr. 5487, where it is
noted that this title is actually the first part of <em>Enum. pl. Galeotti</em> ... (i.e. TL-2/3, nr. 5488);
(c) <em>Enum. pl. Galeotti</em> ... 1842-1845, see TL-2/3, nr. 5488.
(d) <em>Enumeratio Graminearum et Cyperacearum</em> ... <em>collectarum</em> ... 1842, which is the third
part of <em>Enum</em>. <em>pl. Galeotti</em> ... (i.e. TL-2/3, nr. 5488); the first and third parts being the only ones
issued with different titles (i.e. without <em>Enumeratio synoptica plantarum</em> ...). <em>Copy</em>: BM.
(2) Co-author with Achille Richard, <em>Monographie des Orchidées mexicaines</em> ... 1844
(TL-2/4, nr. 9149).
(3) Scientific editor of the 10th-14th years of <em>Journal d'horticulture pratique de la Belgique</em>
... (1853-1857).
(4) Editor of the first 2 vols. of <em>L'Horticulteur practique; revue de l'horticulture française
et étrangère</em> ... Paris (1857-1858).

PAGE: 107
HEADING: GALLÉ

Gallardo, Ángel (1867-1934), Argentinean botanist, naturalist and diplomat, born 19 Nov
1867 in Buenos Aires, civil engineering degree 1894 Faculty of Physical Sciences and
Mathematics, visited Europe several times and took courses at the Sorbonne (Paris), Dr.
Sci. Nat. 1902 Buenos Aires, dir., Natural History Museum 1911-1916, President, Con-
sejo Nacional de Educación, 1916-x, ambassador to Rome until 1921, Minister of External
Affairs and Culture 1922-1928, rector, Univ. of Buenos Aires 1932-1934, received many
honors from Argentinean and foreign societies, Dr. h.c., Univ. of Padua, died 13 Mai 1934
in Buenos Aires. (<em>Gallardo</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 25; CSP 15: 190; Hirsch p. 93; Kew 2: 367;
Rehder 5(index): 306; Tucker 1: 267, 3: 114.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Auctt., 1942. Anales Soc. Ci. Argent. 133: 3-184. (bibl. [p. 169-184], portr.) [nine
	articles by diverse authors]
Barabino, E., 1922. Anales Soc. Ci. Argent. 93: 214-220. (bibl.)
Birbabén, M., 1970. Revista Mus. Argent. Ci. Nat., "Bernardino Rivadavia" Inst. Nac. In-
	vest. Ci. Nat. Bot. 3(5-12): [all papers of this issue in homage to Ángel Gallardo]
Bruch, C., 1934. Rev. Soc. Entomol. Argent. 6: 235-242. (bibl. [entomol.], portr.)
Carpenter, M.M., 1953. Amer. Midl. Naturalist 50: 288.
Doello-Jurado, M., 1936. Anal. Mus. Nac. Hist. Bern. Rivad. 38: ix-xliv. (portr.)

Gallé, László [Ladislaus] (1908-1980), Hungarian lichenologist, born 15 Feb 1908 in Zenta,
Austro-Hungarian Empire (now Senta, Serbia), studied at Univ. of Belgrade and Academy of
Sciences, Univ. of Szeged, Hungary 1925-1931, teaching dipl. 1930, teaching asst., teacher
and administrator (asst. principal, principal and superintendent) at various high schools, col-
laborator in botany, Móra Ferenc Museum 1963, died 4 Mar 1980 in Szeged. (<em>Gallé</em>).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Not to be confused with his son László Gallé (1942-x), who studies ants and ecol-
ogy.

HEADING: GALLESIO

Verseghy, K., 1963. Feddes Repert. Spec. Nov. Regni Veg. 68: 112-113.
Verseghy, K., 1980. Bot. Közlem. 67: 167-171. (bibl., portr.)

Gallesio, Giorgio [Georges] (Conte) (1772-1839), Italian geneticist, pomologist, magis-
trate, deputy and diplomat, born 23 Mai 1772 in Finalborgo (now Finale Ligure) on the
Gulf of Genoa (then Republic of Genoa), law degree 1793 Univ. of Pavia, "Consiglio Gen-
erale", Dept. of Montenotte 1808, elected deputy from Dept. of Montenotte 1809, died 29
Nov 1839 in Florence. (<em>Gallesio</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown. – Archivio Gallesio-Piuma, Genoa; additional (exten-
sive) mss. materials at Dumbarton Oaks Research Library and Collection (Washington,
D.C., U.S.A.).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 216; Backer p. 228; Blunt p. 222, ed. 2: 260; BM

451 (index); Jackson p. 128; Kew 2: 367; Langman p. 299; MW p. 134; NI 2: 65; NI suppl.
p. 34; Portr. 3: 462; Pritzel ed. 2: 3179; Rehder 5(index): 307; Saccardo 1: 77; TL-2/4: 1171
(index); Tucker 1: 268.

36.000. <em>Theorie der vegetabilischen Reprodukzion</em> [sic], oder: Untersuchungen über die
Natur und die Ursachen der Abarten und Missgebilde ... Wien (F. Stöckholzer) 1814. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 1814, p. [1]-140. <em>Copies</em>: British Library (n.v.), UC-Berkeley. <em>Microfilm</em>: [London]
	(British Library), 1991, 1 reel (179 fr., 35 mm). <em>Copy</em>: British Library (n.v.).

36.001. <em>Pomona italiana</em>, ossia trattato degli alberi fruttiferi ... Pisa (Presso Nicollò
Capurro) 1817-1839. Fol. 

<em>Publ</em>.: Issued originally in 41 fascs. ... <em>314 pl</em>. (part col.; i.e. 160 hand-colored aquatints,
	154 uncol.). <em>Copies</em>: BM (2 vols.), HH (2 vols. in 4) (n.v.), K (6 vols.) (n.v.), NYPL (5
	vols.) (n.v.), USDA (1 vol. text, 1 vol. <em>pl</em>.).
<em>Illus</em>.: Domenico del Pino, Antonio Serantoni (1780-1837), Bozzolini, Isabella and many
	others.
<em>Note</em>: (1) The text, with the exception of the introduction, is unpaginated and the plates are
	unnumbered. There are two copies of each plate, one colored and one uncolored, except
	in 6 instances in which there is no uncolored copy. In all there are 160 colored plates
	(2 double) and 154 uncolored plates (2 double). Two further livraisons to contain fron-
	tispieces, tables, etc. based on the mss. left by Gallesio, were promised, but they never
	appeared. Some of the plates are printed on two sheets, which in some copies are joined.
	(2) The BM copy is bound in two volumes; Vol. 1 dated 1817 (but p. viii signed 2 Sep
	1839!) and Vol. 2 dated 1839. (3) A copy of the entire work was offered for sale in 2005
	for $US 286,700.
<em>Electronic version</em>: (1) NYPL Digital Gallery (col. lith. only?). (2) Pomona Italiana di
	Giorgio Gallesio, Ist. Marsano, Genova (2004).

36.002. <em>Pomona italiana</em>, parte scientifica, fascicolo primo, contenente il <em>trattato</em> del <em>fico</em> ...
Pisa (Presso Nicollò Capurro) 1820. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 1820, p. [i]-xiii, [1]-123, schema (fold.). <em>Copies</em>: BM (n.v.), K, UC-Berkeley
	(n.v.).

*Galløe, Olaf (1881-1965), Danish lichenologist, born 22 Jun 1881 in Copenhagen, Mag.
scient. 1907 and Dr. phil. 1913 Univ. of Copenhagen, grammar school teacher, "Øster
Borgerdydskole", Copenhagen, 1909-1948, died 24 Dec 1965 in Lyngby nr. Copenhagen.
(<em>Galløe</em>).

<em>Note</em>: There is a second state of this work (seen in US-Stevenson), which was issued in the
	journal. It differs from the thesis by a cover citing Dansk Botanisk Arkiv 1(3) with the
	back cover stating ready for printing 20 Aug 1913. Other differences are: (a) all the pages
	are numbered with roman numerals; (b) the pref. ("Forord") is changed to a postscript
	("Efterskrift") and moved to p. 116; (c) the beginning of the bibliography is moved to p.
	117-119; and (d) the Theses (p. [119]) are suppressed.
<em>Ref</em>.: Lind, L., Bot. Centralbl. 125(7): 169-170. 17 Feb 1914 (rev.).

*Gamble, James Sykes (1847-1925), British forester and botanist, born 2 Jul 1847 in Lon-
don, educated at the Royal Naval School, New Cross, B.A. 1869 Oxford, studied at the
École Nationale des Eaux et Forêts, Nancy, France, entered the Indian Forest Dept. 1871,
in Burma (now Myanmar) and other places 1872-1877, posted to Madras Presidency 1882,
transfered to Dehra Dun in 1890 where he was dir., Imperial Forest School until retirement
in 1895, F.L.S., F.R.S. 1899, died 16 Oct 1925 in East Liss (Hants). (<em>Gamble</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: K (orig.), duplicates B, BM, CAL, DD, E, G, H (Musc.), L, MH,
OXF, US.

HEADING: GAMBLE

(2) <em>Fl. Madras</em> ... (see TL-2/1, nr. 1936), add:
<em>Ed. 2</em> [reprinted]: [1957 &amp; 1967] ... Calcutta (Botanical Survey of India) ... 3 vols. (but

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) Pref. <em>in</em> Upendranatha N. Kanjilal (1859-1928), <em>Forest flora of the
school circle, N.-W.P.</em> ... 1901.
(2) Collaborated with Sir G. King, <em>Mat. fl. Malay. Penins.</em> (King) ... 26 parts, 1889-1936
(TL-2/2, nr. 3655, emend.), being co-author of fascicle nos. 14-21 and sole author of nos.
22-25. <em>Note</em>: (a) The title is incorrect in TL-2/2, nr. 3655. It should be <em>Materials for a flora
of the Malayan Peninsula</em> and abbreviated <em>Mat. fl. Malay. Penins.</em> (King). Confusion is
compounded by the running head of all pages: "Flora of the Malayan Peninsula". (b) The
title is the same and easily confused with that of a contemporary work by Henry Nicholas
Ridley (1855-1956), abbreviated <em>Mat. fl. Malay Penins.</em> [the 3rd word not an abbreviation !]
(Ridley), see TL-2/4, nr. 9208. (c) <em>Flora of the Malayan Peninsula</em> ... Delhi (Cosmo) ...
1986 ... is a confusingly titled reprint of only nos. 16-17 of King &amp; Gamble's work (the
final part of the Rubiaceae to the Pedalinaceae). <em>Copy</em>: MO.

36.007. The <em>Bambuseae</em> of <em>British India</em> ... Calcutta (Printed at the Bengal Secretariat
Press) [1894-]1896. Fol. 

<em>Illus</em>.: Choudhury, D.N.; Dass, G.C.; Dass, K.P.; Hormusji, Mr.; Idrees, Mahomed (fl.
	1888-1890); Mila, S.A.D.; Molla, A.D.; and Singh, A.L.
<em>Publ</em>.: [1894-]1896 (p. 128 dated 16 Oct 1894, p. xvii dated 8 Aug 1895, p. 3 index to
	scientific names dated 7 Mar 1896), cover-t.p. (of journal and another t.p. for the work),
	p. [i-ii], [iii]-[iv], errata, [i]-xvii [=introd.], [1]-128, h.t., [129]-133 [=appendix], [1]-3
	[=index to scientific names], [1]-4 [=index to vernacular names], [i, advert], <em>pl. 1-119
	</em>(lith.). <em>Copies</em>: G, K (n.v.), NY (n.v.), MO, US, WU. <em>Microfilm</em>: Wakefield, Yorkshire,
	United Kingdom (EP Group of Companies, Microform Division), [19–], 1 reel (35 mm).
	<em>Copy</em>: (n.v.). – Issued as Ann. Roy. Bot. Gard. Calcutta 7: 1-133, <em>pl</em>. <em>1-119</em>. 1896.
<em>Ref</em>.: Engler, A., Bot. Jahrb. Syst. 26(Lit.) 51-52. 31 Jan 1899 (brief notice).
<em>Reprint</em> (1) [1896 ed.]: 1966 ... Yorkshire, England (Micro Methods)/New York (Johnson
	Reprint Corp.), xvii, 133, 3, 4, p., <em>pl. 1-119.</em> 1966. <em>Copy</em>: MO (n.v.).
<em>Reprint</em> (2) [1896 ed.]: 1978, ... Dehra Dun (Bishen Singh), t.p., facsimile t.p., t.p., [er-
	rata], p. [i]-xvii, [h.t.?], [1]-133, [[1]-3], [[1]-4], [advert.], <em>pl. 1-119</em> (uncol. lith). Qu.
	<em>Copies</em>: LC (n.v.), US. <em>Note</em>: a slight reduction in size.
<em>Note</em>: TL-2/1: 908 (sub "Composite Works") suggested that Gamble co-authored the treat-
	ment of the Bambuseæ in J.D. Hooker, <em>Fl. Brit. India</em>, vol. 7: 375-420 [late Apr-early Dec]
	1896. In fact, Hooker, who wrote the Gramineae for the flora, stated (p. 375) that the treat-
	ment of the bamboos was "drawn up, almost verbatim, from Mr. Gamble's 'Bambuseæ of
	British India,' ..." and that he [Hooker] had a copy in advance of its publication in the jour-
	nal. Hooker could well have gotten a copy of the text after 16 Oct 1894 (without t.p. or in-
	dices). The printer's dates indicate the main text was printed first (p. [1]-128. 16 Oct 1894),
	the introd. was printed 8 Aug 1895 and, finally, the indices were printed 7 Mar 1896.

Gammie, George Alexander (1839-1935), Scottish agriculturalist, born 12 Nov 1839 in
Kingcausie (Kincardine), apprenticed as a gardener, sent to Sikkim in 1865 to manage cin-
chona plantations and quinine extraction, F.L.S., retired in 1897. (<em>Gammie</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: A, B, CAL, DD, G, H (Musc.), K, L, LE, MICH, P (Pter.), U, US.

Gams, Helmut (1893-1976), Austrian botanist and bryologist, born 23 [25?] Sep 1893 in
Brünn (Brno) (now Czech Republic) to a Swiss family that moved to Zurich 1899, Dr. phil.
1918 Univ. of Zurich, founded a private biol. station in Wasserburg (Germany), began work
with G. Hegi in Munich 1920, "privat-docent" 1928, prof. 1929 and dir. 1959-1964, Institut
et Jardin Botaniques, Univ. of Innsbruck, where he also founded (1950) the alpine research
station in Obergurgl, died 13 Feb 1976 in Innsbruck. (<em>Gams</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: IB, Z, and duplicates at M.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 217; Backer p. 650; Barnhart 2: 27; BFM p. 285
(index); Biol.-Dokum. 6: 76.744-76.785; BL 2: 405, 588, 657; Bossert p. 139; Frahm&amp;E.
p. 124-125 (bibl., portr.); Futak-Domin p. 216; GR p. 449; Hirsch p. 93; Hortus 3: 1193; IH
2: 215; Kew 2: 370; Kleppa p. 322 (index); LS suppl. 9245-9248; MW p. 134; Portr. 1: 62
(index), 3: 463; Roon p. 42; Sarjeant Suppl. 2: 640; SBC p. 120; Strid p. 124, ed. 2: 172;
TL-2/2, 2/6, Suppl. 6 (indices); Tucker 3: 114; Zander ed. 11: 753-754, ed. 17: 949.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Intl. address book botanists: 18. 1931; Alpengart. 19(2): 3. 1976. (portr.);
	Taxon 25: 280. 1976.
Charpin, A. &amp; J. Timbal, 2007. Acta Bot. Gallica 154: 450. (as "Helmuth")
Franz, H., 1978. Ver. Zool.-Bot. Ges. Österreich 116/117: 5-6.
Fuchs, H.P., 1991. Bull. Murith. Soc. Valais. Sci. Nat. 109: 146.
Gärtner, G., 1976. Nat. Land (Salzburg) 62: 83-84.
Hertel, H. &amp; A. Schreiber, 1988. Mitt. Bot. Staatssamml. München 26: 218.
Jones, G.N., 1966. An annotated bibl. Mexican ferns: 220.
Lauscher, F., 1976. Wett. Leb. 28: 178-179.
Pitschmann, H., 1977. Ber. Naturwiss.-Med. Vereins Innsbruck 64: 207-222. (portr.) (n.v.)
Pitschmann, H., 1977. Rev. Bryol. Lichénol. 43: 113-115. (bryol. &amp; lichenol. bibl., portr.)
Pitschmann, H., 1980. Ber. Deutsch. Bot. Ges. 93(3): 673-675. (portr.)

Steiner, M., 1977. Decheniana 130: 16-22. (portr.)

1 col.), 1 schema (fold.). 1963.

<sm>OUTSIDE OUR PERIOD</sm>: Gams &amp; Paul Ozenda, <em>Alpenblumen</em>, farbige Wunder ... 1963, 2
vols.; Ed. 5 ... 1967; Dutch transl., <em>Alpenbloemen in kleuren</em> ... 1963; French transl., <em>Fleurs
des Alpes</em> ... 1966, 2 vols.; Swedish transl., <em>Alpina blommor</em> ... 1966.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) One of many collaborators with G. Hegi, <em>Ill. Fl. Mitt.-Eur.</em> ...
[1906-1931], 7 vols. (TL-2/2, nr. 2571).
(2) Co-author with G.E. Du Rietz, <em>Bestandstreue Pflanzengesellschaften</em> ... 1924 (TL-2/
Suppl. 6, nr. 32.100).

PAGE: 115
HEADING: GAMS

(3) Co-author with Friedrich Morton, <em>Höhlenpflanzen</em>, Wien (Eduard Hölzel), 1925. In
series, Speläologische Monographie, Bd. 5
(4) Contributed <em>Schistostega osmundacea</em> (i.e. maps 9-10) to E. Hannig &amp; H. Winkler,
<em>Pflanzenareale</em> ... Zweite Reihe, Heft 1 ... 1928 (TL-2/7: nr. 17.993).
(5) One of many collaborators with F. Verdoorn:
(a) <em>Man. bryol.</em> ... 1932 (TL-2/6, nr. 16.031).
(b) <em>Man. pteridol.</em> ... 1938 (TL-2/6, nr. 16.041).

<em>Ref</em>.: Schmid, R., Taxon 44(3): 473-474. Aug 1995 (rev., "... a beautiful little work").

*Gandoger, [Jean] Michel [Michael, Michaële, Michaeli, Michale] (Abbé) (1850-1926),
French botanist, born 10 Mai 1850 in Arnas (Rhône), began collecting plants at age 15,
joined the Société Botanique de France at age 21, became a priest at age 26, began his <em>Flora
Europae</em> (which eventually included more than 100,000 formae) at age 32, amassed an
enormous herb. through collecting and purchase, ceased traveling in 1921 after becoming
ill, died 4 Oct 1926 in Lyon. (<em>Gand</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: LY (80,000, orig.), duplicates in many herbaria (see IH 2: 216,
and add PAL, USPIY). N.B.: The citations of localities on labels of duplicates distributed
by Gandoger are not always trustworthy. He issued various sets of exsiccatae, e.g. <em>Flora
algeriensis exsiccata, Flora gallia exsiccata, Plantae maroccanae, Flora hispanica exsic</em>-

PAGE: 118
HEADING: GANDOGER

<em>cata, Flora Africae bor</em>. – Some corr. in GH (Archives), SIA (Record Unit 221, Divison of
Plants) and Univ. of Cape Town (Bolus papers).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 217; Barnhart 2: 27; Biol.-Dokum. 6: 76.801-76.814;
BL 1: 45, 297, 2: 657; BM 2: 637, 6: 355; Bossert p. 139; CSP 7: 734, 9: 958, 12: 260, 15:
200-201; DBF 15: 334 (as "Michel", d. "1927"); DTS 1: 81-82 "Dieser Autor wird im
vorliegenden Werke nicht mehr weiter berücksichtigt"); Ewan Pap. p. 76; FNA ser. 2(10):
209; Futak-Domin p. 216; GR p. 321; Herder p. 451 index); Hist. Coll. BMNH p. 150 (as
"Michael"); Hortus 3: 1193; IF p. 698; IF suppl. 2: 36, 3: 209, 4: 354; IH 2: 215; Jackson p.
549 (index); Kelly p. 87-88; Kew 2: 371; Kew List p. 25; Langman p. 302; LS 9589-9591;
Morren ed. 10: 59; MW p. 134; NAF 28B2): 331, ser. 22): 157; NW p. 46 (index); Portr.
3: 463; Rehder 5index): 308; Saccardo 1: 77; Strid p. 125, ed. 2: 172-173; TL-1: 163-164,
193 ("one of the greatest splitters ever"); TL-2/1: 909-911, indices Suppl. 2, 4; Tucker 1:
268, 3: 114-115; Urban-Berl. p. 264, 348; Wagenitz p. 61; Zander ed. 17: 949.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., A catalog of the Edward L. Greene collection: 131. 1986.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: Prix Gandoger, Société Botanique de la France.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: (1) <em>Fl. Eur.</em> ... 27 vols. (TL-2/1, nr. 1942) is listed in the Appendix VI "Opera
Utique Oppressa" of the 2006 Vienna <em>Code</em>. Species names appearing in this work are not
to be accepted as validly published. This Appendix was established by action of the Tokyo
Congr. (1993) and first appeared in the 1994 Tokyo <em>Code</em>.

	1819G5"). <em>Copy</em>: (n.v.).

*Garcke, [Christian] August [Friedrich] (1819-1904), German botanist, born 25 Aug 1819
in Bräunrode nr. Mansfeld (Saxony), studied theology in Halle 1840-1844 and pupil of
D.F.L. von Schlechtendal also at Halle, after 1854 curator, "dozent" and ultimately prof. of
botany at Berlin, died 10 Jan 1904 in Berlin. (<em>Garcke</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Germany and Switzerland: B (orig.); his <em>Flora halensis</em> at HAL.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: ADB 6: 71; AG 5(2): 502, 12(2): 581; APN p. 219; Barn-
hart 2: 29; BM 2: 638-639, 6: 356; BN p. 174; Bossert p. 139; CSP 2: 766-767, 6: 664, 7:
734, 9: 960, 15: 206; Frodin ed. 2: 586; GR p. 80; Herder p. 452 (index); Hortus 3: 1193
(as "Friedrich, August"); IH 2: 217 (as "Friedrich August"); Jackson p. 304-305 (index)
(as "Garcke, F.A."); KR p. 236; Langman p. 307; LS 9598-9603, 33.546; MW p. 236; NDB
6: 71 (d. 25 Oct"); Nordstedt p. 15; Portr. 3: 465; PR ed. 2: 3191-3192, 10.564; Rehder 5(in-
dex): 309 (as "Friedrich August"); SO p. 23 (index); TL-1: 518 (index); TL-2/1: 912-914,
indices 2/2 (in part leads to 2/1!), 2/3, 2/4, 2/5, 2/6, Suppl. 1, 4, 6; Tucker 1: 269; Urban-
Berl. p. 348; Zander ed. 10: 603; Zep.-Tim. p. 50-51.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Ascherson, P., 1860. Fl. Prov. Brandenburg 1: 5.
Barthel, K.-J. &amp; J. Pusch, 2005. Die Botaniker des Kyffhäusergebietes: 112-114. (handwr.,
	portr.) (b. "25 Oct")
Dörfler, I., 1896. Botaniker-Adressbuch: 15; 1902. Id., ed. 2: 16.
[Engelmann, W.], 1891. Botanisches Adressbuch: [1].
Hoffmann, P. et al., 1965. Wiss. Z. Humboldt-Univ. Berlin, Mat.-Nat. R. 14: 807.
Niedenzu, F., 1908. <em>In</em>, A. Garcke, Ill. Fl. Deutschland, ed. 20: iii-iv. (portr.)
Rottenbach, H., 1904. Ber. Deutsch. Bot. Ges. 22: (44)-(48). (bibl.)
Stafleu, F.A., 1970. <em>In</em>, P. Smit &amp; R.J.Ch.V. ter Laage (eds.), Regnum Veg. 71: 323-324.
	(Miguel-Schlechtendal corr.)
Tschirch, A., 1904. Ber. Pharm. Ges. 14(2): 52-66. (portr.)

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) Contributed to W.C.H. Peters, <em>Naturw. Reise Mossambique</em> ...
[1861-]1862-1864 (TL-2/4, nr. 7759).
(2) Co-author with J.F. Klotzsch, <em>Bot. Ergebn. Reise Waldemar</em> ... 1862 (TL-2/2, nr. 3746).
(3) Collaborator with G. Schweinfurth, <em>Beitr. Fl. Aethiop.</em> ... 1867 (TL-2/5, nr. 11.459).
(4) Nachtr. (Jul 1872) for P. Rohrbach, <em>Morph. Silene</em> ... 1869 (TL-2/4, nr. 9458).
(5) Provided identifications for G. Rohlfs, <em>Quer d. Afrika</em> ... 1874-1875 (TL-2/4, nr. 9454).
(6) Edited O.C. Berg, <em>Pharmakognosie des Pflanzen- und Thierreichs</em> ... ed. 5, 1879.

HEADING: GARDNER

(7) Co-author with F. Buchenau of Malvaceae (Part 3: 198-200. 1881, 8: 200. 1889) and

..., see TL-2/4: 1008 and Suppl. 3, nr. 23.498.
(8) One of numerous authors with P. Ascherson, <em>Prop. Lois nom. bot.</em> ... [1892] (TL-2/
Suppl. 1, nr. 19.614).
(9) One of numerous authors with A. Engler, <em>Nomenclaturregeln Berlin</em> ... 1897) (TL-2/
Suppl. 6, nr. 33.035).

*Gardner, Nathaniel Lyon (1864-1937), American phycologist, born 26 Feb 1864 in
Keokuk, Iowa, in business in Tacoma, Washington to 1893, school teacher, Coupeville (Is-
land Co.), Washington, B.Sc. 1900 Univ. of Washington at Seattle, M.Sc. 1903 and Ph.D.
1905 Univ. of Calif. at Berkeley (student of W.A. Setchell), Head of Biology Dept., Los
Angeles Polytechnic High School 1906-1913, Acting Asst. Prof. 1909-1910, Asst. Prof.
1913-1923, Assoc. Prof. 1923-1934 and Curator of the Herb. 1920-1934, all Univ. of Calif.
at Berkeley, married in 1915 Edith Jordan, daughter of David Starr Jordan (1851-1931), ich-
thyologist and univ. administrator, died 15 Aug 1937 in Berkeley, Calif. (<em>N.L. Gardner</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: UC (orig.), duplicates (see IH 2: 217, and add M); for series see
Sayre (1975).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Amer. Men Sci. ed. 5: 398; Andrews p. 266; APN p. 219;
Barnhart 2: 30; Bossert p. 140; Ewan Pap. p. 76; IH 1 (ed. 6): 358, 2: 217; Kelly p. 88; Len-
ley p. 178; LS 9610; LS suppl. 9342; MW p. 135, suppl. p. 74; NW p. 46 (index); Rhodora,
index p. 329; TL-2/1: 916, 2/5: 1030 (index).

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Intl. address book botanists: 471. 1931; Univ. of Calif.: In memoriam,
	1937: 11-13. 1937; Science, ser. 2, 86: 192. 1937.
Constance, L., 1978. Botany at Berkeley: passim. (portrs., figs. 33, 34)
Drouet, F., 1943. Amer. Midland Naturalist 30: 529-532. [obit. of Setchell notes collabora-
	tion with Gardner]
Ewan, J., 1955. A century of progress in the natural sciences: 49.
Ewan, J. (ed.), 1969. Short hist. bot. U.S.: 76.
Franks, J.W., 1973. Manchester Mus. Publ., new ser., no. NS.1.73: 3, 14.
Hedge, I.C. &amp; J.M. Lamond (eds.), 1970. Index collectors Edinburgh Herb.: 82.
Hertel, H. &amp; A. Schreiber, 1988. Mitt. Bot. Staatssamml. München 26: 199.
Hultén, E., 1940. Bot. Not. 1940: 324.

Gareiso, Joseph (Abbé) (1805-1885), French cleric and botanist, born 31 Mar 1805 in
Pont-Saint-Esprit (Gard), studied in Avignon and Nîmes, ordained as a priest 1828, served
in different functions and parishes in Dépt. Gard, Prof. of Canon Law 1840-1853 and Supe-
rior 1853-1877 of the Grand séminaire, Nîmes, "Vicaire général" of Nîmes diocese 1877,
died 5 Feb 1885 in Nîmes. (<em>Gareiso</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 30; BL 2: p. 149; BM 2: 640; DBF 15: 419;
Rehder 5(index): 310.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Charpin, A. &amp; G.G. Aymonin, 2003. J. Bot. Soc. Bot. France 21: 70.
Lombard-Dumas, A., 1900. La botanique dans le Gard: 62-63.

36.076. <em>Synopsis analytique</em> de la <em>flore</em> de <em>Gard</em>; ou, Méthode facile pour arriver au nom de tou-
tes les plantes vasculaires de ce département ... Nîmes (Chez Isidore Waton) 1847. 18-mo. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 1847, p. [i]-xxxiv, [errata], [1]-348. <em>Copies</em>: BM (n.v.), NY.
<em>Note</em>: Author as "M. l'Abbé J.G." on cover-t.p.

Garjeanne, Anton Johan Marie (1875-1965), Dutch botanist (bryologist and taxonomist),
born 22 Nov 1875 in Delft, Ph.D. 1901 Erlangen, Germany, died 29 Jun 1965 in Groes-
beeck. (<em>Garjeanne</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Netherlands: NBV.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 30; BL 2: 432, 657 (index, "b. 1877"); Bossert
p. 140; IH 2: 217; Portr. 3: 466; SBC p. 120 (b. "1899"); TL-2/6: 897 (index).

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Intl. address book botanists: 262. 1931.
Dörfler, I., 1902. Botaniker-Adressbuch, ed. 2: 142; 1909. Id., ed. 3: 201.
Heimans, J., 1965. Levende Natuur 68: 217-218.

36.080. <em>Handboek</em> voor de <em>Nederlandsche flora</em> ... Meppel (H. Ten Brink) 1907. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 1907, cover-t.p., p. [i-ii], [1]-552. <em>Copy</em>: MO.

*Garovaglio, Santo [Sancto, Sanctus] (1805-1882), Italian cryptogamic botanist, born 28
Jan 1805 in Como, enrolled, Faculty of Medicine, Univ. of Pavia 1821, asst. in botany to G.
Moretti 1833 and prof. of natural history 1839-1852, both Univ. of Pavia, doctorate 1840
Vienna, full prof. of botany from 1852 (succeeding Moretti), dir. of Botanic Garden 1853-
1882, and founder of the "Laboratorio Crittogamico" 1871, all in Pavia, died 20 [18?] Mar
1882 in Pavia. (<em>Garov</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: PAV (orig.; 30,000), duplicates GJO, K, M, RO. – <em>Exsiccatae</em>: see
TL-2/1: 916.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 219; Barnhart 2: 31; BM 2: 641, 6: 357; BN p. 174;
Bossert p. 140; CSP 7: 736-737, 9: 963-964, 12: 261; DBI 52: 379-380 (d. "18 Mar"); DTS 1:
82-83, 5: x1viii; Ewan Pap. p. 76; GR p. 517; GR cat. p. 63; Hawksworth p. 182; Herder p. 452
(index); Hist. Coll. BMNH p. 150; IH 2: 217; Jackson p. 549 (index); Kew 2: 379; Kew List p.
25; LS 9621-9696, 33.569; Morren ed. 2: 27; NAF ser. 2(13): 105; ÖBL 1: 403; Portr. 3: 466;
PR ed 1: 3505-3508, ed. 2: 3201-3212, 10.565; Rehder 5(index): 310; Saccardo 1: 78, 2: 52;
SBC p. 120; TL-1: 164; TL-2/1: 916-918; Tucker 1: 270, 3: 115; Urban-Berl. p. 287, 299.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., J. Bot. 21: 381. 1883.
Ardissone, F., 1883. Rendiconti Ist. Lombardo Sci., ser. 2, 15(20): 696-710. (bibl.)
Candolle, A.L., 1880. Phytographie: 414.
Cattaneo, A. et al., 1882. Arch. Lab. Crittog. Univ. Pavia 4: xii-li. (bibl. 57 nos.)
Charpin, A. &amp; J. Timbal, 2007. Acta Bot. Gallica 154: 450.
Hertel, H. &amp; A. Schreiber, 1988. Mitt. Bot. Staatssamml. München 26: 145, 157.
Kanitz, A., 1882. Magyar Növényt. Lapok 6: 27-31. (bibl.)
Sayre, G., 1967. Mem. New York Bot. Gard. 19: 127; 1975. Id. 19: 325.
Sordelli, F., 1882. Atti Soc. Ital. Sci. Nat. 25: 119-134. (bibl. 77 nos.)
Wittrock, V.B., 1903. Acta Horti Berg. 3(2): 162; 1905. Id. 3(3): 178, <em>pl. 136.</em>

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: (additional) <em>Garovaglia</em> Endl. (1836, as "<em>Carovaglia</em>"); <em>Garovaglina</em> Trevisan
1880.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: The following are now available in microform:
(1) <em>Enum. musc. Austria inf.</em> ... Jan-Mar 1840 (TL-2/1, nr. 1952), i.e. trade edition of his thesis:
<em>Microfiche</em>: Westport, Conn. (Meckler/Chadwyck-Healey Publishing), [1987?], 1 micro-
	fiche, (Plant taxonomic lit. microfiche coll., "1872C4-1872G4"). <em>Copy</em>: HH (n.v.).

*Garsault, François Alexandre [Pierre] de (1691/1693-1778), French writer, botanical
artist and naturalist with interests in poisonous plants, also a leading French horse-breeder,
entered royal administration and trained horses for the military as "Capitaine des Haras",
Académie des sciences. (<em>Garsault</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 220; Baillon 2: 674 (d. "vers 1776"); BM 2: 642;
DA 1967; DBF 15: 578-579 (b. "1693"); Hortus 3: 1193; HU 2(2): nr. 585; IF suppl. 4: 354;
Langman p. 308-309; MW p. 135; NI 2: 65; Plesch p. 234; PR ed. 1: 3509, ed. 2: 3216; Reh-
der 5(index): 310; Sotheby 1: 228; TL-1: 165; TL-2/1: 918-919: Tucker 1: 270, 3: 116.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Brunet, J.-Ch., 1861 [1966 reprint]. Manuel du libraire et de l'amateur de livres
	2: 1495-1496.
Davy de Virville, A., 1954. Hist. bot. France: 74, 103.
Engelmann, W., 1846. Biblioth. hist. nat.: 161, 168.
Gibson, J.A. &amp; E.C. Nelson, 2001. Cumulative index Archives Nat. Hist.: 58.
Thellung, Alb., 1908. Bull. Herb. Boissier, sér. 2, 8: 713-714, 778-793, 901-913. (see also
	J. Bot. 47: 322. 1909) ["Nomenclator Garsaultianus"]
Welter-Schultes, F.W. et al., 2008. Archives Nat. Hist. 35: 118-127. (b. 1891)

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: Garsault contributed illus. to a number of other works on natural his-
tory, incl.:
(1) Labeyrie &amp; Jean Goulin, <em>Dictionnaire raisonné universel</em> de <em>matière médicale</em> ... Paris
(F. Didot) ... 1773.
(2) A. von Störck, <em>Expériences</em> et <em>observations</em> sur l'usage interne de la <em>pomme épineuse</em> ...
1763, which is a transl. of <em>Libell. Stramonium</em> ... 1762 (TL-2/6, nr. 13.158).
In addition, after his death, his illus. were reused in, a.o.:
(3) <em>Dictionnaire</em> des <em>plantes usuelles</em>, des arbres et arbustes, des animaux qui servent d'ali-
mens, de médicamens ou d'amusement à l'homme, et les minéraux qui sont d'usage en méde-
cine; ouvrage mis à la portée de tout le monde; orné d'environ huit-cents planches ... Par une
société de gens de lettres, naturalistes et médecins ... Paris (Lamy) An II [1793-1794], 8 vols.
(4) <em>Nouveau dictionnaire</em> d'<em>histoire naturelle</em> appliquée aux arts, principalement à l'agricul-
ture et à l'économie rurale et domestique: par une société de naturalistes et d'agriculteurs:
avec des figures tirées des trois règnes de la nature ... Paris (Deterville) 1803-1804, 24 vols.

PAGE: 132
HEADING: GASILIEN

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Three Garsault titles in TL-2/1 (nrs. 1959-1961), are listed in the Appendix V "Opera
Utique Oppressa" of the 2006 Vienna <em>Code</em>. Names appearing in these works in the ranks
specified at the end of each listing are not to be accepted as validly published. This list was
first established by action of the Tokyo Congr. (1993) and first appeared in the 1994 Tokyo
<em>Code</em>.
(1) Les <em>figures</em> de <em>plantes</em> et <em>animaux</em> d'<em>usage</em> en <em>médecine</em>, décrit[s, although mis-corrected
to décrit[es] in TL-2/1] dans la matière médicale de Mr. Geoffroy (i.e. <em>Fig. pl. méd.</em>) ...
1764, 5 vols. (TL-2/1, nr. 1959). [Species and infraspecific taxa]. The original entry in TL-
2/1 can be amended as follows: <em>Copies</em>: NY, NYPL (n.v.), P (n.v.), WIS (n.v.).
(2) <em>Explication abrégée</em> de <em>sept cent</em>["s"] <em>dix-neuf plantes</em> (i.e. <em>Expl. abr. pl.</em>) ... 1765
(TL-2/1, nr. 1960). [Species and infraspecific taxa].
(3) <em>Description</em>, <em>vertus</em> et usages de sept cent["s"] dix-neuf <em>plantes</em>, tant étrangères que de
nos climats (i.e. <em>Descr., vertus pl.</em> ... [1764]-1767, 5 vols. (TL-2/1, nr. 1961). [Genera, spe-
cies and infraspecific taxa.]. The original entry in TL-2/1 can be amended as follows:
<em>Copies</em>: G, HH-Dumbarton Oaks, P (n.v.), USDA (n.v.). <em>Microfiche</em>: Zug, Switzerland
	(IDC), 1985, 22 microfiches. <em>Copy</em>: MO (n.v.).
<em>Note</em> (3): (a) The G copy was stated to have 728 <em>pl</em>. However, most other copies have 729
	<em>pl</em>. (as does <em>Fig. pl. méd.</em>). Plates 1-643 depict plants, the remaining ones are zoological.
	(b) In 2005, Antiquariaat Junk offered for sale the 1767 reissue of this 5 vol. work and
	the 1 vol. <em>Expl. abr. pl.</em> ... for US$5600 (then €4500).

Gasilien (Frère) (1851-1907), French lichenologist and bryologist, who was born Géraud
Parrique, under which name he was treated; see TL-2/4: 77-78.

*Gasparrini, Guglielmo (1804-1866), Italian botanist, born 13 [14?] Jun 1804 in Castel-
grande (Basilicata), graduated 1823 in veterinary medicine, became dir. of botanic garden
Boccadifalco in Palermo, returned to teach botany at the Naples veterinary school 1842,
appointed prof. of botany, Naples Univ. 1844, prof. and dir. of the Pavia Botanic Garden
1857-1861, returned again to Naples as dir. of its Botanic Garden from 1861 until his death,
Accademia nazionale delle scienze 1862, died 28 Jun 1866. (<em>Gasp</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: PAV (orig.; 14,500), duplicates BM, BP, CGE, FI, K, P, PC, W.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 3: 106; APN p. 220; Backer p. 229, 651; Baillon 2:
675; Barnhart 2: 32; BM 2: 643; Bossert p. 140; Cron. p. xxii; CSP 2: 778-779, 6: 665, 7:
741, 9: 968, 12: 262, 15: 222; Ewan Pap. p. 77; Herder p. 452 (index); Hist. Coll. BMNH
p. 150; Hortus 3: 1193 (as "Gulielmo"); IF p. 698; IF suppl. 4: 354; IH 2: 218; Jackson
p. 549 (index); Kew 2: 380-381; Kew List p. 25 (as "Guilielmo"); Langman p. 309; LS
9705-9729; MW p. 135; NI 3514-3522; Portr. 1: 62 (index), 3: 467; PR ed. 1: 3514-3522,
ed. 2: 3219-3228; Rehder 5(index): 311; RS p. 84; Saccardo 1: 78, 2: 52; TL-2/1: 919-920,
2/4: 1171 (index); Tucker 1: 270; Zander ed. 17: 949.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Flora 50: 15, 379-380. 1867; Bot. Zeitung (Berlin) 25: 16. 1867; Gard.

Gassner, [Johann] Gustav (1881-1955), German botanist esp. interested in plant pathology,
born 17 Jan 1881 in Berlin, Ph.D. 1906 Berlin, prof. of botany and plant pathology, Agricul-
tural Univ. of Montevideo, Uruguay 1907, returned to Germany 1910, Univ. of Kiel 1911, as-
soc. prof., Univ. of Rostock 1915, prof. of Botany, Univ. of Braunschweig 1918, dir., "Türki-
schen Pflanzenschutzdienst" in Ankara, Turkey 1934-1939, rector, Univ. of Braunschweig
1945, dr. h.c. Univ. of Göttingen, died 5 Feb 1955 in Lüneburg (Lower Saxony). (<em>Gassner</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Turkey: ANK, B.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 220; Barnhart 2: 32; Biol.-Dokum. 6: 77.262-77.279
(possibly others listed only as "Gassner, G."); BM 6: 358; Hirsch p. 94; IH 2: 218, 386 (sub
Krause, Kurt); Kew 2: 381 (fl. 1932-1940); Krok p. 236; LS suppl. 9370-9388; Moebius p.
310; NDB 6: 83-84.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Intl. address book botanists: 137. 1931.
Dörfler, I., 1909. Botaniker-Adressbuch, ed. 3: 395.
Hassebrauk, [K.], 1955. Anzeiger für Schädlingskunde 28: 47. (portr.) (n.v.)
Hassebrauk, K., 1955. Ber. Deutsch. Bot. Ges. 68a: 189-192. (portr.)
Richert, H., 1955. Phytopath. Zeitschr. 23: 221-232. (n.v.)

<sm>FESTSCHRIFT</sm>: Hassebrauk, K., 1951. Festrede zum 70. Geburtstage von Professor Dr. Dr.
h.c. Gustav Gassner am 17. Januar 1951, Braunschweig (Appelhans): 1-8.

36.099. Über <em>Solanum commersonii</em> und Solanum "commersonii violet" in <em>Uruguay</em> ...
Berlin ... 1910. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 1910, p. 1011-1020, <em>1 pl. Copy</em>: Stanford Univ. Library (n.v.). – Reprinted and to be
	cited from Landw. Jahrb. 39: 1011-1020, <em>1 pl</em>. 1910.

36.100. Über <em>Mutationen</em> in einer biologischen <em>Rasse</em> von <em>Puccinia</em> glumarum tritici
(Schmidt) Erikss. und Henn. ... Berlin (Gebrüder Borntraeger) 1932. Oct. 

<em>Co-author</em>: Straib, W.
<em>Publ</em>.: 1932 (submitted 12 Mai 1932), cover-t.p., p. [154]-180. <em>Copy</em>: K. – Reprinted and to
	be cited from Z. Indukt. Abstamm.- u. Vererbungslehre 63(1): 154-180. 1932.

*Gaterau, Jean-Pierre (1763-1794), French botanist, born 6 Sep 1763 in Montauban (now
Dépt. Tarn-et-Garonne), Dr. en médecine 1786 Montpellier, worked at the hospital in Mon-
tauban, also a student of Antoine Gouan, died 2 Vend. an III [i.e. 28 Sep 1794]. (<em>Gaterau</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 220 (as "Gaterau fl. 1789"); Baillon 2: 677; BL

amended as follows:
<em>Copies</em>: BM (n.v.), HH, K (n.v.), LC (n.v.), MO, NY (n.v.). <em>Microfiche</em>: (1) Westport, Conn.
	(Meckler/Chadwyck-Healey Publishing), [1987?], 3 microfiches (Plant taxonomic lit.
	microfiche coll., "8181C2-8183D7"). <em>Copy</em>: MO. (2) Zug, Switzerland (Inter Documen-
	tation Company), [1987?], 1 microfiche. <em>Copy</em>: LC (n.v.). <em>Microfilm</em>: London (British

	Available online via "Gallica".
<em>Note</em>: All of the names published in this flora are illegitimate, superfluous names (cf. Raynal
	1968, cited above).

Gates, Frank Caleb (1887-1955), American botanist, born 12 Sep 1887 in Lake View (now
Chicago), Illinois, son of a Great Lakes ship capt., A.B. 1910 Univ. of Illinois, Ph.D. 1912 Univ.
of Michigan, Ann Arbor, Prof. of Botany, Univ. of Philippines 1912-1915, from 1915 taught
botany and biology (summers only) at Univ. of Michigan Biological Station, Douglas Lake
(Cheboygan Co.), Prof. of Biology, Carthage College, Illinois 1916-1919, acting Asst. Prof. of
Botany, Univ. of Michigan, Ann Arbor 1919-1920, Asst. Prof. 1919, Assoc. Prof. 1922 and Prof.
1928, Kansas State College of Agriculture (now Kansas State Univ.), Manhattan, President,
Ecological Society of Amer. 1952, died 21 Mar 1955 in Manhattan, Kansas. (<em>F.C. Gates</em>).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: A son, David Murray Gates (1921-x), is an ecologist and was fifth dir. of the Mis-
souri Botanical Garden (1965-1971).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Philippines (col. 1912-1915, also in B. S. [= Bureau of Science]
series): F, MICH, PNH. U.S.A.: mostly at CART, F, KSC, MICH, US, but widely distrib-
uted. – Mss. in Bentley Historical Library, Univ. of Michigan, Ann Arbor (Frank C. Gates
collection, 1912-1915 and 2000) and corr. in GH (Archives).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Amer. Men Sci. ed. 8: 870; APN p. 220; Barnhart 2: 32;
BL 1: 175, 181, 191, 297; BM 6: 358; Bossert p. 140; Hirsch p. 94; IH 2: 218; Kew 2: 381;
Pennell p. 607; Portr. 1: 62 (index), 3: 467; Rhodora, index p. 329; SK 1: 186, 5: cclxxx (d.
"1954"); Tucker 1: 270, 3: 115.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Intl. address book botanists: 471. 1931; Pl. Sci. Bull. 1(2): 3. 1955.
Barnard, I., 2003. Trans. Kansas Acad. Sci. 106: 81-91. [hist. Kansas State Univ. Herb.]
Burgess, R.L., 1996. Huntia 10(1): 45.
Dörfler, I., 1909. Botaniker-Adressbuch, ed. 3: 331.
Gates, D.M., 2000. Frank Caleb Gates, botanist and ecologist and his companion Margarent
	Thompson Gates [Self published]: 492, [11] p., <em>61 pl</em>. (n.v.)
Gleason, H.A., 1961. Thumbnail sketches of botanists: 67-69. [Unpubl. typescript at NY]
Greene, H.C. &amp; J.T. Curtis, 1955. Bibl. Wisconsin vegetation: 74. (index)
Hertel, H. &amp; A. Schreiber, 1988. Mitt. Bot. Staatssamml. München 26: 315.
Voss, E.G., 1955. Asa Gray Bull., ser. 2, 3: 32.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: Gates Lab., Univ. of Michigan Biol. Station, Douglas Lake, Michigan.

1941.
(2) <em>Field manual of plant ecology</em> ... New York (McGraw-Hill Book Co.) 1949.

tributions by Albert Dickens (1867-x), Charles Anderson Scott (1875-1930) and Margaret

Gates, R[eginald]. Ruggles (1882-1962), Canadian-born British anthropologist, biologist,
botanist and geneticist, born 1 Mai 1882 in Middleton, Nova Scotia, B.A. and M.A. 1903
Mount Allison Univ., Sackville, New Brunswick, demonstrator in botany, McGill Univ.,

PAGE: 140
HEADING: GATES

Montreal 1905, B.Sc. 1906 McGill Univ., Ph.D. 1908 Univ. of Chicago, research at Mis-
souri Botanical Garden 1910-1911, Mendel Medal (Paris) 1911, lecturer in cytology, Bed-
ford College, London 1912, 1914 and Oxford Univ. 1914, assoc. prof. of zoology, Univ.
of Calif. 1915-1916, gunnery instructor, W.W.-I (1917-1918), reader in botany, then prof.,
King's College (Univ. of London) 1919-1942, Hon. LL.D. 1927 Mount Allison Univ., F.R.S.
1931, D.Sc. 1933 Univ. of London, traveled widely for expeds., lectures and temporary univ.
appointments, many other academic honors, died 12 Aug 1962 in London. (<em>R.R. Gates</em>).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Gates' first wife, Marie Charlotte Carmichael Stopes (1880-1958), was a paleobota-
nist who became an advocate of birth control, sex education and emancipation of women
after their brief disastrous marriage (1911-1914) was annulled; see TL-2/6: 26-27.

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BM (<em>Oenothera</em>). – Mss. materials and corr. are in Cambridge
Univ., GH (Archives), Kings College Archives (Univ. of London), Oxford Univ. and Kew.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Amer. Men Sci. ed. 9: 391-392; APN p. 220; Barnhart 2:
32; Bossert p. 140; Desmond p. 246, ed. 2: 272-273; DNB 1961-1970: 424-425; DSB 5:
293-294; Ewan ed. 1: 83, ed. 2: 83, Ewan Pap. p. 77; Hirsch p. 95; Hortus 3: 1193; IH 2:
218; Kent ed. 2: 146; Kew 2: 381-384; Langman p. 310; LS 2736; MW suppl. p. 74; Portr.
1: 62 (index), 3: 468; Rhodora, index p. 329; Strid p. 128, ed. 2: 176; Tucker 1: 270-271,
3: 116.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Intl. address book botanists: 181. 1931. (as "R. Ruggles"); The Times
	(London) [newspaper]: 13 Aug 1962. (obit.); Memorial Service for Professor Reginald
	Ruggles Gates, F.R.S.: [p. 1-4]. 25 Oct 1962; Curriculum Vitae. Reginald Ruggles Gates,
	M.A., D.Sc., F.R.S., Professor, University of London 1921-1942, Edinburgh (Macdonald
	Printers): [p. 1-8, unnumb.]. 1962; Mount Allison University announces the establish-

Gatin, Charles Louis (1877-1916), French agricultural engineer and botanist, born 6 Dec
1877 in Rambouillet, graduated from the Agronomy Inst., Paris 1898, internship, experi-
mental garden in Tunis, Tunisia "préparateur", lab. of botany, École supérieure des sciences,
Algiers, Algeria 1901, Dr. ès-sciences 1906 Paris, dir. of research, École des hautes études,
Muséum natl. d'Histoire naturelle, Paris 1913, mobilized in 1914 for military service in
W.W.-I and wounded the same year in Alsace, after recuperating he was again sent to the
front and killed in action 26 Feb 1916 at Douaumont nr. Verdun, Chevalier de la Légion
d'Honneur, Croix de Guerre. (<em>Gatin</em>).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Gatin's widow, Valentine Gatin (née Selitzky) (1888-1977), married the botanist
Pierre Allorge (1891-1944) in 1920.

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 32; BFM p. 285 (index); BL 2: 102, 657; BM
6: 358; BN p. 174; DBF 15: 664; Kew 2: 384; Langman p. 310; Plesch p. 234; TL-2/Suppl.
1: 448 (index); Tucker 1: 271, 3: 116.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Charpin, A. &amp; J. Timbal, 2007. Acta Bot. Gallica 154: 450.
Davy de Virville, A., 1954. Hist. bot. France: 132, 136, 261.
Dörfler, I., 1909. Botaniker-Adressbuch, ed. 3: 109.
Fridel, J., 1919. Rev. Gén. Bot. 31: 65-74. (bibl., portr.)
[Gatin, C.L.], 1924. Dict. Bot.: viii-x. (portr.)
Lavaud, S., 1955. Cat. thèses de Doctorat ès Sciences nat. soutenues à Paris de 1891 à 1954: 41.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) Co-author with É.C. Perrot, <em>Les Algues marines</em> ... 1911; see TL-
2/4, nr. 7714, where no credit is given to Gatin).

(Masson et Cie, Éditeurs) 1906. Oct.

	[i-iii, "Table des matières", "Deuxième thèse"], <em>pl. 1-11</em> (uncol. photomicrograph.). <em>Cop-
	ies</em>: K (n.v.), NY. – Reprinted and to be cited from Ann. Sci. Nat., Bot., sér. 9, 3(2-3):
	191-192. Apr 1906, Id. 3(4-6): 193-315, <em>pl. 1-11.</em> Jun 1906.
<em>Note</em>: (1) Doctoral thesis, Univ. of Paris, Série A, No. 517, No. 1234. (2) Gatin's Deuxième
	thèse (p. [iii]), approved 27 Jan 1906, is not included in the journal.

Gattefossé, Jean (1899-1960), French industrial chemist and botanist, born in Lyon, chem-
ical engineer 1918 Univ. of Lyon, employed by his father's perfume factory for which he
went to Morocco with Émile Jahandiez in 1920, established a factory to exploit aromatic
plants in Provence, returned to Morocco and settled there 1927, died Jun 1960 in Aïn Seba,
Morocco. (<em>Gattefossé</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: A, AL, G, K, MO, MPU (in Herbier Raphélis), P, RAB.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 220; Barnhart 2: 32; BL 1: 44, 297; Frodin ed. 2:
509; GR p. 322; IH 2: 218 (b. "1886"); Kew 2: 384; Tucker 3: 116.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Intl. address book botanists: 258. 1931.
Charpin, A. &amp; J. Timbal, 2007. Acta Bot. Gallica 154: 450.
Granel de Solignac, L. &amp; L. Bertrand, 1967. Naturalia Monspel., Sér. Bot., 18: 276.
Sauvage, Ch., 1962. Bull. Soc. Sci. Nat. Maroc 42: 121-126, <em>pl. 5.</em> (portr.)

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: Editor-in-chief of <em>La Parfumerie Moderne</em>, in which he published
many studies of aromatic plants.

*Gattinger, Augustin ('August') (1825-1903), German-born American botanist and sur-
geon, born 2 Feb 1825 in Munich, medical student who, for political reasons, emigrated to
Tenn. 1849, resident physician to the Ducktown Copper Mines in s.e. Tenn., surgeon for
U.S. Army in Nashville, Tenn. during Civil War, Tenn. State Librarian for a 5-year period
after the war, died 18 Jul 1903 in Nashville. (<em>Gattinger</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: TENN (orig., but lost in fire), duplicates CM, DH (now NY), GH,
GOET, K, LE, M, MANCH, MIN, MO, NY, PENN, PH, US, VT, WELC (now NY). – Some
mss. material in Vanderbilt Univ., Nashville, Tenn. and in GH (Thomas Morong papers).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 220; Barnhart 2: 32; BL 1: 214-215, 297; BM 2:
644; Bossert p. 141; CSP 15: 226; Ewan Pap. p. 77; Frahm&amp;E. p. 127 (portr.); Frodin ed.
2: 213; Hortus 3: 1193 (as "Gattinger, August"); IH 2: 218; Kew 2: 384; Kew List p. 25;
Lenley p. 178; ME 1: 186, 3: 730; Morren ed. 10: 131; Pennell p. 607; Rehder 5(index): 311;
TL-2/1: 921; Tucker 1: 271; Wagenitz p. 61-62; Zander ed. 11: 754, ed. 17: 949.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Bessey, C.E., 1904. Science, n.s., 19: 869.
Core, E.L., 1970. <em>In</em>, P.C. Holt (ed.), The distributional hist. biota S. Appalachians, Part 2:
	Flora: 47-50. (portr.)
Dörfler, I., 1896. Botaniker-Adressbuch: 195.
[Engelmann, W.], 1891. Botanisches Adressbuch: 135.
Franks, J.W., 1973. Manchester Mus. Publ., new ser., no. NS.1.73: 3, 14.
Gattinger, A. 1901. Preface to his Fl. Tenn. p. 3-10. (autobiogr., portr.)
Halley, R.A., 1904. Dr Augustin Gattinger ... Nashville, Tenn. (The Cumberland Press): 28
	p. (portr.) [repr. from Amer. Hist. Mag. 9: 153-178 for Apr 1904].
Hertel, H. &amp; A. Schreiber, 1988. Mitt. Bot. Staatssamml. München 26: 157, 315.
Lamson-Scribner, F., 1893. Bull. Torrey Bot. Club 20: 332-334.
Lubrecht, H., 1967. Early Amer. botany, New York (Stechert-Hafner, Inc.): 18. [reprinted
	1999]
Mears, J.A., 1981. Proc. Acad. Nat. Sci. Philadelphia 133: 151.
Oakes, H.N., 1932. A brief sketch of life and works of Augustin Gattinger ... Nashville,
	Tenn. (Cullom &amp; Ghertner): 152 p., frontisp. (portr.) [Master's thesis: reprinted from J.
	Tenn. Acad. Sci. 7(4): 260-412. 1932]
Priestly, M., 2001. Pl. Press (Sewanee) 5(1): 1, 3.
Rodgers, A.D., 1944. Amer. Bot. 1873-1892: 111-112, 128, 232-233.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: Lamson-Scribner (1893: 333) wrote that Gattinger contributed "the most
chapters in Killebrew's work on [grasses] ...", presumably in reference to <em>The grasses of
Tennessee</em> ... Nashville (American Co.) 1878, by Joseph Buckner Killebrew (1831-1906).

HEADING: GAUDICHAUD-BEAUPRÉ

36.157. The <em>medicinal plants</em> of <em>Tennessee</em> exhibiting their commercial value with an ana-

<em>Note</em>: (1) Gattinger's "Letter of Transmittal" [of the original mss.] (p. [iii]) is dated 10
	Mai 1894; the US copy is inscribed "Received from the author Sept. 30, 1894, Lester F.
	Ward". (2) The t.p. contains a misspelling "The medicinal plants of <em>Tennnessee</em> [sic] ...",
	which is not found on the cover. (3) T.F.P. Allison was Commissioner of Agriculture for
	the state of Tenn.

*Gaudichaud-Beaupré, Charles (1789-1854), French pharmacist, naturalist and circum-
navigator, born 4 Sep 1789 in Angoulême (now Dépt. Charente), studied under A.-L. de
Jussieu and L.-C. M. Richard, entered corps of "pharmacien de la Marine" 1810 and even-
tually became "pharmacien en chef de la Marine", stationed at Anvers 1811-1814, sailed
three times around the world: on (1) the <em>Uranie</em> (wrecked and replaced by), the <em>Physicienne</em>
(1817-1820), (2) the <em>Herminie</em> (1831-1833) and on (3) the <em>Bonite</em> (1836-1837), "aide-
naturaliste", Muséum natl. d'Histoire naturelle, Paris 1845-1846, Académie de Médecine
1825, Légion d'Honneur 1826, Académie des Sciences 1837, died 16 Jan 1854 in Paris.
(<em>Gaud</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: [mostly repeated from TL-2/1: 921] Gaudichaud gave all his col-
lections to P [and PC]. The collections made on the voyage of the <em>Uranie</em> and the <em>Physi-
cienne</em> (1817-1820) went directly to P. Part of the collections were lost during the voyage
when the <em>Uranie</em> stranded in the Falkland Islands (Îles Malouines). Gaudichaud's mss.
journal of the voyage is at P. The collections made in Brazil from 1831-1833, as part of
the voyage of the <em>Herminie</em>, were given by him to the Muséum natl. d'Histoire naturelle,
Paris (i.e. P) on 2 Nov 1833 (5000 specimens); those made on the voyage of the <em>Bonite</em>
(1836-1837), numbering 3500 specimens, were received by P in 1837. All cryptogams are
at PC. The plants figured in the atlas of the voyage of the <em>Bonite</em>, however, form a special
case. I.M. Johnston (1944) pointed out that not all plates are based on specimens collected
during that voyage. Some of the plates must have been made from specimens collected by

PAGE: 147
HEADING: GAUDICHAUD-BEAUPRÉ

Gaudichaud on other voyages, or from specimens found by him in other herbaria. Some of
these specimens may be in the Webb herb. (FI). Duplicates can be found in A, B, BM, DS,
FH, G, G-DC, K, L, M, MO, MPU (in Herb. Cambessèdes), PH (Lich., few), US, W.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Académie p. 207; AG 5(l): 427; APN p. 220; Backer p.
229, 651; Baillon 2: 677-678; Barnhart 2: 33; BM 2: 644; BN p. 174; Bretschneider p.
307-308; CSP 2: 781-782; DBF 15: 700-702; Frank 3(Anh.): 34; GR p. 279; GR cat. p. 63;
Herder p. 452 (index); Hortus 3: 1193; IF p. 698-699; IF suppl. 4: 354; IH 2: 219; Jackson p.
223-224; Kelly p. 88; Kew 2: 385; Kew List p. 25; KR p. 236; Krempelh. 1: 610; Langman
p. 311; Lasègue 78-83; LS 9741-9743; MD p. 121-124; NAF 9(6): 436; NI 2: 65-66; Portr.
3: 468; PR ed. 1: 3527-3528, ed. 2: 3233-3235; Rehder 5(index): 311-312; RS p. 84; SK 1:
186-187 (portr.), 8: xxxviii; TL-1: 165-167; TL-2/1: 921-923, indices 2/3 (misalphabet-

603, ed. 11: 755, ed. 17: 949.

36.158. <em>Rapport</em> sur la <em>flore</em> des <em>îles Malouines</em> de M. Gaudichaud ... Extrait des Annales
des Sciences Naturelles ... Paris ... 1825. Oct [or smaller]. 

<em>Author</em>: Mirbel, Charles François Brisseau de (1776-1854), see TL-2/3: 520-522 and IH
	2: 543.
<em>Publ</em>.: 1825 (read 16 Mai 1825), p. 1-20, <em>pl. 2-3</em> (uncol. copper engr.). <em>Copies</em>: K, WU. –
	Reprinted and to be cited from Ann. Sci. Nat. (Paris) 5: 89-110, <em>pl. 2-3.</em> 1825.
<em>Note</em>: (1) Mirbel's paper is a review of mss. and specimens (?) sent by Gaudichaud. (2) In
	presenting the review to the Académie Royale de Médecine [i.e. publishers of the jour-
	nal!], it is "Signé, Desfontaines, Mirbel, <em>rapporteur</em>". (3) The novelties proposed in the
	"... tableau de la végétation des Malouines" are to be attributed to Gaudichaud alone.

36.159. Secondes <em>notes relatives</em> à la <em>protestation faite</em> à la Académie des Sciences, dans
sa séance du 12 juin 1843, à la <em>suite de la lecture du mémoire de M. de Mirbel</em>, ayant pour
titre: Recherches anatomiques et physiologiques sur quelques végétaux monocotylés ...
Paris ... 1843. Oct. 

<em>Subject</em>: Mirbel, Charles François Brisseau de (1776-1854), see TL-2/3: 520-522 and IH
	2: 543.
<em>Publ</em>.: Oct 1843 (on t.p.), p. [1]-20. <em>Copy</em>: L. – Reprinted and to be cited from Ann. Sci.
	Nat., Bot., sér. 2, 20: 199-218. 1843.
<em>Note</em>: This is the second of four notes (in five fascicles) by Gaudichaud and concerning
	Mirbel's memoir. The others, for which we have not seen reprints, are: "Premières notes
	relatives à la protestation faite dans la séance du 12 juin 1845 [sic], à la suite de la lecture
	du mémoire de M. de Mirbel Mirbel ...", Id., sér. 2, 20: 32-45. Jul 1843; "Troisième notes
	...", Id., sér. 3, 1: 263-291. Mai 1844 (read 8 Apr 1844); and "Quatrièmes notes ...", Id.,
	sér. 3, 2: 33-45. Jul 1844 (read 20 Mai 1844), 124-140. Aug 1844 (read 20 Mai 1844).

Gaudin, Charles Théophile (1822-1866), Swiss paleobotanist, born 4 Aug 1822 in Lausanne,
studied theology in Lausanne but not consecrated, private tutor ("précepteur") in England
for the family of Lord Ashley (1801-1885) (later 7th Earl of Shaftesbury) 1845, returned to
Switzerland and began paleobotany studies 1851, private tutor for Gabriel de Rumine (1841-
1871), the son of a Russian emigré family that settled in Lausanne and which also financed
Gaudin's paleontological research, founded with Mme. Catherine de Rumine (1818-1867) the
Musée Industriel, Lausanne 1862, died 7 Jan 1866 in Lausanne. (<em>C.T. Gaudin</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown, but not to be confused with that of Jean François Aimé
Gottlieb Philippe Gaudin (1766-1833).

PAGE: 149
HEADING: GAUDIN

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 33; BM 2: 644; Bossert p. 141; CSP 2: 783-784;
Jackson p. 549 (index); Kew 2: 385; LS 9744; Portr. 3: 468; Quenstedt p. 154; Rehder 5(in-
dex): 312; Sarjeant p. 1066; TL-2/2: 954 (index); Tucker 1: 271.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Candolle, A.L., 1880. Phytographie: 414.

Gaussen, Henri [Marcel] (1891-1981), French phytogeographer and specialist in gymno-
sperms, born 14 Jul 1891 in Cabrières-d'Aigues (Vaucluse), Dr. ès-sciences 1926 Paris,
chair of botany at Toulouse 1928-1947, founder of the scientific section of the Institut Fran-
çais in Pondichery, India, Grand Prix de la Société de Géographie pour Travaux et Publica-
tions Géographiques 1971, died 27 Jul 1981 in Toulouse. (<em>Gaussen</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: TLF (now incorporated in TL). – Collection Henri Gaussen
(phot.) on permanent loan to Archives Dépt. de la Haute-Garonne, Toulouse.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 221; Barnhart 2: 33; BFM p. 285 (index); BL 2:
102, 110-111, 154, 658; Bossert p. 141; GR p. 323; IH 2: 219; Kew 2: 385-386; Langman p.
311; MW p. 135, suppl. p. 74; Portr. 1: 62 (index), 3: 469; Strid p. 128, ed. 2: 176; Tucker
3: 116-117; Zander ed. 17: 949.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Intl. address book botanists: 108. 1931.
Balcells, R.E., 1981. Pirineoś 31(114): 91-108. (bibl.) (n.v.)

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Gaussenia</em> A.V.F.C. Bobrov &amp; A.P. Melikian (2000). The serial <em>Gaussenia</em>

addition, the Prix Henri-Gaussen (Académie des sciences, inscriptions et belles-lettres
de Toulouse), the Jardin Botanique Henri Gaussen, Univ. Paul Sabatier, Toulouse and the
Arboretum Henri Gaussen, Jouéou honor him.

*Gautier, [Marie or Maurice] Clément Gaston (1841-1911), French botanist and land pro-
prietor, born 10 Apr 1841 in Narbonne (Aude), studied natural history while he oversaw
cultivation on his extensive land holdings, died 7 Oct 1911 in Narbonne. (<em>Gaut</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: DS (through Herman Knoche), duplicates BR, CLF, F, K, MANCH,
MPU, P. The Gautier herb. at DS (126,000 sheets) contains the types of Gautier's new taxa
published in his two floras, as well as the types of J.V. Martrin-Donos' <em>Florule du Tarn</em>.
The <em>Hieracium</em> collection of Gautier was not included in the herb. as it came to DS. – <em>Exs-
iccatae</em>: Gautier, together with Casimir Arvet-Touvet, issued an <em>Hieraciotheca</em>.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 2(1): 525; APN p. 221; Barnhart 2: 34; BL 2: 124, 193,
658; BM 2: 645 (as "Gaston"); Bossert p. 141; CSP 12: 252, 463, 733, 15: 235; DBF 15:
827-828; Herder p. 173; IH 1 (ed. 6): 358, 2: 219; Kew 2: 386-387; Kew List p. 25; Morren
ed. 10: 67; Rehder 5(index): 312; TL-2/1: 924-925, Suppl. 1: 448 (index); Tucker 1: 271.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Cavillier, [Frère]. 1941. Boissiera 5: 11. (sub Arvet-Touvet)

	1909. Id., ed. 3: 109. (as "Gautier, Gaston")

Gave, Pierre (Abbé) (1846-1916), French Redemptorist priest and botanist, born 6 Dec
1846 in Saint-André-sur-Boëge (Haute Savoie), Kingdom of Sardinia, entered novitiate in
Saint-Nicolas-de-Port (now Dépt. Meurthe-et-Moselle) 1862, took his vows 1863, instruc-
tor of natural sciences at various secondary schools 1873-1884, later chaplain ("aumônier")
for various convents, died 15 Mar 1916 in Uvrier nr. Sion (Valais), France. (<em>Gave</em>).

PAGE: 155
HEADING: GAY

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: G, also E; some Rosaceae at BR; his herbarium (at Agen) was
discussed by Père Garroute (Bull. Soc. Bot. France 55(8): 683-884. 15 Jan 1909). Part of
the orig. herb. is held by Werner Greuter (A. Charpin, pers. comm.).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 34; BL 2: 198, 658; CSP 15: 237; IH 2: 219;
Portr. 3: 469; TL-2/Suppl. 4: 609 (index).
