Charpin, A. &amp; J. Timbal, 2007. Acta Bot. Gallica 154: 451.
Dörfler, I., 1896. Botaniker-Adressbuch: 58; 1902. Id., ed. 2: 75; 1909. Id., ed. 3: 276.
Fuchs, H.P., 1991. Bull. Murith. Soc. Valais. Sci. Nat. 109: 146-147.
Hedge, I.C. &amp; J.M. Lamond (eds.), 1970. Index collectors Edinburgh Herb.: 83.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) Contributed a "Florule des environs de Faucigny" to François
Bouchage, <em>Les Ruines de Faucigny, près Bonneville</em> (<em>Haute-Savoie</em>) ... 1891.

to which Gave also contributed a "Petit supplément à la Flore populaire de Savoie ...
1905-1906".

	"Fr. Gay del."). <em>Copies</em>: BM (n.v.), MO (n.v.), NY (inscribed by the author).
<em>Note</em>: Commercial (?) version of the author's dissertation, see also TL-2/1, nr. 1976.

Gay, Hippolyte (fl. 1882-1909), French botanist and secondary school teacher in Algeria
(1882-?), holding positions at the Collège du Blida, Collège de Médéa (1888, at least) and
in Crescia (Khraicia). (<em>H. Gay</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: A, B, CHE, G, L, MPU, P, U, W.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: BL 1: 19 (as "Hippolyte"), 297 (as "Hippolyte"); CSP
15: 237; IH 2: 219; Morren ed. 10: 113; Rehder 5(index): 312 (as "Henri"); Urban-Berl.
p. 348.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Davy de Virville, A., 1954. Hist. bot. France: 355.
Dörfler, I., 1902. Botaniker-Adressbuch, ed. 2: 216; 1909. Id., ed. 3: 305.
[Engelmann, W.], 1891. Botanisches Adressbuch: 121.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: There is evidence that Gay privately published a <em>Synopsis</em> de la <em>flore</em> de la <em>Mitidja</em> et
des montagnes qui l'entourent ... Crescia, in two parts (1893, 1895), but we have not seen a
copy nor have we learned sufficient details to describe it. We suspect that this is either a re-
print or otherwise derived from a series of articles with the same title published in Rev. Sci.
Bourbonnais 3: 129-140, 206-216, 280-288. 1890, Id. 4: 36-45, 160-169. 1891 (fide Anon., J.
Bot. 29: 94. Mar 1891; Anon., Bull. Soc. Bot. France 39(RBC-D): 181. 5 Jan 1892).

36.188. <em>Excursions botaniques</em> dans les <em>Beni-Salah</em> (environs de Blida) ... Extrait de la
Revue de Botanique ... Auch (G. Foix) 1886. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: Mar &amp; Apr 1886 (in journal, p. 301 signed 15 Dec 1885), cover-t.p., p. [1]-15. <em>Copy</em>:
	G. – Reprinted and to be cited from Rev. Bot. (Toulouse) 4(45): 289-300. Mar 1886;
	(46): 301. Apr 1886.

36.189. <em>Florule de Blida</em> ... Revue de Botanique ... Auch (Imprimerie et Lithographie G.
Foix) 1888. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 1888 (p. 7 signed 2 Jun 1888), cover-t.p., p. [1]-68. <em>Copy</em>: HH. – Reprinted and to be
	cited from Rev. Bot. (Toulouse) 7: 87-155. 1888.
<em>Note</em>: The serial publication includes additional material not in the reprint, viz. pp. 149-155
	("Végétaux cellulaires" and "Remarque"; p. 155 signed 21 Jun 1888) by L[ouis]. Cor-
	bière (1850-1941), see IH 2: 138, TL-2/1: 545-546 and TL-2/Suppl. 4: 352-354.

*Gay, Jacques Étienne (1786-1864), Swiss-born French botanist, born 11 Oct 1786 in
Nyon (Ct. Vaud), student of Jean Gaudin in Nyon, educated at Univ. of Laussane, went to
Paris 1811 where he was appointed to the offices of the Senate and the Comité des Pétitions,
awarded Légion d'honneur 1824, served as an officer from the founding of the Société
Botanique de France in 1854, died 16 Jan 1864 in Paris. (<em>J. Gay</em>).

PAGE: 157
HEADING: GAY

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: K (orig. purchased by Sir J.D. Hooker), duplicates CGE, DBN,
E, FI, MO, NA, PH, US. Gay material was bequeathed to the herb. of Jean Gaudin, which
was later sold to Kew but eventually returned to LAU. – Mss. materials at Kew and extant
corr. with C. Darwin, William Henry Fox Talbot (20 letters, <em>fide</em> Glasgow Univ. electronic
resource) and Philip Barker Webb (80 letters), at least.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 2(1): 226, 5(1): 501, 673; APN p. 221; Backer p. 230,
651; Baillon 2: 679; Barnhart 2: 34; BL 2: 490, 658; BM 2: 646; Bossert p. 141; Colmeiro
1: clxxvi; CSP 2: 797-799, 6: 666, 7: 748, 12: 264; DBF 15: 893; Herder p. 452 (index);
Hortus 3: 1193; IH 1 (ed. 6): 359, 2: 219; Jackson p. 549 (index); Kent ed. 2: 147; Kew 2:
387-388; Krempelh. p. 610; Langman p. 311; Lasègue p. 318-319; MW p. 135; Portr. 3: 470;
PR ed. 1: 3542-3549, ed. 2: 3248-3252; Rehder 5(index): 312; TL-1: 168; TL-2/1: 926-927,
indices 2/1, 2/4, 2/5, 2/6, Suppl. 4; Tucker 1: 272; Zander ed. 10: 603, ed. 11: 754, ed. 17:
949.

	de feu M.J. Gay, etc., Paris. 1864. (n.v.)

Gáyer, Gyula [Julius in German] (1883-1932), Hungarian plant geographer, born 16 Feb
1883 in Celldömölk, Ph.D. 1907 Kolozsvár, died 13 Jul 1932 in Szombathely. (<em>Gáyer</em>).

p. 95; Hortus 3: 1193; IH 2: 219; Kew 2: 388; MW suppl. p. 74; Portr. 3: 470; Strid p. 128,
ed 2: 176; Zander ed. 17: 949.

Geay, [Martin] François (1859-1910), French pharmacist, botanist and natural history col-
lector, born in the Cour d'Arcenay, Canton de Précy-sous-Thil (Côte d'Or), studied at the
Lycée in Dijon, then at the Sorbonne and the School of Pharmacy in Paris, also studied
natural history under Alphonse Milne-Edwards, pharmacist, Compagnie du Canal de Pa-
nama 1886-1887, briefly returned to Paris 1887, "voyager-naturalist" for the Muséum natl.
d'Histoire naturelle, Paris in the Darien (now Panama) and Venezuela 1888-1895, returned
to Paris 1895, to British Guiana and the contested French-Brazilian territory 1897-1899, to
Madagascar several times from 1904-1907, died 15/16 Mai 1910 in Melbourne, Australia.
(<em>M.F. Geay</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: G, L, MO, P (orig.), TAN. – Some mss. material at P.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 35; CSP 15: 239; IH 2: 220, 228 (as "Goay").

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., 1905. Bull. Mus. Hist. Nat. (Paris) 11: 131; 1906. Id. 12: 2, 233; 1910. Id.
	16: 176.
Costantin, J.N. &amp; D.G. Bois, 1907. Rev. Hort. 79: 489-494.
Costantin, J.N. &amp; E.-I. Gallaud, 1905. Bull. Mus. Hist. Nat. (Paris) 11: 345-354; 1906. Id.
	12: 415-421.
Dorr, L.J., 1997. Pl. coll. Madagascar Comoro Isls.: 172-173. (portr.)
Grandidier, G., 1935. Bibl. de Madagascar, 1904-1933: 956.
Griveaud, P., 1967. Cah. O.R.S.T.O.M., Sér. Biol. 4: 56. ("Geary")
Guillaumin, A., 1929. Fleurs de jardins 1: xli.
Hillerman, F.E. &amp; A.W. Holst, 1996. Introd. cult. angraecoid orchids Madagascar: 10.
	(portr.)
Hoff, M. &amp; G. Cremers, 1996. Index noms lieux récoltes botaniques Guyane Française: 145.
Humbert, H., 1962. <em>In</em>, A. Fernandes, Compt. Rend. Réun. Plén. Assoc. pour Étude Taxon.
	Fl. Afrique Trop. 4: 138.

	Cinquantenaire: 35.

Gedner, Christophor [Eliasson] (1729-1773), Swedish student of Linnaeus, born 24 Jul
1729 in Vittinge, Uppland, at Uppsala Univ. 1743, in Berlin 1755, died 3 Mai 1773 in
Karlstad. (<em>Gedner</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 35; BM 2: 647; Dryander 5: 247 (index); KR
p. 237; SO p. 23 (index); TL-2/3: 948 (index).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Gedner was respondant for the thesis <em>Cui bono?</em> ... [i.e. "To what purpose?" on the
utility of natural history ...] [1752] (see TL-2/3, nr. 4766), which has a more involved his-
tory than earlier given. The earlier entry can be augmented as follows:
<em>Publ</em>.: 21 Oct 1752, p. [i-viii], [1]-29, [30]. <em>Copies</em>: B, BM, HH, K, LC (as Dissertationes
	academicae (Linné) no. 42) (n.v.), MO. <em>Microfilm</em>: London (British Library), 1993, 1
	reel (220 fr., 35 mm). <em>Copy</em>: (n.v.).
<em>Reprinted</em> [Sep 1756] ... <em>Amoen. Acad.</em> 3(4): 231-255 (TL-2/1, nr. 4753).
[1762]: Of the <em>use of curiosity</em> ... <em>in</em> B. Stillingfleet, <em>Misc. tracts</em> ... ed. 2, p. [159]-200
	(TL-2/6, nr. 13.112). <em>Copies</em>: G, KU, MO, NY, US (n.v.).
[1764]: ... <em>Amoen. Acad.</em>, ed. 2. [Amsterdam ed.?]. (TL-2/1, nr. 4753).

	HH, KU, NYPL (n.v.), PH.

<em>Swedish transl</em>.: En Fråga, som altid föreställes de naturkunniga, Då det heter: <em>Hwartil duger
	det?</em> (Cui bono?). Först framstäld och beswarad i en disputation på Latin, under ... Carl Lin-
	næi Öfwerwaro, den 21 Octob. år 1752. Men nu, efter hög Befalning, på Moders-målet öf-

	ed.]. <em>Copy</em>: (n.v.).

Gee, N[athaniel]. Gist (1876-1937), American naturalist and educator, born 20 Apr 1876
in Union, South Carolina, graduated 1896 Wofford College, Spartanburg, South Carolina,
principal, Jordan Academy, Jordan, South Carolina 1896-1898, Prof. of Natural Science,
Columbia Female College, Columbia, South Carolina 1898-1901, Prof. of Natural Science
1901-1915 and Prof. and Head, Dept. of Biology 1915-1920, both Dongwu Univ., Suzhou,
China, superintendent of public schools, Summerton, South Carolina 1920-1921, returned
to China and mostly involved in medical education for the Rockefeller Foundation 1922-
1928, vice-president, Yanjing Univ. (now part of Beijing Univ.), but stationed in Manhat-
tan, New York 1932-1935, head, Biology Dept., Lander College (now Univ.), Greenwood,
South Carolina 1935-1937, LL.D. Wofford College, died 18 Dec 1937 in Greenwood, South
Carolina of influenza. (<em>N.G. Gee</em>).

PAGE: 164
HEADING: GEE

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Older brother of Wilson [Parham] Gee (1888-1961), see below.

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown. – Some corr. in SIA (see also Haas, 1996, p. 333-334).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 35; MW p. 136; Tucker 3: 117.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., New York Times [newspaper]: 19 Dec 1937.
Carpenter, M.M., 1953. Amer. Midl. Naturalist 50: 289.
Haas, W.J., 1991. Gist Gee: a life in science and in China, Ph.D. Thesis, Harvard Univ.,
	Cambridge, Mass.: xi, 479 lvs. (n.v.)
Haas, W.J., 1996. China voyager: Gist Gee's life in science, Armonk, New York (M.E.
	Sharpe): i-xii, 1-345. (bibl. [p. 322-331], portrs.) [Wright, R., 1977. Bull. S.O.A.S.
	60(2): 1997 (rev.)]
Needham, J.G., 1938. Science, n.s., 88: 250.
Pickens, A.L., 1939. Auk 56: 111.
Shavit, D., 1990. The United States in Asia: a historical dictionary, New York (Greenwood
	Press): 185.

36.225. <em>List</em> of <em>plants</em> found in <em>Kiangsu Province</em> ... Reprinted from "The National Re-

<em>Publ</em>.: 1914 (<em>fide</em> Haas, 1996, p. 323), cover-t.p., p. [1]-35. <em>Copies</em>: HH(2) (n.v.), K, LC
	(n.v.), US. – Reprinted and to be cited from [Millard's China] National Review (Shang-

	812. 27 Jun 1914. (n.v.)

	Province</em>" was published as an appendix to N.G. Gee, <em>A text-book of botany</em>, Shanghai
	(Commercial Press, Limited) 1915 (n.v.). (2) HH has a 46 p. mss. dated 1917 (n.v.),
	which appears to be yet another revised and enlarged version of the 1914 list.

Gee, Wilson [Parham] (1888-1961), American social scientist, born 18 Sep 1888 in Union,
South Carolina, B.S. 1908 and hon. D.Sc. 1937 Clemson Agricultural College (now Univ.),
South Carolina, M.A. 1910 Univ. of South Carolina, Ph.D. 1913 Univ. of Calif. at Berkeley,
medical corps in France during W.W.-I, taught at Univ. of South Carolina, Univ. of Calif.
and Emory Univ., Atlanta, Georgia, Prof. of Rural Social Economics and Rural Sociology,
Univ. of Virginia, Charlottesville 1923-1959, published extensively on agriculture and rural
economics of the South, Dr. h.c. 1938 Univ. of Alabama, died 1 Feb 1961 in Urbana, Il-
linois. (<em>W.P. Gee</em>).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Younger brother of Nathaniel Gist Gee (1876-1937), see above.

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Amer. Men Sci. ed. 8: 875; Barnhart 2: 35; Kelly p. 88;
ME 1: 52; RUS 3: 250, 4: 252.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Gilmour, R.W., 2002. Occ. Pap. Eastern Bot. 1: 15.
Gregory, E.W., Jr., 1961. Social Forces 39(4): 386.

Geel, Pierre [Petrus] Corneille van see *Van Geel, Pierre Corneille (1796-1836), Bel-

Geert, Auguste van see *Van Geert, Auguste [August] (1888-1938), Belgian horticultur-
alist specializing in azaleas, treated in TL-2/6: 665.

Geerts, Antonius Johannes Cornelius (1843-1883), Dutch chemist and encyclopaedist,
prof. of chemistry, School of Military Medicine, Utrecht, prof. of natural science, Medical
School, Nagasaki 1868-1873, advisor, Dept. of Hygiene and Public Health, Tokyo and later
Yokohama 1877-1883, also charged with establishing a chemical lab. in Kyoto, Order of the
Rising Sun, died 30 Aug 1883 in Yokohama. (<em>A.J.C. Geerts</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 35; BM 2: 648; CSP 9: 979, 15: 243; Kew 2:
390 (as "Geerts, Dr."); MW p. 136; Rehder 5(index): 313; Tucker 1: 273.

*Geheeb, Adalbert [Adelbert] (1842-1909), German bryologist, born 21 Mar 1842 in
Geisa (Thüringen), student of Ferdinand Senft at Eisenach, began collecting plants in 1856,
first publication in 1861 (19 years old), inherited his father's pharmacy in Geisa 1867, after
serious illness he sold the drugstore in 1897 and moved to Breisgau (Baden), died 13 Sep
1909 in Königsfelden (nr. Brugg, Aargau), Switzerland. (<em>Geheeb</em>).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: TL-2/1 used the uninformative author abbreviation "<em>Geh</em>.", which should be replaced.

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: B (destroyed), other material BM, BP, BR, C, E, GOET, H, JE,
K, L, MANCH.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 36; Biol.-Dokum. 6: 77.893-77.924; BM 2:
649; BN p. 174; Bossert p. 141; CSP 2: 810, 7: 750 (as "Adelbert"), 9: 980-981 (as "Adel-
bert"), 12: 264 (as "Adelbert"), 308 (sub Hampe, E.), 15: 245-246 (as "Adelbert"); DTS
1: 84-85; Frahm&amp;E. p. 128-132 (bibl., portr. with 2nd wife); Herder p. 452 (index as "Adel-
bert"); IH 2: 220; Kew 2: 390; Kleppa p. 322 (index); Maiwald p. 277; Morren ed. 2: 11,

Saccardo 1: 79; SBC p. 120; TL-2/1: 928-929, indices 2/4, 2/5; TR p. 89; Urban-Berl. p.

<em>Illus</em>.: "Adalbert &amp; Emmy Geheeb-Belart ad nat. del."; the latter is Emmy (Emilie) Caroline

	tronic copy</em>: MA (as "Biblioteca Digital"). – Reprinted and to be be cited from Biblioth.
	Bot. 13: 1-13, <em>pl. 1-8.</em> 1889.
<em>Note</em>: (1) Author as "Adelbert (sic) Geheeb". (2) Hepaticae contributed by F. Stephani (see
	TL-2/5: 890, sub Composite Works (2)).
<em>Ref</em>.: Anon., Bot. Gaz. 14(6): 158. Jun 1889 (noticed).

Gehrmann, Karl [Carl] Anton (1885-1925), German botanist, born 21 Nov 1885 in
Rössel (then East Prussia), attended school and gymnasium in Braunsberg, then Univ. of
Königsberg until 1906, Ph.D. 1908 Univ. of Breslau, joined the German colonial service
and went to Samoa 1909 where he published on diseases of cacao and other crops, first
dir., Rabaul Botanic Gardens, New Britain (Bismarck Archipelago) 1911-1914, on exped.
in New Guinea 1913, traveled widely 1914-1919, settled in Königsberg where he died.
(<em>K. Gehrmann</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: B, WRSL (formerly BRSL).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 222; Biol.-Dokum. 6: 78.024-78.026; IH 2: 220;
LS 33.586-33.589; LS suppl. 9457; MW p. 136; SK 1: 188; Urban-Berl. p. 349; Zep.-Tim.
p. 51.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Dörfler, I., 1909. Botaniker-Adressbuch, ed. 3: 35. (as "Carl").
Poschmann, A., 1975. Altpreussische Biographie 3: 918.
Smith, A.C., 1979. Fl. Vit. Nov. 1: 54.

sichtigung der afrikanischen Arten ... Leipzig (Wilhem Engelmann) 1908. Oct.

Geilinger, Gottlieb (1881-1955), Swiss plant-geographer, born 21 Dec 1881, doctorate
1908 Univ. of Zurich, Prof. in the Kantonsschule Winterthur where he died. (<em>Geil</em>.).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Not to be confused with Gottlieb Geilinger (1853-1927), a Swiss industrialist, nor
with Walter Geilinger, who collected plants in Africa in 1933.

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 222; BFM p. 285 (index); BL 2: 367, 658; IH 2:

*Geisenheyner, [Franz Adolf] Ludwig [Louis] (1841-1926), German botanist, born 8 Mar
1841 in Potsdam, began teaching at Bad Kreuznach gymnasium 1870, retired 1911, died 28
Jan 1926 in Bad Kreuznach. (<em>Geisenh</em>.).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: In TL-2/1: 930-931 his name was given as "Geisenheyner, Franz Adolf Louis" (sic).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Kreuznacher Heimatmuseum (30,000; orig. herb.), duplicates E,
GOET, IBF, L, POLL, WRSL.

2: 220; Kew 2: 392; Portr. 3: 471; Rehder 5(index): 314; TL-2/1: 930-931; Tucker 1: 273;

*Geitler, Lothar (1899-1990), Austrian algologist and cytologist, born 18 Mai 1899 in
Vienna, Ph.D. 1922 Univ. of Vienna (under Richard von Wettstein), prof. 1937 and dir.,
botanical garden from 1946, both Univ. of Vienna, Corr. member B.S.A., died 1 Mai 1990
in Vienna (false report of death in 1922). (<em>Geitl</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: LI, WU.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 222; Barnhart 2: 37; BFM p. 285 (index); GR p.
449; Hirsch p. 96; IH 2: 220; LS suppl. 9460; Moebius p. 76, 172; MW p. 136; Portr. 3:
471; TL-2/1: 931.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Intl. address book botanists: 18. 1931.
Friedmann, E.I., 1996. <em>In</em>, D.J. Garbary &amp; M.J. Wynne (eds.), Prominent phycologists of
	the 20th century, Hantsport, Nova Scotia (Lancelot Press): 11-20. (portr., p. 10)
Hesse, M., 1979. Pl. Syst. Evol. 131: 166-168. (bibl. [items 302-347])
Jaenicke, L., 2000. Protist 151: 353-365. (n.v.)

Titz, W., 1969. Oesterr. Bot. Z. 116: 6-17. (bibl. [items 1-301])
Weber, A., 1990. Pl. Syst. Evol. 172: i-ii.

Gelert, Otto Carl [Christian, Kristian] Leonor [Laurtis, Lauritz] (1862-1899), Danish
batologist and floristic taxonomist, born 9 Nov 1862 in Nybol, pharmacy examination 1883,
worked as a druggist then in a sugar refinery and finally at the Botanical Museum, Copenhagen,
visited Canary Islands 1897, died of consumption (phthisis) 20 Mar 1899 in
Copenhagen. (<em>Gelert</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: A, C (esp. <em>Rubus</em>), DBN, K, LD, LY, MANCH. – <em>Exsiccatae</em>: see
Friderichsen, [Peter] Kristian [Nikolaj] (1853-1932).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 222; Barnhart 2: 37 (as "Otto Kristian Lauritz
Gelert"); BL 1: 155, 297, 2: 457, 658; BM 6: 361; BN p. 23, 174; CSP 15: 253; IH 2: 209
(sub Friderichsen, Kristian), 220; KR p. 237; Rehder 5(index): 314; TL-2/3: 948 (index);
Tucker 1: 273; Urban-Berl. p. 349.

Gelting, Paul [Emil Elliot] (1905-1964), Danish lichenologist, born 30 Mar 1905 in Aakir-
keby/Bornholm, member of the Danish Three Year Exped. to Greenland 1931-1934, Ph.D.
1937 Copenhagen (subject: "Food of the E. Greenland Ptarmigan"), died 18 Feb 1964 in
Copenhagen. (<em>Gelting</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: C. – A few letters at GH (Archives).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 222; Collander p. 121; GR p. 677 (photo in 1937),
GR cat. p. 35, 64; Hawksworth p. 182; Kew 2: 393; SBC p. 120.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Hansen, A., 1964. Bot. Tidsskr. 60: 136-137.
Pringle, J.S., 1995. Canad. Field-Naturalist 109: 379. (index)

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Geltingia</em> Alstrup &amp; D. Hawksw. (1990).

Géneau de Lamarlière, [Jean Baptiste] Léon [Isidore] (1865-1903), French botanist, born
4 Apr 1865 in Tardinhem (Pas de Calais), Dr. ès-sciences 1893 Univ. of Paris, placed in
charge of courses at the School of Medicine and Pharmacy, Reims 1896, published some

PAGE: 174
HEADING: GENEVIER

80 papers on a wide range of botanical subjects, won two prizes and unexpectedly died 25
Sep 1903 in Reims. (<em>Géneau</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown (mosses at PC?).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 222; Barnhart 2: 37; BL 2: 178-179, 658; CSP 15:

Genevier, [Léon] Gaston (1830-1880), French pharmacist and botanist, born 18 Jun 1830
in Saint-Clément-de-la-Place (Maine-et-Loire) where he also was a student, took a dipl.
in pharmacy in Paris and settled in Mortagne-sur-Sèvre (Vendée) 1856, accepted official
position as inspector of mushrooms sold at Nantes 1867, died 11 Jul 1880 in Nantes.
(<em>Genev</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BM, BORD, C (Fungi), CGE (<em>Rubus</em>), CN, E-GL, P.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 222; Barnhart 2: 38; BL 2: 210, 658; BM 2: 654;
Bossert p. 142; CSP 2: 820, 12: 266; IH 2: 221 (b. "1831"); Jackson p. 286; Kelly p. 88;
Kew 2: 394; LS 9815-9817; Morren ed. 2: 20; Portr. 3: 472; PR ed. 2: 3271-3272; Rehder
5(index): 315; TL-2/4: 1171 (index, but leads to 2/3!); Tucker 1: 273, 3: 117.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Bouvet, G., 1881. Bull. Soc. Études Sci. Angers 10: 235-239.
Charpin, A. &amp; G.G. Aymonin, 2003. J. Bot. Soc. Bot. France 21: 72.
Charpin, A. &amp; J. Timbal, 2007. Acta Bot. Gallica 154: 451.
Dayrat, B., 2003. Botanistes fl. France: 473-479. (portr.)
Hedge, I.C. &amp; J.M. Lamond (eds.), 1970. Index collectors Edinburgh Herb.: 83.
Le Grand, A., 1891. Notices biogr. &amp; bibl. pour l'histoire de la botanique en Berry: 20.
Tourlet, E.H., 1905. Documents pour servir à l'historie de la botanique en Touraine: 58-60.
	[Reprinted from Bull. Soc. Pharm. Indre-et-Loire 1905]

PAGE: 176
HEADING: GENLIS

Genlis, (Caroline) Stéphanie Félicité (née du Crest de Saint-Aubin) (Comtesse de)
(1746-1830/1831), French writer, educator and botanical historian, born 25 [26?] Jan 1746
in Champcéry (nr. Autun), in 1762 married Charles Brillart de Genlis (1737-1793), a colo-
nel of grenadiers who later became Marquis de Sillery, lady in waiting to the duchess of
Chartres (i.e. Louise Marie Adélaïde de Bourbon-Penthièvre, 1753–1821, the mother of
Louis-Philippe I, 1773-1850) 1770, governess to the daughters and sons of the family, fled
to Switzerland during the Revolution 1793, moved to Berlin 1794 and then Hamburg, re-
turned to France during the Consulate 1799, died 31 Dec 1830 (or 1 Jan 1831) in Paris.
(<em>Genlis</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Baillon 2: 686; Barnhart 2: 38; Bossert p. 142; DBF 15:
1045-1049; Jackson p. 214 (as "[Brulart de Sillery, (S.F)]"); Kew 2: 394; Plesch p. 235;
Portr. 3: 472; PR ed. 1: 3564, ed. 2: 3273; Rehder 5(index): 315; Sotheby 1: 230; Tucker
1: 273-274.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Bearne, C.M.C., 1907. Heroines of French society in the court, the revolution, the
	empire and the restoration ... New York (E.P. Dutton and Co.): xxiv, 485, [1] p., front.,
	<em>pl</em>., portrs. (n.v.)
Bertaut, J., [1941]. Madame de Genlis ... Paris (B. Grasset): 291 p. (portr.) (n.v.)
Broglie, G. de, 1985. Madame de Genlis ... Paris (Librairie Académique Perrin): 528 p.
	[16] lvs. (n.v.)
Carpenter, M.M., 1953. Amer. Midl. Naturalist 50: 289. (as "... Félicitaté Ducrest ...")
Chabaud, L., 1901. Mesdames de Maintenon, de Genlis &amp; Campan, leur rôle dans l'éducation
	chrétienne de la femme ... Paris (Plon-Nourrit et cie.): 2 lvs., xxiv, 335 p. (n.v.)
Dobson, A., 1893. Four French women ... London (Chatto &amp; Windus): viii, 207 p. (n.v.);
	American ed. [1890], ... New York (Dodd, Mead and company): 6 lvs., 207 p., front.
	(portr). (n.v.); [1923] ... London, New York (H. Milford, Oxford University Press): 5
	lvs., [3]-212 p., front. (portrs.). (n.v.)

	lvs., 380 p. front. (portr.). (n.v.)

	rin): xii, 557 p., frontisp., <em>pl</em>. (portr.). (n.v.); English transl. ... 1913. A keeper of royal
	secrets, being the private and political life of Madame de Genlis ... London (E. Nash):

	American ed., 1960 ... New York (Roy Publishers): 304 p. (n.v.)

*Gennari, Patrizio (1820-1897), Italian botanist, born 24 Nov 1820 in Moresco (Ascoli
Piceno), studied medicine at Univ. of Macerata, M.D. (?) 1842 Bologna, Prof. of Botany
and Materia Medica, Univ. of Macerata 1844, served in the Austro-Sardinian War, Prof. and
dir. of Botanic Garden, both Univ. of Cagliari (Sardinia) 1866-1892, possibly collected in
Ethiopia in 1888 with L. Traversi, died 1 Feb 1897 in Cagliari. (<em>Gennari</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: TO, other material CAG?, CN, FI, GE, PC, W.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 3: 390; APN p. 223; Barnhart 2: 38; BL 2: 362, 389,
390; Bossert p. 142; CSP 2: 820, 7: 755, 12: 266, 15: 258; IH 2: 221; Jackson p. 549 (index);
Kew 2: 395; Morren ed. 2: 26, ed. 10: 82; PR ed. 1: 8157, ed. 2: 3274; Rehder 5(index): 315;
Saccardo 1: 80, 2: 53, cron. p. xxiii; Portr. 3: 472; TL-2/1: 931; Tucker 1: 274.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Burnat, E., 1883 [i.e. 1884]. Bull. Soc. Bot. France 30(SE 2): cxviii.
Cavillier, [Frère], 1941. Boissiera 5: 45-46.
Cufodontis, G., 1962. <em>In</em>, A. Fernandes, Compt. Rend. Réun. Plén. Assoc. pour Étude Taxon.
	Fl. Afrique Trop. 4: 235, 247. ("L. Traversi &amp; Gennari" in Ethiopia 1888)
Dörfler, I., 1909. Botaniker-Adressbuch: 98.
[Engelmann, W.], 1891. Botanisches Adressbuch: 99.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Gennaria</em> Parl. (1860).

in Saint-Macaire-du-Bois (Maine-et-Loire), prof. of natural sciences at Le Mans Lycée
1886-1906, died 13 Jul 1927 in Le Mans. (<em>Gentil</em>).

Gentil, Louis [Théodore Auguste François] (1874-1949), Belgian botanist, born Oct 1874
in Liège, trained at the School of Horticulture, Tournai, Belgium, employed by Petersham
nurseries, London, then Messrs. James Veitch &amp; Sons, Chelsea and finally the Royal Bo-
tanic Gardens, Kew 1896-1897, dir., coffee and cocoa plantations, Equatorville (now Mban-
daka), Congo Free State, Inspecteur forestier, Congo Free State, chief of culture 1902 at the
State Botanic Garden in Bruxelles, retired 1939. (<em>L. Gentil</em>).

PAGE: 180
HEADING: GENTILE

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Often confused with Louis Gentil (1868-1925), a French geologist and explorer in
n. Africa (Algeria and Morocco) who also collected plants.

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BR.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 223; Backer p. 651; Barnhart 2: 38; BM 6: 362;
Hortus 3: 1193; IH 2: 221 (excl. Morocco); Langman p. 312; Sotheby p. 230; TL-2/Suppl.
5: 429 (index); Tucker 1: 274, 3: 117; Zander ed. 11: 754, ed. 17: 949.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Gard. Chron., ser. 3, 179: 298. 24 Apr 1926. (obit., portr.)
B[artlett]., A.C., 1915. J. Kew Guild 3(22): 185. (portr.)

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: Co-author with E. De Wildeman:
(1) <em>Observ. Apocyn. latex</em> ... 1901 (TL-2/Suppl. 5, nr. 30.141); and
(2) <em>Lianes Caoutch</em>. ... 1904, see TL-2/Suppl. 5, nr. 30.151, where no credit is given Gentil.

Genty, Paul [-André] (1861-1955), French botanist, born 20 Oct 1861 in Dijon (Côte
d'Or), member of the Société Botanique de France from 1881, co-founder, Société bourgui-
gnonne d'histoire naturelle et de préhistoire, dir., Dijon Botanic Garden 1898-1955 (served
57 years!), died 10 Mai 1955 in the house where he was born. (<em>P.A. Genty</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: AUT, BR, E, MJSD.

*Georgia, Ada Eljiva (1859-1921), American botanist and educator, born in Newfield,
New York, daughter of a stone mason who helped build Cornell Univ., Ithaca, New York,
school teacher, Elmira, New York, asst. 1906-1911, Cornell Nature-Study Bureau, which
was directed by Liberty Hyde Bailey, and instructor in farm nature-study until 1920, died 8
Jan 1921 in Ithaca. (<em>Georgia</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 223; Barnhart 2: 39; BM 6: 364; Kew 2: 397; NAF
28B(2): 331. 1945; TL-2/1: 932; Tucker 3: 117.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Nature-Study Rev. 17: 94. 1921; Connell Rural School Leafl. 15(1): 174. 1921.
Comstock, A.B., 1923. Cornell Rural Sch. Leafl. 17(1): 55-57. (portr.)
Kohlstedt, S.G., 2005. Isis 96: 349, note 73.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Her major publication, <em>Man. weeds</em> ... 1914 (TL-2/1, nr. 1992), was treated earlier,
but that entry can be amended as follows:

	BM (n.v.), K (n.v.), LC (n.v.), NY(2), PH(2) (n.v.), US, USDA. – A volume in the series
	"The Rural Manuals", edited by Liberty Hyde Bailey (1858-1954), see TL-2/1: 94-96
	and Suppl. 1: 165-168.

PAGE: 183
HEADING: GEPP

Georgiev [Georgieff], Toma [Thoma] Coev (1883-x), Macedonian-born Bulgarian bota-
nist, born 15 Mar 1883 in Titov Veles, doctorate 1911 Sofia, asst. in applied botany, Faculty
of Agriculture, Sofia Univ. ca. 1931, specialist in <em>Cerastium</em> and <em>Hieracium</em>. (<em>T. Georgiev</em>).

<sm>OUTSIDE OUR PERIOD</sm>: <em>Opredelitel na divorastiashtite i kultivirani u nas duŭrvesni i
khrastovi vidove</em> ... 1956 [i.e. identification of Bulgarian trees and shrubs].

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: Co-author with: (1) N.A. Stojanov &amp; B. Stefanoff, <em>Für die Flora Bul-
gariens neue und seltene Pflanzen</em> ... 1928; and
(2) B. Stefanoff, Prinos za razgranichenie na vidovete na roda <em>Centaurea</em> L. ot <em>sect. Cyanus</em>
D.C. Beitrag zur Begrenzung der Arten der Gattung <em>Centaurea</em> L. von der <em>Sect. Cyanus</em>

*Gepp, Antony [Anthony] (1862-1955), British cryptogamic botanist, born 9 Mai 1862
in High Easter (Essex), B.A. 1885 Cambridge (St. John's College), hired as asst., BMNH

PAGE: 184
HEADING: GEPP

1886, Ph.D. 1889 Cambridge Univ., married fellow botanist Ethel Sarel Barton (1864-
1922) on 9 Jun 1902, retired 1927, member, Committee on Bryological Nomenclature
1929, F.L.S., died 16 Dec 1955. (<em>A. Gepp</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BM (incl. corr. and papers).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 223; Backer p. 651; Barnhart 2: 39; BL 1: 47, 68,
92, 121; BM 2: 660, 6: 364; Bossert p. 142; CSP 15: 262; Desmond p. 248, ed. 2: 274; GR
p. 398-399; Hirsch p. 96; IF suppl. 3: 209, 5: 354; Kew 2: 397; Lenley p. 179; LS 9830,
33.602; LS suppl. 9387; Portr. 3: 474; SBC p. 121; TL-2/1: 932, indices 2/1, 2/4, 2/5, Suppl.
1, 3; Tucker 3: 117.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., J. Bot. 65: 184. 1927. [retirement]; Intl. address book botanists: 181. 1931;

	paper]: 21 Dec 1955.

Mirecourt (Vosges), prof. of natural history, École centrale des Vosges, attached to the Mu-
séum natl. d'Histoire naturelle, Paris 1803, died 17 Jul 1816 in Paris. (<em>Gérardin</em>).

	that reach their northern-most extent in Germany.

Gérôme, Joseph (1863-1928), French horticulturist, born 29 Jun 1863 in Hadol (Vosges),
studied at the Ferme-École in Beaufroy (Vosges) and the École Natl. d'Horticulture in Ver-
sailles, joined the Muséum natl. d'Histoire naturelle, Paris in 1888 as an intern but rose to
asst. dir of the experimental garden before retirement, Légion d'honneur, died 31 Dec 1928
in Hadol. (<em>Gérôme</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 224; Barnhart 2: 42; BL 2: 102, 658; Hortus 3:
1193; Kew 2: 399-400; Langman p. 313; MW p. 137; Rehder 5(index): 318; TL-2/1: 1118
&amp; Suppl. 2: 459 (indices); Tucker 3: 117; Zander ed. 11: 754, ed. 17: 949.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Gard. Chron., ser. 3, 85: 90. 1929; Rev. Hort. 101: 328. 1929.
Bois, D.G.J.M., 1929. Bull. Mens. Soc. Nat. Hort. France, sér. 5, 2: 43-45. (portr.)
Bois, D.G.J.M., 1929. Bull. Mus. Natl. Hist. Nat., sér. 2, 1: 8-10.
Dörfler, I., 1896. Botaniker-Adressbuch: 59; 1902. Id., ed. 2: 76; 1909. Id., ed. 3: 110.

Gertz, Otto Daniel (1878-1948), Swedish geologist and botanist, born 20 Mai 1878 in
Malmö, fil. kand. 1900, fil. lic. 1905 and Ph.D. 1906 Lund Univ., docent at Lund to 1915,
also published on Linnaeus and O. Celsius, the Elder, died 15 Feb 1948. (<em>Gertz</em>).

Gheorghieff [Georgiev], Stefan [Stephan] (1859-1900), Russian-born Bulgarian botanist,
born 1 Aug 1859 in Bolgrad (Bessarabia), entered Prague Univ. in 1881, Leipzig in 1883,
Ph.D. 1887 Leipzig, prof. of botany, Sofia Univ., died 22 Mai 1900 in Sofia (Görbersdorf).
(<em>Gheorghieff</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 223 (as "Georgiev"); Barnhart 2: 43; BN p. 174;
CSP 15: 284; Langman p. 314; Rehder 5(index): 319.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Stanev, S., 2000. Piroda: Nauchnopopuliarno Spisanie (Sofia), no. 1-2: 136-141.
	(portr.) (n.v.)

(Separat-Abdruck aus dem Botanischen Centralblatt Band XXX/XXXI) ... 1887. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 1887, p. [i-iii, t.p. &amp; vita], [1]-67, <em>pl. 4-7</em> (double). <em>Copies</em>: G, LC (n.v.), MO (n.v.).

<em>Note</em>: This is Gheorghieff's Inaugural Dissertation.

Giacomini, Valerio (1914-1981), Italian bryogeographer, ecologist and conservationist,
born 21 Jan 1914 in Fagagna (Udine), enrolled Univ. of Pavia 1933, postgraduate work
in Jena, asst., agronomy faculty, Univ. of Florence 1940, imprisoned by the Wehrmacht in
Poland and n. Germany, freed by British troops 1945, returned to Florence 1946 and then
worked at a succession of Italian universities, died 6 Jan 1981 in Rome. (<em>Giacom</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: HBBS, PA, RO.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 225; Barnhart 2: 43; BFM p. 285 (index); BL 2:
334, 367, 659; DBI 54: 170-173; Ewan Pap. p. 78; GR p. 531; Hortus 3: 1193; Kew 2: 404;
Roon p. 43; SBC p. 121; Zander ed. 17: 949.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: De Marco, G. &amp; A. Dinelli, 1974. Ann. Bot. (Rome) 33: 209. [collected in Saudi
	Arabia 1967-1968]

PAGE: 194
HEADING: GIARD

Fuchs, H.P., 1991. Bull. Murith. Soc. Valais. Sci. Nat. 109: 146-148.
Gehu, J.M. et al. (eds.), 1988. Studi sulla flora e vegetazione d'Italia. Braun-Blanquetia: re-
	cueil de travaux de geobotanique 2: 225 p. (bibl.) [vol. in memory of Giacomini] (n.v.)
Miller, A.G. et al., 1982. Notes Roy. Bot. Gard. Edinburgh 40: 49. (bibl.)
Pirola, A., 1981. Arch. Bot. Biogeogr. Ital. 56(1-2): 1-2. (n.v.)
Pirola, A., 1980-1981 [i.e. 1983]. Atti Inst. Bot. Univ. Lab. Crittogam. Pavia 14 (ser. 6):
	xvii-xix.
Tomaselli, R., 1981. Inform. Bot. Ital. 13(1): 13-31. (bibl., portr.)
Wickens, G.E., 1982. Notes Roy. Bot. Gard. Edinburgh 40: 313.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Giacominia</em> Cif. &amp; Tomas. (1953).

<sm>OUTSIDE OUR PERIOD</sm>: (1) "Saggio fitogeografico sulle pteridofite d'Italia" [i.e. an appen-
dix] <em>in</em> A. Fiori, <em>Filicinae, Equisetinae, Lycopodinae</em> ... 1943.
(2) <em>Flora micologica dell'Agro Bresciano</em> (Hymenomyceteae, Helvellineae, Pezizineae)
... 1947.
(3) Co-author with Raffaele Ciferri (1897-1964) &amp; P. Poggio, <em>La Flora fanerogamica della
risaie dell'Italia transpadana</em>, &amp;c. ... 1949.
(4) Co-author with Raffaele Ciferri (1897-1964), <em>Nomenclator florae Italicae</em> ... 1950.
(5) Co-author with Sandro Pignatti (1930-x), <em>Flora</em> e <em>vegetazione</em> dell'Alta <em>Valle</em> del <em>Brau-
lio</em>,<em>con speciale riferimento ai pascoli di altitudine</em> ... 1955.
(6) Author with Luigi Fenaroli (1899-1980) &amp; Leo Ferlan (1928-1961), <em>La flora</em> ... Milano
(Touring club italiana) 1958.
(7) <em>Monografie sulla flora e vegetazione d'Italia</em> ... (Flora et Vegetatio Italica, Memoria
No. 1) 1959.
(8) <em>Il paesaggio vegetale</em> della provincia di <em>Sondrio</em> ... (Flora et Vegetatio Italica, Memoria
No. 3) 1960.
(9) <em>Italia verde</em> ... [Genoa?] (Shell italiana) [1970]; [Ed. 2], ... 1975.
(10) Co-author with Nunzio Longhitano &amp; Linneo Corti, <em>Cartography</em> of the <em>vegetation</em> of
the <em>Eastern (Hasa) Province</em> of <em>Saudi Arabia</em> ... 1979.
(11) Translated into Italian the English-language textbook <em>Introductory botany</em> ... ed. 2
(1971) by Arthur John Cronquist (1919-1992), which appeared as <em>Botanica</em> ... Bologna
(Zanichelli) 1979.

36.344. Eine heterotopische, postglaziale <em>Bryophytenkolonie</em> aus der <em>Adamogellogruppe</em>
(Italienische Zentralalpen) ... Leiden (Chronica Botanica Co.) 1938. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: Sep 1938 (in journal, p. 75 signed Apr 1938), cover-t.p., p. [68]-75. <em>Copy</em>: Gr-V. –
	Reprinted and to be cited from Ann. Bryol. 11: 68-75. 1938.

Giard, Alfred-Mathieu (1846-1908), French zoologist interested in entomophagous fungi,
born 8 Aug 1846 in Nord (Valenciennes), École normale supérieure, Paris 1869-1872,
named "préparateur" 1871, Dr. ès-sciences naturelles 1872, prof. "suppléant" 1873 and
"titulaire" 1880-1882, Faculty of Sciences, Lille, founder and dir., marine lab. at Wime-
reux (Pas de Calais) 1874, Député de Valenciennes 1882-1885, lecturer ("maître de confe-
rences"), École Normale Superiéure 1887, prof. and dir., Faculty of Sciences, Sorbonne
1888-1908, elected, Académie des Sciences 1900, died 8 Aug 1908 in Orsay (Essonne).
(<em>Giard</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 226; Barnhart 2: 44; BM 2: 672; CSP 7: 767,
9: 997-998, 12: 271 (63 papers!), 15: 286-290 (many papers!); De Toni 4: xxiv; DSB 5:
385-386, 15: 1437-1439; GR p. 323; Kelly p. 89; Kew 2: 404; Morren ed. 10: 64; Quenstedt
p. 162; Rehder 5(index): 320; Sarjeant p. 1089.

PAGE: 195
HEADING: GIARD

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: [Anon.?] Proc. Linn. Soc. 121: 40. 1909; Bull. Soc. Hist. Nat. Autun 22: (Proc.-
	Verb.) 14-19. 1909; Ann. Soc. Entomol. France 81: 237-270. 1912. (portr.)

	didate for the Chair of Comparative Anatomy at the Muséum d'Histoire Naturelle de

de Wimereux, vol. 7.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: Giard edited (1) <em>Bulletin scientifique du département du Nord et des
départements voisins</em>, vols. 10-18 (1879-1887) and, its successor (2) <em>Bulletin scientifique
de la France et de la Belgique</em>, vols. 19-42 (1888-1908), a bastion of Neo-Lamarckian
biology.

Giardelli de Bracco, María Luisa (?-1983), Argentinean botanist, began collecting
plants in 1935, taught at the Instituto Superior del Profesorado Secundario and in the
Colegio Nacional de Buenos Aires 1956-1966, specialist in Lemnaceae, died 14 Jan 1983.
(<em>Giardelli</em>).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: She signed her publications as "Giardelli", not "Giardelli de Bracco".

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: SI.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 226 (as "Giardelli"); Barnhart 2: 44 (as "Gi-
ardelli”); IH 2: 223 (as "Giardelli"); Kew 2: 404 (as "Giardelli").

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Darwiniana 25: 381-382. 1984 (as "Giardelli de Bracco").

<sm>OUTSIDE OUR PERIOD</sm>: Lemnaceae <em>in</em>: (1) A.L. Cabrera, <em>Fl. Prov. Buenos Aires</em> ... 1968;
and (2) M.N. Correa (ed.), <em>Fl. Patagónica</em> ... 1969.

Gibbes, Lewis [Louis] Reeve (1810-1894), American mathematician and naturalist, born
14 Aug 1810 in Charleston, South Carolina, attended Pendleton Academy, Pendleton, South
Carolina 1823-1827, graduated 1829 South Carolina College (now Univ. of South Caro-
lina, Columbia), held various teaching appointments while studying medicine, M.D. 1836
Medical College of the State, studied in Paris 1836-1837, prof. of mathematics and later
astronomy and physics, College of Charleston from 1838 (and for 54 years!), emeritus
1892, died 21 Nov 1894 in Charleston. (<em>Gibbes</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: CHARL (marine alg.), NY (1500 specimens), P, YU. – Papers of
Lewis Reeves [sic] Gibbes in LC; some corr. in GH, NY (John Torrey papers) and SIA.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 226; Barnhart 2: 44; Bossert p. 143; CSP 2:
871-872; Ewan Pap. p. 78; IH 2: 223; Lenley p. 180; Portr. 3: 477; PR ed. 1: 3624, ed. 2:
3317; Rehder 5(index): 320; Tucker 1: 277.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Tributes to Lewis R. Gibbes, 1810-1894: professor of astronomy and
	chemistry in the College of Charleston, 1838-1892. Professor emeritus, 1892-1894. (n.v.);
	Amer. J. Sci., ser. 3, 49: 80. 1895. (obit.)
Abbott, R.T. (ed.), 1973. Amer. Malacologists: 104.
Adler, K., 1989. Contr. hist. herpetology: 155.

Gee, W., 1918. South Carolina botanists: 42-45.

[Gibbes, L.R.], [1897]. Catalogue of herbarium, of Professor L.R. Gibbes, [Charleston,
	S.C.]: [1]-67. [<em>Copies</em>: HH, MO, NY] (4000 specimens)
Porcher, W.P., 1920. <em>In</em>, H.A. Kelly &amp; W.L. Burrage, Amer. Med. Biogr. 1: 434.
Sanders, A.E. &amp; W.D. Anderson, Jr., 1999. Nat. hist. investigations in South Carolina from
	colonial times to the present, Columbia, South Carolina (Univ. of South Carolina Press):
	318. (index) (portr.)

*Gibbs, Lilian Suzette [Susette] (1870-1925), British botanist, born 10 Sep 1870 in Lon-
don, attended Swanley Horticultural College 1899-1901, enrolled in the Dept. of Botany,
Royal College of Science (now Imperial College, London) 1901 where J.B. Farmer was her
prof., collected plants in the Alps, s. Rhodesia (now Zimbabwe) 1905, Fiji and New Zea-
land 1907, Mt. Kinabalu 1910 (and was the first woman to ascend to its summit), Iceland
1912, and the Arfak Mts. of New Guinea, Australia and Tasmania 1913, F.L.S. 1905, R.G.S.
1919, died 30 Jan 1925 in Santa Cruz, Teneriffe. (<em>Gibbs</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BM, duplicates in BO, K, L, MO, P (some ferns). – Papers in BM.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 226; Backer p. 233, 651; Barnhart 2: 44; BB p.
121; BL 1: 55, 69, 86, 108, 120; BM 6: 372; Desmond p. 249, ed. 2: 276; Hortus 3: 1193;
IH 2: 223; Kew 2: 405; Lenley p. 180; LS 33.624; LS suppl. 9541-9542; MW p. 137, suppl.
p. 74; SK 1: 190 (itin., portr.), 4: cxlvi, cl, 8: xxxviii; TL 2/1: 940, Suppl. 3: 545 (index):
Tucker 3: 118.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Nature 115: 345. 1925; Rep. Bot. Soc. Exch. Club Brit. Isles 7: 848. 1926;
	Times [London] [newspaper]: 14 Feb 1925. (n.v); Bot. Soc. Exch. Club Brit. Isles 7:
	848. 1926.
C[otton]., A.D., 1925. Bull. Misc. Inform. Kew 1925: 189.
Digby, L., 1925. Proc. Linn. Soc. London 1924-25: 72-74. (bibl. by B.D. Jackson)
Dörfler, I., 1909. Botaniker-Adressbuch, ed. 3: 157.
Godley, E.J., 2004. Newslett. New Zealand Bot. Soc. 77: 19-23. (n.v.)
Henriques, J.A., 1925. Bol. Soc. Broter., ser. 2, 3: 239-242. (portr.)
Mossman, F., 1979. Quart. Bull. Amer. Rhododendron Soc. 33: 224.
Quintanilha, A., 1925. Bol. Soc. Broter., ser. 2, 3: 329-341. (portr.)
Rendle, A.B., 1925. J. Bot. 63: 85, 116-117. (bibl. by J. Ardagh)
Sayre, G., 1975. Mem. New York Bot. Gard. 19: 327.

*Gibelli, Giuseppe [Josephus] (1831-1898), Italian /Austrian botanist and illustrator, born
9 Feb 1831 in Santa Cristina (Pavia) (then part of the Austro-Hungarian Empire), studied
medicine at Pavia Univ., Ph.D. 1854, taught at Veterinary school in Mailand, returned to
Pavia 1861, prof., Modena Botanic Garden 1874-1879, and then at botanical gardens in
Bologna 1879-1883 and Torino 1883-1898, died 16 Sep 1898 in Turin. (<em>Gibelli</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: TO, additional material DBN, FI, MANCH, MOD, NH, PAV.

PAGE: 200
HEADING: GIBELLI

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 6(1): 71; APN p. 226; Backer p. 651; Barnhart 2: 45;

Gibert, Ernesto José (1818-1886), French republican, botanist and photographer, born 3
Apr 1818 in Nogent-le-Rotrou (and almost certainly as "Ernest Joseph"), studied in Amiens,
then Paris, worked as a newspaper editor but his political beliefs compelled him to flee
France after the Jun 1848 uprising that ultimately led to the Second Empire (1852-1870),
exiled first in the U.S.A. (Calif.) and then in Chile where he began to study natural history,
after joining an exped. to study the flora of Paraguay he settled in Montevideo, Uruguay
1851, collected plants in Uruguay, neighboring Brazil and Paraguay, died 8 Mar 1886 in
Montevideo. (<em>Gibert</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: B, BAF (5000), CORD, GOET, K, LE, MVFQ, MVM (orig. in
Collección Arechavaleta), SI, W.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 226 (as "José Ernessto"); Barnhart 2: 45 (as "José
Ernesto"); BL 1: 297, 259; BM 2: 673 (as "Ernestus"); IH 2: 223; Jackson p. 377; Kew List
p. 26 (as "Ernest"); Morren ed. 10: 142 (at Montevideo, Uruguay); Rehder 5(index): 320;
Tucker 1: 277; Urban-Berl. p. 300; Wagenitz p. 63.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Arechavaleta, J., 1903. Fl. Uruguaya 2: xli-xlii.
Candolle, A.L., 1880. Phytographie: 415.
[Engelmann, W.], 1891. Botanisches Adressbuch: 150.

Gibson, George Stacey (1818-1883), British banker and amateur botanist, born 20 Jul
1818 in Saffron Walden (Essex), his Quaker family's fortune was founded on malting and
brewing and then banking (the family bank merged with others in 1863 to become Bar-
clays), mayor of Saffron Walden 1877-1878 and later alderman and Justice of the Peace
for the borough, F.L.S. 1847, died 5 Apr 1883 "at the Temperance House, Bishopsgate",
London. (<em>Gibson</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BM, BRSTM, CGE, CLR, HAMU, K, MANCH, NMW, SRD,
SWN (orig.); he also purchased part of the Lambert herb. (<em>fide</em> Miller, H.S, Taxon 19: 509.
1970). – Corr. and papers in the Saffron Walden Museum (Essex).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 226; Barnhart 2: 45; BB p. 122; BL 2: 239-240,
659; BM 2: 673; CSP 2: 873-874, 7: 770; Desmond p. 250, ed. 2: 276-277; DNB 7: 1155;
IH 2: 223; Jackson p. 252; Kent p. 56, ed. 2: 148; Kew 2: 407; Portr. 3: 477; PR ed. 2: 3322;
Rehder 5(index): 320; TL-2/5: 1031 (index); Tucker 1: 277; Zander ed. 17: 949.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Proc. Linnean Soc. London 1882-1883: 41-42. 1883; Herts and Essex Ob-
	server [newspaper?], 7, 14 and 21 Apr 1883: 8 p.
Boulger, G.S., 1883. J. Bot. 21: 161-165. (portr.)
Bridson, G.D.R. et al., 1980. Nat. hist. manuscript resources British Isles: 403. (index)

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: For eponyms based on the name Gibson see William Hamilton Gibson (TL-2/1).

Giesebrecht, Werner (1880-x), German apothecary and mycologist, born 29 Jan 1880 in
Stettin (now Szczecin, Poland), doctorate 1915 Würzburg. (<em>Giesbrecht</em>).

HEADING: GIESENHAGEN

*Giesenhagen, Karl [Carl] Friedrich Georg (1860-1928), German botanist, born 18 Jun
1860 in Teterow (Mecklenburg), doctorate 1889 (thesis on cystoliths in <em>Ficus elastica</em>)
and "Habilitation" 1890 Univ. of Marburg, asst., Munich botanical garden 1892, curator
of cryptogams and botany instructor, recipient of Buitenzorg stipendium (600 Marks) and
visited Malesia 1899, prof., Univ. of Munich 1901, prof. of botany, Munich Veterinary Col-
lege (Hochschule) 1906, died 8 Apr 1928 in Munich. (<em>Giesenh</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: M (orig.), H (some musc.).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 226; Backer p. 651; Barnhart 2: 46; Biol.-Dokum.
7: 80.499-80.523; BJI 1: 21; BM 2: 674-675, 6: 373; CSP 15: 296; DTS 1: 87; Frahm&amp;E.
p. 135-136 (portr.); Hirsch p. 98; IF p. 699, suppl. 4: 354; IH 2: 224; Kew 2: 407; LS
9958-9969, 33.639-33.640; LS suppl. 9569-9570; MW p. 137; NDB 6: 388-389 (d. "7 Apr");
Portr. 3: 478; Rehder 5(index): 320; SBC p. 121; SK 1: 190-191; TL-2/1: 941, indices 2/5,
Suppl. 4; Tucker 1: 277.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Bay, J.C., 1910. Flora Gesamt-Register 26-100: 13.
Dörfler, I., 1896. Botaniker-Adressbuch: 16; 1902. Id., ed. 2: 300; 1909. Id., ed. 3: 35.
Dunzinger, G., 1928. Ber. Deutsch. Bot. Ges. 46: (156)-(169). (bibl., portr.)
Dunzinger, G., 1928. Heil u. Gewürz-Pflanzen 11: 49-55. (portr.)
[Engelmann, W.], 1891. Botanisches Adressbuch: 17.
Giesenhagen, K., 1902. Auf Java und Sumatra, Leipzig: x, 270 p.
Goebel, K., 1928. Arch. Bot. Caen Bull. Mens. 2: 119.
Hertel, H. &amp; A. Schreiber, 1988. Mitt. Bot. Staatssamml. München 26: 316.
Jones, G.N., 1966. An annotated bibl. Mexican ferns: 74.
Pilger, R.K.F., 1929. Hedwigia 68 (Beibl.): 47, 48.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: (1) Published <em>Lehrbuch der Botanik</em> ... 1894, a text book that had 9 editions through
1924.
(2) <em>Niphobolus</em> ... 1901 (TL-2/1, nr. 2011) is now available in microfiche:
<em>Microfiche</em>: Westport, Conn. (Meckler/Chadwyck-Healey Publishing), [1987?], 4 micro-
	fiches (Plant taxonomic lit. microfiche coll., "8199D6-8202A4"). <em>Copy</em>: MO (n.v.).

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) Co-author with H. Christ, <em>Pteridographische Notizen</em> ... 1899
(TL-2/Suppl. 4, nr. 26.233).
(2) Giesenhagen et al., <em>Botanische Untersuchungen S. Schwendener</em> zum 10. Februar 1899
dargebracht ... Berlin (Verlag von Gebrüder Borntraeger) ... 1899 (see TL-2/5: 444-445),
a Festschrift in honor of Simon Schwendener (1829-1919).
(3) Wrote new text for <em>Jul. Hoffmanns Alpenflora für Alpenwanderer und Pflanzenfreunde
...</em> Stuttgart (E. Schweizerbart'sche Verlagsbuchh.) [1914], which was Ed. 2 of <em>Alpen-Flora
für Touristen und Pflanzenfreunde ...</em> 1902 by Julius Hoffmann (?-1904), neither title trea-
ted earlier in TL-2.

Giger, Emil (Heinrich) (1885-1962), Swiss botanist, born 17 Feb 1885 in Appenzell (Ct.
Appenzell), attended schools in Stein (St. Gallen), Dr. sc. Nat. 1912 Swiss Federal Univ.
Zurich, prof. at a girl's school ("a.d. Töchterschule"), Zurich, died 20 Jan 1962. (<em>Giger</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 46; SO p. 23 (index).

borealis</em>).

Gilbert, Benjamin Davis (1835-1907), American amateur botanist interested in ferns, born
21 Nov 1835 in Albany, New York, A.B. 1857 Hamilton College, Clinton, New York, book
trade 1860-1876, Utica, New York, literary and agricultural editor 1877-1888, Utica Morn-
ing Herald [newspaper], secretary 1892-1897, New York State Dairymen's Association,
died 3 Jun 1907 in Clayville, New York. (<em>B.D. Gilbert</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Bermuda (leg. 1898), Jamaica, Lesser Antilles: GH, NY, US; New
York: E, NYS. – Corr. in GH (George Edward Davenport papers).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 226; Barnhart 2: 47; CSP 12: 272, 15: 301; Ewan
Pap. p. 78; Hortus 3: 1193; IF suppl. 4: 354; IH 2: 224; Lenley p. 180; NW p. 46 (index),
Portr. 3: 479; Zander ed. 17: 949.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon. [Clute, W.N.?], 1901. Fern Bull. 9: 66. (portr.); Torreya 7: 132. 1907.
Chisholm, M.L., 1909. Fern Bull. 17: 115. [BDG herb. in Utica Public Library]

Gilbert, Édouard-Jean (1888-1954), French mycologist, born 13 Oct 1888 in Molles
(Allier), Dr. (pharmacy) 1918 Paris, subsquently devoted himself to mycology, died 20
Mar 1954 in Paris. (<em>É.-J. Gilbert</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

HEADING: GILBERT

Ostoya, P., 1958. Mycopath. Mycol. Appl. 9(2): 183-184.

HEADING: GILG

Gilbert, Edward Martinius (1875-1956), American mycologist, born 20 Sep 1875 in
Blair, Wisconsin, graduated 1901 Normal School, Stevens Point, Wisconsin, taught high
school in n. Wisconsin, Ph.B. 1907 and Ph.D. 1914, Univ. of Wisconsin at Madison, Asst.
Prof. 1913, Prof. 1922 and Chairman 1925, all Botany Dept., Univ. of Wisconsin at Madi-
son, retired 1946, died 23 Apr 1956 in San Marcos, Texas. (<em>E.M. Gilbert</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: WIS?

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Amer. Men Sci. 9: 402; APN p. 227; Barnhart 2: 47;
Hirsch p. 98; Lenley p. 180; LS suppl. 9593-9595; RUS 3: 254, 4: 256-257.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Madison Wisconsin State Journal [newspaper] 24 Apr 1956 (n.v.); Wis-
	consin Academy Rev. 3(3): 140. 1956 (portr.); Dictionary of Wisconsin History (elec-
	tronic resource).
Backus, M.P. &amp; H.C. Green, 1957. Mycologia 49: 151-155. (bibl. [7 works], portr.)

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: Co-author with: (1) Charles Elmer Allen, <em>Textbook of general botany</em>
... Boston, New York [etc.] (D.C. Heath &amp; Co.) 1917.
(2) Gilbert Morgan Smith et al., <em>A textbook of general botany</em> ... New York (Macmillan &amp;
Co.) 1924; Rev. ed., 1928; Ed. 3, 1935; and Ed. 4, 1942 (see TL-2/5: 673).

36.392. <em>Studies</em> on the <em>Tremellineae</em> of <em>Wisconsin</em> ... [Wisconsin Academy of Sciences,
Arts, and Letters] 1910. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: Oct 1910 (issue date on cover), cover-t.p., p. [1137]-1170, <em>pl. 82-83</em> (fold. phot.),
	<em>84</em> (phot.). <em>Copies</em>: MICH (n.v.), USDA-Mycol., WIS (n.v.). – Reprinted and to be cited
	from Trans. Wisconsin Acad. Sci. 16(Pt. 2, No. 4): 1137-1170, <em>pl. 82-84.</em> 1910.

*Gilg, Ernst [Friedrich] (1867-1933), prolific German systematist and pharmacologist,
born 12 Jan 1867 in Obereggenen (Baden), Ph.D. 1891 Berlin (under I. Urban), qualified
(habilitated) 1894, curator of the botanical museum 1902-1932, a.o. prof. of botany, Berlin
1906, died 11 Oct 1933 in Berlin. (<em>Gilg</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: B, duplicates K, P. – Some corr. in GH (Archives) and Univ. of
Cape Town (Bolus papers).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 227; Backer p. 234, 651; Barnhart 2: 48; Biol.-
Dokum. 7: 80.697-80.723; BJI 1: 21; BL 1: 27, 297; BM 2: 676, 6: 375; Bossert p. 144; CSP
15: 305; Ewan Pap. p. 78 (as "Eruss"); Hirsch p. 98; Hortus 3: 1193; IH 2: 224; Kew 2:
411-412; KR p. 241; Langman p. 315; MW p. 137; Portr. 3: 479-480; Rehder 5(index): 321;
RS p. 84; TL-2/1: 304 (sub Brandis), 941-942, indices 2/1, 2/3, 2/4, 2/5, 2/6, 2/7, Suppl.
1, 3, 5, 6; Tucker 1: 278, 3: 118; Urban-Berl. p. 349; Zander ed. 11: 755, ed. 17: 949; Zep.-
Tim. p. 52.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Intl. address book botanists: 137. 1931.

Wittrock, V.B., 1905. Acta Horti Berg. 3(3): 205.

HEADING: GILG

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Gilg published a number of papers with his wife, Charlotte Gilg-Benedict (née
Benedict) (fl. 1915-1936).

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) One of numerous authors with P. Ascherson, <em>Prop. Lois nom. bot.</em>
... [1892] (TL-2/Suppl. 1, nr. 19.614).
(2) One of several collaborators with A. Engler, <em>Verzeichniss Götzen'schen Expedition
Pflanzen</em> ... [1895] (TL-2/Suppl. 6, nr. 33.029).
(3) Co-author with K. Schumann of a botanical textbook, <em>Pflanzenr</em>. ... [1896] (TL-2/5, nr.
11.380).
(4) One of a number of signatories to A. Engler, <em>Nomenclaturregeln Berlin</em> ... 1897 (TL-2/
Suppl. 6, nr. 33.035).
(5) Authored two monographs in A. Engler, <em>Monogr. afrik. Pflanzen-Fam.</em> ... (see TL-2/1,
nr. 1709), viz.:
(a) <em>Melastomataceae</em>: 2: [i], [1]-52, <em>pl. 1-10.</em> Oct. 1898. <em>Copies</em>: G, K (n.v.), MO (n.v.).
(b) <em>Strophanthus</em>: 7: [i], [1]-48, <em>pl. 1-10.</em> Feb 1904. <em>Copies</em>: G, K (n.v.), MO (n.v.).
(6) Chapter 10 <em>in</em> R.E.B. Sadebeck, <em>Kulturgew. Deut. Kolon.</em> ... 1899 (TL-2/4, nr. 9971).
(7) Co-author ("Adjuvante") with I. Urban, <em>Monogr. Loas.</em> ... 1900 (TL-2/6, nr. 15.689).
(8) Collaborator with A. Zahlbruckner, <em>Pl. Pentherianae</em> ... Part I, 1900 (TL-2/7, nr.
18.507).
(9) First author with W. Busse, <em>Die von W. Busse in Deutsch-Ostafrika gesammelten Strych-
nos Arten</em> ... Part II, 1902) (see TL-2/Suppl. 3, nr. 23.958, Part II).
(10) Co-author with A. Engler of 12 families in O. Warburg, <em>Kunene-Sambesi-Exped</em>. ...
1903, see TL-2/7, nr. 16.665 and Suppl. 6, nrs. 33.068-33.079.
(11) Author or co-author of several parts (e.g. Loasaceae, Malesherbiaceae, Marcgravi-
aceae) of I. Urban (ed.), <em>Plantae novae andinae</em> ... 1906-1913 (TL-2/6, nr. 15.691).
(12) First author with R.C. Muschler, <em>Phanerogamen</em> ... Leipzig (Quelle &amp; Meyer) 1909,
see TL-2/3: 674 (sub Composite Works).
(13) Contributed determinations to Aug. Chevalier, <em>Sudania</em> ... Tome 1, 1911 [and 2, 1914]
(see TL-2/Suppl. 4, nr. 25.839).
(14) Assisted A. Engler ["mit Unterstützung von Dr. Ernst Gilg"], <em>Syllabus</em> ... Ed. 7, 1912,
8, 1919, &amp; 9 and 10 (a single issue), 1924 (see TL-2/1, nr. 1707).
(15) Authored Monimiaceae and Flacourtiaceae, at least, <em>in</em> C. Lauterbach, <em>Beitr. Fl. Pa-
puas.</em> ... 1912, 1924, see TL-2/2, nr. 4240.
(16) Co-editor with F. Pax &amp; L. Diels, <em>Engler-Fest-Band</em> der Botanischen Jahrbücher für
Systematik ... 1914.
(17) Authored Connaraceae and Loganiaceae <em>in</em> J. Schmidt, <em>Flora of Koh Chang</em> ... 1916
(TL-2/5, nr. 10.891).
(18) Collaborated with J. Wiesner, <em>Rohst. Pflanzenr.</em> ... ed. 4, 1927-1928 (TL-2/7, nr.
17.545).
(19) Authored Flacourtiaceae <em>in</em> F.L.E. Diel, <em>Descriptions species in British Papua</em> ... 1929,
(TL-2/Suppl. 5, nr. 30.500).

HEADING: GILIBERT

<em>Publ</em>.: 1920, p. 1-8. <em>Copy</em>: HH. – Reprinted and to be cited from Angew. Bot. 2: 1-8. 1920.

*Gilibert, Jean Emmanuel (1741-1814), French botanist, physician and politician, born
21 Jun 1741 in Saint-Clair (Lyon), studied medicine in Montpellier 1760-1763, at Chazay-
d'Azergues 1766-1768, through the intercession of A. von Haller and A. Gouan went to
Lithuania (Grodno and Vilnius) 1775-1783, where at the behest of Stanislas II (King of Po-
land) he was to modernize teaching of natural history and medicine, returned to Lyon 1783
and practiced medicine, played an active role in the French Revolution, elected "Girondist"
mayor of Lyon 1793, briefly imprisoned, returned to teaching 1796-1803, died 2 Sep 1814
in Lyon. (<em>Gilib</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: LY?, KRAM, KW; France (Lyon, leg. 1802): P-JU. It is question-
able whether the Gilibert collections at Kiev (KW) are complete and they may have been
transfered to Krakow (KRAM). Magnin stated that Gilibert's herbaria were given, at least
in part, to Alexis Jordan (1814-1897). If so, these specimens are to be sought in LY.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 227; Backer p. 234, 651; Baillon 2: 699; Barnhart
2: 48 (b. "20 Jun"); BM 2: 676; Bossert p. 144; DBF 16: 24-26; Dryander 5: 251 (index);
Frank 3(Anh.): 35; GFB Suppl. p. 96; GR p. 279-280; GR cat. p. 64; Herder p. 452 (index);
Hortus 3: 1193; IF p. 699; IF suppl. 4: 354; IH 2: 224; Jackson p. 550 (index); KR p. 459, nr.
168(b); Lasègue p. 400; Lenley p. 456; Lipschitz 3: 290-292 (bibl.); LS 9977-9980, 33.646;
NI 2: 67; Portr. 3: 480; PR ed. 1: 3630-3640, ed. 2: 3326-3331; Rehder 5(index): 322; SBC
p. 121; SO p. 23-24 (index); Sotheby 1: 234; TL-1: 170-171, 484; TL-2/1: 942-944, indices
2/2, 2/3, 2/4 (leads to 2/3!), 2/6, Suppl. 1; TR p. 92-95; Tucker 1: 278; Zander ed. 10: 603,
ed. 11: 755, ed. 17: 949.

	(Neriton): 72 p., [8] p., <em>pl</em>. (n.v.)

<sm>NOTE</sm>: (1) Four of Gilibert's works (TL-2/1, nrs. 2012-2015) are listed in the Appendix V
<em>Opera Utique Oppressa</em> of the 2006 Vienna <em>Code</em>. Names appearing in these works in the
ranks specified at the end of each listing (species and infraspecific taxa, in Gilibert's case)

PAGE: 214
HEADING: GILIBERT

are not to be accepted as validly published. This list was established by action of the Tokyo
Congr. (1993) and first appeared in the 1994 Tokyo <em>Code</em>.
(2) Christine Barker (Kew) pointed out several typographical errors associated with TL-2/1,
nrs. 2013 and 2015, involving the Latin word <em>Exercitium</em> (exercise), its plural <em>Exercitia</em>, and
its abbreviation, <em>Exerc</em>. In nr. 2013, the abbreviation "<em>Excerc</em>." should be "<em>Exerc</em>." In nr.
2015, the first title word "<em>Excercitia</em>" should be corrected to "<em>Exercitia</em>" and the abbrevia-
tion "<em>Excerc</em>." should be corrected to "<em>Exerc</em>.".
(3) A number of titles reprinted in <em>Syst. pl. Eur.</em> ... 1785-1787, 7 vols. (TL-2/1, nr. 2014) have
subsequently been analyzed in more detail in the later volumes of TL-2. These include:
(a) M. Alphonin, <em>Usum hist. nat.</em> ... 1766 (TL-2/Suppl. 1, nr. 19.316), "Reprinted in ... ed.
J.E. Gilibert, <em>Syst. pl. Eur.</em> 5: i-xix. 1786".
(b) J.A. Murray, <em>Vindic. nom. triv.</em> ... 1782 (TL-2/3, nr. 6574), "<em>Reprinted</em>: ... in Gilibert,
<em>Syst. pl. Europ.</em> 5: xlvii-lxxv. 1786".
(c) M.A.L.C. de Latourrette, <em>Chlor. lugd.</em> ... 1785 (TL-2/2, nr. 4231), "Reprinted in J.E.
Gilibert, <em>Syst. pl. Eur.</em> vol. 1, 1786 (no. 2014), (with a supplement; orig. text consists of
orig. sheets)".
(d) D. Villars, <em>Flora delphinalis</em> ... 1786 (see TL-2/6: 740), "in J.E. Gilibert, C. Linnaei
... Systema plantarum europae 1, 1785 (publ. Jun 1786), vii, 127 p. (Latin transl. of <em>Pro-
spectus</em>)".
(4) Several of Gilibert's works are now available in microform:
(a) <em>Fl. lit. inch.</em> ... 1781-1782 (TL-2/1, nr. 2012).
<em>Microfilm</em>: Ann Arbor, Michigan (University Microfilms), 2 reels (35 mm). <em>Copy</em>: NY (n.v.).
(b) <em>Amoen. acad. Gilibert ed.</em> ... 1782 (TL-2/3, nr. 4756).
<em>Microfiche</em>: New Canaan, Conn. (Readex Microprint), [1995], 34 microfiches (Landmarks
	II). <em>Copy</em>: (n.v.).
(c) <em>Caroli Linnaei fundamentorum botanicorum</em> ... 1786-1787, which was issued as "Car-
oli Linnaei botanicorum principis systema plantarum Europae, v[ols]. 5-7" (see TL-2/1,
nr. 2014).
<em>Microfiche</em>: [Zug, Switzerland?], IDC, [19–], 41 microfiches, 9×13 cm. <em>Copy</em>: MO (n.v.).
(d) <em>Exerc. phyt.</em> ... 1792 (TL-2/1, nr. 2015).
<em>Microfiche</em>: [Zug, Switzerland], IDC, [19–], 17 microfiches, 9×13 cm. <em>Copies</em>: MO (n.v.),
	USDA (n.v.).
(e) <em>Hist. pl. Europe</em> ... <em>Seconde édition</em> 1806 (TL-2/1, nr. 2016).
<em>Microfiche</em>: Naples, Florida (NewsBank), [2003], 46 microfiches (Landmarks II). <em>Copy</em>:
	(n.v.).

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) Edited <em>Amoen. acad. Gilibert ed.</em> ... 1786 (TL-2/3, nr. 4756).
(2) Contributed text (p. [i]-xxxvi) and edited G.F. Hoffmann, <em>Util. lich.</em> ... 1787 (TL-2/2,
nr. 2881).
(3) Edited and annotated M.A.L.C. de Latourrette, <em>Démonstr. élem. bot.</em> ... eds. 3, 1787, &amp;
4, 1796 (TL-2/2, nr. 4229). – <em>Note</em>: With respect to ed. 4, Gilibert copied the plates that were
used by J.D. Leers in the latter's <em>Fl. herborn.</em> ... 1775 (TL-2/2, nr. 4293).

36.430. <em>Methodi Linnæanae botanicæ delineatio</em>: exhibens characteres essentiales generum
necnon specierum, quae in demonstrationibus elementaribus botanicis describuntur, seu
plantarum in Europâ vulgarium, aut utilium &amp; curiosarum in hortis observandarum; additis
synonymis, necnon figuris præstantioribus, cum cujusque statione, tempore florendi, dura-
tione, &amp;c. ... Lugduni (Typis Jo. Mar. Bruyset) [1790]. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>: 1790 (date from Soulsby), p. [i]-xxiv, [1]-472, <em>pl. 9-11</em> (part fold., uncol. copper
	engr.). <em>Copies</em>: BM, K (plates wanting), MO (n.v.). <em>Microfiche</em>: Westport, Conn. (Meck-
	ler/Chadwyck-Healey Publishing), [1987?], 6 microfiches (Plant taxonomic lit. micro-
	fiche coll., "1942A1-1947B1"). <em>Copy</em>: MO (n.v.).
<em>Note</em>: Page 418 was misnumbered 428 and the error continues through p. 472 (i.e. misnum-
	bered p. 482).

PAGE: 215
HEADING: GILKEY

36.431. Le <em>calendrier</em> de <em>flore</em>, pour l'année 1778, autour de Grodno, et pour l'année 1808,
autour de Lyon ... Lyon (Chez Amable Leroy) 1809. Qu. 

<em>Co-author</em> [in part]: Lortet, Mme. Clémence (née Richard) (1772-1835), see TL-2/3: 164.
<em>Publ</em>.: 1809, h.t., p. [i], t.p., [i]-viii, [1]-88, 1 map (unnumb., uncol., fold., Lyon &amp; vicin-
	ity). <em>Copy</em>: BM.
<em>Note</em>: (1) Earlier Stafleu &amp; Cowan (TL-2/3: 164) wrote "Clémence Lortet contributed to
	publications by [J.-B.] Balbis and Gilibert; published – through Gilibert – a <em>Calendrier
	de Flore</em> (1809) ...." Their statement is mostly correct; she contributed to the Lyon por-
	tion, at least, of this calender, which is confirmed on p. vi where Gilibert mentions the
	zealous way in which Mme. Lortès (sic) botanized regularly around Lyon and how they
	pooled their data on flowering times. (2) Lyon data are presented on p. 1-48, 61-62 (as a
	suppl.) and 63-88 (index); Grodno data (gathered by Gilibert alone) on p. 49-60.

*Gilkey, Helen Margaret ('Hazel') (1886-1972), American mycologist, botanist and sci-
entific illustrator, born 6 Mar 1886 in Montesano, Washington, moved to Corvallis, Oregon
1903, B.S. 1907 and M.S. 1911 Oregon Agricultural College (now Oregon State Univ.),
Corvallis, Ph.D. 1915 Univ. of Calif. at Berkeley, scientific illustrator Univ. of Calif. at
Berkeley 1912-1918, asst. prof. of botany and curator of the herb., Oregon State Col-
lege, 1918-1927, assoc. prof. 1928-1945, prof. 1945-1951, died 7 Aug 1972 in Corvallis.
(<em>Gilkey</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: OSC, duplicates BUT, CUP, WVA. – Mss. materials in Oregon
State Univ. Archives (Helen M. Gilkey papers, 1907-1974) and Yale Univ. Library (Albert
[N.] and Celia Steward papers).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Amer. Men Sci. ed. 10: 1398; APN p. 227; Barnhart 2: 49;
BL 1: 209, 297; Bossert p. 144; Ewan Pap. p. 78; Frodin ed. 2: 166; Hawksworth p. 182;
Hirsch p. 98; IH 2: 225; Kelly p. 89; Kew 2: 412; Langman p. 315; Lenley p. 180; LS suppl.
9621-9623; NAF ser. 2(1): 32; NW p. 46 (index); Portr. 1: 63 (index), 3: 480; Roon p. 43;
TL-2/1: 944.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Intl. address book botanists: 472. 1931; Madroño 21: 539. 1972.
Constance, L., 1978. Botany at Berkeley: passim.
Cowan, R., 1973. Taxon 22: 708.
Hasselbring, B., 2003. The Scene (The Univ. Mag. of Willamette Univ.) 20(3): (electronic
	version).
Lawrence, G.H.M., 1969. Catalogue: A selection of 20th century botanical art &amp; illus.:
	48-49. (portr.)
Love, R., 1998. Bull. Native Plant Soc. Oregon 31(2): (electronic version).
Trappe, J.M., 1976. Mycologia 67: 207-213. (portr., frontisp.)

<sm>OUTSIDE OUR PERIOD</sm>: (1) <em>Northwestern American plants</em> ... Oregon State Monogr. Stud.
Bot. no. 9 ... 1945.
(2) <em>Weeds of the Pacific Northwest</em> ... [Corvallis, Oregon] (Oregon State College), xxix,
441 p. ... 1957; revised by La Rea J. Dennis (1935-x) as <em>Gilkey's Weeds of the Pacific
Northwest</em> ... [Corvallis, Oregon] (Oregon State University), 382 p. 1980.
(3) Co-author with Albert Newton Steward (1897-1959) &amp; La Rea J. Dennis (1935-x),
<em>Aquatic plants of the Pacific Northwest</em> ... Oregon State Monogr. Stud. Bot. no.11 ...
1960.
(4) First author with Patricia L. Packard (1927-x), <em>Winter twigs</em>: a wintertime key to de-
ciduous trees and shrubs of northwestern <em>Oregon</em> and western <em>Washington</em> ... Oregon State

<em>Note</em>: La Rea J[ohnston]. Dennis (1935-x), asst. curator of the herb. at Oregon State Univ.,
	later published as La Rea D[ennis]. Johnston.

HEADING: GILKINET

Gilkinet, [Charles] Alfred (1845-1926), Belgian mycologist and paleobotanist, born 21
Mai 1845 in Ensival, Dr. en sciences naturelles, prof. of pharmacy, Liége Univ. 1884, died
30 Sep 1926. (<em>Gilkinet</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BR.

225; Jackson p. 550 (index); Kelly p. 89-90; Morren ed. 10: 45; Portr. 3: 480; Quenstedt
p. 163.

PAGE: 218
HEADING: GILL

Gill, Lake Shore (1900-1969), American forest pathologist, born 25 Apr 1900 in San Fran-
cisco, Calif., A.B. 1923 and A.M. 1932 Stanford Univ., Palo Alto, Calif., Ph.D 1934 Yale
Univ., New Haven, Conn., Forest Pathologist, U.S.D.A. 1923-1960, visited Tanganyika
(now Tanzania) to investigate forest diseases ca. 1963, died 5 Jul 1969. (<em>L.S. Gill</em>).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Not to be confused with L.S. Gill (1940-x), who published on Labiatae and Nigerian
ethnobotany.

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: FPF (but dispersed to US and UC).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Amer. Men Sci. ed. 10: 1399; APN p. 227; Barnhart 2: 49;
Langman p. 315; NW p. 46 (index); LS suppl. 9624-9625; Tucker 3: 118.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Intl. address book botanists: 472. 1931.
Hawksworth, F.G. &amp; D. Wiens, 1972. USDA, Agric. Handbook 401: v. (dedication)

36.441. <em>Arceuthobium</em> in the <em>United States</em> ... New Haven, Conn. (Published by the Con-
necticut Academy of Arts and Sciences) 1935. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: Jul 1935 (date on t.p.), p. [111]-245, <em>pl</em>. <em>3-13</em> (uncol. phot.). <em>Copies</em>: BM, HH (n.v.),
	LC (n.v.), NY (n.v.), U, USDA-Mycol., WU. – Reprinted and to be cited from Trans.
	Conn. Acad. Arts Sci. 32: 111-245, <em>pl. 3-13.</em> 1935.
<em>Note</em>: (1) Descriptive letterpress on verso facing plates. (2) Publication based on Gill's
	Ph.D. thesis.

Gillespie, John Wynn (1901-1932), American botanist, A.M. 1926 Stanford Univ., Palo
Alto, Calif. (thesis entitled "Notes on the fungus Dicaeoma evadens ..."), Bernice P. Bishop
Museum Fellow, Yale Univ., New Haven, Conn., during which period he visited Fiji Jul
1927-Apr 1928, Research Associate in Botany, Bernice P. Bishop Museum 1928-1932,
Ph.D. 1930 Stanford Univ., Natl. Research Fellowship, Gray Herb., Harvard Univ., Cam-
bridge, Mass., appointed prof. of botany, Arizona State Teachers College (now Arizona
State Univ.), Tempe 1932, visited Kew summer 1932 and died of pneumonia on 13 Sep
1932 in Albany, Georgia, U.S.A. while enroute home. (<em>Gillespie</em>).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: His wife, Doris Kildale Gillespie (subsequently Niles) (1903-1995), also received
an A.M. (1927) and Ph.D. (1931) from Stanford Univ., assumed her husband's position in
Tempe after his death, then taught at the Humboldt Normal School (1927-1930) and Hum-
boldt State Univ. (1930-1950), both Arcata, Calif., and finally the Univ. of Calif. at Davis
(1960-1990). From 1982-1990, she published 20 illus. booklets in the Humboldt Co. Sci-
ence Series, many on Calif. botany. She is commemorated by <em>Dorisia</em> Gillespie (1933).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Fiji: BISH (orig.), duplicates A, AMES, BH, DS, GH, K, MO, NY,
UC, US and elsewhere; Panama: DS; s.w. U.S.A. and Mexico: A, DS, GH, NY, US. – Corr.
in GH (Archives).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 227; Barnhart 2: 49; BL 1: 108 (sub Seemann);
Ewan Pap. 78; IH 2: 225, 1154 (sub Wiggins); Tucker 3: 119.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Science, ser. 2, 66: 370. 1927 (Yale fellowship); Intl. address book bota-
	nists: 472. 1931; Science, ser. 2, 76: 289. 1932.
Gregory, H.E., 1930. Bernice P. Bishop Mus. Bull. 78: 15-16.
Gregory, H.E., 1931. Bernice P. Bishop Mus. Bull. 82: 13-14.
Gregory, H.E., 1932. Bernice P. Bishop Mus. Bull. 94: 12.
Gregory, H.E., 1933. Bernice P. Bishop Mus. Bull. 106: 11.
Keck, D.D., 1933. Madroño 2: 111.

Gillet, Abel (1857-1927), French teacher, bureaucrat and lichenologist, born 30 Oct 1857
in Chauffourt (Haute-Marne), teacher, Dépt. Côte-d'Or, then bureaucrat, Paris, died 12 Nov
1927, Saint-Mammès, nr. Moret-sur-Loing (Seine-et-Marne). (<em>A. Gillet</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown (possibly in herb. Maheu, PC).

*Gillet, Claude [Casimir] (1806-1896), French surgeon and veterinarian, born 19 Mai 1806 in
Dormans (Marne), joined military 1823, served in Africa from 1830-1834, Légion d'honneur
1847, settled in Alençon (Basse-Normandie), pensioned 1853 and devoted himself to botani-
cal studies, his first botanical publication appeared in 1862 and a decade later when he was 67
he began publishing his stunning mycological work, died 1 Sep 1896 in Alençon. (<em>Gill</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: PC.

*Gillot, [François-] Xavier (1842-1910), French botanist, physician and zoologist, born
[12 Sep?] 14 Nov 1842 in Roussillon-en-Morvan (Autun, Saòne-et-Loire), Dr. en médecine
1869 Paris where he worked with A.T. Brongniart on the local flora, but returned to Autun
where he cared for the sick and botanized (collecting and publishing) the remainder of his
life, died 18 Oct 1910 in Autun. (<em>Gillot</em>).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: He often published as "M. le Dr. X. Gillot" or "F.-X. Gillot".

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: AUT (orig., 50,000), duplicates BR, E, LY, MJSD.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 6(1): 76, 6(2): 45; APN p. 228; Barnhart 2: 50, 297;
BL 2: 115, 140, 195, 196, 659; BM 2: 678; BN p. 174; Bossert p. 145; CSP 7: 776, 9: 1011,
12: 274, 15: 312-313; DBF 16: 90; GR p. 324; IH 2: 225; Jackson p. 279, 288; Kelly p.
90; Kew 2: 417-418; LS 9996-10.021, 15.941, 15.947, 23.106, 33.649-33.658, 41.218-41.219;
Morren ed. 10: 59; NAF 9(6): 437; PFC 1: xliii, 2(2): xvi, 3(1): viii-ix, 3(2): x; Portr. 1:
63 (index); Rehder 5(index): 322; Saccardo 1: 82; TL-2/1: 947, indices 2/3, 2/4; Tucker 1:
278-279, 2: xvii, 3: 119.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bull. Soc. Bot. Deux-Sèvres 19: <em>pl. 9.</em> 1908.
Barbier, M., 1911. Bull. Soc. Mycol. France 27: 192-199. (bibl., portr.)

36.479. <em>L'empoisonnement</em> par les <em>champignons</em> et l'étude des champignons vénéneux ...

<em>Note</em>: Victor Gillot (1872-x), a son of and collaborator with X. Gillot on mushroom poi-
	soning, published on this subject independently, e.g. a 356 page thesis published 1900
	in Lyon: "Étude médicale sur l'empoissonnement par les champignons" (see Roth, Bot.
	Centralbl. 87(38): 421-422. 19 Sep 1901 (rev.)).

HEADING: GILMAN

36.486. Sur un variété de houx commun (<em>Ilex aquifolium</em> var. <em>aucubiformis</em>) ... Tours (Impr.
de Deslis Frères) 1904. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 1 Oct 1904, p. [1]-6. <em>Copy</em>: G. – Reprinted and to be cited from Rev. Bot. Syst.
	Géogr. Bot. 2(21): 135-140. 1904.

Gilman, Joseph Charles (1890-1966), American mycologist, born 23 Mar 1890 in Hast-
ings, Nebraska, B.S. 1912 and M.S. 1914 Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, Ph.D. 1915 Wash-
ington Univ., St. Louis, Prof. of Biology, Ripon College, Ripon, Wisconsin 1915-1918,
Asst. Plant Pathologist 1918-1921, Asst. Prof. 1921-1924, Assoc. Prof. 1924-1934 and Prof.
of Botany 1934-1966, all at Iowa State College (now Iowa State Univ.), Ames, Iowa, presi-
dent, Iowa Academy of Science 1945 and Mycological Society of Amer. 1951-1952, died
24 Dec 1966 in Ames. (<em>J.C. Gilman</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: FH. – Mss. in Univ. Archives, Iowa State Univ. Library (Joseph
Charles Gilman papers) and some corr. in NY (Archives).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Amer. Men. Sci. ed. 8: 899; APN p. 228; Barnhart 2:
50; Bossert p. 145; Hawksworth p. 182; Hirsch p. 98; Lenley p. 181; RUS ed. 3: 256, 4:
258-259; TL-2/4, Suppl. 1 (indices).

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Intl. address book botanists: 473. 1931; Mycologia 45: 1. 1953 (portr.).
Tiffany, L.H., 1967. Mycologia 59: 939-942. (portr.)

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) First author with W.A. Archer (1894-?), <em>The fungi of Iowa parasitic
on plants</em> ... [Jul] 1929, see TL-2/Suppl. 1, nr. 19.387.
(2) One of many collaborators with L.H. Pammel, <em>Weed fl. Iowa</em>, ed. 2 ... 1926, see TL-2/4,
nr. 7257.
(3) Editor, <em>Iowa State College Journal of Science</em> (1940-1948).
(4) Assoc. editor, <em>Phytopathology</em> (1932-1935).

Iowa, (The Collegiate Press, Inc.) 1945 [second printing, 1950]; ed. 2 (revised) ... 1957.

Gilmour, John Scott Lennox (1906-1986), English plant taxonomist and horticulturist, born
28 Sep 1906 in London, educated at Downs School nr. Uppingham, Uppingham School and
Clare College, Cambridge, curator of the Cambridge herb. and the Botanical Museum 1930-

PAGE: 227
HEADING: GILMOUR

1931, asst. dir., Kew 1931-1946 (except during W.W.-II when he served with Ministry of
Fuel and Power 1940-1944), dir., R.H.S. Garden, Wisley 1946-1951, dir., Botanical Gardens,
Cambridge 1951-1973 (retirement), chairman, Intl. Commission on Horticultural Taxonomy
1952-1966, secretary (later chair), Intl. Commission on the Nomencl. of Cult. Plants 1956-
1965, R.H.S. Victoria Medal of Honour 1957, died 3 Jun 1986 in Cambridge. (<em>Gilmour</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: CGE, K, NMW, UPP (now LSR). – A few letters are at BMNH.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 228; Barnhart 2: 51; BL 2: 296, 659; Bossert p.

HEADING: GINZBERGER

Ginzberger, August Ferdinand Karl (1873-1940), Austrian botanist, born 1 Jul 1873 in
Vienna, Ph.D. 1896 Vienna, worked in various capacities at the Botanical Garden and Mu-
seum, Vienna 1900-1923, qualified (habilitated) 1923 Univ. of Vienna, traveled to Brazil
1927, prof. 1929, died 26 Mar 1940 in Remscheid, Germany. (<em>Ginzb</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Brazil (1927): F, WU (orig.); Dalmatia (1896-1925): GB, LI, W,
WU (orig.); Spain (1924): GB. – Mss. materials in the Archive and History of Science
Dept., Natural History Museum Vienna.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 228; Barnhart 2: 51; DTS 1: 87-88; Futak-Domin
p. 219; GR p. 450; Hirsch p. 99; IH 2: 226; Kew 2: 421; Langman p. 316; ÖBL 1: 444;
Rehder 5(index): 322; SBC p. 121; Strid p. 131, ed. 2: 181; TL-2/Suppl. 4: 609 (index);
Tucker 1: 279.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Intl. address book botanists: 19. 1931; Oesterr. Bot. Z. 89: 256. 1940.
	(death notice)
Dörfler, I., 1896. Botaniker-Adressbuch: 112; 1902. Id., ed. 2: 152; 1909. Id., ed. 3: 215.
Grönblad, R.[L]., 1945. Acta Soc. Sci. Fennicae, n.s., B, 2(6): 1-43, <em>pl. 1-16.</em> (G's Amazo-
	nian alg. collections)
Schlesinger, G., 1940. Blätt. Naturk. Naturgesch. 27: 56-57.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Ginzbergerella</em> Zahlbr. (1931).

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: As part of the program for the Second Intl. Bot. Congr. (1905) in Vi-
enna, Ginzberger co-authored two of the six excursion guides published shortly in advance
of the Congress, see <em>Führer Exc. Kongr. Wien</em> ... 1905 (TL-2/Suppl. 4, nr. 26.421).

Giordano, Giuseppe Camillo (1841-1901), Italian bryologist, born 1 Mar 1841 in Pomarico
(Basilicata), educated in Matera, studied at the Royal Technical and Nautical Inst.,
Naples, student of N.A. Pedicino, taught natural history in secondary school and ultimately
prof. at the Technical Inst., Naples, died 17 Nov 1901 in Bernalda (Basilicata) nr. Naples.
(<em>G.C. Giord.</em>).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Not to be confused with G. Giordano (fl. 1937-1941), a forestry inspector of the Italian
colonial government who collected plants in Ethiopia.

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: FI, NAP, RO. <em>Note</em>: He bequethed his herb. to the Technical Inst.,
Naples, and it presumably now is deposited in NAP.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 228; Barnhart 2: 51; BL 2: 342, 659; Bossert p.
145; CSP 12: 275, 15: 317; Herder p. 263; Jackson p. 319; Morren ed. 10: 85; Portr. 3: 482;
Rehder 5(index): 322; Saccardo 1: 83.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Boudier, [M.], 1901 [i.e. 1902 (sero)-Jun 1904]. Bull. Soc. Bot. France 48(8-9):
	404-405. (as "Joseph-Camille")

Girard, [Eugène Sylvain] Frédéric de (1809-1850), French botanist, born 28 Jul 1809 in
Agde (Hérault), studied with Aug. St.-Hilaire and helped him publish on the flora of Brazil,
died 21 Oct 1850 in Montpellier. (<em>Girard</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: MPU (orig.); France: FI, PC.

("1810-1851").

Gislén, Torsten Rikard [Richard] Emanuel (1893-1954), Swedish plant anatomist and

Uppsala Univ., secondary school teacher, appointed Prof., Lund Univ. 1932, also dir. Lim-
nological stations in Lund and Aneboda 1934-1945. (<em>Gislén</em>).
