Glatfelter, Noah Miller (1837-1911), American physician and salicologist, born 28 Nov
1837 in York, Penn., M.D. 1864 Univ. of Penn. (thesis on hospital gangrene), commis-
sioned as Asst. Surgeon U.S. Volunteers and served in the Dakota Territories until 1867
when he settled in St. Louis at which time he began collecting and paying attention to <em>Salix</em>,
and then later to Hymenomycetes, died 2 Apr 1911 in St. Louis. (<em>Glatf</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: MO (orig.), duplicates A, K, MICH, MIN, NY.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 229; Barnhart 2: 54; CSP 15: 332; IH 2: 227; Kelly
p. 91; Kew 2: 424; LS 10.058; Pennell p. 607; Rehder 5(index): 324; Tucker 1: 280.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Dörfler, I., 1902. Botaniker-Adressbuch, ed. 2: 251; 1909. Id., ed. 3: 331.
Mohlenbrock, R.H., 1982. Ann. Missouri Bot. Gard. 69: 389.
Spaulding, P., 1909. Popular Sci. Monthly 74: 256-257. (portr.)

*Gleason, Henry Allan (1882-1975), American botanist, pioneer ecologist and plant ge-
ographer, born 2 Jan 1882 in Dalton City, Illinois, published his first paper at age 13, B.Sc.

PAGE: 232
HEADING: GLEASON

1901 and M.A. 1904 Univ. of Illinois (and teaching there 1906-1910), Ph.D. 1906 Columbia
Univ., New York, New York (under N.L. Britton), taught at Univ. of Michigan 1910-1919,
traveled to Philippines, Java and Ceylon 1913-1914, held various research and administra-
tive positions at New York Botanical Garden from 1919 until his retirement Dec 1950, first
president (and one of the organizers) of A.S.P.T. 1937, president B.S.A. 1948, specialist on
Melastomataceae, died 21 Apr 1975 at the home of his son in Toronto, Canada. (<em>Gleason</em>).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Gleason's son, Henry Allan, Jr. (1917-2007), was a linguist but also privately pub-
lished booklet entitled <em>Mosses and moss collecting</em> ... [Hartford, Conn.] 34 p. 1950.
<em>Copy</em>: NY (n.v.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: mostly at NY (see IH 2: 227, for details). – Extensive mss. Ma-
terials at NY (Henry Allan Gleason papers), which include a card file with notes (proto-
logues, sketches, measurements, phot.) on neotropical Melastomataceae. The card file was
extensively annotated by John J. Wurdack (1921-1998) while on extended loan to US (now
returned to NY).

p. 44; SK 1: 194; TL-1: 52; TL-2/1: 950-951, 2/5: 1031 (index); SK: 194; Tucker 3: 119;
Zander ed. 17: 949.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: (additional) <em>Neogleasonia</em> Maguire (1972); also Henry Allan Gleason Award
of the New York Botanical Garden; and Henry Allan Gleason Nature Preserve, Mason
Co., Illinois.

<sm>OUTSIDE OUR PERIOD</sm>: (1) Responsible for <em>The new Britton and Brown illustrated flora</em> ...
1952, 3 vols. (and subsequent printings through 1968), which is a revision of N.L. Britton
&amp; A. Brown, <em>Ill. fl. n. U.S.</em> ... 1896-1898 (see TL-2/1, nr. 778).
(2) Gleason &amp; Arthur John Cronquist (1919-1992), <em>Manual of the vascular plants of north-
eastern United States and adjacent Canada</em> ... 1963; Ed. 2, ... 1991, ... 7th printing ...
2004. – <em>Note</em>: See also, Noel H[erman]. Holmgren, <em>Illustrated companion to Gleason and
Cronquist's manual</em> ... 1998; Reprinted with corr. ... 2004.
(3) Gleason &amp; Arthur John Cronquist (1919-1992), <em>The natural geography of plants</em> ...
1964. <sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) Co-author with W.A. Kellerman &amp; John Henry Schaffner (1866-
1939), <em>Spring flora for beginners and amateurs</em> ... Eds. 2 (1906) and 3 (1914), which were
based on Kellerman, <em>Spring fl. Ohio</em> ... 1895 (TL-2/2, nr. 3572).
(2) Co-author with Charles Arthur Hart (1859-1918), "On the <em>biology</em> of the <em>sand areas</em>
of <em>Illinois</em>", Bull. Illinois State Lab. Nat. Hist. 7(7): cover-t.p., map (frontisp.), t.p., p. [i,
contents], 137-272 [errata], <em>pl. 8-23</em> (uncol. phot.). Jan 1907.
(3) Co-author with Melville Thurston Cook (1869-1952), "<em>Ecological survey</em> of the <em>flora</em>
of <em>Porto Rico</em>", J. Dept. Agric. Porto Rico 12(1-2): 139 p., <em>pl</em>., maps. 1928. – <em>Note</em>: This is
a popularized version of "<em>Plant ecology</em> of <em>Porto Rico</em>", which appeared in the <em>Scientific
survey of Porto Rico and the Virgin Islands</em> 7(1): 1-96, <em>pl. 1-20</em>, Id. 7(2): 97-173, <em>pl. 21-50</em>
(1926 [i.e. 1927]). The plant taxonomic parts of the Scientific survey ... were treated under
N.L. Britton (see TL-2/1, nr. 788).
(4) Author with A.C. Smith (1906-1999), <em>Plantae krukovianae</em> ... 1933-1939 (see TL-2/5,
nr. 12.164). – <em>Note</em>: Gleason was first author of parts 1 &amp; 2, sole author of part 3 and Smith
was sole author of parts 4-6.
(5) Co-founder and editor with Harold Norman Moldenke (1909-1996) of the serial <em>Phyto-
logia</em>, vol. 1-3(7) (Dec 1933-Dec 1950).
(6) Melastomaceae <em>in</em> A.A. Pulle (ed.), <em>Fl. Suriname</em> ... vol. 3(1): 178-281. Jun 1935 (see
TL-2/4, nr. 8393).
(7) Founder and asst. editor with Edmund Henry Fulling (1903-1975), <em>The Botanical Re-
view</em>, vol. 1-3 (Jan 1935-Dec 1937).
(8) One of several collaborators with A.C. Smith, <em>A collection of flowering plants from
Mount Roraima</em> ... 1940 (see TL-2/5, nr. 12.172).
(9) Editor (or associate editor), at various times, of (a) <em>Addisonia</em>; (b) <em>Bulletin of the New
York Botanical Garden</em>; (c) <em>Bulletin of the Torrey Botanical Club</em>; and (d) <em>Garden Journal
of New York Botanical Garden</em> (precise details wanting).

*Gleditsch, Johann Gottlieb (1714-1786), German botanist and sylviculturist, born 5 Feb
1714 in Leipzig, doctorate 1730 Leipzig, curator in Leipzig 1731-1735, Dr. med. 1742 Univ.
Frankfurt/Oder, first Dir. (Praefectus) Berlin Botanical Garden 1744-1786 and other posts
in forestry, died 5 Oct 1786 in Berlin. (<em>Gled</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: The Gleditsch herb., acquired by the Berlin Academy of Sciences
in 1791, is lost. The <em>Berichte über die ... Verhandlungen der Königl. Preuss. Akademie der
Wissenschaften zu Berlin</em> for the year 1840 contains a statement on p. 81 that H. Goeppert
showed a 'Verzeichnis' of the former Gleditsch herb., and a further note on p. 119 in which
Link presented this register "mit der Bemerkung das dieses Herbarium nicht mehr vorhan-

PAGE: 241
HEADING: GŁOWACKI

den sei". Urban could not trace the collection either. Gleditsch was a corr. of Linnaeus and
there are plants collected by him in LINN.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: ADB 9: 224-225; AG 6(2): 182; Ainsworth p. 342 (index);
APN p. 229; Backer p. 236, 651; Baillon 2: 706; Barnhart 2: 54; BM 2: 682-683, 6: 379;
Bossert p. 146; De Toni 1: l-li; Dryander 5: 253 (index); Frank 3(Anh.): 35; GR p. 15-16;
HA 2: 293-295, 404, 700; Herder p. 452 (index); Hortus 3: 1193; IF p. 699; IF suppl. 4:
354; IH 2: 227; Jackson p. 16, 297, 430; Kelly p. 91; Kew 2: 425; Langman p. 317; LS
10.059-10.072; Mägdefrau p. 310 (index); Moebius p. 450 (index); NDB 6: 442-443; Portr.
3: 484; PR ed. 1: 3352-3365, ed. 2: 3668-3685; Quenstedt p. 165; Ratzeburg 1: 187-190;
Rehder 5(index): 324-325; RS p. 85; SO p. 24 (index); TL-1: 171-172; TL-2/1: 951-952,
indices 2/4, 2/5, 2/7, Suppl. 2, 3; Tucker 1: 280; Urban-Berl. p. 11, 349; Zander ed. 10: 603,
ed. 11: 755, ed. 17: 949; Zep.-Tim. p. 53-54.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Nouv. Mém. Acad. Sci. [Berlin] Hist.: 49-54. 1788. (n.v.)
Ascherson, P., 1860. Fl. Prov. Brandenburg 1: 5.

	Naturkunde vol. 3]: 301-314. (portr.)

	Charakter ... Aerzte und Naturforscher 4(95). (n.v.)

Scholz, H., 1987. Englera 7: 283. (index)

Stafleu, F.A., 1972. <em>In</em>, G.S. Daniels &amp; F.A. Stafleu, Taxon 28: 298. (portr.)
Timler, F.K. &amp; B. Zepernick, 1978. Der Berliner Botanische Garten, Berlin (Presse- und
	Informationsamt des Landes Berlin): 1-94. (portr.)

	Professor Dr. Johann Gottlieb Gleditsch. Zürich: 111 p. (biogr., letters, portr., etc.)
Wittrock, V.B., 1903. Acta Horti Berg. 3(2): 117. 1905. Id. 3(3): 125.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: (additional) <em>Gleditschiacanthus</em> Lakow. (1895); <em>Gleditsiophyllum</em> E.W. Berry
(1910); <em>Gleditsioxylon</em> Müll.-Stoll &amp; E. Mädel (1967).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: One of Gleditsch's 1753 works, "<em>Observation sur la pneumonanthe</em> ..." (not treated
in TL-2) is listed in the Appendix V "Opera Utique Oppressa" of the 2006 Vienna <em>Code</em>.
Names appearing in these works in the ranks specified at the end of each listing are not to
be accepted as validly published (in this case all ranks). This list was established by action
of the Tokyo Congr. (1993) and first appeared in the 1994 Tokyo <em>Code</em>.

*Głowacki, Julius [Julij] (1846-1915), Austrian bryologist also interested in lich., born 18
Jun 1846 in Idria (Krain, now Slovenia), studied in Vienna and Graz, middle school prof.

PAGE: 242
HEADING: GŁOWACKI

from 1870 in various towns, dir. of the gymnasium in Marburg (now Slovenia) 1899-1911,
died 18 Mai 1915 in Graz. (<em>Glow</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: GJO, further material E, FR, GOET, GZU, KL, LD, M, PC,
POLL.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 230; Barnhart 1: 55; BM 6: 379; CSP 7: 789, 15:
340; Frahm&amp;E. p. 136-137 (bibl., portr.); GR p. 450; IH 2: 227; Jackson p. 161; Kelly p. 91;
LS 10.076-10.081; Morren ed. 10: 37; ÖBL 2: 11; Saccardo 1: 83-84; SBC p. 121; TL-2/1:
953-954, Suppl. 1: 448 (index); Wagenitz p. 64.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bot. Not. 1915: iii. 1915.
Breidler, J., 1914. Mitt. Naturwiss. Vereins Steiermark 50: 3-7. (port.)
Breidler, J., 1914. Oesterr. Bot. Z. 64: 39-43.
Dörfler, I., 1896. Botaniker-Adressbuch: 112; 1902. Id., ed. 2: 152; 1909. Id., ed. 3: 215.
[Engelmann, W.], 1891. Botanisches Adressbuch: 47.
Hedge, I.C. &amp; J.M. Lamond (eds.), 1970. Index collectors Edinburgh Herb.: 84.
Hertel, H. &amp; A. Schreiber, 1988. Mitt. Bot. Staatssamml. München 26: 158, 219.
Knapp, F., 1912. Jahresber. K.K. Staatsgymnasiums Marburg 1911/12: 3-5. (bibl., portr.)

*Glück, [Christian Maximilian] Hugo (1868-1940), German botanist specializing in
aquatic plants, born 13 Dec 1868 in Windsheim on the Aisch (Bavaria), Ph.D. 1895 Mu-
nich, habilitation 1899 Heidelberg, Prof. of Botany and Pharmacognosy, Heidelberg Univ.
1903, died 28 Sep 1940 in Heidelberg. (<em>Glück</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: B, BM, DUKE, NMW, NY, PH.

Gmelin family. The genealogy of this family that contributed greatly to Botany is analyzed
in [Moriz Gmelin], <em>Stammbaum der Familie Gmelin</em> 1877 (n.v.). The "botanical" Gmelins

PAGE: 246
HEADING: GMELIN

essentially begin with Johann Georg Gmelin (1674-1728) who defended a botanical thesis
under Rudolf Jakob Camerarius in 1699, married in 1706, and had three "key" children and
three "key" grandchildren:
1. Johann Konrad Gmelin (1707-1759) who had 15 children, incl.:
	*Samuel Gottlieb Gmelin (1745-1774) (TL-2/1: 958) who traveled in s. Russia with
	P.S. Pallas and died in Persia; and Christian Gottlieb Gmelin (1749-1809) who had a
	connection with Goethe.
2. *Johann Georg Gmelin (1709-1755) (TL-2/1: 956-957) who traveled in Siberia, be-
	came Prof. of Bot. and Chemistry in Tübingen, and published <em>Fl. siber.</em> ... 1747-1769,
	4 vols. (TL-2/1, nr. 2047), the last 2 vols. of which were edited by his nephew, *Samuel
	Gottlieb Gmelin (see above).
3. *Philipp Friedrich Gmelin (1721-1768) (TL-2/1: 957-958), also of Tübingen who had
	the following sons: *Johann Friedrich Gmelin (1748-1804), (TL-2/1: 955-956), Prof. at
	Tübingen, then at Göttingen, editor of the 13th (i.e. the last) ed. of <em>Syst. nat.</em> ... 1788-1793
	(TL-2/1, nr. 2043); and *Carl Christian Gmelin (1762-1837) (TL-2/1: 954-955), author
	of <em>Fl. bad.</em> ... 1805-1826, 4 vols. (TL-2/1, nr. 2040).

*Gmelin, Carl [Karl] Christian (1762-1837), German physician and naturalist, born 18
Mar 1762 in Badenweiler nr. Freiburg, studied, Univ. of Strassburg, Dr. of medicine 1784
Friedrich-Alexander-Univ., Erlangen, prof. of natural sciences and dir. from 1786 of the
botanical garden at Karlsruhe, died 26 Jun 1837 in Karlsruhe (Baden-Württemberg). (<em>C.C.
Gmel.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm> [previously listed as unknown]: MPU (musc., "Collectionem mus-
Corum in Germania lectorum").

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: ADB 9: 271-272; AG 2(1): 264; APN p. 230; Baillon 2:
714; Barnhart 2: 55; BM 2: 684; Bossert, p. 146; CSP 6: 672; Dryander, 5: 254 (index);
Frahm&amp;E. p. 138-139 (portr.); Herder p. 452 (index); Hortus 3: 1193; HU 2(2): nr, 531;
Jackson p. 425; NDB 6: 478; Portr. 3: 485; PR ed 1: 3708-3712, ed. 2: 3387-3391; TL-2/1:
954-955; Tucker 1: 281, 3: 120; Zander ed. 17: 949.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Burdet, H., 1974. Candollea 29: 503-504. (handwr.)
Burdet, H.M., 1979. Auxilium ad botanicorum graphicem: [sub Gmelin, Carl Christian].
	(handwr.)
Fürst, R., 1989. Carl Christian Gmelin und die "Flora Badensis Alsatica et confinium region-
	num cis et transrhenana": die Entstehung des ersten botanischen Handbuches Badens in
	der C.F. Müller'schen Hofbuchdruckerei 1805-1833: eine Dokumentation zur Verlagsge-
	schichte, Karlsruhe (C.F. Müller): 32 p. (n.v.)

	(n.v.)

	fiches (Plant taxonomic lit. microfiche coll., "1963A6-1966B2"). <em>Copy</em>: MO (n.v.).

36.584. <em>Consideratio generalis filicum</em>, quam summi numinis auspicio Academiae Fride-
rico Alexanderinae ... ex decreto gratiosae facultatis medicae pro gradu doctoris legitime
obtinendo D. aprilis ... MDCCLXXXIV solemni ervditorum examini submittit Carolus

PAGE: 247
HEADING: GOBI

<em>Publ</em>.: Apr 1784, p. [i]-lxiii, [corrigenda]. <em>Copies</em>: BM (n.v.), NY (n.v.), US. <em>Microfilm</em>:
	London (British Library), 1991, 1 reel (194 fr., 35 mm). <em>Copy</em>: (n.v.).
<em>Note</em>: Inaugural dissertation, Erlangen.

*Gobi [Ghobi], Christoph [Christopher, Christophos, Christophus, Khristofer, Khristofor,
Khristov, Kristofer, Kristofor] Iakovlevich [Iakovlevitch, Jakoblewitsch, Jakosolewitsch,
Jakovlevich, Jakowlewitsch, Yakovlevich] (1847-1919), Russian mycologist and phycolo-
gist, born 12 Apr 1847 [24 Apr <em>teste</em> Wittrock] in St. Petersburg, Ph.D. 1881 St. Petersburg,
curator of the herb., then dir., St. Petersburg Bot. Gard. 1896, died 24 Dec 1919 in Petrograd
(i.e. St. Petersburg). (<em>Gobi</em>).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Lipschitz gives 24 Dec 1919 as the date of death, but does not indicate o.s. or n.s.,
possibly o.s., i.e. Jan 1920 n.s.

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: HERZ, LECB. – <em>Exsiccatae</em>: <em>Algae Rossicae Exsiccatae</em> (nos.
1-50, 1880, or later?) (<em>Algae Ross. Exsicc.</em>): B, C, KIEL, L.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 230 (as "Christophos Jacoblewitsch"); Barnhart 2:
56 (d. "1920"); BM 2: 671 (as "Ghobi, Kristofor Yakovlevich"); Bossert p. 146 (d. "1920");
Collander, hist. p. 155 (index); CSP 7: 790, 10: 10-11, 15: 342; De Toni 1: li, 4: xxiv; Frank
3(Anh.): 36; Herder p. 251; IH 2: 228 (as "(Kristofer) Jakosolewitsch"; d. "1925"); Jackson p.
551 (index); Kew 2: 428; Lipschitz 2: 290-294; LS 10.092-10.106, 33.679-33.690; Morren ed.
10: 95-96; NAF 7(15): 1066; Nordstedt p. 15-16; Nordstedt suppl. p. 7; Portr. 1: 63 (index, as
"Khristofor Yakovlevich"), 3: 485; Rehder 5(index): 326, 949; TL-2/1: 959 (as "Christophos
Jacoblewitsch"), 2/5 (as "K.Y.") &amp; 2/6 (as "C.J.") (indices); TR p. 98-100; Urban-Berl. p. 264.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bot. Not. 1920(4): 126. 1920; Hedwigia 62: 82. 1920; Nuova Notarisia
	32: 72. 1921.
Dörfler, I., 1896. Botaniker-Adressbuch: 128; 1902. Id., ed. 2: 175; 1909. Id., ed. 3: 248.
	(as "Christopher Jakowlewitsch")
[Engelmann, W.], 1891. Botanisches Adressbuch: 107.
Gaidukov, N., 1925. Nuova Notarisia 36: 196-208. (bibl.)
Henckel, A., 1902. Westnik Imp. Russ. Obschtsch. Sadowodst St. Petersburg 43(12): 1-12.
	(portr.)
Henckel, A., 1925. Nuova Notarisia 36: 378-379.

Wittrock, V.B., 1903. Acta Horti Berg. 3(2): 173-174, <em>pl. 21</em>; 1905. Id. 3(3): 188. (portr.)

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) Co-editor, <em>Botanicheskiya Zapiski. Scripta Botanica Horti Univer-
sitatis Imperialis Petropolitanae</em> (1886-1907).
(2) First author of <em>Beiträge zur Pilzflora Russlands</em> ... Part 1 (1890), which is treated under
its co-author, Woldemar Tranzschel, see TL-2/6, nr. 14.864.
(3) Translated E.A. Strasburger, <em>Lehrb. Bot.</em> ... 1894, into Russian (1897; ed. 2, 1904), see
TL-2/6, nr. 13.237.

Goddijn, Wouter Adriaan (1884-1960), Dutch botanist, born 9 Apr 1884, studied phar-
macy and graduated from Leiden 1909, asst., then curator from 1914 of Rijksherbarium,
Ph.D. 1926 Leiden, prof. in 1934, died 22 Feb 1960 in Warmond. (<em>Goddijn</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: L.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 230; Barnhart 2: 57; BM 6: 380; Bossert p. 146;
IF suppl. 2: 36, 3: 209, 4: 354; IH 2: 228; JW (1): 442, 2: 191; MW p. 138; Portr. 1: 63
(index), 3: 485.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Intl. address book botanists: 262. 1931.
Hegnauer, R., 1960. Pharmac. Weekbl. 95: 224-229. (portr.)
Jones, G.N., 1966. An annotated bibl. Mexican ferns: 74.
[Verdoorn, F.?], 1935. Chronica Bot. 1: 219. (portr.)

<sm>NOTE</sm>: (1) In 1913, Goddijn revised R.B. van den Bosch, <em>Syn. Hymenophyll.</em> ... [1858]-1861,
with the parts appearing in 1913 &amp; 1919. His revision was cited earlier (see TL-2/1, nr.
676), but without mention of copies seen, which is here rectified:
<em>Copies</em>: BM, US (orig. of 1st part, copy of 2nd part.).
(2) Co-author with W.A. Goddijn, Ein <em>künstlich erzeugter Bastard</em>, <em>Scrophularia Neesii</em>,
Wirtg. ×<em>S. vernalis</em>, L. ... 1913.
(3) In 1931, Goddijn published a history of the Rijksherbarium (1830-1931) in Meded.
Rijks Herb. Leiden 62a-b: 53 p., <em>2 pl</em>. and 3 portr. (no reprint seen).

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) Editor, <em>Resumptio Genetica</em> (1927-1953).
(2) Editor, <em>Genetica</em> (1930-1958).
(3) Co-editor, <em>Bibliographia Genetica</em>, vols. 6-10.

36.595. <em>Kweekproeven</em> met eenjarige Vormen binnen Linné's soort <em>Hyoscyamus niger</em> ...
Dieren (Druk "Mercurius") 1927. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 1927, cover-t.p., p. [1]-37. <em>Copy</em>: L. – Reprinted and to be cited from Pharmaceutisch
	Weekblad 64: 81-96, 118-137. 1927. – Also issued as Mededelingen Pharmac. Lab. Ri-
	jks Herb. Leiden 47.
<em>Note</em>: (1) Kew (library cat.) reports the same title with ": proefschrift ..." added. (2) Also
	published in Genetica 8: 161-328 [with col. pl.]. 1926, which is the full publication of
	Goddijn's inaugural dissertation, as opposed to the later abstracts cited above.

PAGE: 250
HEADING: GODEFROY-LEBEUF

36.596. De <em>Wegen</em> der <em>Pharmacognosie</em> ... 's-Gravenhage (Martinus Nijhoff) 1934. Oct. (<em>Wegen Pharmacogn</em>.)

<em>Publ</em>.: 9 Nov 1934 (date of presentation), cover-t.p., p. [i-iv], [1]-31. <em>Copy</em>: L.

*Godefroy-Lebeuf, Alexandre (né Godefroy) (1852-1903), French horticulturist and im-
porter of exotic plants, gardener, Service de la Culture, Museum natl. d'Histoire Naturelle,
Paris 1869, then worked for L. Linden in Belgium and studied at Kew 1871-1872, head gar-
dener, botanical garden, Saigon, French Indochina 1874, married Mlle. Lebeuf (daughter of
the horticulturist V.F. Lebeuf) 1876, his horticultural firm the Maison A. Godefroy-Lebeuf
of Montmartre (Paris) became the principal importer to France of plants and exotic orchids
from its colonies, traveled in Cambodia and Laos 1876-1878 with Frère François-Jules
Harmand (1845-1921), died 2 Aug 1903 in Paris. (<em>God.-Leb.</em>).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: The spelling of his surname is corrected from TL-2/1 where it was given as "Gode-
froy Leboeuf". He married (1876) Mlle. Lebeuf (<em>not</em> Leboeuf) and became son-in-law and
successor to V.F. Lebeuf, who was the proprietor of an horticultural firm in Argenteuil,
France; presumably the hyphenated name commercially advantageous.

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Indochina: C, K, P (orig.), W; Portugal: K.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 230 (as "-Lebeuf"); Backer p. 238 (as "Leboeuf");
Barnhart 2: 57 (as "Lebeuf"); BM 2: 686 (as "-Lebeuf"); Briquet p. 244-245 (sub Guillot);
CSP 15: 344 (as "-Lebeuf"), IH 2: 228 (as "Lebeuf"); Kew 2: 429 (as "Lebeuf"); Kew List
26; Langman p. 318 (as "-Lebeuf"); Morren ed. 2: 39; NI 2: 230 (as "-Lebeuf"); Rehder 5(in-
dex): 326 (as "-Lebeuf"); TL-2/1: 959 (as "Leboeuf"); Zander ed. 17: 950 (as "-Lebeuf").

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Gard. Chron., ser. 3, 34: 99. 1903; J. Kew Guild 2(11): 149. 1903 (portr.);
	Rev. Cult. Colon. 13: 121-123. 1903 (portr.); Rev. Hort. 75: 374. 1903 (as "-Lebeuf").
Ballif, P.[?], 1903. Chron. Orchideenne 1: 406.
Daveau, J., 1902. J. Soc. Hort. France, sér. 4, 4: 524; 537-539. (portr.) (as "-Leboeuf")
Dörfler, I., 1896. Botaniker-Adressbuch: 59; 1902. Id., ed. 2: 76; 1909. Id., ed. 3: 110.
Dorr, L.J., 1997. Pl. collectors Madagascar Comoro Isls.: 180-181.
Dubard, M.M.M., 1906. Bull. Soc. Bot. France 53(4): 301.
Ek, R.C., 1990. Fl. Guianas, Suppl. Ser., Fasc. 1: 43.
Gagnepain, F., 1944. <em>In</em>, P.H. Lecomte, Fl. Indochine, tome prél.: 41. (portr.)
Guillaumin, A., 1929. Fl. Jard.: lxiii.
Hedge, I.C. &amp; J.M. Lamond, 1970. Index collectors Edinburgh Herb.: 84.
Martinet, G., 1903. Le Jardin 296: 241. (portr.)
Newton, L.E., 2006. Sansevieria 14: 15-16. (portr.)

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: The etymology of <em>Godefroya</em> Gagnep. (1923) is not stated, but presumably
commemorates Godefroy-Lebeuf who collected in Cambodia.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) Founded with Comte François de Buysson and edited the popular
journal <em>L'Orchidophile</em> (Argenteuil), vols. 1-13 (1881-1893) (see NI nr. 2361).
(2) Contributed to the founding of <em>Le Jardin</em> (1887), which he edited until 1892.

Oct.

	1886), 8 p. <em>Copy</em>: Bibl. nat. (n.v.).

36.599. Les <em>sansevierias gigantesques</em> de l'<em>Afrique orientale</em> et leurs fibres ... Paris (Mai-

*Godet, Charles Henri (1797-1879), Swiss botanist, born 16 Sep 1797 in Neuchâtel, stud-
ied in Neuchâtel and Zurich, instructor in Russia 1822-1829 ("Précepteur des enfants du
comte Orlowski"), accompanied Christian von Steven to the Caucasus where they collected
plants and insects 1828, sojourned in Paris where he met G. Cuvier, P.A. Latreille and A.
von Humboldt, returned to Switzerland 1834, served as school inspector 1839-1848 and
librarian in Neuchâtel 1859-1876, died 16 Dec 1879 in Neuchâtel. (<em>Godet</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BERN, FI, G, NEU. Also, a volume by Godet entitled <em>Souvenir
de la flore des Alpes</em> (1867), which is in the Swiss Natl. Library, evidently contains dried
plants.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 6(1): 57; APN p. 230; Backer p. 238; Barnhart 2: 57
(as "C. Henry"); BFM p. 286 (index); BL 2: 561, 577-578, 660; BM 2: 686, 3: 1143 (sub
Neuchâtel), 6: 380; Bossert p. 146; CSP 2: 926, 7: 791; Herder p. 452 (index); Hortus
3: 1193; IH 2: 228; Jackson p. 344; Portr. 1: 63 (index), 3: 486; PR ed. 1: 2739, ed. 2:
3400-3401; Rehder 5(index): 326; Sotheby 1: 236; TL-2/1: 959-960; Tucker 1: 281.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Amer. J. Sci., ser. 3, 19: 158. 1880.
Burdet, H.M., 1975. Saussurea 6: 29. (portr.)
"C.", 1880. Flora 63: 45-47.
Charpin, A. &amp; G.G. Aymonin, 2003. J. Bot. Soc. Bot. France 21: 75.
Christ, H., 1881. Verh. Schweiz. Naturf. Ges. 63: 123-132.
Godet, P., 1879. Souvenirs de la vie de Charles Henri Godet, naturaliste suisse, [Neuchâ-
	tel]: 4 lvs. (portr.). <em>Copy</em>: HH.
Godet, P.G., 1880. Bull. Soc. Neuchâtel Sci. Nat. 12: 166-175.
Morthier, P., 1880. Bull. Trav. Soc. Murith. Valais 1880 (10): 13-19.
Perret, P. &amp; H.M. Burdet, 1981. <em>In</em>, H.M. Burdet, Candollea 36: 399-400. (bibl.)
Steinberg, C., 1977. Webbia 32: 26. (specimens at FI)
Wittrock, V.B., 1903. Acta Horti Berg. 3(2): 151; 1905. Id. 3(3): 162.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: <em>Fl. Jura</em> ... 1852-1853 (TL-2/1, nr. 2055) has been issued in microfiche:

HEADING: GODFERY

<em>Publ</em>.: 1846 (p. 8 signed Apr 1845, p. 5 [Avant-propos] signed 13 Feb 1846), p. [1]-8

	HH.
<em>Nouvelle éd</em>.: 1864, Les <em>plantes vénéneuses</em> du Canton de <em>Neuchâtel</em> ... Neuchâtel (Mon-
	tendon Fréres), p. [i]-x, 1-59, [i, Table], <em>26 pl</em>. (unnumb. chromolith.). Oct. <em>Copy</em>: BM.

<em>Note</em>: (1) BM cat. attributes authorship to "Société Neuchâteloise d'Utilité Publique". (2)
	The introduction is signed "C.G.", i.e. C.H. Godet.
<em>Note</em> [both eds.]: Sotheby (1: 236) asserts that <em>Flore des plantes vénéneuses</em> de la Suisse ...
	1849 is based on Godet's <em>Description</em> ... 1845 [i.e. 1846], which then reverted to its orig.
	title in 1864, 1880 [sic]. This seems unlikely and although the 1849 title is superficially
	similar and was published anonymously we accept its earlier attribution to D. Rapin
	(TL-2/4, nr. 8634).

Godfery, Masters John (Col.) (1856-1945), British soldier and botanist (authority on Brit-
ish and European orchids), R.A.S.C., F.L.S. 1915, died 8 Apr 1945 in Torquay (Devon.).
(<em>Godfery</em>).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: His wife, Hilda Margaret Godfery (née Simpson) (1871-1930), was an accomplished
botanical artist (water-colorist) who illustrated a.o. his publications.

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: AMES, HAMU, WEDGWOOD; Malta: BM. – Orig. watercolors,
corr., phot., notes and R.H.S. Gold Medal award certificate (1925) of H.M. Godfery are at
BMNH.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 230; Barnhart 2: 57 ("Godfery, Hilda Margaret"
only); Desmond p. 256, ed. 2: 283; IH 2: 228 (as "Godfrey, M.J."); Kent ed. 2: 150; NI 2:
69.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Intl. address book botanists: 182. 1931; Nature 155: 627. 1945; Orchid
	Rev. 53: 64. 1945; Times [of London?] [newspaper] 14 Apr 1945 (n.v.).
Stephenson, T., 1946. Proc. Linn. Soc. 157: 110-111.

Godfrin, Julien (1850-1913), French pharmacist, mycologist and plant anatomist, born 26
Feb 1850 in Châtel-Saint-Germain (Moselle), student at the École Normale in Metz, teacher
in Moselle and then Oise, adjunct prof. of agriculture at the École Normale in Aleçon where
he obtained his bachelor degree 1873, "pharmacien de première classe" 1878, Dr. en phar-
macie 1880 Nancy, named "Maître de conférences de botanique", Faculty of Sciences, Al-
giers, Algeria but recalled to Nancy to oversee materia medica courses at the univ. 1882, Dr.
ès-sciences 1884 Paris, prof. of materia medica and natural sciences, Univ. of Nancy 1884-
1913, and dir., School of Pharmacy 1901-1913, died 26 Mar 1913 in Nancy. (<em>Godfrin</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: NCY?

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 57; BFM p. 286 (index); BL 2: 174, 660; BM
2: 686; CSP 15: 344-345; DBF 16: 458-459; Jackson p. 94; Kelly p. 91; LS 10.112-10.124;
Morren ed. 10: 66; MW p. 138; TL-2/4, 2/6 (indices); Rehder 5(index): 326; Tucker 2:
281.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Charpin, A. &amp; G.G. Aymonin, 2003. J. Bot. Soc. Bot. France 21: 75.
Charpin, A. &amp; J. Timbal, 2007. Acta Bot. Gallica 154: 452.
Davy de Virville, A., 1954. Hist. bot. France: 129, 138, 221, 234, 262.
Dörfler, I., 1896. Botaniker-Adressbuch: 59; 1902. Id., ed. 2: 76; 1909. Id., ed. 3: 110.

PAGE: 254
HEADING: GODRON

[Engelmann, W.], 1891. Botanisches Adressbuch: 91.
Grélot, P., 1913. Bull. Soc. Sci. Nancy, sér. 3, 14: 74-81. (bibl., portr.)
Werner, R.G., 1966. Bull. Acad. Soc. Lorraine Sci. 6(2): 107.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Godfrinia</em> Maire (1902).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Godfrin was first author of <em>Fl. Lorraine</em> ... 1909 (text), 1913 (atlas), which was
analyzed earlier under M.G.C. Petitmengin, the second author (see TL-2/4, nr. 7777).

technique d'anatomie végétale</em> ... 1886 (see TL-2/6, nr. 13.232).

36.612. <em>Homologie</em> des <em>hyphes vasculaires</em> des <em>Agaricinés</em> ... Paris (Impr. nationale) 1902. Oct.

	Congrès Soc. Savantes 1901 [i.e. 1902]. – Also published in Bull. Soc. Mycol. France
	18(2): 147-150. 1902.

*Godron, Dominique [Alexandre] (1807-1880), French botanist, naturalist and physician,
born 25 Mar 1807 in Hayange nr. Thionville (Meurthe-et-Moselle), studied classics in Paris
ca. 1819, removed to Strasbourg to work with C.G. Nestler 1827, Dr. en-médecine 1833,
prof., natural history and materia medica, School of Medicine, Nancy 1835, adjunct prof. of
botany, Jardin des plantes 1837, Dr. ès-sciences 1844 Strasbourg, briefly in Vesoul and Mont-
pellier but returned to Nancy where he became prof. of natural history, Faculty of Science
1854 and Dir. of the botanical garden, retired in 1871, received many honors, incl. Légion
d'honneur 1852, corr., Académie des Sciences 1877, died 16 Aug 1880 in Nancy. (<em>Godr</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: NCY, duplicates AUT, BR, CN, FI, GOET, P, PC, W. – <em>Exsic-
catae</em>: (1) <em>Flora cryptogamica nanceiensis exsiccata</em> (<em>Fl. Cryptog. Nance. Exsicc.</em>) (fasc.
i-ii, nos. 1-100), sets at CN, NCY; (2) <em>Plantae galliae australis</em> (no details). – Some corr.
with C. Darwin.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Académie p. 219; AG 6(1): 509, 6(2): 941; APN p. 231;
Backer p. 238, 651; Baillon 2: 716; Barnhart 2: 58; BFM p. 286 (index); Biol.-Dokum. 7:
82.002; BL 2: 103, 163, 174, 182, 660; BM 2: 687-688, 6: 381; CSP 2: 927-928, 7: 791-792,
10: 13, 12: 278; DBF 16: 479-480; Frank 3(Anh.): 36; GR p. 324; Herder p. 452 (index);
Hortus 3: 1193; IH 2: 229; Jackson p. 551 (index); Kew 2: 430-431; Langman p. 318; LS
10.128, 33.681; Morren ed. 2: 19; Portr. 3: 486; PR ed. 1: 3722-3730, ed. 2: 3403-3421;
Rehder 5(index): 326-327; Saccardo 1: 84; TL-1: 173-174, 181-182; TL-2/1: 961-962, indi-
ces 2/1, 2/3, 2/4, 2/5; Tucker 2: 281-283, 3: 120-121; Zander ed. 11: 755, ed. 17: 950.

<em>Note</em>: (1) The verso of the half-t.p. [=p. [2]] of the reprint states "Extrait des Mémoires de

36.632. <em>Mémoire</em> sur les <em>Fumariées</em> à <em>fleurs irrégulières</em> et sur la cause de leur irrégularité
... Nancy (Ve Raybois, Imprimeur de l'Académie de Stanislas) 1864 [i.e. 1865]. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 1865, cover-t.p., p. [1]-16, <em>1 pl</em>. (unnumb., uncol. lith.). <em>Copies</em>: BM (n.v.), G, HH
	(2), K, US (as "Contributions ..."). – Reprinted and to be cited from Mém. Acad. Stan-
	isles 1864: 182-195, <em>1 pl</em>. 1865. – This version was republished with type reset and other
	minor changes from Ann. Sci. Nat., Bot., sér. 5, 2: 272-280, <em>pl. 17.</em> 1864.
<em>Note</em>: (1) The position of the six figures in the orig. plate (i.e. <em>pl. 17</em>) were changed and the
	figure captions included in the revised, unnumb. plate! (2) In his "Contributions à la flore
	de France" (see nr. 36.656 below).

36.655. <em>Note</em> sur le maïs géant caragua (<em>Zea Caragua</em> Molin.) ... Montpellier (Typogr.

	tions ..."). – Reprinted and to be cited from Rev. Sci. Nat. 9 [=sér. 2, 2(1)]: 51-53. 1880.

36.656. <em>Contributions</em> à la <em>flore</em> de <em>France</em>; botanique descriptive et physiologie végétale ...
Paris (Librairie J.-B. Baillière et fils) [1880]. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: [1847-1880], 1 vol. (various pagings), <em>pl</em>. <em>Copies</em>: HH ("40 pamphlets, in 3 vol."),
	K (n.v.), US.
<em>Note</em>: (1) This is a bound collection of 22 (or more) offprints published from 1847-1880 in
	different serials, with various pagings, with or without cover-t.p., with or without plates
	and with advert. (incl. end papers). The titles that concern us are treated separately (see
	above) and are flagged as "In his 'Contributions à la flore de France'". (2) The same
	publisher issued a similarly titled volume for C. Grenier (see below).

*Goebel, Karl [Immanuel Eberhard] (later Ritter von) (1855-1932), German morpholo-
gist, born 8 Mar 1855 in Billigheim nr. Heilbronn (Baden) but family from Reutlingen,
studied in Tübingen 1873-1876 (under W.F.B. Hofmeister), Strassburg 1876 (under H.A.
de Bary) and Würzburg 1877-1880 (under J. von Sachs), habilitation 1880, studies briefly
interrupted by military service, botanical asst., Leipzig 1881, assoc. prof., Strassburg 1881
and then Rostock 1882-1887 (traveled to India, Ceylon and Java 1885-1886), prof., Mar-
burg 1887-1891, traveled to South America 1890-1891, settled in Munich 1891, traveled
to Australia and New Zealand 1898-1899, prof., Munich 1907, knighted 1909, traveled to
Brazil 1913, prorector at Erlangen 1916, traveled to Pacific 1924-1925, F.R.S. 1926, Corr.
Member B.S.A., F.L.S., died 9 Oct 1932 in Munich. (<em>K.I. Goebel</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: M, further material at B, DBN, K, MB, P, ROST, RV. – <em>Note</em>:
Goebel sold the Lamarck herb. to Paris in 1887; the herb. had been acquired in 1824 by
J.A.C. Roeper (see TL-2/4: 850-851), Goebel's predecessor at Rostock.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 231; Barnhart 2: 58 (as "Eberhard"); BFM p.
286 (index); Biol.-Dokum. 7: 82.034-82.132; BJI 1: 21; BM 2: 688, 6: 381; Bossert p. 147;
CSP 10: 15-16, 15: 347-348; De Toni 1: li; DSB 5: 437-439; Frahm&amp;E. p. 139-142 (bibl.,
portr.; as "Eberhart"); Frank 3(Anh.): 36; GR p. 83; Hirsch p. 100; IF p. 699; IF suppl. 3:
209-210, 4: 354; IH 2: 229 (as "Eberhard"); Kelly p. 91; Kew 2: 432-433; Lenley p. 183;
LS 10.130-10.138; LS suppl. 9702-9708; Mägdefrau p. 310 (index); Moebius p. 155 (as
"Eberhard"), 450 (index); Morren ed. 10: 26; MW p. 138; NDB 6: 504-505; Nordstedt p.
16; Plesch p. 238; Portr. 1: 63 (index), 3: 486-487; Rehder 5(index): 327 (as "Eberhard");
SBC p. 121; SK 1: 194-195 (itin.), 5: cclxxxi, 8: xxxix; TL-1: 254; TL-2/1: 963-964 (as
"Eberhard"), indices 2/4, 2/5, 2/7; Tucker 2: xvii, 3: 121; Urban-Berl. p. 300, 320.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: Edited: (1) <em>Flora</em> (1889); (2) <em>Botanische Abhandlungen</em> ... Heft 1-21
(1922-1932); and (3) was president of <em>Botanisches Centralblatt</em> ... (1902 -1905).

36.657. <em>Entwicklungsgeschichte</em> des <em>Prothalliums</em> von <em>Gymnogramme leptophylla</em>. Inaugu-
ral- Dissertation der Mathemathischen [sic] und Naturwissenschaftlichen Facultät der Kai-
ser Wilhelms-Universität Strassburg zur Erlangung der Doctorwürde vorgelegt von Karl
Goebel aus Reutlingen ... Separatabdruck aus der Botanischen Zeitung ... 1877. Qu 

<em>Publ</em>.: 1877, p. [1]-20, <em>pl. 10</em> [=<em>11 bis</em>] (uncol. lith.). <em>Copies</em>: FH (n.v.), G(2). – Reprinted and
	to be cited from Bot. Zeitung (Berlin) 35(42-44): col. 671-678, 681-694, 697-711, <em>pl. 10
	[</em>=<em>11 bis</em>]. 1877.
<em>Note</em>: (1) Inaugural dissertation, Kaiser Wilhelms Universität, Strassburg. (2) The plate is
	numbered "X" but misnumbered as it falls between <em>pl. 11</em> and <em>12</em> in the journal.

*Goeppert [Göppert], [Johann] Heinrich [Robert] (1800-1884), German physician, paleo-
botanist and morphologist, born 25 Jul 1800 in Sprottau (Lower Silesia), studied medicine
in Breslau and Berlin, graduated 11 Jan 1825, tutor to 1827, extraord. prof. 1831, full prof.
1839, dir. of the botanic garden in Breslau 1852, founded first German botanical museum in
1854, appointed Privy Medical Councilor (Geheimer Medicinal-Rath) by the King of Prus-
sia (Frederick William IV) in 1855, F.L.S. 1855, Murchison Medal (Geological Society Lon-
don 1883), died 18 Mai 1884 in Breslau (Vratislav) (succeeded by A. Engler). (<em>Goepp</em>.).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Not to be confused with Heinrich Robert Göppert (1838-1882).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: WRSL (formerly BRSL), duplicates B, BP. – <em>Arboretum fossile</em>,
Sammlung von Dünnschliffen fossiler Coniferenhölzer der palaeozoischen Formation
Breslau 1881, with 6 p. accompanying text.
<em>Note</em>: [Goeppert, H.R.], 1868 [p. [ii] signed 20 Jul 1867]. Verzeichniss der paläontolo-
	gischen Sammlungen des Prof. Dr. H. R. Göppert in Breslau ... Görlitz (Verlag von E.
	Remer), cover-t.p., p. [i-ii], [1]-15, [i, printer's mark]. Oct. <em>Copy</em>: LC.
<em>Ref</em>.: Anon., Bot. Zeitung (Berlin) 26: 671-672. 9 Oct 1868 (on a "Verzeichniss" of his
	collections).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: ADB 49: 455-460; AG 4: 252; Andrews p. 268-270 (as
"Henricus Robertus"); APN p. 235 (as "Göppert"); Baillon 2: 716-717; Barnhart 2: 58;
Biol.-Dokum. 7: 82.352-82.418; BJI 1: 22; BM 2: 689-690, 6: 382; BN p. 174; Bossert
p. 148; CSP 2: 938-944, 6: 674, 7: 798-799, 10: 26-27, 12: 279, 15: 350-351 (as "Göp-
pert"); De Toni 1: li; DSB 5: 440-442; DTS 1: 88; Frahm&amp;E. p. 142 (as "Göppert"); Frank
3(Anh.): 36; Futak-Domin p. 221-222 (as "Göppert"); GR p. 16; GR cat. p. 64; Herder p.
452 (index); HL 3486-3503; Hortus 3: 1194 (as "Göppert"); IH 2: 229; Jackson p. 551
(index); Kelly p. 91; Kew 2: 433-434; Klášterský p. 83; KR p. 242; Langman p. 318; LS

450 (index); Morren ed. 2: 6, ed 10: 9; MW p. 139; NDB 6: 519-520; NI 2: 69; Nordstedt
p. 16; Portr. 3: 487; PR ed. 1: 3424-3451, ed. 2: 3738-3758; Quenstedt p. 166; Ratzeburg

pert"), 4; Tucker 1: 283 (as "Göppert"), 3: 121; Urban-Berl. p. 287.

	<em>Copy</em>: G.

<em>Note</em>: (1) Said to have been presented at the 11 Jul 1830 meeting <em>teste</em> Verh. Vereins Beförd.
	Gartenbaues Königl. Preuss. Staaten 7(14): 166. 1831. (2) Later revised as <em>Führer durch
	den Königlichen botanischen Garten der Universität Breslau</em> ... which went through at
	least 9 editions during Goeppert's career, e.g. ed. 2. 1868 (20 p.); ed. 3. 1874 (32 p., <em>pl.
	1</em>); ed. 4. 1874 (26 p., map); ed. 5. 1875 (50 p.); ed. 7. 1879; ed. 8. 1880; ed. 9. 1883
	(53 p., <em>pl. 1-2</em>); the same title by F. Pax (Goeppert's successor at the Garden in Breslau),
	see TL-2/4, nr. 7547 (=eds. 1 &amp; 2), and add ed. 3. 1914 (63 p., 1 map). (3) see also <em>Der
	Königliche Botanische Garten der Universität Breslau</em> ... 1857 (nr. 36.686 below).

Görz, Rudolf (1879-1935), German salicologist, born 19 Nov 1879 in Rathanow, middle
school teacher in Brandenburg (on the Havel), where he died 10 Mai 1935. (<em>Görz</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Turkey: A, B, C, GH, LE, MU, NY. – <em>Exsiccatae</em>: (1) <em>Fl. Germa-
niae Borealis</em>: GB, L; (2) <em>Salicaceae Asiaticae</em> (3 fascs.): B, GB, S. (3) <em>Salices Branden-
burgenses Exsiccatae</em> (2 centuries, nos. 1-200): B, GB, M, S.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 231 (as "Goerz"); Barnhart 2: 58; BFM p. 286 (in-
dex); Bossert p. 149; Futak-Domin p. 222; IH 2: 233; Kew 2: 434; MW p. 139; Tucker 3: 121.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Charpin, A. &amp; G.G. Aymonin, 2003. J. Bot. Soc. Bot. France 21: 76.
Charpin, A. &amp; G.G. Aymonin, 2004. J. Bot. Soc. Bot. France 27: 86.
Dörfler, I., 1909. Botaniker-Adressbuch, ed. 3: 35.
Fedchenko, B.A., 1936. Sovietska Bot. 1936(1): 153-155. (portr.)
Hertel, H. &amp; A. Schreiber, 1988. Mitt. Bot. Staatssamml. München 26: 317.
Mattfeld, J., 1936. Verh. Bot. Vereins Prov. Brandenburg 76: 114-115. (member since 1906)

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Goerziella</em> Urb. (1924) is named for Carl Paul Goerz (1854-1923), founder of an
optical company that made lenses for cameras and microscopes.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: Contributed ("Determined") Salix to A. Rehder &amp; C.E. Kobuski,
"<em>Enumeration</em> of the <em>ligneous plants</em> collected by <em>J.F. Rock</em> ....", J. Arnold Arbor. 13(4):
387-404. 24 Oct 1932.

Goethart, Jan Willem Christiaan (1866-1938), Indonesian-born Dutch botanist, born 21 Jul
1866 in Semarang, Java, studied at Landwirtschaftlichen Hochschule, Wageningen, Ph.D. 1890
Univ. of Göttingen, asst. to Hugo de Vries in Amsterdam, reader (Lektor) in systematic botany,
Rijksuniversität, Leiden, appointed to Rijksherbarium, Leiden 1897, dir. 1910-1932, died 3
Feb 1938 in Leiden, "Dr Goethart war ein Idealist" (<em>fide</em> Goddijn, 1938: 4). (<em>Goethart</em>).

HEADING: GOETHE

<em>Note</em>: The first "aflevering" is paginated as follows: p. [1]-4 with heading "L.S." with au-
	thors' names and the date at the end of page 4; p. [1]-16 with heading "Handleiding tot
	het gebruik der plantenkaartjes" followed by 21 unnumb. lvs. of maps. The only other
	text is inserted in aflevering IV: "Aan onze Medewerkers", p. [1]-4. Otherwise, all other
	fascicles consist of unnumb. lvs. of maps, which were issued loose. (2) Although all title
	pages are dated "1902", the individual maps have dates to Jan 1907. (3) "Bewerkt naar:
	den Prodromus florae Batavae".
<em>Ref</em>.: [Anon.?], Ned. Kruidk. Arch., ser. 3, 2: 1068-1073. 1903.

*Goethe, Johann Wolfgang (von) (1749-1832), famous German author, poet and "Natur-
Philosoph". (<em>Goethe</em>).

This entry is introduced only to:
(1) Take the advice Rudolf Schmid gave F.A. Stafleu (in litt., 1 Feb 1977) clarifying that
Agnes Arber, <em>Goethe's Botany</em> (Chron. Bot. 10(2): 67-124. 1946) includes the perhaps

PAGE: 274
HEADING: GOEZE

most widely read English transl. of Goethe's 1790 <em>Versuch, die Metamorphose der Pflanzen
zu erklären</em> (p. 89-115) (see TL-2/1, nr. 2081).
(2) Note Walter H. Hodge's paper (Principes 26: 194-199. 1982) on "Goethe's palm", stat-
ing that the palm clump of <em>Chamaerops humilis</em> L. that Goethe studied in 1787 in Padua is
still living; Hodge's point was that this particular palm specimen was 200 years old when
Goethe visited it, having been planted in 1585!
(3) Call the reader's attention to several more recent publications concerning Goethe and
botany:
Amrine, F. et al. (eds.), 1987. Goethe and the sciences: a reappraisal, Dordrecht, The
	Netherlands (D. Reidel Publishing Co.) ... xvii, 442 p. [see Schmid, R., Taxon 38(3):
	440-441. Aug 1989 (rev.)].
Breidbach, O., 2006. Goethes Metamorphosenlehre, München (W. Fink): 334 p.
Fast, G., 1988. Spiraltendenz, ein Grundgesetz des Lebens: eine Auswahl aus J.W. v.
	Goethes naturwissenschaftlichen Schriften zur Symbolik des Wachstums, (Frisinga
	[Latin = German Freising]): 59 p.
Froebe, H.A., 1985. Goethes Morphologie der Pflanzen—Ihre Stellung in der Entwicklung
	der Botanik. Hoppea 44: 345-371.
[Goethe, J.W. von], 1989. Goethe's botanical writings, Woodbridge, Conn. (Ox Bow Press)
	... x, 258 p. (reprint of the 1952 University of Hawaii Press ed.; transl. by Bertha Muel-
	ler; introd. by Charles J. Engard).
[Goethe, J.W. von], 1993. The metamorphosis of plants, Kimberton, Penn. (Bio-Dynamic
	Farming and Gardening Association): 56 p. (Rev. by Anne E. Marshall &amp; Heinz Grotzke),
[Goethe, J.W. von], 1993. A metamorfose das plantas, [Lisbon] (Impr. Nacional Casa de
	Moeda): 82 p. (Portuguese transl. by Maria Filomena Molder).
Kahler, M.-L. et al., 1991. Alle Gestalten sind ähnlich: Goethes Metamorphose der Pflan-
	zen, [Weimar] (Klassikerstätten zu Weimar): 103, [1] p.
Mann, G. et al., 1992. In der Mitte zwischen Natur und Subjekt: Johann Wolfgang von
	Goethes Versuch, die Metamorphose der Pflanze zu erklären, 1790-1990: Sachverhalte,
	Gedanken, Wirkungen, Frankfurt am Main (Waldemar Kramer): 164 p.
Schneckenburger, S., 1998. In tausend Formen magst du dich verstecken: Goethe und die
	Pflanzenwelt, Frankfurt am Main (Palmengarten): 94 p.
Spies, H., 1999. Goethe und die Welt der Pflanzen: Sonderausstellung, Düsseldorf (Goethe
	Museum): 135 p. [Exhibition catalog]

Goeze, Edmund (1838-1929?), German horticulturalist and garden administrator, born 13
Feb 1838 in Itzehoe (Holstein), worked at Kew Herb., dir., Botanical Museum in Coim-
bra, Portugal 1866-1876, then Lisbon and finally garden inspector in Greifswald [where he
died?]. (<em>E. Goeze</em>).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: While at Coimbra, Goeze was involved in the negotiations on behalf of the Portu-
guese government to recover the specimens collected by Friedrich Martin Josef Welwitsch
(1806-1872), which had been taken to London for study (see also Bernardino António
Gomes filius).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Portugal: K.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 231 (d. "1929"); Barnhart 2: 59; Biol.-Dokum. 7:
83.045-83.055; BM 2: 691; CSP 7: 793 (as "Edmond"), 10: 16 (as "Edmund"), 15: 354; Herder
p. 333; Hortus 3: 1194; IH 2: 229 (as "Edmond"); Jackson p. 551 (index); Kew List 26 (as
"Edmond"); Langman p. 318-319; LS 10.198; Morren ed. 2: 28, ed. 10: 13; MW p. 139; Portr.
3: 487; Rehder 5(index): 329-330; TL-2/3: 948 (index); Tucker 1: 284 ("Edmund"), 3: 121.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Gartenflora 67: 47. 1911?
Dörfler, I., 1896. Botaniker-Adressbuch: 16; 1902. Id., ed. 2: 17; 1909. Id., ed. 3: 36.

Goidanich [Goidànich], Gabriele (1912-1999), Italian mycologist and univ. administrator,
born 30 Aug 1912 in Sarre (Valle d'Aosta), agronomy degree 1933 Univ. of Bologna, asst.
to V. Peglion, employed, "R. Stazione di patologia vegetale", Rome, returned to Rome after
W.W.-II, visiting prof., Univ. of Calif., prof., plant pathology, Univ. of Bologna 1949 (suc-
ceeding V. Peglion), later dir., Faculty of Agriculture and other administrative posts, presi-
dent, Unione Micologica Italiana, prof. emeritus 1988, died 9 Feb 1999 in Bologna. (<em>Goid</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Ainsworth p. 151; APN p. 231; DBI 57: 556-558; Kew 2:
436.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Canova, A., 1999. Phytopathologia Mediterranea 38(2): 111-113. (n.v.)
Foschi, S., 2000. Informatore Fitopatologico 50(10): 4-8. (n.v.)
Govia, G., 2000. Gabriele Goidanich, Bologna (Lo scarabeo): 48 p. (n.v.). ["Memoria pre-
	sentata il 9 febbraio 2000"]

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Goidanichia</em> Tomas. &amp; Cif. (1952); <em>Goidanichiella</em> G.L Barron ex W. Gams
(1990); <em>Goidanichiomyces</em> Cif. &amp; Tomas. (1953); also Biblioteca Centralizzata della Fa-
coltà di Agraria "Gabriele Goidanich", Univ. of Bologna.

<sm>OUTSIDE OUR PERIOD</sm>: (1) Goidànich &amp; Gilberto Govi (1924-x), <em>Funghi e ambiente</em>: una
guida per l'amatore, Bologna (Edagricole) ... (1982).
(2) <em>Nel mondo dei funghi</em>: guida pratica per i cercatori, Bologna (Edagricole) ... (1991).

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: Founded the serial <em>Phytopathologia mediterranea</em> (1960), which be-
came <em>Micologia Italiana</em> (1972-x).

36.720. <em>Miceti bolognesi</em>: contributo alla conoscenza della flora micologica della provincia
di Bologna: VI. Centuria ... Bologna (Società Tipografica già Compositori) 1932. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 1932 (p. [3] signed 21 Apr 1932), cover-t.p., t.p., p. [1]-26. <em>Copies</em>: FH, USDA-
	Mycol. – Reprinted and to be cited from Malpighia 32(1-12): 339-362. 1932.
<em>Note</em>: (1) Title in serial is "Enumerazione dei funghi della provincial di Bologna. VI. Cen-
	turia". (2) There was at least one addition: "7th Centuria" Id. 33: 15-48, [reprint repagi-
	nated, p. [1]-36]. 1934 (signed 21 Apr 1934). <em>Copy</em>: USDA-Mycol.

Goiran, Agostino [Charles Augustin] (1835-1909), Italian botanist, born 24 Sep 1835 in
Nizza (Kingdom of Sardinia) (from 1860 Nice, France), botany prof. in Verona for 35
years, retired 1904, died 29 Oct 1909 in Nice. (<em>Goiran</em>).

Gola, Giuseppe (1877-1956), Italian botanist, born 26 Feb 1877 in Novara, studied medicine
and natural sciences at Univ. of Turin, "promotion" in medicine 1900 and natural sciences 1902
Univ. of Turin, volunteer asst., pharmacy inst., then at inst. of botany, Univ. of Turin 1901, Univ.
of Cagliari (Sardinia) 1920, prof., Univ. of Padua, died 20 [25?] Jul 1956 in Padua. (<em>Gola</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: FI, PAD, TO (orig.), TOM.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 231; Barnhart 2: 60; Biol.-Dokum. 7: 83.198; BL
2: 373, 377, 660; BM 6: 382; DBI 57: 576-580 (d. "25 Jul"); GR p. 518; GR cat. p. 64;
Hirsch p. 100; Kew 2: 436; LS suppl. 9711-9712; Portr. 3: 488; SBC p. 121; Tucker 1: 284.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Intl. address book botanists: 241. 1931.
Cappelletti, C., 1956. Ann. Bot. (Rome) 25: 1-11. (bibl., portr.)
Cappelletti, C., 1957. Ann. Univ. Padova 1956/57: 641-652. (n.v.)
Cavillier, [Frère], 1941. Boissiera 5: 50.

Goldie, John (1793-1886), Scottish gardener and traveler, born 21 Mar 1793 in Kirko-
swald, (Ayrshire), apprenticed as a gardener, W.J. Hooker who met Goldie at Glasgow
Gardens encouraged him to travel, Goldie then visited N. America 1817-1819 and 1833,
and Russia 1824 and 1830, and emigrated to Canada in 1844, died 23 Jul 1886 in Ayr,
Ontario. (<em>Goldie</em>).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Father of James Goldie (1825-1912), who published the senior Goldie's 1819 diary
in 1897 (see Biofile).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Canada: K (Herb. Hooker), MANCH, MTMG, OXF (few), P
(few), PH. The reports by W.J. Hooker (e.g. <em>Flora Boreali-Americana</em>, 1829) of collec-
tions by Goldie from Anticosti Island, Quebec and Gulf of St. Lawrence are likely to be
those of Frederick Pursh. – Letters in Kew, GH (Library and Archives) and in the Metro-
politan Library, Toronto.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 231; Backer p. 238; BB p. 124-125; BM 2: 692;
Bossert p. 147; Clokie p. 172; CSP 2: 929; Desmond p. 256, ed. 2: 284; Ewan Pap. p. 80;
Hortus 3: 1194; IF p. 699; IF suppl. 4: 354; Kew 2: 437; ME 1: 188, 3: 582; Portr. 3: 488;
Rehder 5(index): 330; Tucker 2: 284; Zander ed. 17: 950.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bot. Gaz. 11(10): 272-274. 1886; Amer. J. Bot., ser. 3, 35: 260-261. 1888.
[Britten, J.], 1888. J. Bot. 26: 299-301.
Cayouette, J., 2005. Bull. Flora Quebeca 10(1): 13-18.
Clute, W.N., 1900. Fern Bull. 8: 73-75. (portr.)
Eckel, P.M., 1989. Clintonia 4(6): 1-5.

Ewan, J., 1968. Rhodora 70: 457-461. [rev. of 1967 republication of diary]

	England States. 1819. 56 p. (portr.) [1967 republished: ... x, 65 p. (portr.), foreword by
	William Spawn)]

HEADING: GOLDMAN

	Microprint), 1979, 1 micro-opaque, 23×15 cm (Landmarks II). <em>Copy</em>: (n.v.). – Reprinted
	and to be cited from Edinburgh Phil. J. 6: 319-333, <em>pl. 1.</em> 1822.

Goldman, Edward Alphonso (né Goltman) (1873-1946), American field naturalist and
mammalogist, born 7 Jul 1873 in Mount Carroll, Illinois, moved with his family to Tu-
lare Co., Calif. 1888, field naturalist (and many other positions), U.S. Biological Survey
(U.S.D.A.) 1892-1943, interrupted only by W.W.-I service in France with the Sanitary
Corps (rodent control) of the American Expeditionary Force 1918-1919, closely associated
with E.W. Nelson in Calif. and Mexico, died 2 Sep 1946 in Washington, D.C. (buried in
Arlington Natl. Cemetary). (<em>E.A. Goldman</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: US (orig., incl. field books), duplicates F, GH, NY. – Mss. materi-
als in SIA.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Amer. Men Sci. ed. 7: 661-662; APN p. 232; Barnhart 2:
61; BL 1: 151, 298; BM 6: 382; Ewan ed. 2: 86; Ewan Pap. p. 80; IH 2: 230; Kew 2: 437;

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Goldmanella</em> Greenm. (1908); <em>Goldmania</em> Rose (1903); <em>Goldmania</em> Greenm.
(1907), hom. illeg. Also commemorated by the bird genus <em>Goldmania</em> E.W. Nelson (1911)
and Goldman Peak in Baja California.

<sm>OUTSIDE OUR PERIOD</sm>: Goldman published posthumously <em>Biological investigations</em> in
<em>Mexico</em> ... Smithsonian Misc. Coll. 115: [i, ii], iii-xiii, [1]-476, 1 map (uncol.), <em>pl. 1-70.</em>
1951, which includes information (itineraries, localities, etc.) on exploration of Mexico
and Guatemala by E.W. Nelson and Goldman from 1892-1906 (see Pitelka, F.A., Ecology
34(2): 446-447. Apr 1953 (rev.)).

HEADING: GOLDSCHMIDT

<em>Ref</em>.: Krause, K., Bot. Jahrb. Syst. 57(Lit.): 70. 1 Apr 1922 (rev.).

Goldschmidt, Moritz (1863-1916), German botanist, born 12 Oct 1863 in Bischhausen
bei Eschwege (Hesse), longtime teacher in Geisa (Thuringia), student and colleague of
Adalbert Geheeb, died of diabetes 7 Sep 1916 in Geisa. (<em>M. Goldschm.</em>).

Golenkin, Mikhail [Michael, Michail] Ilitch [Ilich, Iljitsch] (1864-1941), Russian bota-
nist, born 4 Feb 1864 in St. Petersburg, dir., Moscow Bot. Garden 1900-1931, visited Buit-
enzorg (Bogor) Dec 1904-Mai 1905, died 15 Jun 1941 in Moscow. (<em>Golenkin</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: MW. – Corr. in the Russian Academy of Sciences.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 232; Barnhart 2: 61; Biol.-Dokum. 7: 83.467-83.468;
Bossert p. 147; Collander p. 121; CSP 15: 364; De Toni 4: xxiv; Hirsch p. 100; Lipschitz
2: 300-305; LS 33.705-33.706; MW p. 140; Portr. 3: 488; Rehder 5(index): 330, 949; SK 1:
196; TL-2/7: 634 (index); Tucker 1: 284, 2: xvii.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Intl. address book botanists: 366. 1931.
Dammerman, K.W., 1945. <em>In</em>, P. Honig &amp; F. Verdoorn (eds.), Science and scientists in the
	Netherlands Indies: 68.
Dörfler, I., 1896. Botaniker-Adressbuch: 128 (as "Michael"); 1902. Id., ed. 2: 175. (as
	"Michael"); 1909. Id., ed. 3: 36. (as "Michail Iljitsch")

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Golenkinianthe</em> Koso-Pol. (1914). Presumably the algal genera <em>Golenkinia</em>
Chodat (1894) and <em>Golenkiniopsis</em> O. Korshikov (1953) also commemorate M. Golenkin.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: Helped translate two of E. Warming's works into Russian, viz.:
(1) With S.I. Rostovzev in 1893, the third Danish ed. of <em>Haandb. syst. Bot.</em> ... 1891 (see
TL-2/7, nr. 16.719); and
(2) With W.M. Arnoldi in 1901, <em>Plantesamfund</em> ... 1895 (see TL-2/7, nr. 16.732); the first
of two Russian editions.

Gombault, René (1871-1971), French bureaucrat and botanist, French Customs Inspector-Gén.
of Syria and Lebanon in 1930s, resided in Versailles (Seine-et-Oise) ca. 1939. (<em>Gombault</em>).

PAGE: 288
HEADING: GOMES

Gomes, Bernardino António (1768-1823), Portuguese physician, chemist, botanist and
parasitologist, born 29 Oct 1768 in Paredes de Coura, studied medicine at Univ. of Coim-
bra and graduated Mai 1793, named surgeon to the Royal Navy 1797, resided in Brazil
1797-1801, returned to Portugal and worked as a physician in military hospitals, introduced
smallpox vaccination to Portugal 1812, returned briefly to Rio de Janeiro 1817, died 13 Jan
1823 in Lisbon. (<em>Gomes</em>).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Father of Bernardino António Gomes (1806-1877) (see below).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: B, LISU, MW.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 232 (b. "1769"); Backer p. 651; Baillon 2: 718;
Barnhart 2: 62; Colmeiro penins. p. 124 (index); CSP 2: 932, 7: 795, 10: 21, 15: 368; Hor-
tus 3: 1194; IH 2: 230; Jackson p. 551 (index, b. "1769"); MW p. 140; PR ed. 1: 3774-3776,
ed. 2: 3465; Rehder 5(index): 331; Urban-Berl. p. 350; Zander ed. 11: 756 (as "Gomez"),
ed. 17: 950 (as "Gomes").

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Candolle, A.L., 1880. Phytographie: 415.
Fonseca, O. da, 1972. Bernardino António Gomes. <em>In</em>, Gomes, B.A., Plantas medicinais do
	Brasil 5: 11-20. (frontisp. portr.)
Gomes, B.A., 1857. Noticia da vida e trabalhos scientificos do medico Bernardino António
	Gomes, Lisboa (Typ. da Academia): 25 p. [Mem. Acad. Ci. Lisboa, Cl. Sci., n.s., 2 (Parte
	1, 2)]
Lindemann, E., 1884. Bull. Soc. Imp. Naturalistes Moscou 59: 298.

Gomes, Bernardino António (filius) (1806-1877), Portuguese physician and botanist, born
22 Sep 1806 in Lisbon, bachelor degree in mathematics, Univ. of Coimbra, Dr. en médecine
Paris, dir., Naval Hospital, doctor of the Real Câmara, president, Society of Medical Sciences
of Lisbon, founder and editor, <em>Gazeta Médica</em>, died 8 Apr 1877 in Lisbon. (<em>Gomes f</em>.).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Son of Bernardino António Gomes (1768-1823) (see above).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Europe (1875): K.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 232; Barnhart 2: 62; BM 2: 693; Colmeiro 1:
clxxvii; Colmeiro penins. p. 124-125 (index), CSP 2: 932, 10: 21, 15: 368; Jackson p. 551
(index); Kew 2: 438; Kew List 26 (as "Gomes, Dr."); Rehder 5(index): 331; Tucker 1: 60
(as "Barros Gomes, Bernardino"); Zander ed. 17: 950.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon. [Trimen, H. (ed.)], J. Bot. 15: 160. 1877.
Dolezal, H., 1974. Friedrich Welwitsch: 238. (index)
Francard, D.A., 1963. [B.A. Gomes Filho, his life and his work (in Portugese)]. Med. Con-
	temp. 81: 233-264. (n.v.)
Gomes, B.A., 1857. Noticia da vida e trablahos scientificos do medico Bernardino António
	Gomes, Lisboa (Typographia da Academia Real das Sciencias): 33 p. (n.v.)
Stearn, W.T., 1973. Garcia de Orta, Bot. 1(1-2): 101-104. [background on the lawsuit be-
	tween the King of Portugal and the executors of the will of F. Welwitsch]

36.777. On <em>Welwitschia</em>, a <em>new genus</em> of <em>Gnetaceae</em> by J.D. Hooker. Extracto e noticia pu-
blicados no Diario de Lisboa de 2 de junho de 1863 ... Lisboa (Imprensa Nacional) 1863.

	1136.

<em>Note</em>: (1) The first section (p. [3]-6), entitled "Uma viagem scientifica em Angola", de-
	scribes F. Welwitsch's exped. to Angola. (2) The second section (p. [7]-29), is a transl.
	from English to Portuguese of J.D. Hooker, "On Welwitschia, a new genus of Gneta-
	ceae", Trans. Linn. Soc. London 24(1): 1-48, <em>pl. 1-14.</em> [30 Jan] 1863. (3) <em>Welwitschia
	</em>Hook. f. (1862) (Welwitschiaceae), nom. cons., see ING 3: 1863. 1979.

HEADING: GÓMEZ

Gómez de la Maza [y Jiménez], Manuel (1867-1916), Cuban botanist and physician, born
10 Mai 1867 in Havana, Doctorate in Medicine and Natural Sciences 1887 Univ. of Havana,
prof. of botany and phytogeography, Univ. of Havana, died 26 Jan 1916 in Havana, "... era
un botánico de gabinete" who on his death left numerous unpublished mss. (<em>M. Gómez</em>).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Colleagues who know Hispanic personal nomenclature postulate [not confirmed]
that (1) his paternal family name was Gómez, (2) his paternal grandmother's family name
was de la Maza, presumably an important family name and (3) his maternal family name
was Jiménez. Nonetheless, he signed his publications as "Manuel Gómez de la Maza".

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: not cited in IH 2, presumably at one of the herbaria in Havana.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 233; Barnhart 2: 63; BM 2: 693; CSP 15: 369;
Frodin ed. 2: 288; Kew 2: 439; Lenley p. 284 (as "Maza"); Rehder 5(index): 331; TL-2/3:
948 (Maza confused with Mazé, Hippolyte Pierre, 1818-1892), 2/6: 897 (indices); Tucker
1: 284, 2: xvii; Zander ed. 17: 950.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Revista Fac. Letras Ci. Univ. Habana 22: 143. Jan 1916.
Alvarez Conde, J., 1958. Hist. Bot. Cuba: 297-300. (portr. p. 295)
Dörfler, I., 1902. Botaniker-Adressbuch, ed. 2: 292; 1909. Id., ed. 3: 396.
Manitz, H., 1999. Regnum Veg. 136: 251-252. (bibl.)
Roig, J.T., 1916. Mem. Soc. Cubana Hist. Nat. Felipe Poey 2: 47-48.
Trelles, C.M., 1918. Biblioteca científica cubana: 310. (portr. facing p. 312) (n.v.)
Urban, I., 1902. Symb. Antill. 3: 83. (as "Maza")

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Mazaea</em> Krug &amp; Urb. (1897), nom illeg.; <em>Neomazaea</em> Krug &amp; Urb. (1898). The
algal genus <em>Mazaea</em> Bornet &amp; Grunow (1882), however, honors Hippolyte Pierre Mazé
(1818-1892), see TL-2/3: 391-392.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Earlier Gómez de la Maza was cited as co-author with J.I. Torralbas of <em>Flórula fa-
nerogámica</em> del <em>Jardin botánico</em> ... 1895 (TL-2/6, nr. 14.740), but our analysis of a copy at
NY suggests that the authorship should be reversed and that the paging is more extensive
than earlier thought, viz.:
<em>Flórula fanerogámica</em> del <em>Jardin Botánico</em> y del Vedado ... Habana (Imprenta de A. Alvarez
y Compañia) 1895. Oct.
<em>Co-author</em>: Torralbas, José Ildefonso (1842-1903), see TL-2/6: 399 and IH 2: 1032.
<em>Publ</em>.: 1895, t.p. [=p. 1], p. [2]-40. <em>Copies</em>: HH, NY, USDA. – Originally published as a
	separate ("pliego aparte") to Anales Inst. Segunda Enseñ. 2(6). Dec 1895 (n.v.).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1887, cover-t.p, t.p. [=p. 1], p. [2]-53, [i-ii, "autores citados", "erratas"]. <em>Copies</em>: LC
	(n.v.), NY, USDA.
<em>Note</em>: Doctoral thesis, Facultad de Ciencias de La Habana.

<em>Ed. 2</em>: 1916, ... unchanged (except for better quality paper). <em>Copies</em>: HH (n.v.), USDA.

*Gomont, Maurice Augustin (1839-1909), French forester and algologist, born 11 Mai
1839 in Rouen, entered forestry school in Nancy 1858, appointed "garde-général des
forêts" in Rouen, frustrated by administrative duties he resigned, began painting (with some
success) but by the 1870s turned again to natural sciences, "Préparateur", Muséum natl.
d'Histoire naturelle, Paris, where he focused his attention on algae, died 22 Jun 1909 in
Rouen. (<em>Gomont</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: PC, duplicates BERN, L.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 233; Barnhart 2: 63; BJI 1: 22; BM 2: 693; BN p.
174; Bossert p. 147; CSP 15: 369; De Toni 1: li-lii, 4: xxiv-xxv; DTS 1: 92; IH 2: 231; KR
p. 241; Moebius p. 75; MW p. 140; Nordstedt suppl. p. 7; Portr. 3: 489; TL-2/1: 970, 2/5:
1031 (index).

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Bornet, Éd., 1909. Bull. Soc. Bot. France 56(7): 440-449, <em>pl. 7.</em> (bibl., portr.)
Bourelly, P., 1962. Introduction to facsimile reprint Monogr. Osc. Weinheim: v-xi.
Charpin, A. &amp; J. Timbal, 2007. Acta Bot. Gallica 154: 453.
Davy de Virville, A., 1954. Hist. bot. France: 209, 215.
De Toni, G.B., 1909. Nuova Notarisia 20: 160-161. (as "Maurizio Agostino")
Dörfler, I., 1896. Botaniker-Adressbuch: 59; 1902. Id., ed. 2: 76; 1909. Id., ed. 3: 110.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: <em>Monogr. Oscill.</em> ... 1896 (see TL-2/1, nr. 2085) has been reprinted a second time in
the series Historiae naturalis classica ... Lehre (Cramer) 1972.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: Contributed <em>Myxophyceæ hormogoneæ</em> ... to J. Schmidt, <em>Flora of Koh
Chang</em> ... Part IV, Aug 1901 (see TL-2/5, nr. 10.891). – <em>Note</em>: Also issued as a separate, viz.
cover-t.p., p. [119]-128, <em>pl. 5</em> (chromolith.). <em>Copies</em>: FH, K.

Gonggrijp [Gonggryp], Justus Willem (1885-1974), Surinam-born Dutch forester, born
20 Mai 1885 in Plantage Clevia, educated at Wageningen Agricultural College, Wagenin-
gen, The Netherlands, Forest Officer in Surinam 1908-1923, then in Dutch East Indies (In-
donesia) until retirement in 1935, in retirement a lecturer in geography, Delft Technical
College, The Netherlands, died 3 Oct 1974 in Breda, The Netherlands. (<em>Gonggrijp</em>).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: (1) In 1948, at least, he spelled his surname "Gonggryp". (2) Louis Gonggrijp
(1893-1957), also a forester in Surinam and Indonesia, was a cousin.

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Surinam (chiefly in B.W. series): B, L, U (orig.), WAG; Indonesia:
BO.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 63; IH 2: 231; Kew 2: 440; SK 1: 196-197.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Ek, R.C., 1991. Fl. Guianas, Suppl. Ser., Fasc. 2: 10, 40.
Gonggryp, J.W. &amp; D. Burger, 1948. Fonds Lanbouw Exportbureau 1916-1918, Wageningen
	Publicatie no. 32: 227-229. (bibl.)
[Steenis, C. van], 1975. Fl. Males. Bull. 28: 2307.

36.804. <em>Wild Hevea</em> in <em>Dutch-Guyana</em> (Surinam) ... Amsterdam (J.H. de Bussy) 1911. Oct. (<em>Wild Hevea Dutch-Guy</em>.).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1911, cover-t.p., p. [1]-16. <em>Copy</em>: U.

1920. Fol. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 23 and 30 Apr 1920 (in journal), cover-t.p., p. [1]-35. <em>Copies</em>: K (photocopy, "p.
	269-293"), NY (photocopy, "p. [269]-271, [289]-292") (n.v.), U. – Reprinted and to be
	cited from Indisch Mercuur 17-18: 269-293. 23 and 30 Apr 1920.
<em>Note</em>: The bois de rose femelle is <em>Aniba</em> (Lauraceae).

36.806. <em>Verslag</em> over een <em>studiereis</em> door een <em>gedeelte</em> van <em>Venezuela</em> (balata, chicle, vee-
teelt) ... Paramaribo [Surinam] (J.H. Oliviera) 1921. Oct.

Gonnet, Philippe[-Prosper ?] Hilarion (Abbé) (1796-1861), French cleric and botanist,
born 12 Oct 1796 in Baucet (Vaucluse), ordained 1820 and held various posts in Gard from
1840 until his death 10 Feb 1861 in Tresques. (<em>Gonnet</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: CGE, DBN.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 63 (as "Propser [sic] Hilarion"); BM 2: 693;
IH 2: 231; Jackson p. 274; PR ed. 2: 3467; Rehder 5(index): 331; Tucker 2: 284.

HEADING: GONZÁLEZ

Charpin, A. &amp; G.G. Aymonin, 2003. J. Bot. Soc. Bot. France 21: 76. ("Prosper Hilarion")
Nelson, E.C., 1980. Glasra 4: 48. (specimens at DBN)

36.807. <em>Flore élémentaire</em> de la <em>France</em>, rédigée d'après le système de Linnée modifié par le

*González Fragoso [Gonzales Fragoso], Romualdo (1862-1928), Spanish physician and
mycologist, born 18 Mai 1862 in Seville, finished his study of medicine in 1882 in Seville,
went to Paris and received M.D., received the Order of Isabella the Catholic 1884, pediatri-
cian in Seville from 1885, traveled again to France, Belgium and Switzerland, conservator,
museum for natural sciences, Madrid 1911, president, Real Sociedad Española de Historia
Natural 1920, died 3 Jun 1928 in Madrid. (<em>Gonz. Frag.</em>).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Treated in TL-2/1: 868 as "Fragoso, Romualdo Gonzalez" but the author himself
(and sometimes mycologists) generally used "González Fragoso". One reprint at NY is
signed by the author "ommagio de Gz. Fragoso".

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BC, further material at BERN, MA, PC.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 234; Barnhart 2: 63; BM 2: 694, 6: 384; Bossert
p. 147; Colmeiro 1: clxxviii; CSP 10: 23 (as "Gonzalez Fragoso"), 15: 373 (as "Gonzalez
Fragoso"); De Toni 1: xlviii (as "Fragoso, R.G."); GR p. 758; GR cat. p. 64 (as "Gonzalez-
Fragoso"); Hawksworth p. 182; IH 2: 205 (as "Fragoso, Romualdo Gonzalez"); Lipschitz
5178-5179, 8707-8777, 9743-9781 (sub Gonzalez); LS suppl. 8707-8777 (as "Fragoso,
R.G."), 9743-9781 (as "Gonzalez-Fragoso, R. (de)"); Morren ed. 10: 52 (as "Fragoso");
NAF 7(15): 1066; TL-2/1: 868 (as "Fragoso, R.G."), Suppl. 4: 609 (index, as "Fragoso,
R.G."); Tucker 3: 111 (as "Fragoso, R. Gonzalez").

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Arch. Bot. Caen Bull. Mens. 2: 184. 1928.
Chardon, C.E. &amp; R. Ciferri, 1928. Mycologia 20: 353.
Charpin, A. &amp; J. Timbal, 2007. Acta Bot. Gallica 154: 453.
Ciferri, R., 1928. [Publ.] Estac. Agron. Moca (Santo Domingo), Ser. B, Bot. no. 12: 1-17.
	(bibl. (98 works), phot. frontisp.)
Cuatrecasas, J., 1929. Butl. Inst. Catalana Hist. Nat. 9: 49-51.
[Engelmann, W.], 1891. Botanisches Adressbuch: 96. (as "Fragoso, Romualdo Gonzalez")
Fernández Riofrio, B., 1928. Cavanillesia 1(7-8): 120-127. (bibl. [ mycol.], portr.)
Rodríguez Sardiña, J., 1928. Bol. Patol. Veg. Entomol. Agr. 3: 75-80. (portr.)
Unamuno, L.M., 1928. Ann. Crypt. Exot. 1: 257-265. (bibl., portr.)
Unamuno, L.M., 1928. Reseñas Cient. Soc. Españ. Hist. Nat. 3: 81-101. (portr.)
Unamuno, L.M., 1929. Bull. Soc. Mycol. France 44: 309-316. (portr.)

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Fragosoa</em> Cif. (1926); <em>Fragosoella</em> Petr. &amp; Syd. (1927).

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: With R. Ciferri:
(1) <em>Hong. paras. Dominic.</em> ... 1925[-1928], which is treated under the latter mycologist, who
was first author of nos. 1-3 and co-author of nos. 4-16 (see TL-2/Suppl. 4, nr. 26.426).
<em>Note</em>: A note on this work found at FH: "In this version, González Fragoso is main author of

PAGE: 297
HEADING: GONZÁLEZ

	Parts 1-3 and 16 with Ciferri as co-author; in Parts 4-15, Ciferri is main author and González
	Fragoso co-author. As later reprinted in Republica Dominica Estación Agronomica de Haina
	(Parts 1-5) and ... de Moca (parts 6-16 and Icones 1-6), authorship is reversed".
(2) <em>Iconogr. hong. paras.</em> ... 1926, also treated under the latter mycologist, who was co-
author of the entire work (see TL-2/Suppl. 4, nr. 26.427).

Good, Ronald D'Oyley (1896-1992), British botanist and plant geographer, born 5 Mar
1896 in Dorchester (Dorset), military service W.W.-I from 1914-1918 and wounded in ac-
tion, M.A. and Sc.D. Cambridge, Botany staff, BMNH 1922-1928, then head of Botany,
Hull Univ., Hull, England from 1928 until retirement in 1959, F.L.S., died 11 Dec 1992 in
Hull (Yorks.). (<em>R.D. Good</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: (mostly England): BM, DOR, HLU, K, NMW, WRHM; Bahrain
(1950): K. – Mss. materials in Hull Univ. Archives and Dorset History Centre.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 234; Barnhart 2: 64; BFM p. 286 (index); BL 1:

HEADING: GOOD

22, 298, 2: 237-238, 660; Ewan ed. 2: 86-87; Hirsch p. 101; Hortus 3: 1194; IH 2: 231; Kent
ed. 2: 150; Kew 2: 441-442; Langman p. 326; MW p. 140, suppl. p. 77; NW p. 46 (index);
TL-2/Suppl. 5: 429 (index); Tucker 3: 121.

Goodale, George Lincoln (1839-1923), American botanist and physician, born 3 Aug
1839 in Saco (York Co.), Maine, A.B. 1860 and M.A. (hon.) 1866 Amherst College, Am-
herst, Mass., M.D. 1863 Bowdoin College, Bowdoin, Maine and 1863 Harvard Medi-
cal School, Cambridge, Mass., practised medicine in Portland, Maine and taught in the
Portland School for Medical Instruction 1863-1866, chair of natural science and chem-
istry, Bowdoin College 1867-1872, prof. of materia medica, Medical School of Maine
1868-1872, lecturer on vegetable physiology 1872-1873, asst. prof. 1873-1878, prof. of
botany 1878-1909 (Fisher Prof. of Natural History 1888-1909) and dir. 1879-1909, Bo-
tanic Garden, all at Harvard Univ., responsible for the Botanical Museum of same and
commissioned the "glass flowers" made by Leopold (1822-1895) and Rudolf Blaschka
(1857-1929), retired 1909, Natl. Academy of Sciences, president, A.A.A.S. 1890-1891,

PAGE: 303
HEADING: GOODALE

LL.D. 1890 Amherst, 1890 Bowdoin and 1896 Princeton, president (and one of several
founders), New England Botanical Club 1897-1899, died 12 Apr 1923 in Cambridge, Mass.
(<em>Goodale</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: GH; Maine: WELC (now NY). – Mss. at Harvard Univ., Cam-
bridge, Mass., incl. Botanical Museum (Curatorial records), Gray Herb. (Administrative
corr.) and Harvard Univ. Archives (papers George Lincoln Goodale).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Amer. Men Sci. ed. 4: 262; Barnhart 2: 64; BL 1: 3, 184,
298; BM 2: 694; Bossert p. 147; CSP 15: 375; DAB 9: 231-232; Ewan Pap. p. 80; IH 2: 231;
Jackson p. 552 (index); Kew 2: 442; Lenley p. 183; ME 1: 53, 3: 582 (index); Morren ed.
10: 122; NI 2: 70; NW p. 46 (index); PH p. 401 (index); Portr. 3: 490; Rehder 5(index):
331; Rhodora, index p. 331; TL-2/5, 2/6, Suppl. 1 (indices); Tucker 1: 285, 3: 121.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Ames, O., 1925. Proc. Amer. Acad. Arts. 59: 640-644.
Bailey, L.H., 1923. Rhodora 25: 117-120. (portr.)
Coulter, J.M., 1924. Bot. Gaz. 77: 453. (portr.)
Dörfler, I., 1896. Botaniker-Adressbuch: 195; 1902. Id., ed. 2: 251; 1909. Id., ed. 3: 331.
[Engelmann, W.], 1891. Botanisches Adressbuch: 129.
Ewan, J. (ed.), 1969. Short hist. bot. U.S.: 166. (index)
Jackson, R.T., 1923. Harvard Grad. Mag. 32: 54-59. (portr.)
Jones, G.N., 1966. An annotated bibl. Mexican ferns: 76.
Osterhout, W.J.V. et al., 1923. Amer. J. Sci., ser. 5, 6: 275-276. [reprinted from Harvard
	Univ. Gazette, 16 Jun]
Robinson, B.L., 1927. Mem. Natl. Acad. Sci. 21(6th Mem.): 1-19. (bibl., portr.)
Trelease, W., 1923. Science, n.s., 57: 654-656.
Warnement, J., 1997. Taxon 46: 649-660.
Wittrock, V.B., 1903. Acta Horti Berg. 3(2): 179; 1905. Id. 3(3): 195.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) Goodale and Rev. Joseph Blake (fl. 1868) prepared <em>The Portland
catalogue of Maine plants</em> ... 1868, which was reprinted, with omission of localities and
separation of introduced species, from the Proc. Portland Soc. Nat. Hist. 1: 37-63, 127-138.
1862. <em>Copies</em>: US(2). – <em>Note</em>: M.L. Fernald was responsible for a second edition of the
Portland catalogue in 1892 (see TL-2/Suppl. 7, nr. 34.299).
(2) Co-editor with Cyrus Fogg Brackett (1833-1915), <em>Bowdoin Scientific Review</em>, vols.
[1]-2 (nrs. 1-51) (15 Feb 1870-17 Sep 1872).
(3) The reissue of A. Gray, <em>Bot. text</em> ... ed. 6, 1885 (see TL-2/1, nr. 2122), also has on the
t.p. "Part 2: Physiological botany by G.L. Goodale ...."
(4) <em>Wild fl. Amer.</em> ... [1876-]1880-1882[-1894] (TL-2/5, nr. 12.635) was treated earlier un-
der its illustrator, Isaac Sprague. Issued in parts, the publication is more complicated than
the earlier entry suggests. There is an 1876-1880, Salem [Mass.] (S.E. Cassino)/New York
(Dodd Mead &amp; Co.) imprint and an 1879-1880 [© 1879] subscription edition ("Sold only
to subscribers for the whole work") with a Boston (S.E. Cassino) imprint. In addition, two
imprints, both Boston (Bradlee Whidden), are the most commonly encountered ones; the
first was issued in 1886 [© 1879] and the second 1894 [© 1879]. The BKL copy of the 1894
imprint is dated by pen "February 13th 1894".
(5) Watson, S. &amp; G.L. Goodale, <em>List of the writings of Dr. Asa Gray</em>: <em>chronologically ar-
ranged</em> ... Amer. J. Sci., ser. 3, 36 (App): 1-42. 1889, <em>see</em> Asa Gray (below).
(6) One of nine signatories to O. Ames et al., <em>Prop. changem. lois nom.</em> ... 1904 (TL-2/
Suppl. 1, nr. 19.149), proposals submitted to the 1905 Vienna Congr. in opposition to the
"American school of nomenclature". – <em>Note</em>: In TL-2, the exact same title is also treated
under the final signatory, Roland Thaxter, and given a different abbreviation and number
(TL-2/6, nr. 14.014).
(7) Associate editor (for botany) of the <em>American Journal of Science</em>, ser. 3.

Goodenough, Samuel (Rev. Dr.) (1743-1827), clergyman and student of British plants,
born 29 Apr 1743 in Kimpton (Hants.), B.A. 1764, M.A. 1767, Dr. Civil Law (LL.D.)
1772 Oxford, one of the three founders of the Linnean Society 1788 and its first treasurer,
F.R.S. 1789, Bishop of Carlisle 1808, died 12 August 1827 in Worthing (Sussex) (buried in
Westminster Abbey). (<em>Gooden</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BM (<em>Carex</em> drawings), CLE (now K), GL, K, YRK. – Mss. mate-
rials in the Linnean Society of London and at Kew.

ed. 2: 285; De Toni 2: lii; DNB 8: 124-125; Dryander 5: 256 (index); Herder p. 279; IH 2:

<em>Note</em>: Later J.E. Smith wrote (in Rees, <em>Cyclopedia</em>) "It did not occur to me that <em>Gooden-
ovia</em> might have come closer to the original". The Bishop Goodenough, a first-class Greek
and Latin scholar, often criticized Smith's naming of plants (<em>teste</em> Walker, 1996).

Goodman, George Jones (1904-1999), American botanist, born 5 Nov 1904 in Evanston,
Wyoming, A.B. 1929 Univ. of Wyoming, Laramie, M.Sc. 1930 and Ph.D. 1933, Washing-
ton Univ., St. Louis, Missouri (under J.M. Greenman), Asst. Prof. of Botany, Univ. of Okla-
homa, Norman 1933-1936, then Assoc. Prof. of Botany and Curator of Herb., Iowa State
College, Ames 1936-1945, returned to Univ. of Oklahoma as Prof. of Botany and Curator of
Robert Bebb Herb. 1945-1975, Curator emeritus 1975-1999, died 23 Mai 1999 in Norman,
Oklahoma. (<em>Goodman</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: OKL.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 235; Amer. Men Sci. ed. 12: 2223; Barnhart 2: 65;
Bossert p. 148; Ewan ed. 1: 217, ed. 2: 87; Ewan Pap. p. 80; IH 2: 232; Kew 2: 444; Lang-
man p. 326; Portr. 3: 491; Rhodora, index p. 331; Roon p. 44.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Intl. address book botanists: 474. 1931; ASPT Newslett. 14: 3-4. 2000.

Goodspeed, Thomas Harper ('Harper') (1887-1966), American botanist specializing in <em>Nic-
otiana</em>, born 17 Mai 1887 in Springfield, Mass., studied briefly at Gaillard College, Lausanne,
Switzerland, A.B. 1909 Brown Univ., Providence, Rhode Island, Ph.D. 1912 Univ. of Calif.
at Berkeley, instructor in Botany 1912, asst. prof. 1916, assoc. prof. 1920 and prof. 1928, all
Univ. of Calif. at Berkeley, curator 1926 and first dir. 1934 of revived and expanded Botanic
Garden in Berkeley, from which he launched collecting trips to the Andes, Dr. h.c. 1940
Brown Univ. and 1943 Univ. of La Plata (Argentina), hon. Sc.D. 1957 Univ. of Cuzco (Peru),
numerous other honors, retired 1957, died 17 Mai 1966 in Calistoga, Calif. (<em>Goodspeed</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: A, GH, MO, POM, UC (p.p. orig.), US, WTU. – Thomas Harper
Goodspeed: Corr. Relating to Research on Tobacco, 1926-1950, Bancroft Library, Univ.

PAGE: 307
HEADING: GOODSPEED

of Calif., Berkeley; other papers at HU and reprints at Rancho Santa Ana Botanic Garden,
Claremont, Calif.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Amer. Men Sci. ed. 10: 1458; APN p. 235; Barnhart 2:
65; Bossert p. 148; DSB 17 (Suppl. 2): 359-360; Ewan Pap. p. 80; Hirsch p. 101; Hortus
3: 1194; IH 2: 232; Kew 2: 444; Langman p. 326; Lenley p. 183; MW p. 141; Portr. 1: 63
(index), 3: 491; Sotheby 1: 249; Strid p. 133, ed. 2: 183; TL-2/5, Suppl. 3, 4 (indices);
Tucker 3: 121.

Ewan, J. (ed.), 1969. Short hist. bot. U.S.: 166. (index)

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) <em>Notes on the California species of Trillium</em> ... 1916-1917 (TL-2/
Suppl. 3, nr. 22.559) of which Goodspeed was first author of parts 1 and 2, and sole author
of 4, was treated earlier under R.P. Brandt.
(2) First (not co-) author of <em>F-1 sp. hybr. Nicotiana</em> ... 1917 (TL-2/Suppl. 4, nr. 26.520),
which was treated earlier under R.E. Clausen.
(3) Co-author with R.E. Clausen, <em>Appar. fl. measure</em> ... 1918 (TL-2/Suppl. 4, nr. 26.521).
(4) First author or co-author of parts 1-6 and 8 of <em>Interspecific hybridization in Nicotiana</em>
I[-XXVIII] ... 1922[-1957] (TL-2/Suppl. 4, nr. 26.523), most parts of which were treated
earlier under R.E. Clausen.
(5) Co-author of various parts of <em>Inheritance in Nicotiana tabacum</em> I[-XXVIII] ... 1922
[-1957], (TL-2/Suppl. 4, nr. 26.523), which was treated earlier under R.E. Clausen.
(6) Co-author with R.H. Chipman, <em>Inheritance in Nicotiana tabacum</em> VIII ... 1927 (TL-2/
Suppl. 4, nr. 25.949).
(7) Editor, <em>University of California Publications in Botany</em> (1930-1938).
(8) Editor, <em>Essays in geobotany in honor of William Albert Setchell</em> ... 1936 (see TL-2/5:
530, sub Festschrift).

<sm>OUTSIDE OUR PERIOD</sm>: (1) <em>Plant hunters in the Andes</em> ... New York (Farrar and Rinehart),
