*Goor, Andreas Cornelis Joseph van (1881-1925), Dutch phycologist, born 24 Oct 1881
in Amsterdam, Ph.D. 1917 Amsterdam, asst., Dutch marine biol. station, Den Helder where
H.C. Redeke was dir., asst. to Gino Pollacci in Siena, Italy 1924, became ill and returned to
Amsterdam where he died 23 Apr 1925. (<em>Goor</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: L (principal part) and AMD (some types); additional material
probably still unlocated in Italy.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 235; Barnhart 2: 65; Biol.-Dokum. 7: 83.740-83.741;
BL 2: 434, 660; IH 2: 232; JW (1): 442; TL-2/1: 971, 2/4: 1172 (index).

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Dörfler, I., 1909. Botaniker-Adressbuch, ed. 3: 204. (as "Van Goor, A.C.J.")
Frémy, P., 1928 ['1926']. Rev. Algol. 3: 1-7. (bibl., portr.)
Pollacci, G., 1926. Atti Accad. Fisiocrit. Siena ser. 10, 1: 205-208. (bibl., portr.)
Stomps, Th. J., 1925 ['1924']. Ned. Kruidk. Arch. 34: 239-244. (bibl.)
Stomps, Th. J., 1926. Ber. Deutsch. Bot. Ges. 43: (44)-(46). (bibl., 44 items)

Gortani, Luigi (1850-1908), Italian /Austrian building engineer, architect and botanist, born

Gosselman(n), Carl August (1831-1893), Swedish botanist, born 18 Aug 1831 in Karls-
krona, student in Lund 1849, Ph.D. 1853 Lund, teacher in Karlskrona from 1865, died 15
Apr 1893 in Elestrop (Skåne). (<em>Gosselman</em>).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Not to be confused with Karl (Carl) August Gosselman(n) (1799/1800-1843), a
Swedish naval officer who published on his travels in N. and S. America, which were trans-
lated from Swedish into German by Albert Georg Friedrich Freese (1786-1854).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

333; SMK 3: 76-77.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Wittrock, V.B., 1905. Acta Horti Berg. 3(3): 13.

*Gothan, Walther [Walter] [Ulrich Eduard Friedrich] (1879-1954), German paleontolo-
gist, born 26 Aug 1879 in Woldegk (Mecklenburg), briefly studied at Clausthal College of
Mines, Harz, then College of Mines and Univ. of Berlin, Ph.D. 1905, lecturer, Berlin Col-
lege of Mines 1908-1914 and Berlin College of Technology 1914-1933 (prof. from 1919),
Prof. of Paleobotany, Humboldt Univ., Berlin 1946-1954, also Geologist, Prussian Geologi-
cal Survey and from 1913 Keeper of the Institute of Paleobotany, hon. president of the 1950
and 1954 Botanical Congresses, died 30 Dec 1954 in Berlin-Charlottenburg, "the Nestor of
German Palaeobotany and leader of the Berlin school of palaeobotanists ...." (<em>Gothan</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: B.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Andrews p. 270-271; APN p. 236; Barnhart 2: 68; BFM p.
286 (index); Biol.-Dokum. 7: 83.906-83.922; BM 6: 386; Bossert p. 149; Hirsch p. 102; IH
2: 233; Kew 2: 450; KR p. 242; Langman p. 327; LS suppl. 9824; Moebius p. 143; NDB 6:
654; Portr. 1: 63 (index), 3: 494; Sarjeant p. 1125; TL-2/1: 973, 2/4: 1172 (index); Tucker
1: 286, 3: 122.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Intl. address book botanists: 138. 1931; "Paläobotanische Beiträge zum
	100. Geburtstag Walther Gothans", p. 341-388, In, Wiss. Z. Humboldt-Univ. Berlin,
	Math.-Naturwiss. Reihe 39(3): 249-388, i-viii. 1980.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) Co-author with H. Potonié:
(a) <em>Vegetationsbilder</em> der <em>Jetzt</em>- und <em>Vorzeit</em>. <em>pl. 1-8</em>, 1907-1922 (see TL-2/4: 359 sub Com-
Posite Works (5)); and
(b) <em>Paläobot. Prakt.</em> ... 1913 (TL-2/4, nr. 8228).
(2) Contributed text (with R. Pilger &amp; H. Winkler) to R.H. Francé, <em>Leben Pfl., Pfl.-leben
Deutschlands</em> ... <em>III. Abteilung</em> ... 1913.
(3) Co-author with W.J. Jongmans:
(a) <em>Paläobotanisch-stratigraphische Studien</em> im <em>Niederländischen Carbon</em> ... 1915;
(b) <em>Beiträge</em> zur <em>Kenntnis</em> der <em>Flora</em> des <em>Oberkarbons</em> von <em>Sumatra</em> ... 1925; and
(c) "2. Die <em>paläobotanischen Ergebnisse</em>" in Die Ergebnisse der paläobotanischen Djambi-
Exped. 1925 ... 1935.
(4) Edited titles by H. Potonié:
(a) <em>Entst. Steinkohle</em> ..., ed. 6, 1920 (TL-2/4, nr. 8225); and
(b) <em>Lehrb. Pfl.-Palaeont.</em> ..., ed. 2, 1921 (TL-2/4, nr. 8217), and Gothan was criticized
for his "strict editing". This title later was reworked by Gothan &amp; H[ermann]. Weyland
(1888-1974) as <em>Lehrbuch der Paläobotanik</em> ... 1954; ed. 2, ... 1964; and ed. 3 ... 1973.

36.898. <em>Bemerkungen</em> zur <em>Alt-Carbonflora</em> von <em>Perú</em>, besonders von Paracas ... Separat-

	59: 292-299, <em>pl. 13-15.</em> 1928.

*Gottsche, Carl [Karl] Moritz (1808-1892), Danish-born German physician and hepati-
cologist (noted for superb drawings), born 3 Jul 1808 in Altona (then part of Denmark),
graduated in Berlin and Copenhagen as doctor of medicine and surgery in 1831, settled in
Altona 1834 to care for his father and practice medicine, after his father's death in 1837
he devoted his life to botany and often traveled (e.g. E. Asia 1885), died 28 Sep 1892 [of
typhus?] in Altona (then part of Prussia). (<em>Gottsche</em>).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Not to be confused with the geologist Carl Christian Gottsche (1855-1909).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Gottsche's original herb., mss. and drawings were at B. "... wohl
haben Asa Gray und Hooker versucht, es uns Deutschen zu entführen; dem patriotischen
Manne war es ein Herzensbedürfniss, dass es in Deutschland blieb, und so verbindet sich
mit dem Schmerz über seinem Heimgang, die Freude, dass uns dieser Schatz ... erhalten
geblieben ist" (<em>fide</em> Stephani). BM has "many authentic specimens of hepatics described
by him, acquired with Herb. Hampe in 1881", MANCH has Bryoph., and other specimens
are at GH and GJO. Also of note are the <em>Icones jubularum</em>, tracings of drawings and he-
patics by Gottsche and others, now at FH (see TL-2/6: 706). – <em>Exsiccatae</em>: (1) Co-author
of fascs. 6-11 of J.B.W. Lindenberg, <em>Sp. Hepat.</em> (<em>Lindenberg</em>) ... Bonn ([1839-]1846-1851)
(see TL-2/3, nr. 4632). (2) Co-author of decades 23-66 of G.L. Rabenhorst, <em>Hepat. Eur.,
Leberm.</em> ... Dresden ([1855-]1869-1879 (see TL-2/4: 463 sub "Exsiccatae: (9)")).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: ADB 49: 491-493 (as "Karl"); Andrews p. 271; APN p.
237; Barnhart 2: 69; BM 2: 699-700, 6: 387; BN p. 174; Bossert p. 149; CSP 2: 955-956,
7: 804, 10: 34, 15: 397; DTS 1: 92; Frahm&amp;E. p. 144-147; Frank 3(Anh.): 37; Herder p.
261; Hist. Coll. BMNH p. 151; IH 2: 233; Jackson p. 552 (index); Kew 2: 450; Kew List p.
27, 54; Mägdefrau p. 122; Moebius p. 122; Morren ed. 10: 8; MW p. 141; NI 2: 70; Portr.
3: 494; PR ed. 1: 5915, 7437, ed. 2: 3483-3484; Rehder 5(index): 333; SBC p. 121; TL-1:
175, 269; TL-2/1: 974-975, indices 2/1, 2/2, 2/3, 2/4, 2/5, 2/6; Tucker 1: 286; Urban-Berl.
p. 264, 300, 350.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Bescherelle, E., 1893. Rev. Bryol. 20: 46-48.
[Engelmann, W.], 1891. Botanisches Adressbuch: 6.
Ewan, J. (ed.), 1969. Short hist. bot. U.S.: 96.
Fischer-Benzon, R.J.D., 1890. <em>In</em>, P. Prahl, Krit. Fl. Schlesw.-Holst. 2: 19-20.
Fischer-Benzon, R.J.D., 1895. Heimat 5: 130-132.
Franks, J.W., 1973. Manchester Mus. Publ., new ser., no. NS.1.73: 3, 15.
Hedge, I.C. &amp; J.M. Lamond (eds.), 1970. Index collectors Edinburgh Herb.: 83.
Hertel, H. &amp; A. Schreiber, 1988. Mitt. Bot. Staatssamml. München 26: 221.

*Gouan, Antoine (1733-1821), French botanist and naturalist, born 15 Nov [not Dec] 1733
in Montpellier, studied in Toulouse then Montpellier, doctorate 1752 (at 19 years of age!),
student of F.-B. Sauvages whom he succeeded as dir. of the Jardin des Plantes, Montpellier
1767, died 1 Sep 1821 in Montpellier. (<em>Gouan</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: K (through W.J. Hooker, see Edinburgh J. Sci. 2: 184. 1825); ad-
ditional material C, K, KIEL, LINN, MEL, MPU, NY (few specimens), P-HA, PH, SBT,
UPS (Thunberg herb.). – Corr. of Linnaeus.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 2(1): 563; APN p. 237; Backer p. 240, 651; Baillon
2: 725-726; Barnhart 2: 69; BM 2: 700; Bossert p. 149; Colmeiro 1: clxxviii; Colmeiro,
penins. p. 74; DBF 16: 676-677; De Toni 2: lii; Dryander 5: 257 (index); Ewan Pap. p. 81;
Frank 3(Anh.): 37; GFB ed. 2: 96; GR p. 280; GR cat. p. 64; Herder p. 453 (index); Hortus
3: 1194; IF p. 699; IF suppl. 4: 354; IH 2: 233; Jackson p. 34, 287, 420; Kelly p. 92; Kew
2: 450-451; Kew List p. 27; KR p. 242; Krempelh. 1: 610; Lasègue 569 (index); Lenley p.
456; LS 10.260-10.263; MW p. 141; NI 2: 70, Suppl. p. 35; Plesch p. 240; Portr. 3: 495; PR
ed. 1: 3795-3803, ed. 2: 3485-3492; Rehder 5(index): 333; SO p. 25 (index); Sotheby 1:
240-241; TL-1: 175-176; TL-2/1: 975-976, 2/5: 1031 (index); Tucker 1: 286-287; Zander ed.
10: 664, ed. 11: 756, ed. 17: 950.

	permis de qualifier les personnes d'après les titres féodaux, et qu'on la réimprimer telle
	qu'elle étoit".

Goy, Doris Alma (1912-1999), Australian botanist, born in Mount Morgan, Queensland,
educated in Mount Morgan state primary and high schools, clerk, Dept. of Agriculture
and Stock, Brisbane, Queensland, transfered to Botany Branch (now Queensland Herb.)
early 1930s, married botanist Lindsay Stuart Smith (1917-1970) in 1942 and her marriage
brought her (then) compulsory retirement, active member Queensland Naturalists' Club
and a specialist in Australian ferns, died 9 Oct 1999 in Chernside, Brisbane. (<em>Goy</em>).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: After our period of concern she published as D[oris]. A[lma]. Smith.

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: A, BM, GH, MO, NSW.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 238; IF suppl. 4: 322, 354; IH 2: 234.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Henderson, R.J.F., 1997. <em>In</em>, J. McKay, Brilliant careers: women collectors and
	illustrators in Queensland, South Brisbane (Queensland Museum): 59. (portr.)

<sm>OUTSIDE OUR PERIOD</sm>: (1) Smith, D.A., 1946. <em>Check list</em> of <em>North Queensland ferns</em>. Publi-
cation (North Queensland Natural. Club) 3: 11 p.
(2) Smith, L.S. &amp; D.A. Smith, 1982. The naturalised <em>Lantana camara complex</em> in eastern
Australia. Queensland Botany Bull. 1: 1-26.

Gradmann, Robert Julius Wilhelm (1865-1950), German floristic botanist, geographer
and priest, born 18 Jul 1865 in Lauffen am Neckar, Lutheran priest in Forchtenberg am
Kocher, Dr. phil. 1898 Univ. of Tübingen, library dir., Univ. of Tübingen 1901-1919, ha-
bilitated 1909, prof., Univ. of Erlangen, retired 1934, died 16 Sep 1950 in Sindelfingen nr.
Stuttgart. (<em>R. Gradmann</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Herb. and letters at Staatl. Mus. Naturkunde Stuttgart. – Phot., at
least, Stadtarchiv Schaffhausen, Switzerland.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 72; BFM p. 286 (index); Bossert p. 150; CSP
15: 410; Kew 2: 456; LS 10.274; NDB 6: 703-705; TL-2/Suppl. 6: 515 (index as "Grad-
man"); Tucker 1: 288.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Borsdorf, A. &amp; C. Ellger, 2003. Die Erde Sonderheft 1: 70.
Champier, L., 1952. Ann. Univ. Saraviensis, Philosophie, lettres, I, 2, 1952: 190-202. (n.v.)
Charpin, A. &amp; J. Timbal, 2007. Acta Bot. Gallica 154: 453.
Dörfler, I., 1902. Botaniker-Adressbuch, ed. 2: 17; 1909. Id., ed. 3: 36.
Eck, H., 1991. Staatsanzeiger Baden-Württemberg, Beiträge zur Landeskunde 6: 11-14. (n.v.)
Schäfer, R. (ed.), 2002. Robert Gradmann: vom Landpfarrer zum Professor für Geographie
	... 50. Todestages von Robert Gradmann. DRW-Verlag. ix, 150 p. (portr.) (n.v.)

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) Co-editor with J. Eichler &amp; E.W.G. Meigen of the serial <em>Ergebnisse
der pflanzengeographischen Durchforschung von Württemberg</em> ... 1[7], 1905-[1926], see
TL-2/6, nr. 32.569 and B-P-H/S 1991: 319.
(2) Editorial board of <em>Die Erde</em> (1923-1935).

	2-25</em> (chromolith.). <em>Copies</em>: G, K (n.v.).
[Bd. 2]: frontisp. [=<em>pl. 26</em>], p. [i]-xxxii, [1]-423, <em>pl. 27-50</em> (chromolith.). <em>Copies</em>: G, K (n.v.).
<em>Ref</em>.: Goebel, K., Flora 87: 116. 8 Feb 1900 (rev.).
	Engler, A., Bot. Jahrb. Syst. 27(Lit. Ber.): 37. 23 Feb 1900 (brief rev.).
	Solms, H., Bot. Zeitung (Berlin) 48 (Abt. II, 7): 99. 1 Apr 1900 (rev.).
<em>Ed. 3</em>: 1936, [Bd. 1]: <em>Pflanzengeographische Darstellung</em>, ... p. [i]-xvi, [1]-470, <em>pl. 1-25
	</em>(chromolith.). <em>Copies</em>: G, K (n.v.).
[Bd. 2]: Nachschlagebuch, p. [i]-xxxix, [1]-351, [i, colophon], 1 loose-leaf abbrev. <em>Copies</em>:
	G, K (n.v.).
<em>Ref</em>.: Ginzberger, A., Oesterr. Bot. Z. 86(3): 229-230. 1937 (rev.).

HEADING: GRAEBNER

<em>Ed. 4</em> [4. Aufl.]: 1950, ... Bd. 1: <em>Pflanzengeographische Darstellung</em>, ... Stuttgart (Verlag

*Graebner, [Karl (Carl) Otto Robert Peter] Paul (1871-1933), German botanist, born 29
Jun 1871 in Aplerbeck (nr. Dortmund), studied at the Kolberg Kgl. Dom. Realgymnasium
1882-1888, in military 1888-1889, employed in nurseries in Gardelegen and Steglitz nr.
Berlin, at the garden school Wildpark 1890, volunteer asst. at the Berlin Botanic Garden
1891, studied botany at Berlin Univ. at the instigation of F. Pax, asst. to P. Ascherson 1892,
Dr. phil. 1895 Univ. of Berlin, from 1895 employed at the Berlin Botanic Garden, from 1903
also employed by the Dahlem horticultural school, prof. 1910, expert on the heather com-
munities in n. Germany, died 6 Feb 1933 in Berlin (buried in Lichterfelde). (<em>Graebn</em>.).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: His son, Paul Graebner (1900-1978) (see below), was also a botanist.

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: B (partly extant).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 1, ed. 2: 2, 3: 836, 5(3): 88; APN p. 238; Backer p. 241,
651; Barnhart 2: 72; BFM 50, 55; BM 2: 703, 6: 35, 388-389; Bossert p. 150; CSP 15: 412;
DTS 1: 11, 92, 6(4): 142; Hirsch p. 103; Hortus 3: 1194; IF p. 675; IF suppl. 4: 354; IH 2: 234;
Kelly p. 92; Kew 2: 456-457; Langman p. 328; LS 10.275-10.278, 33.735-33.737; Mägdefrau
p. 310 (index); Moebius p. 367; Morren ed. 10: 24; MW p. 142, suppl. p. 17; NDB 6: 706
(listed as brother of Robert Fritz Graebner); Portr. 1: 63 (index), 3: 487; Rehder 5(index):
334; SO p. 25 (index); TL-2/1: 977-978; indices 2/1, 2/4, 2/5, 2/6, 2/7, Suppl. 1, 6; Tucker 1:
288, 3: 123; Urban-Berl. p. 350; Zander ed. 10: 664, ed. 11: 714, ed. 17: 950; Zep.-Tim. p. 54.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Steglitzer Anzeiger (2. Beil., nr. 148), 27 Jun 1931 (portr.); Intl. address
	book botanists: 138. 1931 (as "P.P."); Cavanillesia 6(4-9): 141. 1934.
Dörfler, I., 1896. Botaniker-Adressbuch: 16; 1902. Id., ed. 2: 17; 1909. Id., ed. 3: 36.
Fuchs, H.P., 1991. Bull. Murith. Soc. Valais. Sci. Nat. 109: 151. (b. "19 Jun")
Runge F., 1978. Natur &amp; Heimat (Münster) 38(3): 103-104. (n.v.)

Wittrock, V.B., 1905. Acta Horti Berg. 3(3): 136.

(TL-2/1, nr. 2105), viz. ed. 1 (1901): (a) Solms, H., Bot. Zeitung, 2. Abt. 60 (Abt. II, 8):
116-118. 16 Apr 1902, and (b) Gürke, M., Bot. Jahrb. Syst. 31(Lit.): 21-22. 29 Aug 1902.
(rev.); and ed. 2 (1925): (aa) Krause, K., Beibl. Hedwigia 65(3): 107. 15 Oct 1925, and (bb)
Mattfeld, J., Bot. Jahrb. Syst. 60(Lit.): 66-67. 1 Apr 1926. Additionally, ed. 2 was reprinted
in 1976 in Vaduz (Gantner Verlag).
(2) <em>Taschenb. Pflanzenbest.</em> ... 1911 (TL-2/1, nr. 2106) is now available in microfiche:

	fiches (Plant taxonomic lit. microfiche coll., "2037F3-2040C5"). <em>Copy</em>: MO (n.v.).

Graebner, Paul (1900-1978), German botanist, born 4 Feb 1900 in Berlin-Lichterfelde,
Ph.D. 1924 Berlin, employed, Westfälisches Provinzial-Museum für Naturkunde, Münster
1931 (at least). (<em>Graebn. f.</em>).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Son of Paul Graebner (1871-1933) (see above).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: B, MSTR.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 238; Barnhart 2: 72; IH 2: 234; Moebius p. 367;
TL-2/1: 1120 (index); Tucker 3: 123 (p.p., confused with father!).

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Intl. address book botanists: 138 (1931). (as "Graebner, Paul, jun.")
Weisse, A., 1934. Ber. Deutsch. Bot. Ges. 51: (188).

<sm>OUTSIDE OUR PERIOD</sm>: <em>Die Pflanzenwelt des Paderborner Raumes</em> ... Paderborn (Junfer-
mannsche Verlagsbuchhandlung) ... 1964, which often is misattributed in library catalogs
to the senior Graebner.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: Co-author with his father on Band 5(2) (Liefer. 1-10) of <em>Syn. mitteleur.
Fl.</em> ... (1920-1929), see TL-2/1, nr. 200 (sub "Graebner s. e. f."). The younger Graebner
also co-authored or authored other parts of this 12 vol. <em>Synopsis</em> and carried on after the
death of his father as editor of the last issues through 1938 (Id. sub "Graebner fil.").

36.923. <em>Beiträge</em> zur <em>Flora</em> des <em>Urwaldes</em> von <em>Bialowies</em> ... Berlin (Gebrüder Borntraeger)
1925. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 1925, cover-t.p., t.p., p. [i], [117-118, contents], 119-236, map. <em>Copies</em>: BM (n.v.),
	HH (n.v.), NY (cover-t.p. wanting), USDA. – In series, Beiträge zur Naturdenkmalpflege,
	Bd. 10, Heft 3.
<em>Note</em>: (1) At head of title "Staatliche Stelle für Naturdenkmalpflege in Preussen". (2) Al-
	though often misattributed in library catalogs to the senior Paul Graebner (1871-1933),
	the t.p. clearly states "Paul Graebner filius".

Graëlls [Graells, Graélls] [y de la Agüera], Mariano de la Paz (1809-1898), Spanish phy-
sician, botanist and naturalist interested in Lepidoptera and mammals, born 24 Jan 1809
in Tricio (Logroño), studied medicine and natural sciences, Barcelona Univ., one of the
founders of the Museo de Historia Natural de la Academia de Ciencias y Artes, moved to
Madrid in 1837 to be Prof. of Zoology, Real Museo de Ciencias Naturales, then dir. of the
museum and the Real Jardín Botánico de Madrid 1845-1868, co-founder Real Academia de
Ciencias Exactas, Físicas y Naturales de Madrid, died 14 Feb 1898 in Madrid. (<em>Graëlls</em>).

PAGE: 323
HEADING: GRAFF

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BM ("Herbarium Castellanum" purchased 1872), CGE, FI, LY,
MA, MACB, MPU, OXF, P, PH and Real Colegio Alfonso XII (Madrid). – Archival ma-
terials in Museo Nacional de Ciencias Naturales.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 238; Barnhart 2: 72; Clokie p. 172; Colmeiro 1:
clxxviii; Colmeiro, penins. 125 (index); CSP 2: 974-975, 6: 675, 10: 42, 15: 413; Herder p.
176; Hist. Coll. BMNH p. 151 (as "Graells"); IH 2: 234; Kew 2: 457; PR ed. 2: 3500-3501;
Rehder 5(index): 335; Tucker 1: 288; Zander ed. 17: 950.

Graff, Paul Weidemeyer (1880-1969), American mycologist, born 10 Oct 1880 in India-
napolis, Indiana, B.S. 1907 Conn. Agric. College, Storrs, Conn. (now Univ. of Conn.), Aus-
tin Teaching Fellow, Harvard Univ., Cambridge, Mass. 1907-1909, mycologist, Bureau of
Science, Manila, Philippines 1911-1914 and botanist, Univ. of Philippines 1912-1914, New
York Botanical Garden and Columbia Univ., New York, New York 1915-1916, M.A. 1916

PAGE: 324
HEADING: GRAFF

and Ph.D. 1932 Columbia Univ., Botany Instructor, Univ. of Montana, Missoula, 1916-ca.
1920, in New York 1920s, from 1931 consulting mycologist, also taught at Mountain Lake
Biol. Station, Univ. of Virginia, Charlottesville 1945 and Furman Univ., Greenville, South
Carolina 1945, died Oct 1969. (<em>P.W. Graff</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Philippines: PNH (destroyed in W.W.-II), duplicates BPI, BR, M,
NY, RUTPP, S, UC; U.S.A (Montana, South Carolina &amp; Virginia fungi): BPI, VA and
Mountain Lake Biol. Station, Pembroke, Virginia. – Corr. in FH (David H. Linder papers)
and Lloyd Library, Cincinnati (Curtis Gates Lloyd papers).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Amer. Men Sci. ed. 10: 1481; APN p. 238; Barnhart 2: 73;
BL 1: 195, 298; GR p. 189; GR cat. p. 64; Hirsch p. 103; IH 2: 235; Kelly p. 92; Kew 2: 457;
LS suppl. 9874-9886; SK 1: 199; TL-2/5: 1031 (index).

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., J. New York Bot. Gard. 16: 228. 1915, 19: 249. 1918; Intl. address book
	botanists: 474. 1931; Cat. Farlow Ref. Library 2: 339. 1979.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: In 1922, Graff published additions to P.C. Standley, <em>Flora of Glacier
National Park Montana</em> ... 1921, see TL-2/5, nr. 12.772.

Graham, Edward Harrison (1902-1966), American botanist and conservationist, born 30
Nov 1902 in New Brighton, Penn., B.Sc. 1927 and Ph.D. 1932, Univ. of Pittsburgh, Asst.
Curator of Botany, Carnegie Museum, Pittsburgh, U.S.D.A. Soil Conservation Service
1937-1964, becoming Asst. Admin. for Intl. Programs, Guggenheim Fellow 1954, Board
of Governors, The Nature Conservancy, Chairman, Commission on Ecology, I.U.C.N.
1957-1966, in retirement with the Conservation Foundation, Washington, D.C., collected
plants in the Guianas (1924) and Utah (1931, 1933, 1935), died 16 Mai 1966 in Falls
Church, Virginia. (<em>E.H. Graham</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: CM (orig., incl. field notes), duplicates GH, MO, NY, US.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Amer. Men Sci. ed. 10: 1483; APN p. 238; Barnhart 2: 73;

Frodin ed. 2: 328; Hirsch p. 103; IH 2: 235; Kew 2: 458; Pennell p. 607.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Intl. address book botanists: 474. 1931.

Stieber, M.T., 1982. Huntia 4: 156, 168.

Graham, Robert James Douglas (1884-1950), Scottish botanist, born 20 Jul 1884 in Perth,
B.Sc. and M.A. 1904 Univ. of St Andrews, economic botanist in Indian Agricultural Service
1907-1917, D.Sc. 1917 Univ. of St Andrews, W.W.-I Army service as Lieut.-Col., Asst. Dir.
and then Dir. of Agriculture, Mesopotamia (now Iraq) 1917-1920, lecturer in Botany, Univ.
of Edinburgh 1921-1934, Prof. of Botany, Univ. of St Andrews 1934-1950, F.R.S.E. 1924,
died 3 Sep 1950 in St Andrews (Fife). (<em>R.J.D. Graham</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BAG, BM, K.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 239; Barnhart 2: 73; BL 2: 295, 661; Desmond p.
262, ed. 2: 290: Kew 2: 459.

	Oct 1950 (obit.); <em>In</em>, S. Devlin-Thorp, Scotland's cultural heritage, vol. 1: [1 p.] 1981.
	(bibl., portr.) (n.v.).
Anthony, J., 1935. Notes Roy. Bot. Gard. Edinburgh 18: 277-303. (Iraq collections)

*Gran, Haaken Hasberg (1870-1955), Norwegian algologist, born 17 Apr 1870 in Tøns-
berg, cand. real. 1894 Univ. of Bergen, asst., botany lab., Univ. of Bergen 1894, studied
plant physiology with Wilhelm Pfeffer in Leipzig 1896-1897 and bacteriology with Mar-
tinius Beijerinck in Delft and Texel, Ph.D. 1902, Prof. of Botany, Oslo Univ. 1905-1940,
traveled to Seattle 1928, died 2 Jun 1955 in Oslo. (<em>Gran</em>).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: (1) In 1902, Gran coined the term "bloom" for the appearance of phytoplankton
species in the sea in the spring. (2) Gran, together with T(h)orbjørn Gaarder (1885-1970),
introduced the oxygen method of measuring phytoplankton production.

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: O.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 239 (as "Haaken"); Barnhart 2: 74 (as "Haakon");
BM 2: 705; BN p. 174; Bossert p. 150; CSP 15: 418; De Toni 4: xxv; Hirsch p. 103; IH 2:
235 (as "Haakon"); Kew 2: 460 (as "Haaken"); Kleppa p. 322 (index); KR p. 322 (index)
(as "Haaken"); LS 10.295; MW p. 142; Moebius p. 70 (as "Haakon"); Portr. 3: 498 (as
"Haakon"); TL-2/1: 978 (as "Haaken").

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Intl. address book botanists: 278. 1931.
Benson, K.R., 1990. Deutsche Hydrographische Zeitschrift, Ergänzungsheft (Reihe B) 22:
	375-377. (n.v.)
Braarud, T., 1956. Cons. permanent int. Explor. Mer 21: 121-124. (portr.)
Braarud, T., 1956. Deep-Sea Research 3: 232-233.
Braarud, T., 1956. Norske Vidensk.-Akad. Oslo Årb. 1955: 53-57. (portr.)
Dörfler, I., 1896. Botaniker-Adressbuch: 108; 1902. Id., ed. 2: 302; 1909. Id., ed. 3: 207.
Holmboe, J., 1979. <em>In</em>, E. Bull &amp; E. Jansen (eds.), Norsk Biografisk Leksikon 4: 558-
	560.
Kleppa, P., 1973. Norsk bot. bibl. 1814-1964: 322. (index as "Haaken")
Sundene, O., 1956. Blyttia 14: 37-40. (portr.)
Wittrock, V.B., 1905. Acta Horti Berg. 3(3): 183.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Grania</em> (Rosenv.) Kylin (1944). <em>Note</em>: The annelid genus <em>Grania</em> Southern
(1913) is named for a 16th century female chief on Clare Isl., Ireland.

*Grand'Eury, François Cyrille (1839-1917), French mining engineer and paleontologist,
born 9 Mar 1839 in Houdreville-sous Vézelise (Meurthe-et-Moselle), studied at the École
Loritz, Nancy, then at the School of Mines, St.-Étienne (Loire), tutor ("répétiteur") from
1863, then prof. of mathematics 1883-1899, also at the School of Mines, corr., Académie
des Sciences 1885, Légion d' honneur and many other academic prizes, died 22 Jul 1917 in
Malzéville-sous-Nancy (Meurthe-et-Moselle). (<em>Grand' Eury</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: P.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Académie p. 223; Andrews p. 272; APN p. 239; Barnhart
2: 74; BM 2: 705, 6: 390; BN p. 174; CSP 7: 815, 10: 45, 12: 288, 14: 939, 15: 418-419; DBF
16: 958-959; DSB 5: 497-498; Frank 3(Anh.): 37; IH 2: 235; Jackson p. 180, 184; Kew 2:
460; LS l0.299; Moebius p. 381 (as "Cyrill"); Morren ed. 10: 68; NI 2: 71; Quenstedt p.
169; Sarjeant p. 1131; TL-2/1: 979.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Andrews, H.N., 1980. The fossil hunters, Ithaca, New York (Cornell Univ. Press):
	419. (index)
[Appell, P.], 1917. Compt. Rend. Acad. Sci., Paris 165: 168-170.

Davy de Virville, A., 1954. Hist. bot. France: 333, 335, 339.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: Co-author with B. Renault, "<em>Étude sur le Sigillaria spinulosa</em> ..."
1875, which is one of several articles by Renault in the series "<em>Recherches sur les végétaux
silicifiés d'Autun</em>" and although treated earlier (see TL-2/4, nr. 9001) no mention was made
then of Grand'Eury's contribution.

36.954. [Mémoire sur la] <em>Flore Carbonifère</em> du <em>Département de la Loire</em> et du Centre de
la France, étudiée aux Trois points de vue[:] botanique, stratigraphique et géognostique ...
Paris (Imprimerie Nationale) 1876. Qu. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 1876, p. [1]-348 [=1st part, Botanique], [349]-624 [=2nd part, Géologie], 1 map (col.),
	<em>pl. 1-34</em> (uncol. lith.), <em>A-D</em> (uncol. lith.) [=Atlas]. <em>Copies</em>: BM(3) (n.v.), G, HH (n.v.),
	K (n.v.), MO (n.v.), NY (n.v.), NYPL (n.v.); IDC E-5359/2. – Reprinted and to be cited
	from Mém. Acad. Sci. Inst. Natl. France 24(1): 1-624, <em>pl. 1-34, A-D.</em> 1876.
<em>Note</em>: Vol. 24 as a whole is dated 1877.

36.955. <em>Notice paléontologique</em> ... Saint-Étienne (Société de l'Imprimerie Théolier – J.
Thomas &amp; Cie) 1897. Qu.

	1897.

Grant, Adele [Adèle] [Gerard] (née Lewis) (1881-1969), American botanist, born 3 Jul
1881 in Carpenteria, Calif., B.Sc. 1902 Univ. of Calif. at Berkeley, married George F.
Grant, M.A. 1919 and Ph.D. 1923 Washington Univ., St. Louis, Missouri, botany instruct-
tor, Cornell Univ., Ithaca, New York 1920-1926, lecturer, Huguenot Univ. College, S. Afr.
1926-1930, Asst. Prof., Washington Univ. 1930-1931, lecturer, Univ. of S. Calif., retired in
1952, died 19 Jun 1969 in Los Angeles (Ingelwood). (<em>A.L. Grant</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: S. Afr.: B, BM, F, K, LA (3000), LISM, MO, POM, UC; Calif.:
CU, MO, UC, WELC (now NY). – Letters at GH.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Amer. Men Sci. ed. 9: 426; APN p. 239; Barnhart 2: 75
(sub Grant) &amp; 374 (sub Lewis); Bossert p. 150; Ewan Pap. p. 82; Hirsch p. 103; Hortus 3:
1194; IH 2: 235; Langman p. 329; MW p. 142; NW p. 46 (index); Portr. 1: 64 (index); Strid
p. 135, ed. 2: 185; Tucker 3: 123.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Intl. address book botanists: 474. 1931.
Cantelow, E.D. &amp; H.C. Cantelow, 1957. Leafl. W. Bot. 8: 91.
Goldblatt, P., 1976. Taxon 25: 375-376. (d. "1967")
Gunn, M. &amp; L.E. Codd, 1981. Bot. explor. S. Afr.: 172.
Hertel, H. &amp; A. Schreiber, 1988. Mitt. Bot. Staatssamml. München 26: 318.

Botanical Garden] 1924. Oct. (<em>Monogr. Mimulus</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 5 Jan 1925 (issue date as footnote on p. 99), cover-t.p., p. 99-388, <em>pl. 3-10</em> (uncol.

HEADING: GRAY

	phot. &amp; lith.). <em>Copies</em>: G, HH (n.v.), K (n.v.), NY (n.v.). – Reprinted and to be cited

	435-453. 1938.

Grant, Bartle (Capt.) (1856-1924), Scottish soldier, born 16 Sep 1856 at Rothiemurchus,
educated at Edgeborough School, Guildford (Surrey), then a gentleman cadet in Royal Mil-
itary Academy, Woolwich, followed by the Royal Military College Sandhurst, sub-Lieut.
with the VIIIth (King's Royal Irish) Hussars 1875, in Afghanistan (awarded an Afghan
Medal) and then India, made Capt. 1883 and then Major 1886, but stripped of latter rank
for falling into debt, entered the Border Regiment as Capt. 1890, stationed at Rangoon,
returned to England 1898, called back into service during Boer War and entered the Royal
Garrison Regiment in Malta, his only child was the post-impressionist painter and designer
Duncan James Corrowr Grant (1885-1978), died 16 Apr 1924 in Twickenham (ashes in-
terred in Rothiemurchus). (<em>B. Grant</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Kew 2: 461.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Bridson, G.D.R. et al., 1980. Nat. hist. manuscript resources British Isles: 404.
	(index) (as "Grant, B.")
Nelson, E.Ch., 2005. BSBI news 100: 30-31.
Nelson, E.Ch., 2006. Curtis's Bot. Mag. 23: 248-255. (portr.)
Spalding, F., 1997. Duncan Grant: a biography. London (Chatto &amp; Windus). (portr.)

36.958. The <em>orchids</em> of <em>Burma</em> (including the Andaman Islands) described ... Rangoon
(Hanthawaddy Press) 1895. Oct. in halfsheets. (<em>Orch. Burma</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1895, t.p., p. [ii, blank], [iii, errata], [iv, blank], [v-vi, pref.], [1]-424, [1]-8 [=in-
	dex], [i, "Memmoradum [sic] Form", fold.]. <em>Copies</em>: BM, G, HH(2) (n.v.), K(2, 1 being
	Grant's own interleaved annotated copy), NY, USDA; IDC E-7315/2.
<em>Ref</em>.: Anon., J. Bot. 34(407): 487. Nov 1896 (noticed).
<em>Note</em>: (1) "A scissors-and-paste job with little claim to originality ..." (<em>teste</em> Nelson, 2006,
	p. 252). (2) There was also at least one page in the book intended to solicit information:
	"As information as to the localities where the different species of Orchids are to be found,
	and the seasons at which they flower, cannot fail to be of value, I have given some forms
	at the end of the book which can be filled up from time to time, and sent to me for use
	should a second edition of this work be called for".
<em>Reprint</em> [1]: 1966, ... Rangoon (Central Press), 416, 8 p. <em>Copy</em>: HH (n.v.).
<em>Reprint</em> [2]: [1976?], ... Dehra Dun: M/S Bishen Singh Mahendra Pal Singh. <em>Copy</em>: US.
<em>Note</em>: Reprint [2], at least, omits the "Memorandum Form" mentioned above.

*Gray, Asa (1810-1888), American botanist, born 18 Nov 1810 in Sauquoit (Oneida Co.),
New York, son of a farmer, educated at Fairfield (New York) Academy and Fairfield Medical
School (M.D. 1831), science teacher at high school in Utica, New York 1832-1835, asst. to
John Torrey 1833, Curator and librarian, Lyceum of Natural History, New York City 1836,
Prof. of Botany, State Univ. of Michigan (now Univ. of Michigan at Ann Arbor) 1838, visited
European herbaria 1838-1839, appointed to the Fisher Chair of Natural History, Harvard

PAGE: 332
HEADING: GRAY

Univ., Cambridge, Mass. 1842, retired from teaching 1873, president A.A.A.S. 1863-1873,
regent, Smithsonian Inst. 1874-1888, F.R.S. (foreign member) 1873, LL.D. Cambridge, Ox-
ford and Edinburgh (all 1887), died 30 Jan 1888 in Cambridge, Mass. (<em>A. Gray</em>).

"... nobody did more to spread the love of natural history in America" (p. 71 in Foster W.
Russell, Mount Auburn biographies: a biographical listing of distinguished persons interred
in Mount Auburn Cemetery, Cambridge, Massachusetts ... 1953).

<sm>HERBARIUM, TYPES, ORIGINAL MANUSCRIPTS, ARCHIVES, CORRESPONDENCE</sm>: GH (see also
IH 2: 237). – <em>Exsiccatae</em>: (1) <em>N. Amer. Gram.</em> ... 1834-1835 (see TL-2/1, nr. 2119 for de-
tails). (2) <em>Plantae Exsiccatae Grayanae</em> ... 1902-1945, the specimens were not assembled
by Gray but issued by the Gray Herb. long after his death. – Other significant sources of
corr. and archival materials include Harvard Univ. (various collections), Kew and LC; see
Dupree (1959, p. 423-425) for additional sources.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Académie p. 224; AG 3: 13; APN p. 240; Backer p. 243,
644; Barnhart 2: 78; BL 1: 131, 158, 160, 165, 201, 298; BM 2: 709-711, 6: 393; BN p. 174;
Bossert p. 151; Bretschneider 388-390; Clokie p. 713; CSP 2: 994-996, 7: 818-819, 10:
48-49, 12: 290, 15: 431; DAB 7: 511-514; DSB 5: 439-440; Ewan ed. 1: 218-219, 350 (in-
dex), ed. 2: 89-90; Ewan Pap. p. 82; FNA ser. 2(10): 210-211; Frank 3(Anh.): 37; Frodin ed.
2: 1028 (index); GFB ed. 2: 97; GR p. 219; Herder p. 438, 453 (indices); Hist. coll. BMNH
p. 151; Hortus 3: 1194; IF p. 699; IF suppl. 4: 354; IH 2: 237; Jackson p. 552 (index); Kew
2: 466-468; Kew List p. 27; Langman p. 331-332; Lasègue p. 202-203, 569 (index); Lenley
p. 185-187, 456-458; LS 10.326; Mägdefrau p. 310 (index); ME 1: 188-189, 3: 584 (index);
Morren ed. 2: 36, ed. 10: 122; MW p. 142-143; NAF 28B(2): 332, ser. 2(2): 158, ser. 2(7):
40, ser. 2(9): 122, ser. 2(12): 50; NI 2: 71; NI suppl. p. 36; NW p. 47 (index); Pennell p.
608; PH p. 401 (index); Portr. 1: 64 (index), 3: 500; PR ed. 1: 3846-3852, ed. 2: 3522-3532;
Quenstedt p. 171; Rehder 5(index): 337-338; Rhodora, index p. 331-332; RHS 2: 449-450;
RS p. 85; Sarjeant p. 1135-1137, Suppl. 1: 456, Suppl. 2: 672; SO p. 25 (index); TL-1: 518
(index); TL-2/1: 983-993, indices 2/3, 2/5, 2/6, 2/7; Tucker 1: 289-297, 2: 10 (bio.), 3: 124;

	68.</em> (portr.)

EPONYMY (additional): Asa Gray Award, A.S.P.T.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: (1) I [DHN] found a fascinating review of then current botanical events by Asa Gray
in Amer. J. Sci. Arts, ser. 2, 13(37): 42-53. Jan 1852 [reprint repaged, p. 1-13]. It touches on
Alph. de Candolle, posthumous publications of Kunth and Endlicher, Brongniart, Martius,
deaths of Link, Kunth, Koch, Ledebour, Bernhardi, Wahlenberg, what Webb and Weddell
are doing, Montagne, Decaisne, Gaudichaud, Spach, Naudin, Claude Gay, purchase of
Pavon herbarium, Richard, Boissier, Choisy, Lehmann, Blume, Wm. Hooker (noting the
new Palm House), J.D. Hooker, acidulous comments on Griffith's posthumous publica-

PAGE: 336
HEADING: GRAY

tions, work in fossils, ferns, hepatics, mosses, algae, lichens. It shows an astounding grasp
of what was going on in European botany!
(2) Earlier a skeletal revision of <em>Contributions</em> to <em>North American botany</em> ... 1846-1888
(see TL-2/1, nr. 2123) was offered; the serial but not reprints analyzed. Subsequently we
have examined a number of reprints and our analyses are detailed below (each reprint ana-
lyzed also is assigned a new number in the TL-2 series).
(3) Information on IDC microfiches not in TL-2/1:
Nr. 2123 <em>Contr. N. Amer. Bot.</em> is on IDC E-5937/2;
Nr. 2124 <em>Manual</em> (<em>Gray</em>) is on IDC E-7546 (Ed. 1 of 1848);
Nr. 2125 <em>Gen. Amer. Bor.</em> is on IDC E-5130;
Nr. 2127 <em>Pl. wright.</em> is on IDC E-7547/1; and
Nr. 2132 <em>Syn. Fl. N. Amer.</em> is on IDC E7548/1.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) Co-author with J. Torrey:
(a) "Report on the botany of the Expedition" for the <em>Pacific Railr. Rep.</em> of J.W. Gunnison
(1857, see TL-2/6, nr. 14.764) and J. Pope (med. 1857, see TL-2/6, nr. 14.765); and
(b) <em>Revision of the Erigoneæ</em> [sic] ... 1870, see TL-2/6, nr. 14.769.
(2) One of several collaborators with S. Watson, <em>Botany</em> [<em>fortieth parallel</em>] ... 1871, see
TL-2/7, nr. 16.812.
(3) "Gamopetalae" <em>in</em> S. Watson, <em>Bot. California</em> ... vol. 1, 1876, see TL-2/7, nr. 16.815.
(4) Revised "Botany. A.–Phænogamia, Filices, et Lycopodiaceæ ..." <em>in</em> Jerome Henry Kid-
der (ed.), <em>Contributions</em> to the <em>natural history</em> of <em>Kerguelen Island</em>, made in connection with
the United States Transit-of-Venus Expedition, 1874-75. II ... p. 21-25, Washington, D.C.
(Government Printing Office), 1876. <em>Copies</em>: K, US.
(5) Co-author with J.H. Trumball, <em>Notes on the history of Helianthus tuberosus</em> ... 1877,
see TL-2/6, nr. 15.239.

	from Ludwig Kumlien, <em>Contributions</em> to the <em>natural history</em> of <em>Arctic America</em> ... Bull.
	U.S. Natl. Mus. 15: 1-179. 1879. – Also issued as Smithsonian Misc. Collect. 23(15):
	1-179. 1879.
<em>Note</em>: (1) Page 163 (i.e. notes on plant collecting) by [Aaron] L[udwig]. K[umlien].
	(1853-1902), naturalist of the Howgate Polar Exped. and son of Thure L. Kumlien
	(1819-1888) (see below sub E.L. Greene). (2) Not included in bibl. by Watson &amp; Goodale
	(1888).

PAGE: 350
HEADING: GRAY

*Gray, John Edward (1800-1875), British algologist, hepaticologist and zoologist, born
12 Feb 1800 in Walsall (Staffs.), son of Samuel Frederick Gray (1766-1828) (pharmacolo-
gist and botanist) and brother of George Robert Gray (1808-1872) (ornithologist), studied
medicine but abandoned it for zoology, from 1824 asst. Zoology Dept. and from 1840
Keeper of Zoology, BMNH, F.R.S. 1832, president, Bot. Soc. London 1836-1857, Dr. h.c.
1852 Univ. of Munich, F.L.S. 1857, president, Royal Entomol. Soc. London 1858-1859,
died 7 Mar 1875 "at his residence in the British Museum" [i.e. London] (buried in Lew-
isham). (<em>J.E. Gray</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BM, CGE (Alg.), WAR. – Mss. at BM (see Gunther, A.E., Bull.
Brit. Mus. (Nat. Hist) 6(6): 199-244. 1980) and the Amer. Philos. Soc. (ca. 500 items).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: ADB(2) 1: 470; APN p. 240; Baillon 2: 739; Barnhart 2:
78; BB p. 129; BM 2: 712-714, 6: 393-394; BN p. 174; Bossert p. 151; CSP 2: 998-1012, 7:
819-829, 10: 49-50, 12: 290; Desmond p. 264, ed. 2: 292; De Toni 1: lii, 4: xxv; DNB 23:
437-439. 2004; Ewan Pap. p. 82; IH 2: 237; Jackson p. 135, 242; Kelly p. 92; Kent p. 57, ed.
2: 153; Kew 2: 468-469; LS 10.328; Nordstedt p. 16; Portr. 3: 501; PR ed. 2: 3533-3534;
Quenstedt p. 171; Rehder 5(index): 338; TL-2/1: 993-994, 2/5: 1031 (index).

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Catalogue of the first portion of the scientific library of Dr. John Edward
	Gray ... which will be sold by auction by Messrs. Sotheby ... 1874 (n.v.); Ann. Mag. Nat.
	Hist. 15: 281-285. 1875; Gard. Chron. 3: 334-335. 1875; J. Bot. 13: 127. 1875; Proc. Linn.
	Soc. London 1874/5: xliii-xlvii. 1875; Dr. John Edward Gray, F.R.S. [London (Wat-
	son and Hazell)]: [1]-15. (s.d.) [1875?] [Excerpts from the "Athenaeum", "Gardeners'
	Chronicle", "Field", "Queen" and "Academy"]; Trans. Proc. Bot. Soc. Edinburgh 12:
	409-410. 1876.
Adler, K., 1989. Contr. hist. Herpetology: 156.
Babington, C.C., 1897. Memorials: lxxiii.
Barber, L., 1980. The heyday of natural history 1820-1870: 317. (index)
Bridson, G.D.R. et al., 1980. Nat. hist. manuscript resources British Isles: 405. (index)
Brunet, J.-Ch., 1861 [1966 reprint]. Manuel du libraire et de l'amateur de livres 2: 1718-
	1719.
Carpenter, M.M., 1953. Amer. Midl. Naturalist 50: 292.
Engelmann, W., 1846. Bibl. Hist. Nat.: 682. (index)
Gibson, J.A. &amp; E.C. Nelson, 2001. Cumulative index Archives Nat. Hist.: 59.
Gilbert, P., 1977. A compendium of the biographical literature on deceased entomologists:
	148.
Gunther, A.E., 1974. J. Soc. Bibl. Nat. Hist. 7: 35-76. (handwr., portr., excerpts from Gray's
	autobiogr. mss.)
Gunther, A.E., 1975. A century of zoology at the Brit. Mus. ... 1815-1914, [London] (Daw-
	sons of Pall Mall): 524. (index) (portrs.)
Gunther, A.E., 1979. Notes &amp; Rec. Roy. Soc. London 34: 53-63. [Gray-Darwin corr.]
Gunther, A.E. (ed.), 1980. Bull. Brit. Mus. (Nat. Hist.) 6(6): 199-244. [on J.E. Gray's
	autobiogr. mss.]
Gunther, A.E., 1980. The founders of science at the British Museum 1753-1900, Hales-
	worth (The Halesworth Press): 65-74. (n.v.)
[Lankester, E.R.], 1904. History colls. natural hist. depts. British Museum 1: 37.
Milner, J.D., 1906. Cat. Portr. Kew: 52.
Newman, E., 1875. Zoologist, ser. 2, 10: 4466-4468.

	by Dr. John Edward Gray, F.R.S. With a few historical notes. Privately published: 58 p.
	(bibl., 1096 items) [<em>Copies</em>: BM, HH, US]
Stearn, W.T., 1981. Nat. Hist. Mus. S. Kensington: 403. (index)
Wittrock, V.B., 1903. Acta Horti Berg. 3(2): 93; 1905. Id. 3(5): 78.

HEADING: GRECESCU

Woodward, B.B., 1904. Hist. Coll. Nat. Hist. Depts. Brit. Mus. 1: 37.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) Scientific editor, <em>The Annals and Magazine of Natural History,
including Zoology, Botany and Geology</em>, Vol. 1 (ser. 3)-Vol. 15 (ser. 4) (1858-1875).
(2) Scientific editor of Wm. Smith, <em>List Brit. Diat.</em> ... 1859 (see TL-2/5, nr. 12.306, where
no mention is made of Gray's role).
(3) Editor of R.A. Salisbury, <em>Gen. pl.</em> ... 1866 (TL-2/5, nr. 10.122).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1864, p. [i]-iv, [1]-123. <em>Copies</em>: BM, FH (n.v.), G, K(2) (n.v.), LC (n.v.), NY (n.v.),
	WU.
<em>Ref</em>.: W.C[arruthers?]., J. Bot. 3: 222-223. 1 Jul 1865 (rev.).

37.037. On <em>Codiophyllum</em>, a new genus of unicellular green algae from Port Natal ... (from
journal) 1872. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: Aug 1872, p. 139-141. <em>Copy</em>: BM. – Reprinted and to be cited from Ann. Mag. Nat.
	Hist., ser. 4, 10: 139-141. 1872.

*Grecescu, Dimitrie [Demetrius] (1841-1910), Romanian botanist and physician, born 15
Jun 1841 in Cernetz, studied medicine in Paris 1868, Academia Româna 1907, died 20 Oct
1910 in Bucharest. (<em>Grecescu</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: B, BUC (main), L, LY, MANCH, W.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 241; Barnhart 2: 79; BN p. 174; Futak-Domin p. 223;
Hortus 3: 1194; IH 2: 237; Jackson p. 431; Portr. 3: 501; Rehder 5(index): 338; Strid p. 136,
ed. 2: 187; TL-2/1: 994-995; Tucker 1: 298, 2: xviii; Urban-Berl. p. 350; Zander ed. 17: 950.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Charpin, A. &amp; J. Timbal, 2007. Acta Bot. Gallica 154: 453.
Dörfler, I., 1896. Botaniker-Adressbuch: 126; 1902. Id., ed. 2: 172; 1909. Id., ed. 3: 243.
	(as "Demetrius")

Green, C[onrad]. Theodore (1863-1940), English physician and amateur botanist, born
18 Nov 1863 in Helme (Yorks.), M.B. 1887 London, Member Royal College of Sur-
geons, F.L.S. 1901, president, Liverpool Bot. Soc. 1934, died 17 Apr 1940 in Birkenhead
(Cheshire.). (<em>C.T. Green</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BHD (or BHDL, now defunct), LIV, NMW. – Green's hand-
colored lantern slides of plants are in the Natural History Museum (London) and World
Museum Liverpool.

<em>Note</em>: (1) The 1902 and 1933 editions contain chapters on geology by J.J. Fitzpatrick and
	meteorology by Rev. J. Cairns Mitchell. (2) The 1902 flora is mainly a new edition of <em>The

	in turn had at least two predecessors, the floras of Joseph Dickinson (ca. 1805-1865) (see
	TL-2/1, nr. 1441 and Suppl. 5: 287-288) and Thomas Batt Hall (1814-1886) (see TL-2/2,
	nr. 2295).

Green, Jacob (1790-1841), American druggist and naturalist, born 26 Jul 1790 in Philadel-
phia, A.B. 1807 and A.M. 1810 Univ. of Penn., Philadelphia, studied and practiced law, held
chairs of chemistry, experimental philosophy and natural history, Princeton Univ., Princ-
eton, New Jersey 1818-1822, prof. of chemistry, Jefferson Medical College, Philadelphia
1825-1841, hon. M.D. 1827 Yale Univ., New Haven, Conn., visited England, France and
Switzerland 1828, published a monograph on trilobites 1832, died 1 Feb 1841 in Philadel-
phia. (<em>J. Green</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: NY, PH (herb. Muhlenberg). – Some mss. materials (botany lec-
ture notes) in Princeton Univ. Library.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 80; CSP 3: 2-3; DAB 7: 548-549; DSB 5:
517-518; Ewan Pap. p. 82; Lenley p. 458; ME 1: 189, 3: 585 (index); Quenstedt p. 171;
Rehder 5(index): 338; Sarjeant p. 1138; Tucker 1: 298.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Abbott, R.T. (ed.), 1973. Amer. Malacologists: 107.

Green, Mary Letitia ['Manna', a.k.a. Mrs. Thomas Archibald Sprague] (1886-1978), Welsh
botanist, bibliographer and botanical artist, born 27 Nov 1886 in Breconshire, Wales, gradu-
ated Univ. College, Aberystwyth 1912 and went to Kew, where she compiled supplements to
<em>Index Kewensis</em> and what is now known as <em>Index Londinensis</em>, F.L.S. 1925, Asst. in the Kew
Herb. 1929, retired 1945, died 15 Jan 1978 in Cheltenham (Gloucs.), England. (<em>M.L. Green</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: K. – Some mss. material, incl. an oral history, at HU.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 241; Barnhart 2: 80; Bossert p. 151; Desmond ed.
2: 647 (as "Sprague"); FNA ser. 2(10): 211; Hortus 3: 1194; IH 2: 237; Kew 2: 494; MW
p. 143; Portr. 1: 64 (index), 3: 502; SO p. 25 (index); Strid p. 136, ed. 2: 187; TL-2/3, 2/4
(indices, but latter leads to 2/3!); Tucker 3: 125; Zander ed. 17: 950.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Intl. address book botanists: 183. 1931.
Meikle, R.D., 1978. Taxon 27: 439.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) Miss Green &amp; T.A. Sprague (1877-1958) compiled suppls. 7, 8 and 9
(1929-1938) of the <em>Index Kew</em>., the last suppl. also acknowledging [Veronica] Mabel Irene
Skan (1902-x) &amp; Sabine Wilson (x-1959). Miss Green (then Mrs. T.A. Sprague), Skan &amp;
Wilson compiled suppl. 10 ... 1947, see TL-2/2, nr. 3218.
(2) Nomenclature proposals by Miss Green were included in T.A. Sprague, <em>Nom. Prop.
Brit. Bot.</em> ... 1929, see TL-2/5, nr. 12.651.
(3) Miss Green revised the English transl. by Sir Arthur Hort (1864-1935) of <em>The "Critica
botanica" of Linnaeus</em> ... 1938, see TL-2/3, nr. 4718.
(4) Mrs. T.A. Sprague took the minutes of the Nomenclature Sessions at the Stockholm
Congr. (1950), the basis of the 1952 report by Joseph Lanjouw (1902-1984).

37.048. <em>Note</em> on <em>anomalous bulbils</em> in a <em>lily</em> ... Ann. Bot. ... 1914. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: Apr 1914 (in journal), cover-t.p., p. [355]-358. <em>Copies</em>: K, NY. – Reprinted and to be
	cited from Ann. Bot. (Oxford) 28(110): 355-358. 1914.

<em>Publ</em>.: 30 Jun 1926 (date of transmittal letter by Kew Dir. on BM copy, Kew copy date-stamped

<em>Note</em>: (1) The work is mimeogr. (2) Basis of the truncated version appearing in "Proposals
	by British Botanists" published in 1929, specifically M.L. Green's Proposal iii (p. 97-100),
	circulated before and during the Cambridge Congr. (<em>fide</em> Stafleu, Taxon 5: 87. 1956).

*Greene, Edward Lee (later Rev.) (1843-1915), American botanist and clergyman, born
20 Aug 1843 in Hopkinton, Rhode Island, at age 12 moved with his family to Wisconsin, in-
fantryman in Union Army during Civil War 1862-1865, Ph.B. 1866 Albion Acad., Wiscon-
sin 1866, taught in rural schools in Illinois until 1870, taught botany and studied theology
in Colorado 1871, ordained Episcopal minister 1873, collected plants in the American West
for 12 years, converted to Catholicism 1885, first Prof. of Botany, Univ. of Calif., Berkeley

PAGE: 356
HEADING: GREENE

1885-1895, LL.D. 1895, Univ. of Notre Dame, Indiana, at Catholic Univ. of America, Wash-
ington, D.C. 1895-1904, hon. assoc. in Botany, Smithsonian Inst. 1904-1915, died 10 Nov
1915 in Washington, D.C. (buried in Notre Dame). (<em>Greene</em>).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: A preliminary study by T.J. Crovello in 1971 (mentioned on a typed card at US)
indicates E.L. Greene published 4412 new taxa.

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: ND-G (shipped Feb 1915 to Notre Dame from Washington, D.C.).
For duplicates see IH 2: 238 (and add BHUPM). Greene stipulated in his will that speci-
mens should never leave his herbarium (<em>fide</em> Thomas, 1961). Greene's library is also at
ND. – Important mss. collections include Edward Lee Greene papers, Univ. of Notre Dame
Archives and Thure L. Kumlien papers, Wisconsin Historical Society, Madison. In addi-
tion, materials concerning Greene and collected by Robert P. McIntosh are in the Univ. of
Notre Dame Archives and the Dept. of Botany, Univ. of Calif., Berkeley.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 241; Backer p. 243, 651; Barnhart 2: 81; Biol.-Do-
kum. 7: 85.344-85.353; BL 1: 151, 167-168, 298; BM 2: 730, 6: 407; BN p. 175; Bossert p.
152; CSP 7: 831, 10: 53, 12: 291, 15: 440-441; DAB: 9: 523-524; Ewan ed. 1: 219; ed. 2: 90-
91; Ewan Pap. p. 82; FNA ser. 2(10): 211; GR p. 219 (as "Green, E.L."); Hist. Coll. BMNH p.
151; Hortus 3: 1194; IF p. 700; IF suppl. 4: 354; IH 2: 238; Kelly p. 92-93; Kew 2: 495-496,
ser. 2(12): 50; Kew List p. 28; Langman p. 332-334; Lenley p. 187-188, 458; LS 36.119; ME 1:
189; MW p. 143, suppl. p. 78; NAF 7(15): 1066, 9(6): 437, 28B(2): 333, ser. 2, 2: 158-159, ser.
2(13): 105; NI 2: 72; NI suppl. p. 36; NW p. 47 (index); Pennell p. 608; Portr. 1: 64 (index),
3: 502-503; Rehder 5(index): 339; Rhodora, index p. 332; SO p. 25 (index); TL-2/1: 995-997,
indices 2/4, 2/6; Tucker 1: 299, 2: xviii; Urban-Berl. p. 350; Zander ed. 11: 757, ed. 17: 950.

	1915; Torreya 15: 249-250. 1915; Computerized index of 4,412 taxa published by Edward
	Lee Greene, Notre Dame, Indiana: (unpaged). 1971; A printout of the Greene index: a

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: (additional) <em>Greenella</em> A. Gray (1880); <em>Greeneocharis</em> Guerke &amp; Harms (1899).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: (1) <em>Landmarks</em> ... 1909 (TL-2/1, nr. 2144) has been reprinted with the addition of a
second part, formerly in manuscript, and other posthumous emendations:
<em>Reprint</em> [<em>Part I</em> = <em>Vol. 1</em>]: 1983, ... Stanford, Calif. (Stanford Univ. Press), p. [i]-x,
	[1]-505.
<em>Note</em>: (a) Frank N. Egerton (1936-x), "Editor's introduction", p. 3-17. (b) Robert Patrick
	McIntosh, "Edward Lee Greene: the man", p. 18-53 (incl. handwr., portr.). (c) Rogers
	McVaugh (1909-x), "Edward Lee Greene: an appraisal of his contribution to botany",
	p. 54-84. (d) Reprint of "Landmarks of botanical history ..." (1909), p. [85]-415. (e)
	"Appendix A. Pre-Grecian knowledge of plants", p. 419-425. (f) "Appendix B. Medieval
	knowledge of plants", p. 426-452. (g) "Note to Part I", p. 453-505.
[<em>Part II</em> = <em>Vol. 2</em>]: 1983, ... p. [unnumb. = p. [505] "Contents, Part II"], [506, blank]
	[507]-1139. <em>Copies</em>: HH (n.v.), K (n.v.), LC (n.v.), MO (n.v.), NY (n.v.), US.
<em>Note</em>: (a) E.L. Greene, "Preface", p. [509]-513. (b) "Appendix C. Botany in the seven-
	teenth century", p. [967]-974. (c) "Notes to Part II", p. [975]-1035. (d) "Bibliography",
	p. [1037]-1109. (e) "Index [to both parts]", p. [1111]-1139.
<em>Note</em> [<em>Parts I-II</em>]: (a) "A publication of the Hunt Institute for Botanical Documentation
	Carnegie-Mellon University" (b) The "text of part II is based on a typescript ... prepared
	at the Smithsonian in 1936 from a handwritten manuscript ... [and] published here for
	the first time". See also the Edward L. Greene Collection, SIA and the HU (microfilm of
	mss. for Part II). (c) Illus. and notes are added to the reprint, the original lacking both.
<em>Ref</em>. [<em>Parts I-II</em>]: Krikorian, A.D., Quart. Rev. Biol. 59(2): 162-163. Jun 1984 (rev.).
	Rudolph, E.D., Pl. Sci. Bull. 30(3): 22-23. Jun 1984 (brief rev.).
	Morton, A.G., Isis 75(4): 742-743. Dec 1984 (rev.).

37.056. <em>Studies</em> in the <em>botany</em> of <em>California</em> and parts adjacent ... [I]-VI ... [San Francisco]
1884-1887. Oct. (<em>Stud. bot. Calif.</em>). 

<em>Publ</em>. [<em>1</em>]: 29 Feb 1884 (in journal), p. 66-127 ... <em>Copies</em>: HH (detached), NY (detached). –
	Detached and to be cited from Bull. Calif. Acad. Sci. 1(3): 66-127. 1884.
<em>2</em>: 29 Aug 1885 (issue date on p. [179]), cover (blank), p. [179]-228 ... <em>Copies</em>: HH, NY.
	– Reprinted and to be cited from Id. 1(4): 179-228. 1885.
<em>Note</em>: Includes four papers: (1) Three new genera, p. 179-182; (2) Miscellaneous species,
	mostly new, p. 182-214; (3) Notes on Guadelupe Island, p. 214-220; and (4) A catalogue
	of the flowering plants and ferns of Guadelupe Island, p. 220-228.
<em>3</em>: 14 Dec 1885 (issue date on p. 5 &amp; p. 276 in journal), p. 5-8. <em>Copies</em>: HH, NY. – Id.
	1(4): 276-282. 1885.
<em>Note</em>: Includes three papers: (1) A revision of Myosurus, p. 5-8 [=276-279]; (2) The genus
	Blepharizona, p. 8 [=279]; and (3) Four new species, p. 9-11 [=280-282].
<em>4</em>: 6 Mar 1886 (issue date on p. 41), cover (blank), p. 41-60. <em>Copies</em>: HH, NY. – Id. 2(5):
	41-60. 1886.
<em>Note</em>: Includes three papers: (1) On some Chicoriaceous Compositae, p. 41-55; (2) Some
	species of Euphorbia § Anisophyllum, p. 56-58; and (3) New Polypetalæ, p. 58-60.
<em>5</em>: 13 Nov 1886 (issue date on p. 125), cover-t.p., p. 125-154, <em>pl. 6</em> (uncol., fold. lith.). <em>Cop-
	ies</em>: HH, NY, US. <em>Microfilm</em>: Berkeley, Calif. (Univ. of Calif., Library Photographic Ser-
	vice), 1985, 1 reel (35 mm). <em>Copy</em>: UC-Berkeley (n.v.). – Id. 2(6): 125-154, <em>pl. 6.</em> 1886.
<em>Illus</em>.: Kellogg, Albert (1813-1887), see TL-2/2: 519 and IH 2: 350.
<em>Note</em>: Includes two papers: (1) Some genera which have been confused under the name
	<em>Brodiæa</em>, p. 125-144; and (2) Miscellaneous species, new or noteworthy, p. 144-154, <em>pl. 6.</em>
<em>6</em>: 28 Mai 1887 (issue date on p. 377 &amp; on p. 417), cover-t.p., p. 377-418. – <em>Copies</em>: HH,
	NY, US (without cover-t.p.). <em>Microfilm</em>: Berkeley [Calif.] (Univ. of Calif., Library Pho-
	tographic Service), 1985, 1 reel (35 mm). <em>Copy</em>: UC-Berkeley (n.v.). – Id. 2(7): 377-418.
	1887.
<em>Note</em>: Includes three papers: (1) Notes on the botany of Santa Cruz Island, p. 377-388; (2)
	A catalogue of the flowering plants and ferns of the Island of Santa Cruz, p. 388-416; and
	(3) Three new species, p. 416-418.

Greene, Henry Campbell (1904-1967), American mycologist, born 13 Dec 1904 in Fort
Wayne, Indiana, attended elementary and secondary school in Fort Wayne, then attended
Wabash College, Crawfordsville, Indiana for two years, B.A. 1928 and M.A. 1929 Univ. of
Washington, Seattle, Ph.D. 1933 Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, instructor from 1937 and
Curator of the Cryptogamic Herb. from 1941, both Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, died 27
Apr 1967 in Tucson, Arizona. (<em>H.C. Greene</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Parasitic fungi: UC, WIS (6000).

PAGE: 364
HEADING: GREENE

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 241; Barnhart 2: 81; Hawksworth p. 182; IH 2:
238; Kew 2: 496; LS suppl. 9994.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Intl. address book botanists: 475. 1931.
Allsup, M., 1978. Henry Greene's Prairie. Arboretum News 27(4): 1-4. (n.v.)
Backus, M.P. &amp; R.I. Evans, 1968. Mycologia 60: 994-998. (portr.)
Greene, H.C. &amp; J.T. Curtis, 1955. Bibl. Wisconsin vegetation: 74. (index)

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: Greene Prairie (dedicated 8 Mai 1967), Univ. of Wisconsin Arboretum, Madi-
son.

<sm>OUTSIDE OUR PERIOD</sm>: (1) Greene published at least thirty-three <em>Notes on Wisconsin para-
sitic fungi</em> ... 1940-1968!, which appeared in various journals (e.g. Amer. Midl. Naturalist,
Farlowia and Trans. Wisconsin Acad. Sci.). The series was a continuation of <em>Notes on
parasitic fungi in Wisconsin</em> 1[-20] by John Jefferson Davis (1852-1937), see TL-2/Suppl.
5, nr. 29.244.
(2) Greene, H.C. &amp; J.T. Curtis, A <em>bibliography</em> of <em>Wisconsin vegetation</em>, Milwaukee Public
Mus. Publ. Bot. 1: 1-84. 1955.

37.089. <em>Myxomycetes</em> of <em>western Washington</em>. ... [Lancaster, Penn.] (Lancaster Press Inc.)
1929. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 1929, p. 261-273. <em>Copy</em>: NY. – Reprinted and to be cited from Mycologia 21(5):
	261-273. 1929.

37.090. <em>Wisconsin myxomycetes</em> ... [Wisconsin Academy of Sciences, Arts and Letters ...]
1932. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 1932, cover (identif.), p. [141]-181, <em>pl. 1-6.</em> <em>Copies</em>: NY, USDA-Mycol. – Reprinted
	and to be cited from Trans. Wisconsin Acad. Sci. 27: 141-181, <em>pl. 1-6.</em> 1932.

Greene, Wesley (1849-1935), American botanist, born 8 Nov 1849 in Yellow Springs,
Penn., LL.B. 1875 Iowa State College of Agriculture and Mechanic Arts (now Iowa State
Univ.), Ames, secretary, Iowa State Horticultural Society 1898-1919, died 28 Mar 1935 in
Cleveland, Ohio. (<em>W. Greene</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 81; BL 1: 178, 298; GR p. 220; RUS 1: 115-116,
2: 187; Tucker 1: 299.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Conard, H.S., 1945. Bryologist 48: 164.
Erwin, A.T., 1935. Proc. Iowa Acad. Sci. 42: 19. (portr.)

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: Editor, <em>Iowa horticulture</em>; <em>a monthly bulletin of plant life</em> (1908).

37.091. <em>Plants</em> of <em>Iowa</em>, a preliminary list of native and introduced plants ... not under cul-
tivation ... Des Moines (Bishard Brothers, Printers) 1907. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: sero 1907 (p. 6 signed 30 Nov 1907, USDA copy rec'd. 3 Jan 1908), cover-t.p., p.
	[1-2= t.p.], [3]-6 [=preface], [7]-264. <em>Copies</em>: G, HH (n.v.), MO (n.v.), NY (n.v.), US,
	USDA, USDA-Mycol. – Issued as Bull. State Hort. Soc.
<em>Ref</em>.: Trelease, W., Bot. Centralbl. 110(21): 556. 25 Mai 1909 (noticed, "3115 species, of
	which about half are cryptogams").

*Greenman, Jesse More (1867-1951), American botanist, born 27 Dec 1867 in North
East (Erie Co.), Penn., B.S. 1893 Univ. of Penn., Philadelphia where he served as asst.

PAGE: 365
HEADING: GREENMAN

and instructor in botany 1890-1892, M.Sc. 1899 Harvard Univ., Cambridge, Mass., where
he was asst. in the Gray Herb. 1894-1899, Ph.D. 1901 Univ. of Berlin (under A. Engler),
again asst. in Botany, Harvard 1902-1905, asst. curator, Field Columbian Museum, Chicago
1905-1913 and asst. prof., Univ. of Chicago 1905-1913, curator, Missouri Botanical Garden
1913-1948 and prof., Shaw School of Botany, Washington Univ., St. Louis, specialist in
<em>Senecio</em> and on the Mexican and Central Amer. flora, president, A.S.P.T. 1938, died 20 Jan
1951 in St. Louis, Missouri. (<em>Greenm</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: GH, duplicates A, B, DS, E, F, L, MO, MONT, NY, US, W. – Mss.
materials MO (Archives, notably: (1) Jesse More Greenman papers, 1899-1944; and (2)
Herbarium curator (Jesse More Greenman) corr. and loan file, 1913-1948).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Amer. Men Sci. ed. 8: 959; APN p. 241; Barnhart 2: 82;
Biol.-Dokum. 7: 85.356; Bossert p. 152; CSP 15: 442; Ewan Pap. p. 83; Hirsch p. 104;
Hortus 3: 1194; IH 2: 238; Kew 2: 497-498; Langman p. 334-335; NAF ser. 2(2): 159, ser.
2(10): 211-212; NW p. 47 (index); Pennell p. 608; Portr. 1: 64 (index), 3: 503; Rehder 5(in-
dex): 339; Rhodora, index p. 332; TL-2/1: 997, indices 2/4, 2/6, Suppl. 1; Tucker 1: 299, 2:
xviii, 3: 126; Urban-Berl. p. 350; Zander ed. 11: 757, ed. 17: 950.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Intl. address book botanists: 475. 1931; [Festschrift] in honor of Jesse
	More Greenman, Ann. Missouri Bot. Gard. 25(1): frontisp., p. [i-iv]. (portr.) 1938; [Por-
	traits of botanists/Missouri Botanical Garden], [St. Louis], Missouri Botanical Garden.
	(postcard) 1988. (n.v.)
Boone, W., 1965. Hist. Bot. West Virginia: 174.
Dörfler, I., 1896. Botaniker-Adressbuch: 196; 1902. Id., ed. 2: 251; 1909. Id., ed. 3: 332.
Harshberger, J.W., 1899. Bot. Philadelphia: 28, 239, 403.
Hedge, I.C. &amp; J.M. Lamond (eds.), 1970. Index collectors Edinburgh Herb.: 84.
Jones, G.N., 1966. An annotated bibl. Mexican ferns: 77.
Mohlenbrock, R.H., 1982. Ann. Missouri Bot. Gard. 69: 389.
Reed, H.S., 1945. Western Penn. Hist. Mag. 28: 151-152.
Rodgers, A.D., 1949. Liberty Hyde Bailey: 451, 454, 473, 485.
Standley, P.C., 1952. Ceiba 3: 66-68.
Wittrock, V.B., 1905. Acta Horti Berg. 3(3): 196, <em>pl. 148.</em> (portr.)
Woodson, R.E., 1951. Ann. Missouri Bot. Gard. 38: 95-100. (bibl., portr.)
Woodson, R.E., 1952. Revista Sudamer. Bot. 10: 57-60.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: (additional) Jesse More Greenman Award (Missouri Botanical Garden, 1968-x).

<sm>FESTSCHRIFT</sm>: Anon., Ann. Missouri Bot. Gard. 25(1): ... (1938), presumably in honor of
his 70th birthday in late Dec 1937 (see Biofile).

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) Co-author of many papers with B.L. Robinson (1864-1935), incl.:
(a) <em>Further new and imperfectly known plants collected in Mexico</em> ... 1893, see TL-2/4,
nr. 9285;
(b) <em>A new genus of Sterculiaceae</em> ... 1896, see TL-2/4, nr. 9287; and
(c) <em>Revision of the genus Gymnolomia</em> ... Proc. Boston Soc. Nat. Hist. 29(5): 87-108. 1899
(also issued as Contr. Gray Herb., nr. 17 ... [24 Aug] 1899).
(2) Contributed a precursory paper (1895) to B.L. Robinson, <em>Flora of the Galapagos</em> ...
1902 (TL-2/4, nr. 9289).
(3) Provided the determinations for a treatment of the Compositae in C.F. Millspaugh,
<em>Contribution</em> [<em>III</em>] <em>to the flora of Yucatan</em> ... 1898 (TL-2/3, nr. 6069).
(4) One of nine signatories to O. Ames et al., <em>Prop. changem. lois nom.</em> ... 1904 (TL-2/
Suppl. 1, nr. 19.149), proposals submitted to the 1905 Vienna Congr. in opposition to the
"American school of nomenclature". – <em>Note</em>: In TL-2, the exact same title is also treated

PAGE: 366
HEADING: GREENMAN

under the final signatory, Roland Thaxter, and given a different abbreviation and number
(TL-2/6, nr. 14.014).

Gregg, William Henry (1845-1913), British soldier and botanist, M.B. (Bachelor of Medi-
cine), asst. surgeon, 4th native infantry, Bengal Medical Dept. 1869, later Surgeon-gen. in
Bengal Army and lecturer in Botany at Hugli Government College (sic?), Calcutta (now
Kolkata). (<em>W.H. Gregg</em>).

Gregory, Eliza Standerwick (née Barnes) (1840-1932), English botanist, born 6 Dec
1840 in Thrapston (Northants.), married 1863, founded a school for boys in Weston-super-
Mare (Somerset) 1887, moved to Cambridge 1904, returned to Weston-super-Mare 1919,
died 22 Mar 1932 in Weston-super-Mare. (<em>E.S. Gregory</em>).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Mother of Reginald Philip Gregory (1879-1918), lecturer in Botany, Cambridge.

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BM (incl. types &amp; plants cited in <em>British violets</em>, 1912), CGE,
DZS, LIV, NMW. – Her field notes (6 vols. quarto) are at BM.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 241; Barnhart 2: 83; BM 6: 408; Desmond p. 267,
ed. 2: 296; IH 2: 238; Kent p. 57, ed. 2: 155; Kew 2: 300; LS 33.775.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Intl. address book botanists: 183. 1931.
Bridson, G.D.R. et al., 1980. Nat. hist. manuscript resources British Isles: 405. (index)
Dörfler, I., 1909. Botaniker-Adressbuch, ed. 3: 158.
T[hompson], H.S., 1932. Forty-eighth Ann. Rept. Watson Bot. Exchange Club 4(3): 102.
Thompson, H.S., 1932. J. Bot. 70: 144-145.

Greguss, Pál [Paul] (1889-1984), Hungarian paleobotanist and wood anatomist, born 31
Dec 1889 in Tornya, studied in Budapest and Prague, Dr. phil., Hochschulprofessor, Szeged,
died 23 Mar 1984 in Szeged. (<em>Greguss</em>).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Not to be confused with the Hungarian physicist Pál Greguss (b. 1921).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Slide collection: József Attila Univ. in Szeged; other material in
BP and Hungarian Geological Survey in Rakóczitelep.

*Grenier, [Jean] Charles [Marie] (1808-1875), French botanist and zoologist, born 4 Nov
1808 in Besançon (Doubs), Dr. en-médecine 1836 Univ. of Strasbourg, prof. of natural his-
tory, medical school, Besançon, 1843, Dr. ès-sciences 1845 Univ. of Strasbourg, died 9 Nov
1875 in Besançon. (<em>Gren</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: P (45,000), duplicates AUT, CGE, CN, DBN, E, FI, G, G-DC, GE,
MANCH, PR, W, WAG.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 4: 860; APN p. 241; Backer p. 651; Baillon 2: 741;
Barnhart 2: 84; BL 2: 103, 111, 132, 146, 661; BM 2: 732, 6: 409; BN p. 175; Bossert p.
152; CSP 3: 11, 7: 835, 12: 292; DBF 16: 1166; DTS 1: 94-95; Frank 3(Anh.): 38; Herder p.
453 (index); Hortus 3: 1194; IH 2: 239; Jackson p. 274, 275, 344; Morren ed. 2: 17; Portr. 3:
505; PR ed. 1: 3860-3867, ed. 2: 3542-3547, 10.569; Rehder 5(index): 340; TL-1: 181-182;
TL-2/1: 999-1000, indices 2/3, 2/4, 2/5; Saccardo 1: 85; Tucker 1: 300, 3: 126; Zander ed.
10: 665, ed. 11: 757, ed. 17: 950.

is a collection of reprints bound with a t.p. and printed "Table des matières". <em>Copy</em>: HH. –

Grenzebach, Myrle Eunice (1902-1986), American botanist, born 20 Jun 1902, A.B. 1924
Oberlin College, Oberlin, Ohio, M.Sc. 1925 Washington Univ., St. Louis, Missouri (under
J.M. Greenman), married Lawrence Dewey Sherod (1898-1984) and became a housewife
in Ohio, died Oct 1986 in Ohio. (<em>Grenzeb</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 242; Barnhart 2: 84; Hortus 3: 1207; Kew 2: 504;
Langman p. 335; Tucker 3: 126.

[Moore, G.T.], 1926. Missouri Bot. Gard. Bull. 14: 16-17.

Annals of the Missouri Botanical Garden ... 1926. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 8 Mai 1926 (issue date on p. 71), cover-t.p., p. 71-100, <em>pl. 8-12</em> (uncol. lith., 1 fold.,

<em>Note</em>: Based on her master's thesis, which was supervised by Jesse More Greenman
	(1867-1951), see TL-2/1: 997 and above.

*Greshoff, Maurits (1862-1909), Dutch botanist and phytochemist, born 11 Oct 1862 in
The Hague, studied at Univ. of Utrecht, doctorate 1887 Univ. of Jena, medical service,
Dutch E. Indian Army and sent to the Botanic Gardens, Buitenzorg, Dutch E. Indies (now
Indonesia) 1888-1892, where he studied Indian poisonous plants, returned to The Nether-
lands for health reasons in 1892, asst. 1895 and ultimately dir. 1901-1909, Koloniaal Mu-
seum Haarlem, died 8 [9?] Dec 1909 in Haarlem. (<em>Greshoff</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BO (few), L (55 Fungi).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 242; Backer p. 244; Barnhart 2: 84; BL 1: 251,
298; BM 2: 733, 6: 409; BN p. 175; Bossert p. 152 (as "Mauritz"); CSP 15: 454; IH 2: 239;
JW (1): 443, 2: 191, 3: 352, 5: 240; Kew 2: 504; Langman p. 335-336; LS 33.779-33.780a;

PAGE: 375
HEADING: GRESHOFF

cxxvii; TL-1: 182; TL2/1: 1001, indices 2/4, Suppl. 4; Tucker 1: 300.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Trop. Life 2: 42. 1906 (portr.); Bull. Misc. Inform. Kew 1909: 424-425.

Greter, Fintan (Pater) (1899-1984), Swiss bryologist and priest, born 21 Mar 1899 in
Ebikon (Kt. Luzern), studied theology and became a Benedictine priest, also studied bot-

Grevelink, Arnold Hermann Bisschop (a.k.a. Bisschop Grevelink, A.H.) (1811-1882),
Dutch naval officer and economic botanist, spent one year in Curaçao and seven years in St.
Eustatius (Netherland Antilles), and briefly was government resident and dir. of a govern-
ment school in Soerabaya, E. Java, returned to The Netherlands 1873, died in Amsterdam,
"... een <em>selfmade man</em>". (<em>Grevelink</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: L.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: BL 1: 105, 298; BM 2: 733; Rehder 5(index): 341; Tucker
1: 300; SK 1: 59 (as "Bisschop").

*Greville, Robert Kaye (1794-1866), Scottish botanist, social activist and painter, born 13
Dec 1794 in Bishop Auckland (Durham), studied medicine in London and Edinburgh but
acquiring independent means chose not to practice, joined the Wernerian Natural History
Society 1819 and made frequent botanical excursions to the Scottish Highlands, F.R.S.E.
1821, LL.D. 1824 Univ. of Glasgow, F.L.S. 1827, president, Bot. Soc. Edinburgh 1836,
1846 and 1865, an active opponent of slavery and advocate of temperance, elected M.P.
for Edinburgh 1856, resorted to painting landscapes of the Scottish Highlands when other
financial resources diminished, died 4 Jun 1866 in Murrayfield, Edinburgh. (<em>Grev</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: E (incl. illus.); in addition B (alg.), BM (incl. diatom types, pur-
chased 1866), FH, GL (transfered to E), K, NME, PH, WAR, YRK. – <em>Exsiccatae</em>: <em>Algae
britannicae, dried specimens of</em> ... <em>algae</em> ... (fasc. i, nos. 1-24. 1824, fasc. ii(?) nos.? 1833),
sets at B, BR, C, CGE, FH, HBG, L, LD, MASS. – Papers in Edinburgh Univ. Library
(Special Collections Division); corr. in many collections, incl. K, Natural History Museum
(London) (incl. corr. with George Arnott), NY (e.g. William Wilson (1800-1869) and John
Torrey papers), P, etc. Also corr. with C. Darwin.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 4: 629-630; Ainsworth p. 71, 227, 313; Ainsworth
&amp; Bisby's Dict. ed. 6: 249; APN p. 242; Baillon 2: 742; Barnhart 2: 85; BB p. 130-131;
Blunt, rev. ed.: 264; BM 2: 733; Bossert p. 153; Clokie p. 174; CSP 3: 12-14, 7: 836; Des-

PAGE: 378
HEADING: GREVILLE

mond p. 268-269, ed. 2: 297; De Toni 1: liii-liv, 4: xxv; DNB 23: 164-166; Ewan Pap.
p. 83; GFB p. 184 (index); GR p. 375; GR cat. p. 64; Hawksworth p. 182; Herder p. 453
(index); Hist. Coll. BMNH p. 152; Hortus 3: 1194; IF p. 700; IF suppl. 4: 354; IH 2: 239;
Jackson p. 553 (index); Kelly p. 93; Kent p. 57, ed. 2: 154; KR p. 244; Lenley p. 188, 458;
LS 10.362-10.369; MD p. 124-135, 158-160; Moebius p. 89; MW p. 143; NAF 7(15): 1066,
9(6): 437; NI 2: 72; Nordstedt p. 16; Portr. 3: 505; PR ed. 1: 3869-3872, ed. 2: 3550-3553;
Rehder 5(index): 341; SBC p. 121; SO p. 25 (index); Sotheby 1: 244; TL-1: 518 (index);

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Microforms (or previously uncited microform versions) are available of:
(1) <em>Tent. meth. musc.</em> ... 1822-1826 (TL-2/1, nr. 2159):
<em>Microfiche</em>: Westport, Conn. (Meckler/Chadwyck-Healey Publishing), [1987?], 3 micro-
	fiches, (Plant taxonomic lit. microfiche coll., "12361F6-12363B5"). <em>Copy</em>: MO (n.v.).
(2) <em>Scott. crypt. fl.</em> ... [1822-]1823-1828 (TL-2/1, nr. 2160):
<em>Microfilm</em>: London (British Library), 1985, 2 reels (811 fr., 35 mm). <em>Copy</em>: (n.v.).

	tation Co. AG)/New York, New York (distributed by Clearwater Pub. Co.), [198-?], 9
	microfiches, 9×13 cm. <em>Copy</em>: (n.v.). (c) <em>Microfiche</em>: Westport, Conn. (Meckler/Chad-

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) Greville was co-author with W.J. Hooker of:
(a) <em>Sketch of the characters of the species of mosses belonging to the genera Orthotrichum</em>
... 1824;
(b) <em>On the genus Tortula, of the order Musci</em> ... 1824;
(c) <em>Hookeria</em> ... 1825 (TL-2/2, nr. 2995);
(d) <em>Calymperes</em> ... 1825 (TL-2/2, nr. 2996); and
(e) <em>Icon. filic.</em> ... [1827-](1831)[-1832] (TL-2/2, nr. 3002).
(2) In addition to illustrating his own works, Greville contributed plates to:
(a) Wm. Curtis [et. seq.], <em>Bot. Mag.</em> ... 1824-1834 (see TL-2/1, nr. 1290);
(b) W.J. Hooker, <em>Fl. bor.-amer.</em> ... [1829] 1833-1840, (TL-2/2, nr. 3003);
(c) W.J. Hooker, <em>Bot. misc.</em> ... 1830-1833 (TL-2/2, nr. 2999);
(d) H.D. Roger, <em>Geol. Pennsylvania</em> ... 1858 (TL-2/4, nr. 9435);
(e) E.J. Ravenscroft, <em>Pinet. brit.</em> ... [1863-]1884, 3 vols. (TL-2/4, nr. 8685); and
(f) [According to Desmond, ed. 2] J. Sowerby &amp; J.E. Smith, <em>Engl. bot.</em> ... Suppl. vol. 1
(1831, <em>pl. 2666</em>), Id. Suppl. vol. 2 (1834, <em>pl. 2717</em>), see TL-2/5, nr. 12.221.
(3) Greville assisted in arranging the "Cryptogamia" for J.C. Loudon, <em>Hort. brit.</em> ... ed. 1,
1830 (A.T. Whittemore, pers. comm.); Id., ed. 2, ... 1832; Id., New Edition [i.e. ed. 3] ...
1839, see TL-2/3, nr. 5027; and <em>Suppl. Hort. brit.</em> ... 1850, see TL-2/3, nr. 5033.
(4) Greville contributed to the following works by Hugh Murray (1779-1846) et al.:
(a) <em>Historical and descriptive account of British India</em> ... 1832; and
(b) <em>An historical and descriptive account of British America</em> ... 1839.

Grey, Charles Hervey (Lt.-Col.) (né Hoare) (1875-1955), British banker, soldier and
nurseryman, educated at Eton and New College, Oxford, entered the family's banking busi-
ness, volunteered and served in the Boer War, afterwards settled in Kent, mobilized and
served in the Dardanelles and France during W.W.-I (five times wounded and awarded
Distinguished Service Order), adopted the surname "Grey" to comply with "testamentary
obligations" 1927, established Hocke Edge (Kent) nurseries in late 1920s, served as com-
mandant of an R.A.F. aerodrome in W.W.-II, moved to Malton (Yorks.) 1945, founded
Northern Horticultural Society's garden at Harlow Car nr. Harrogate 1950, died 24 Jul 1955
in Malton. (<em>Grey</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 242; Desmond p. 269, ed. 2: 298; Hortus 3: 1194;
IH 2: 239 ("Grey, C. H./Temperate S. America: (NY)"); Sotheby 1: 249.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Times [London] [newspaper]: 25 Jul 1955.
R.J., 1957. Proc. Linn. Soc. London 167(2): 135-136. (obit.)

37.186. <em>Hardy bulbs</em>: including half-hardy bulbs and tuberous and fiberous-rooted plants ...
London (Williams &amp; Norgate Ltd.) 1937-1938, 3 vols. Oct.
<em>Illus</em>.: Grey, Cecily (née Grey) (1877-1961), whose second marriage in 1919 was to this
	author, see Desmond ed. 2: 298; this was also C.H. Hoare's second marriage. 

<em>Publ</em>. [<em>1</em>]: 1937 (pref. p. 10 signed Jul 1937), ... "Iridaceae", p. [i]-xxvii, [1]-403, <em>47 pl.
	</em>(incl. <em>15 pl</em>. col., unnumb. &amp; interspersed in text). <em>Copies</em>: HH (n.v.), K (n.v.), LC (n.v.),
	USDA.
<em>2</em>: 1938, ... "Amaryllidaceae, Commelinaceae, Haemodoraceae, Orchidaceae, Scitam i neae",
	p. [i-iv], v [=contents], vii-viii [=list of pl.], [1]-368 [glossary, p. 361-366; index, p.
	367-368], <em>47 pl</em>. (incl. <em>10 pl</em>. col., unnumb. &amp; interspersed in text). <em>Copies</em>: HH (n.v.), K
	(n.v.), USDA.

	pendix and glossary], <em>82 pl</em>. (incl. <em>20 pl</em>. col., unnumb. &amp; interspersed in text). <em>Copies</em>:

Grier, Norman MacDowell [McDowell] (1890-1951), American biologist, malacologist
and psychologist, born 13 Jun 1890 in Pittsburgh, Penn., B.S. 1911, A.M. 1912 and Ph.D.
1919 Univ. of Pittsburgh, Asst., Carnegie Museum, Pittsburgh 1914-1916, Prof. of Biology
or Evolution at several colleges and research institutes 1920s-1930s, incl. Washington &amp;
Jefferson College, Washington, Penn., Dartmouth College, Hanover, New Hampshire, Cold
Spring Harbor, New York, Elizabethtown College, Elizabethtown, Penn. and Wagner Col-
lege, Staten Island, New York, State Social Security Board (Penn.) from1937, died 26 Dec
1951 in Lebanon, Penn. (<em>N.M. Grier</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Amer. Men Sci. ed. 8: 964; Barnhart 2: 85 (b. "1887");
BL 1: 201, 298; FNA ser. 2, 6: 64; GR p. 220 (as "McDonald"); Hirsch p. 104; LS suppl.
10.034-10.036; Rhodora, index p. 332; Tucker 3: 126.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Science, n.s., 52(1332): 134. 1920; Intl. address book botanists: 475.
	1931.
Abbott, R.T. (ed.), 1973. Amer. Malacologists: 108.
Johnson, R.I., 1977. Occas. Pap. Mollusks, Mus. Comparative Zool., Harvard. Univ. 4(57):
	226-227. (bibl. [mollusks])

<em>Note</em> [<em>Parts 1-3</em>]: Sequel to the previous entry (nr. 37.189).

*Griffith, William (1810-1845), British colonial physician, botanist and "man of genius"
(<em>teste</em> Sir George King), born 4 Mar 1810 in Ham (Surrey), studied under J. Lindley and
graduated from London Univ., went to Madras in 1832 as asst. surgeon, in Assam with
N. Wallich 1835-1836, in Bhutan 1837-1838, Afghanistan 1839-1841 and Malacca (now Ma-
laysia) in mid-1841, Superindendent, Calcutta Botanic Gardens 1842-1843, returned to Mal-
acca where he died 9 Feb 1845 of an abscess of the liver (malaria &amp; hepatitis?). (<em>Griff</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Griffith contributed greatly to the herb. of the East India Com-
pany. His herb. was originally given to LINN (<em>fide</em> Bot. Zeitung (Berlin) 8: 632. 1850), but
later transfered to K; for duplicates (important sets at BM, BR, CAL, MPU) see IH 2: 240
(and add PC) and Lamond (1970). – Mss., journals and corr. at Kew, the British Library
(London) and the Linnean Society of London.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 2(2): 386; APN p. 242; Backer p. 244, 651; Baillon
2: 743; Barnhart 2: 86; BB p. 131-132; Biol.-Dokum. 7: 85.918-85.920; Blunt p. 224, ed. 2:
261; BM 2: 735-736; BN p. 175; Bossert p. 153; Bretschneider p. 359-360; Clokie p. 174;
CSP 3: 18-19, 12: 293; Desmond p. 270-271, ed. 2: 299-300; DNB 8: 685-684, 23: 240,
981-983. 2004; DSB 5: 539-540; Ewan Pap. p. 84; Herder p. 453 (index); Hist. coll. BMNH
p. 152; Hortus 3: 1194; IF p. 700; IF suppl. 4: 354; IH 2: 240; Jackson p. 553 (index); Kew
List p. 28; Lasègue p. 569 (index); MW p. 143; NAF ser. 2(9): 122; NI 2: 72; Portr. 3: 507;
PR ed. 1: 3883-3887, ed. 2: 3565-3571; Rehder 5(index): 342-343; RS p. 85; SBC p. 121;
SK 1: 201-202, 4(2): cxvi, 5: cclxxxi, 8: xxxix; TL-1: 183; TL-2/1: 1005-1006, indices 2/4,
2/6; Tucker 1: 301-302, 2: xviii; Urban-Berl. p. 300, 351; Wagenitz p. 65; Zander ed. 10:
665, ed. 11: 757, ed. 17: 950.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon. [?], Calcutta J. Nat. Hist. 6: 294-306. 1845; Flora 28: 431-432. 1845; Proc.
	Linn. Soc. London 1: 239-244. 1845; Bot. Zeitung (Berlin) 3: 392. 1845; Bot. Zeitung
	(Berlin) 4: 159-160. 1846.
Bridson, G.D.R. et al., 1980. Nat. hist. manuscript resources British Isles: 405. (index)
Brunet, J.-Ch., 1861 [1966 reprint]. Manuel du libraire et de l'amateur de livres 2: 1739.
Burkill, I.H., 1965. Chapt. Hist. Bot. India: 59, 239. (index)

	29-33. (n.v.)
