<sm>NOTE</sm>: As was noted by W.J. Hooker (London J. Bot. 7: 446-449. 1848), after Griffith's death
in 1845 at age 35 his unpublished mss. were published by John M'Clelland (1805-1883, see
TL-2/3: 214). Most of these posthumous papers (often criticized) were treated earlier (see
TL-2/1, nrs. 2166-2170). In recent years, however, some of them have been reprinted and/
or issued in microform, viz.:
(1) [Posthumous papers bequeathed to the Honourable The East India Company...] <em>J. trav.</em> ...
1847-1848, see TL-2/1, nr. 2166 (<em>J. trav.</em>=vol. 1) and 2168 (<em>Itin. pl. Khasyah mts.</em>=vol. 2):
[<em>Reprint</em> of selections ...]: 1865, Eden, Sir Ashley, <em>Political missions to Bootan</em> ... <em>with Dr.
W. Griffith's Journal</em> ... Calcutta (Printed at the Bengal Secretariat Office): 1 lf., xi, 137,
xi, 206 p., map (fold., in pocket). <em>Copy</em>: LC (n.v.). <em>Reprinted</em>: ... New Delhi (Munshiram
Manoharlal Publishers), xi, 137, xi, 206 p., map. <em>Copy</em>: LC (n.v.).
[<em>Reprint</em> of Chapters XI, XII, and XIII]: [1974?] ... Griffith, Wm., <em>Bhutan</em>, 1837-1838 ...
New Delhi (Skylark Printers): 197-312, <em>2 pl</em>. <em>Copy</em>: LC (n.v.).
<em>Facsimile</em> ed.: 2001, ... New Delhi (Munshiram Manoharlal Publishers), xxxii, 529 p.
<em>Copy</em>: LC (n.v.).
(2) [Id. ...] <em>Not. pl. asiat.</em> ... 1847-1854 (TL-2/1, nr. 2167):
<em>Microfiche</em>: Zug, Switzerland (Inter Documentation Company), [19–], 34 microfiches,
	9×12 cm. <em>Copy</em>: LC (n.v.).
<em>Reprint</em>: 1976, ... Dehra Dun (M/S Bishen Singh Mahendra Pal Singh), 4 vols. <em>Copy</em>: US.
(3) [Id. ...] <em>Ic. pl. asiat.</em> ... 1847-1854, 4 vols. (TL-2/1, nr. 2169):
Reprint: 1976, ... Dehra Dun (M/S Bishen Singh Mahendra Pal Singh), 4 vols. <em>Copy</em>: US.
(4) [Id. ...] <em>Palms Brit. E. Ind.</em> ... 1850 (TL-2/1, nr. 2170) has been reprinted and now is
available in microfiche:
<em>Reprint</em>: [1977], ... Delhi (Periodical Experts Book Agency), p. [i]-xvi, [1]-182, [xvii]-xx-
viii, [140] lvs. of pl. <em>Copies</em>: LC (n.v.), MO (n.v.), US.
<em>Microfiche</em>: [s.l.] (IDC), 1984, 9 microfiches. <em>Copy</em>: (n.v.).
<em>N.B.</em>: The last line in TL-2/1, nr. 2170 should be corrected to read: "Griffith, Calcutta J. Nat.
	Hist. 5: 1-180 [not 183], 311-355, 445-491. 1845".

... 1820-1822 (TL-2/2, nr. 3216).

37.196. <em>Muscologia Itineris Assamici</em>; or; a Description of Mosses, collected during the

	J. Nat. Hist. 2(8): 465-514 [Jan?], 3(9): 56-75 [Apr], 3(10): 270-282, <em>pl. 16-18, 20</em> [<em>pl.
	20</em> missing in reprint of journal] [Jul]. 1842 [1843?]. <em>Microfiche</em> [of journal, not reprint]:
	Tumba, Sweden (International Documentation Centre), [19–], 2 microfiches, 9×12 cm.
	<em>Copy</em>: US. <em>Electronic version</em> (pdf) [journal, p. 465-514, 270-282, no plates!]: MA (as
	"Biblioteca Digital").
<em>Note</em>: (1) In the journal, a footnote on p. 465 states that this paper was written in 1836 and
	read before the "Linnæan Society in March, 1838". (2) The microfiche (cited above) has
	the plate captions, but not the plates.
<em>Note</em>: The following are among the dozen or so papers that came out after Griffith's death
	in early 1845, the last appearing in 1859!

37.197. Some <em>account</em> of the <em>botanical collection</em> brought from the eastward by Dr. <em>Cantor</em>
... [Calcutta] ... s.d. [1844-1845]. Qu. (<em>Account bot. coll. Cantor</em>).

<em>Collector</em>: Cantor, Theodore Edward (M.D.) (1809-1854), see IH 2: 115 (d. "1860").

PAGE: 388
HEADING: GRIFFITHS

<em>Publ</em>. [<em>Qu. ed.</em>]: late 1844-early 1845 [sometimes miscited as 1837], p. 33-65, <em>pl. 1-4</em> (un-
	col. lith.). <em>Copies</em>: BR (n.v.), HH(2) (without pl., 1 copy imperfect), K. – Preprinted and
	evidently intended to be included in Calcutta J. Nat. Hist. 21, which was never published
	(see note).
<em>Note</em> (1): Thanks to investigations by Rosemary Davies (K) and Gea Zijlstra (U) it is ap-
	parent that this quarto edition was preprinted, with the intention of the article eventually
	appearing in vol. 21 of the Calcutta J. Nat. Hist. These preprints are independent of the
	1854 edition, which was published (in octavo) by J. Asiat. Soc. Bengal (see below).
	 (2) Lending further support to the idea that the quarto is an independent preprint is a
	statement in the octavo edition of the paper, viz. "The following paper has been printed
	for several years and was intended to form part of an interesting communication by Dr.
	Cantor on the Natural History of Chusan which was to lead off Vol. XXI of the Asiatic
	Researches. This publication having been, for the present at all events, discontinued,
	Dr. Griffith's valuable memoir on Chusan Botany has been reprinted and now is pub-
	lished with the four plates which accompanied it. – Ed." (J. Asiat. Soc. Bengal 23:
	623. 1854). (3) Cantor's earlier communication was "General features of Chusan with
	remarks on the flora and fauna of that Island" (Ann. Mag. Nat. Hist. 9(58): 265-278,
	(59): 361-370, (60): 481-493. 1842), in which he acknowledges Griffith for plant iden-
	tifications.
[<em>Oct. ed.</em>]: 1854 [sometimes miscited as 1837], p. 623-650, <em>pl. 1-4</em> (uncol. double lith.).
	<em>Copies</em>: no reprint seen. – Issued and to be cited from J. Asiat. Soc. Bengal 23: 623-650,
	<em>pl. 1-4.</em> 1854.

<em>Publ</em>.: 1846, p. [1]-47, <em>pl. 15-20</em> (double pl.). <em>Copies</em>: FH (n.v.), K, NY (n.v.), WU. – Re-
	printed and to be cited from Calcutta J. Nat. Hist. 5: 227-273, <em>pl. 15-20.</em> 1846.

37.200. On the <em>Ambrosinia ciliata</em> of <em>Roxburgh</em> ... London (R. Taylor) 1851 [i.e. 1847].
Qu. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 11 Dec 1847 (<em>fide</em> Raphael, Biol. J. Linn. Soc. 2(1): 68. Mar 1970, read 4 Nov 1845),
	p. 263-276, <em>pl. 10-12</em> (uncol. lith. from draw. by auth.). <em>Copies</em>: BM (in serial), HH (de-
	tached?). <em>Micro-opaque</em>: New York (Readex Microprint), 1977, 2 micro-opaques, 23×15
	cm (Landmarks II). <em>Copy</em>: (n.v.). – Reprinted (detached?) and to be cited from Trans.
	Linn. Soc. London 20(2): 263-276, <em>pl. 10-12.</em> 1851 [i.e. 1847].
<em>Note</em>: "Communicated by R.H. Solly, Esq., F.R.S., F.L.S. &amp;c., &amp;c.", viz. Solly, Richard
	Horsman (1778-1850), English botanist, see Desmond, ed. 2: 642.

Griffiths, B[enjamin]. Millard (1886-1942), British botanist interested in the taxonomy
and ecology of freshwater algae, born in Kidderminster (Worcs.), B.Sc. 1908, M.Sc. 1909
and D.Sc. 1923 Univ. of Birmingham, Demonstrator in Botany, Queen's Univ., Belfast, Ire-
land 1914, Lecturer in Botany, Reading Univ. 1920, Lecturer in Botany, Armstrong College,
Newcastle-on-Tyne 1921, F.L.S. 1922, Head, Botany Dept., Univ. of Durham 1924-1939,
died 25 Mar 1942 in Durham. (<em>B.M. Griffiths</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: DHM.

*Griffiths, David (1867-1935), Welsh-born American mycologist, agrostologist and hor-
ticulturist, born 16 Aug 1867 in Aberystwyth but grew up in South Dakota, B.S. 1892 and
M.S. 1893 South Dakota Agric. College (now South Dakota State Univ.), Brookings, Ph.D.
1900 Columbia Univ., New York, New York, Prof. of Botany, Univ. of Arizona, Tucson
1900-1901 where he became interested in cacti and xerophytic plants of s.w. U.S.A. and
Mexico, asst. agrostologist 1901, agriculturist 1907 and horticulturist 1918 until retirement,
all Bureau of Plant Industry, U.S.D.A., died 19 Mar 1935 in Washington (Takoma Park),
D.C. (<em>D. Griffiths</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Mexico: MO. U.S.A.: B, BPI, E, GH, MIN, MO, NY, PUR, SDC,
US (7438 incl. 5000 cacti; orig.), WS, YU. <em>– Exsiccatae</em>: <em>West American Fungi</em> (cent. i-iv,
nos. 1-400, Takoma Park; 1-100. 1901; 101-400. 1902), sets at ARIZ, B (complete), BPI,
CUP, DAOM, FH, IA, MASS, MIN, MONT, NEB, NHES, NY, OC, OSC, OTB, PUR,
RUTPP, WIS. – Mss. in SIA (David Griffiths Collection, ca. 1900-1920: glass plate nega-
tives of cacti).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Amer. Men Sci. ed. 5: 442; APN p. 242; Barnhart 2: 86;

Griffon, Édouard (1869-1912), French phytopathologist, born 24 Jul 1869 in Vault-de-
Lugny (Yonne), prof. of Natural History, then Botany, and Dir., Plant Pathology Station at
Versailles and Botanic Garden of the National School of Agriculture at Grignon, died 28
Jun 1912 in Paris. (<em>É. Griffon</em>).

Griggs, Robert Fiske (1881-1962), American botanist and plant ecologist, born 22 Aug
1881 in Brooklyn (Windham Co.), Conn., B.S. 1903 Ohio State Univ., Columbus, Prof. of
Biology, Fargo College, Fargo, North Dakota 1903-1906, M.S. 1906 Univ. of Minnesota,
Minneapolis, Prof. of Biology, Ohio State Univ. 1906-1921, Ph.D. 1911 Harvard Univ.,
Cambridge, Mass. (earned while on leave from Ohio State Univ.), led six expeds. to Alaska
(Katmai Distr.) 1915-1919, Prof. of Botany (first), George Washington Univ., Washington,
D.C. 1921-1947, Chair, Division of Biology and Agric., Natl. Research Council (N.S.F)
1940-1947, President, Ecological Soc. Amer. 1944, Prof. of Biology, Univ. of Pittsburgh,
1947-1952, died 8 Jun 1962 in Kensington, Maryland. (<em>R.F. Griggs</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: OS (orig.), duplicates B, E, NY, UC, US. – Field notes at NY, UC
and US; letters in FH, GH, HU and SIA (Remington Kellogg and E.P. Killip papers).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Amer. Men Sci. ed. 9: 438; APN p. 242; Barnhart 2: 87;
BL 1: 207, 208, 298; BM 6: 410; Bossert p. 152 (d. "8 Jun, Carnegie, Penn."); Ewan Pap.
p. 84; Hirsch p. 105; Hortus 3: 1194; IH 2: 127, 137, 240; Langman p. 336; Lenley p. 189;
LS 33.805-33.809; Pennell p. 608; Portr. 1: 64 (index), 3: 507; Sarjeant p. 1148, Suppl. 1:
459; Tucker 1: 302, 775, 2: xviii.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Intl. address book botanists: 475. 1931; Washington Post, Times Herald
	[newspaper]: B7. 10 Jun 1962, Ibid.: B4. 11 Jun 1962.
Burgess, R.L., 1996. Huntia 10(1): 47-48. (d. "8 Jun")

Dörfler, I., 1902. Botaniker-Adressbuch, ed. 2: 252; 1909. Id., ed. 3: 332.
Ewan, J. (ed.), 1969. Short hist. bot. U.S.: 95.

	(autobiogr.) [book also concerns his wife, Laura A. Tressel Griggs (1884-1956)] (n.v.)
Hedge, I.C. &amp; J.M. Lamond (eds.), 1970. Index collectors Edinburgh Herb.: 86.
Hultén, E., 1940. Bot. Not. 1940: 326-327. (Alaska)

Grimm, Julius (1889-x), German botanist, born in Frankfurt am Main, moved to Limburg

37.228. <em>Entwicklungsgeschichtliche Untersuchungen</em> an <em>Rhus</em> und Coriaria. Inaugural-

Grimme, Arnold [T.] (1868-1958), German bryologist and veterinarian (Tierarzt), born
28 Nov 1868 in Bückeburg, attended veterinary school in Hannover, after military service
studied botany and zoology in Berlin, began moss studies in 1895, doctorate 1902 Marburg,
died 1 Nov 1958 in Kassel. (<em>A. Grimme</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: B (lost?), KASSEL, M.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 243; Barnhart 2: 88; BFM p. 287 (index); Biol.-
Dokum. 7: 86.104; CSP 15: 470; Frahm&amp;E. p. 150-151; IH 2: 240; LS 33.821; SBC p. 121;
Urban-Berl. p. 300.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Intl. address book botanists: 138. 1931.
Dörfler, I., 1896. Botaniker-Adressbuch: 17; 1902. Id., ed. 2: 18; 1909. Id., ed. 3: 36.
Wiedemann, H., 1975. Philippia 2(4): 261-265. (bibl., portr.)

37.229. Die <em>Torf</em>- und <em>Laubmoose</em> des <em>Hessischen Berglandes</em> ... Dahlem bei Berlin (Verlag
des Repertoriums) 1936. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 30 Jun 1936, cover-t.p., p. [i], [1]-135. <em>Copies</em>: BM, FH (n.v.), MO, NY (n.v.), U. – Re-
	printed and to be cited from Feddes Repert. Spec. Nov. Regni Veg. Beih. 92: 1-135. 1936.
<em>Note</em>: (1) The reprint often bound with articles by M[ax]. Koehler (fl. 1936) on hepatics and
	Georg Krasske (1889-1951, see TL-2/2: 664) on diatoms. (2) According to Wiedemann
	(1975), also published in Abh. Ber. Vereins Naturk. Kassel 58: 1-135. 1936 (n.v.).

Grimwade, [Wilfrid] Russell (Sir) (1879-1955), Australian businessman, philanthropist
and botanist, born 15 Oct 1879 in Caulfield, Victoria, B.Sc. 1901 Univ. of Melbourne,
joined the family firm of Felton, Grimwade &amp; Co. 1903, became a partner in the firm 1907,
which merged with Duerdins and Sainsbury in 1929 and later became Drug Houses of Aus-
tralia Pty. Ltd., established Russell Grimwade Prize for "scientific forestry" 1929, C.B.E.
1935, botanical advisor to the Army Dept. during W.W.-II, sponsored the Russell Grimwade
Exped. to W. Australia Aug-Sep 1947, knighted 1950, a generous philanthropist he also
purchased Capt. J. Cook's cottage in Yorkshire (for £800), had it dismantled and shipped to
Melbourne, died 2 Nov 1955 in Melbourne. (<em>R. Grimwade</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown. Willis (1956, p. 162) noted that Grimwade had "a re-
markably comprehensive collection of eucalypt capsules", but its present location also is
unknown. – Papers (mostly related to business) in Univ. of Melbourne Archives.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: ADB(2) 4: 303 (sub Grimwade, Frederick Sheppard), 9:
126-128; HR (as "Wilfred"); Kew 2: 512; Tucker 3: 127.

PAGE: 396
HEADING: GRINDEL

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., The Sydney Morning Herald [newspaper]: 6. 3 Nov 1955 (n.v.); The
	Grimwade Collection: a selection of works form the bequest of Sir Russell and Lady
	Grimwade, Parkville, Australia (Univ. Gallery, Univ. of Melbourne): 24 p. [1987] (n.v.);
	Works of art from the Russell and Mab Grimwade bequest, Parkville [Australia] (Mu-
	seum of Art, Univ. of Melbourne): 93 p. 1989. (n.v.)

	results Grimwade Exped.]

	[Australia] (Univ. of Melbourne Museum of Art): v, 176 p. (portrs.) (n.v.)
Poynter, J.R., 1967. Russell Grimwade, [Melbourne] (Melbourne Univ. Press at the Miegu-
	nyah Press): xiv, 321 p. (portrs.) (n.v.)
Willis, J.H., 1956. Victorian Naturalist 72(10): 162-164. (portr.)

37.230. An <em>Anthography</em> of the <em>Eucalypts</em> ... Sydney (Angus &amp; Robertson Ltd.) 1920. Qu. (<em>Anthogr. Eucalypts</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: Aug 1920 (pref. on p. 5), t.p., p. [1]-14, [15], <em>pl. 1-79</em> (col. phot. with letterpress).

<em>Note</em>: The numbered lvs. have illus. on rectos and text on preceding versos.

Grindel, David Hieronymus [Heinrich] (1776-1836), Latvian druggist and doctor, born
28 Sep (=9 Oct n.s.) 1776 in Riga, studied at Jena, apothecary in Riga, then Prof. of Chem-
istry and Pharmacy, Univ. of Tartu 1804-1814, rector 1810-1812, returned to Tartu to study
medicine 1820 and began practicing in Riga where he also owned a pharmacy 1822, one of
the founders of the Riga Pharmaceutical Society 1803, received degrees from Dorpat where
he taught, published several important textbooks on botany and chemistry for pharmacists
and doctors, died 8 (=20 n.s.) Jan 1836 in Riga. (<em>D.H. Grindel</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 243; Backer p. 244; Barnhart 2: 88; BM 2: 736;
CSP 3: 21-22, 6: 678; GR p. 580; Herder p. 453 (index); Kew 2: 512; Lipschitz 3: 48-49; PR
ed. 1: 3893-3897, ed. 2: 3578-3580; Rehder 5(index): 343; TR p. 104.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Viksna, A.A., 1976. Farmatsiia 25: 82-83. [bicentenary of birth] (n.v.)

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Grindelia</em> Willd. (1807).

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: Published the first pharmaceutical journal, <em>Russisches Jahrbuch der
Pharmazie</em> in the Russian Empire.

Grinţescu [Grintescu, Grintzesco], Joan [Ioan, Ion, Jean, Johann] (1874-1963), Romanian
pharmacist and botanist, born 13/26 Jan 1874 in Broşteni, studied pharmacy in Bucha-
rest 1895-1896 and Geneva 1896-1898 receiving his diploma 1898, Dr. ès-sciences na-
turelles 1902 Geneva (under R.-H. Chodat), asst. and "agrégé-particulier", Inst. of Botany,
Geneva 1897-1911, prof. of natural sciences, Central College of Agriculture, Bucharest
1911-1919, prof. of anatomy and physiology of plants and dir. of the botany inst., Univ. of
Cluj 1919-1936, chair of plant physiology, Univ. of Bucharest 1936-1939, retired 1939, died
1 Jul 1963 in Bucharest. (<em>J. Grinţ.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BUCA, CL, E.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 243; Barnhart 2: 88 (as "Joan"); Hirsch p. 105;
LS suppl. 10.083-10.086; Portr. 3: 508; Strid p. 141 (as "Grintzesco"), ed. 2: 194 (as
"Grintzesco"); TL-2/Suppl. 4: 609 (index).

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Intl. address book botanists: 301. 1931.
Andrei, M. &amp; N. Radulescu-Mitroiu, 1985. <em>In</em>, I. Grinţescu, Botanica, ed. 2: 6-8. (n.v.)
Dörfler, I., 1909. Botaniker-Adressbuch, ed. 3: 276. (as "Grintzesco, Jean")
Fabian, A. &amp; V. Soran, 1987. Contr. Bot. Univ. Cluj-Napoca 1987: 339-343.
Fuchs, H.P., 1991. Bull. Murith. Soc. Valais. Sci. Nat. 109: 151-152.
Hedge, I.C. &amp; J.M. Lamond (eds.), 1970. Index collectors Edinburgh Herb.: 86.
Resmerita, I., 1974. Natura (Rumania) 26(3): 91-92. (portr.) (n.v.)
Stefureac, T., 1968. Communic. Bot. Bucuresti 7: 97-124. (n.v.)
Valeria, D., 1993. Natura (Rumania), Ser. Biol., 46(1-4): 141. (n.v.)

<sm>OUTSIDE OUR PERIOD</sm>: In retirement, Grinţescu was one of the principal collaborators

1952-1964.

Gris, [Jean Antoine] Arthur (1829-1873), French botanist, born 11 Dec 1829 in Châtillon-
sur-Seine (Côte-d'Or), 1857 Dr. ès-sciences, "aide-naturaliste" 1859, then asst. 1864 to A.T.
Brongniart, Muséum natl. d'Histoire naturelle, Paris, died 18 Aug 1873 in Paris. (<em>A. Gris</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown (possibly P).

Grisch, Andreas (1879-1952), Swiss agronomist (and botanist), born either in Sur (Kt.
Graubünden) or "5 Jan 1879 possibly Surlej (Gem. Silvaplana)", Doctorate 1907 Zurich,

Zürich (Dresden, Druck von C. Heinrich) 1907. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 1907, cover-t.p., p. [1]-68. <em>Copies</em>: G, USDA, WU. – Presumably preprinted from
	Beih. Bot. Centralbl. 22, Abt. 2: 255-316. 1907.

*Grisebach, August Heinrich Rudolf [Rudolph] (1814-1879), German botanist (plant ge-
ographer and systematist), born 17 Apr 1814 in Hannover, studied medicine and botany in
Berlin and Göttingen 1832-1835, M.D. 1836 Göttingen, traveled through the Balkan Pen-
ins. and n.w. Asia Minor 1839-1840, prof. extraord. of botany, medical faculty, Göttingen
1841, visited Norway 1842, full prof. 1847-1875 and from 1875-1879 also dir. of Göttingen
Botanical Garden, Dr. h.c. 1875, privy government councilor (Geheimer Regierungsrath),
Göttingen Univ. 1874-1875, died 9 Mai 1879 in Göttingen. (<em>Griseb</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: GOET, but since he also consulted borrowed material, some of

PAGE: 400
HEADING: GRISEBACH

his types are elsewhere (e.g. C and K, which holds many of the types of the <em>Fl. Brit. W.I.</em>).
Other collections in B (lost?), BR, E, FI, G, K, L, LE, MA, MO. – Letters at GOET (se-
lected copies at GH), also some corr. with C. Darwin.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: ADB 49: 551-554; AG 1: 344, 5(l): 453, 5(2): 280, 12(3):
648; APN p. 243; Backer p. 244, 651; Baillon 2: 745; Barnhart 2: 89; Biol.-Dokum. 7:
86.163-86.164; BL 1: 224, 225, 228, 234, 298; BM 2: 737-738; BN p. 175; Bossert p. 153;
Collander hist. p. 155 (index); CSP 3: 24-25, 6: 678, 7: 842, l0: 64, 12: 293; Desmond ed.
2: 301; DSB 5: 546-547; DTS 1: 95-96; Ewan Pap. p. 84; Frank 3(Anh.): 38; Frodin ed.
2: 1028 (index); Futak-Domin p. 223; Herder p. 453 (index); Hortus 3: 1194; IF p. 700; IF
suppl. 4: 354; IH 1 (ed. 6): 359, 2: 241; Jackson p. 553-554 (index); Kanitz nr. 223; Kelly
p. 94; Kew 2: 513-514; Kew List p. 28 (as "Heinrich Rudolf August"); Langman p. 337;
Lasègue p. 569 (index); Lenley p. 189; LS 10.424, 33.822; Mägdefrau p. 311 (index); ME 2:
54, 55; Moebius p. 450 (index); Morren ed. 2: 7; MW p. 144; NAF 28B(2): 333, ser. 2(7):
40; NDB 7: 96-97 (as "Heinrich August Rudolf"); Portr. 3: 508; PR ed. 1: 3902-3908, ed.
2: 3588-3601, 10.570; Rehder 5(index): 344, 949; RS p. 85; Strid p. 141, ed. 2: 194; TL-1:
183-185; TL-2/1: 1007-1011 (as "Rudolph"), indices 2/3, 2/4 (references p.p. to 2/3!), 2/5,
2/7, Suppl. 5; Tucker 1: 303, 3: 127; Urban-Berl. p. 351; Wagenitz p. 66; Zander ed. 10: 665,
ed. 11: 757, ed. 17: 950.

Grönblad, Rolf [Leo] (1895-1962), Finnish dentist and desmidologist, born 24 Sep 1895
in Vaasa, graduated Helsinki Finnish Normal Lyceum 1914, visited Eastern Carelia (Rus-
sia) as a member of a military exped. 1918, Candidate 1920 and Licentiate of Odontol-
ogy 1922 Univ. of Helsinki, practiced dentistry in s. Finland, member, Intl. Committee
Nomencl. Alg., Dr. h.c. 1950 Univ. of Helsinki, died 20 Apr 1962 in Tammisaari. (<em>Grön-
blad</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: H (Alg.), HEL.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 244; Barnhart 2: 89; Biol.-Dokum. 7: 86.393; BN
p. 26; Collander p. 129-130 (24 works); Collander hist. p. 51; Hirsch p. 105; IH 2: 241; FNA
ser. 2, 6: 64; Kleppa p. 323 (index); Portr. 1: 64 (index); TL-2/4, Suppl. 4 (indices).

Luther, H., 1964. Soc. Sci. Fennica Årsb. 43C(1): 1-8. (portr.)

37.258. <em>Beitrag</em> zur <em>Kenntnis</em> der <em>Desmidiaceen Schlesiens</em> ... Helsingfors [Helsinki] (Hel-

*Groenhart, Pieter (1894-1965), Dutch lichenologist, born in Ilpendam, schoolteacher
in The Netherlands 1916-1926, to Java in Aug 1926, stationed at Batavia, then taught at
School of Agriculture in Malang (E. Java) until 1940, studied biology, Utrecht 1932-1936,
returned to Indonesia and Buitenzorg, working one day per week in the herb., briefly at
Leiden 1947, returned again to Indonesia but ultimately settled in The Netherlands, died 3
Nov 1965 in Oegstgeest (Leiden). (<em>Groenh</em>.).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: An incorrect year of death (i.e. 1932), sometimes found in literature, accidentally
appeared in TL-2/1: 1011. F.A. Stafleu himself anonymously reported (Taxon 15: 43. 1966)
the correct date.

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BO, L, other material at H, U.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 243; Bossert p. 154; GR p. 702; GR cat. p. 64;
Hawksworth p. 183; IH 2: 241; SBC p. 121; SK 1: 203, 5: cclxxxii, 8: xxxix; TL-2/1: 1011.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Maas-Geesteranus, R.A., 1966. Persoonia 4: 69-71. (bibl., portr.)
[Stafleu, F.A.], Taxon 15: 43. 1966.
[Steenis, C.G.G.J. van &amp; M. Jacobs], 1966. Fl. Males. Bull. nr. 21: 1371, 1377.

Botanische Vereeniging ... Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 5 Dec 1936 (in journal), p. [690]-784. <em>Copy</em>: NY (photo-offset?). – Reproduced me-
	chanically (photo-offset?) and to be cited from Ned. Kruidk. Arch. 46: 690-784. 1936.

37.264. <em>Eenige Cryptotheciaceae</em> van <em>Java</em> ... 1938. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 1938 (read Jul 1938), cover-t.p. (recto of p. [304]), p. [304]-309, <em>3 pl</em>. (unnumb.
	photomicrogr.), loose errata slip (=pl. caption). <em>Copy</em>: FH. – Reprinted and to be cited
	from Natuurk. Tijdschr. Ned.-Indië 98(6): 304-309, <em>3 pl</em>. 1938.

Groenland [Grönland], Johannes (1824-1891), German horticulturist and microscopist,
born 8 Apr 1824 in Altona (Hamburg), trained as a druggist, joined the Schleswig-Holstein
army 1849, moved to Paris 1853 as an asst. to Louis Vilmorin and began editing <em>Revue
Horticole</em>, returned to Germany after the Franco-Prussian War (1870-1871) and settled in
Dahme (nr. Potsdam) as prof. of natural sciences, Agricultural and Agricultural Chemistry
Research Station 1872-1891, died 13 Feb 1891 in Dahme. (<em>J. Groenland</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 243; Baillon 4(Suppl.): 322; Barnhart 2: 89; Biol.-
Dokum. 7: 86.398-86.399; BM 2: 739 (as "Grönland"); CSP 3: 25-26, 6: 843, 15: 474;
Herder p. 453 (index); Hortus 3: 1194; Jackson p. 554 (index); Kew 2: 515; Langman p.
338; Morren ed. 2: 6, ed. 10: 11; MW p. 144, suppl. p. 79; Rehder 5(index): 345; TL-2/4,
2/6 (indices); Urban-Berl. p. 351; Zander ed. 11: 757, ed. 17: 950.

*Grønlund [Groenlund, Grönlund], [Carl] Christian [Howitz] (1825-1901), Danish bota-
nist, born 14 Jul 1825 in Vordingborg, studied theology 1850, traveled in Iceland 1868 and

PAGE: 407
HEADING: GRØNLUND

1876, taught botany in Copenhagen until 1879 when appointed manager of the Physiological
Laboratory of Nv. Carlsberg (a brewery), died 10 Aug 1901 in Copenhagen. (<em>C. Grønlund</em>).

Grøntved [Gröntved], Johannes (1882-1956), Danish floristic botanist, born 25 Jan 1882
in Mygdad, Ph.D. 1917 Copenhagen, amanuensis in Botanical Museum 1918-1934, died
11 Jul 1956. (<em>Grøntved</em>).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: (1) He signed his papers "Johs. Grøntved". (2) Not to be confused with Julius Grønt-
ved (1899-1967) (see below), who studied phytoplankton.

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: C.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 244; Barnhart 2: 89; BFM p. 287 (index); BL 2:
51, 53, 323, 662; Frodin ed. 2: 609 (as "Gröntved"); Hirsch p. 105 (as "Gröntved"); IH 2:
241 (as "Gröntved"); Kew 2: 515; Rhodora, index p. 333; TL-2/3, 2/4 (indices).

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Intl. address book botanists: 76. 1931.
Christensen, C., 1940. Dansk Bot. Litt. 1912-1939: 195-196. (bibl., portr.)
Fridriksson, A., 1992. Natturufraedingurinn 26: 158-159. (phot.) (n.v.)
Hansen, A., 1957. Bot. Tidsskr. 53: 354-356. (phot.)

<sm>OUTSIDE OUR PERIOD</sm>: <em>Botanische Untersuchungen auf der Insel Dagö</em> (<em>Hiiumaa</em>); ein Bei-
trag zur Flora Estlands ... Copenhagen (Munksgaard) 1953.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) Grøntved, O.V. Paulsen &amp; T.J. Sørensen were editors of vols.
3(2)-4(1), and Grøntved &amp; Sørensen editors of vol. 5(1) of <em>Bot. Iceland</em> ... 1920-1949, 5
vols. (see TL-2/4, nr. 9548, where cited as "Gröntved"). In addition, Grøntved alone au-
thored vol. 4(1), "The Pteridophyta and Spermatophyta of Iceland" 1942, see TL-2/4, nr.
9548 (where cited as "Gröntved').
(2) Co-author with C.H. Ostenfeld, <em>Fl. Iceland</em> ... 1934 (TL-2/3, nr. 7134).
(3) Edited <em>Botanisk Tidsskrift</em> and <em>Dansk Botanisk Arkiv</em> (1937-1947).

... 1938, which was treated earlier sub Seidenfaden (see TL-2/5, nr. 11.639). – <em>Note</em>: The
report was based on the Godthaab (not Gotthaab) Exped. of 1928.

	the defense.

Groff, G[eorge]. Weidman (1884-1954), American horticulturist and "agricultural mis-
sionary", born 29 Mar 1884 in Annville (Lebanon Co.), Penn., attended school in Har-
risburg, Penn., B.Sc. 1907 and M.S. 1912 (horticulture) Penn. State College (now Penn.
State Univ.), State College, Penn., went to China in 1907 and from 1908 served as middle
school teacher, Canton Christian College, then held positions as Field Asst., Office of Crop
Physiology and Breeding Investigation, U.S.D.A. and in the herb., Lingnan Univ. 1918-
1920, Canton (now Guangzhou), Dean and Dir., Agricultural College 1921-1935 and Dir.,
Economic Plant Receiving Station 1935, both Lingnan Univ., moved to Florida 1941 (dur-
ing W.W.-II), worked in s. China for the U.N. Relief and Rehabilitation Administration
1946-1947, died 4 Dec 1954 in Laurel, Florida. (<em>Groff</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: A, LU (founder), PNH, UC. – Mss. in the Penn. State Univ. Li-
braries (George Weidman Groff papers, 1916-1958) and Yale Univ. Library (Archives of
the Trustees of Lingnan Univ.).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Amer. Men Sci. ed. 9: 439-440; Barnhart 2: 90; Hirsch
p. 105; IH 2: 241; Kew 2: 515; Langman p. 338; MW p. 144, suppl. p. 79; RUS 3: 274, 4:
275; Tucker 3: 127.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Brunner, H.S. et al., 1961. Report on the G. Weidman Groff Collection, University
	Park, Penn. (Penn. State Univ.): 510 p., facsim. (bibl.)
Chen, J.H.-M., 1957. A review of the publications and unpublished written works of the late
	Professor G. Weidman Groff, Lingnan University, Canton, China, covering the period
	1918-1953, University Park, Penn. (Penn. State Univ.): 39 lvs. (mimeogr.) (n.v.)

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: Groff inaugurated and published the <em>Lingnan Agricultural Review</em>,
vols. 1-4 (1922/1923-1927); superceded by the <em>Lingnan Science Journal</em>.

*Gronovius, Johan [Jan] Frederik (1690-1762). (<em>Gronov</em>.). – <em>Note</em>: Earlier (TL-2/1: 1012)
it was stated that Gronovius was baptized in Leiden on 10 Feb 1686 and that the birth year,
1690, often given, is erroneous. In those days, the date of birth was not considered as impor-
tant as the date of baptism, many babies not surviving to baptism. Often the birth date was
not recorded but the date of baptism usually was. Possibly Gronovious was born in 1686 and
was baptized in 1690. However, it could just as well be that he was born before 1686 and was
baptized 10 Feb 1686. Only study of the original documents can establish the facts. [DHN]

PAGE: 412
HEADING: GROOM

Groom, Percy (1865-1931), English botanist, born 12 Sep 1865 in Wellington (Shropshire),
B.A. 1887 Cambridge, prof. of botany and arboriculture, Imperial College, Whampoa (now
Huangpu), China 1889-1892, lecturer in botany at various colleges in Great Britain 1892-
1908, ultimately asst. prof. of botany and then prof. of technology of woods and fibres,
Imperial College of Science &amp; Technology (London) 1908-1931, F.R.S. 1924, M.A., D.Sc.
Oxford, F.L.S., died 16 Sep 1931 in Gerrards Cross (Bucks.). (<em>P. Groom</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown. – Papers are in the archives of the Imperial College of
Science, Technology and Medicine (London).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 90; Biol.-Dokum. 7: 85.543; BM 2: 740, 6:
412; CSP 15: 477; Desmond p. 272-273, ed. 2: 301-302; Kelly p. 94; Kew 2: 517-518; Lang-
man p. 338; LS 10.443; Moebius p. 281; Rehder 5(index): 345; TL-1: 518 (index); TL-2/5,
2/7 (indices); Tucker 1: 304, 2: xviii, 3: 127.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Morning Post [newspaper]: 18 Sep 1931; Times (London) [newspaper]:
	18 Sep 1931; Intl. address book botanists: 183. 1931.
Bridson, G.D.R. et al., 1980. Nat. hist. manuscript resources British Isles: 405. (index)
Dörfler, I., 1896. Botaniker-Adressbuch: 82; 1902. Id., ed. 2: 107; 1909. Id., ed. 3: 158.
F[armer]., J.B., 1931. Nature 128: 695.
F[armer]., J.B., 1932. Obit. notices Fellows Royal Soc. 1: 63-64. (portr.)
Farmer, J.B., 1932. Proc. Linn. Soc. London 144: 176-177.
Rendle, A.B., 1931. J. Bot. 69: 266-267.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) <em>Plant-geography upon a physiological basis</em> ... 1903, which is the
English transl. by William Rogers Fisher (1846-1910) of A.F.W. Schimper, <em>Pfl.-Geogr.
Physiol. Grundl.</em> ... 1898, was revised and edited by Groom &amp; I.B. Balfour (1853-1922),
see TL-2/5, nr. 10.670.
(2) E. Warming, <em>Plantesamfund</em> ... 1895, was "prepared for publication in English" by
Groom &amp; I.B. Balfour (1853-1922) and published as <em>Oecology of plants</em> ... 1909, see
TL-2/7, nr. 16.732.
(3) Edited H.M. Ward, <em>Trees</em> ... 1904-1909, vols. 4-5, see TL-2/7, nr. 16.682, where credit
is given Groom for vol. 4 but not 5.

Grossheim [Grossgeim], Alexander [Aleksandr] Alphonsovitch [Alfonsovich] (1888-
1948), Ukrainian-born Soviet botanist, born 6 Mar 1888 in Lichovka nr. Verchnedneprovsk,
Ekaterinoslav (from 1926 Dnipropetrovsk), educated at Karkov, Moscow and Tiflis (Tibilisi),
worked at Tiflis Botanic Garden, Baku 1929-1946 and then in Leningrad 1946-1948, died 4
Dec 1948 in Leningrad. (<em>Grossh</em>.).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Invariably botanical literature cites his surname as "Grossheim", but the translitera-
tion rules we are following would have us write "Grossgeim", which is how he is treated
in most library catalogs.

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: TBI, duplicates A, B, BAK, BM, DSU, E, ERE, G, GH, K, LAU,
LE, LECB, MO, MW, P, S, TB. – <em>Exsiccatae</em>: Grossheim &amp; B.K. Schischkin, <em>Plantae ori-
entales exsiccatae</em>, Tiflis, 1924-1928 (Fascs. 1-16, Nos. 1-400), sets at B, BM, G, K, LAU,
MO, S, TBI?, Z. <em>Note</em>: There is also a 2 vol. "<em>Schedae ad Herbarium 'Plantae orientales
exsiccatae'</em>". <em>Copies</em>: BM (n.v.), K (n.v.), MO (p.p.) (n.v.).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 244; Barnhart 2: 91; BFM p. 287 (index); Biol.-
Dokum. 7: 86.923; Frodin ed. 2: 1082 (index); Hirsch p. 106; Hortus 3: 1194; IF suppl. 4:
322, 354; IH 2: 242; Kew 2: 519; Lipschitz 3: 59-67; MW suppl. p. 79 (as "Grossgeim");
TL-2/2, 2/4, 2/5 (indices); Tucker 3: 127-128; Zander ed. 11: 758, ed. 17: 950.

	listed in the forewords of vols. 5-7, each foreword signed by A.F. Fedorov.

*Grout, Abel Joel (1867-1947), American bryologist, born 24 Mar 1867 in Newfane
(Windham Co.), Vermont, Ph.B. 1890 Univ. of Vermont, Ph.D. 1897 Columbia College,
New York, New York (under Elizabeth G. Britton), taught at various high-schools in Ver-
mont, New Hampshire and New York state until retirement in 1930 when he was made a
research staff member, Cold Spring Harbor Lab., Long Island, New York and hon. curator
of mosses, New York Botanical Garden 1943-1947, died 27 Mar 1947 in East Bradenton,
Florida, "My interest in mosses began in the early [18]90's largely because I could collect
and study them in winter ...." (<em>Grout</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: DUKE (Bryoph.; orig.), see also IH 2: 242 (and add BRIT, DBN,
E, LE, PH, WTU). – <em>Exsiccatae</em>: (1) <em>Hand-lens mosses</em> (nos. 1-76, 1903-x), sets at FH, NY.
(2) <em>North American musci perfecti</em> (nos. 1-475, Newfane, Vermont, 1925-1945), sets at BM,
BRU, CAS, CM, FH, G, GEO, GRI, K, MICH, NY, S-PA, SMU, W, WELC (now NY). (3)
<em>North American musci pleurocarpi</em> (nos. 1-500, Newfane, Vermont, 1900-1922, suppl. nos.
1-74, 1931-1942), sets at FH, G, GEO, GRI, H, NY, SMU. – Letters in many collections, a.o.
Cornell Univ. Library (Albert Leroy Andrews corr., 1899-1964), and archives of FH, GH
and NY (Elizabeth Gertrude Knight Britton &amp; Robert Statham Williams records).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Amer. Men Sci. ed. 6: 564; APN p. 244; Barnhart 2: 92;
BL 1: 202, 299; BM 2: 742, 6: 413; Bossert p. 154; CSP 15: 485; Ewan ed. 1: 220, ed. 2: 92;
Ewan Pap. p. 84; Hirsch p. 106; IH 1 (ed. 6): 359; IH 2: 242; Kew 2: 520; Lenley p. 184 (as
"Grant") 189-190; LS 10.454-10.455, 13.292; NAF 15A(1): 1, ser. 2(3): 35, ser. 2(9:) 122;
NW p. 47 (index); Pennell p. 608; Portr. 1: 64 (index), 3: 510; Rhodora, index p. 333; SBC
p. 121; TL-2/1: 1013-1014, indices 2/4, 2/5, Suppl. 3.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Intl. address book botanists: 475. 1931.
Anderson, L.E., 1999. Bryologist 103: 3-14. (portr.) [early hist. Bryol. &amp; Lichenol. Soci-
	ety]

Ewan, J. (ed.), 1969. Short hist. bot. U.S.: 93-94.
Flowers, S., 1947. Bryologist 50: 208-212.

	[135]-195, <em>6 pl</em>. from: Morse, Rev. Abner, 1857. The genealogy of the descendants of
	several ancient Puritans ...]. <em>Copies</em>: MO-Steere, NY (n.v.)

HEADING: GROUT

Haring, I.M., 1947. J. New York Bot. Gard. 48: 163-165. (portr.)

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: (additional) <em>Groutiella</em> Steere (1950).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: (1) The following corrections to Grout, <em>Moss. hand-lens microsc.</em> (see TL-2 /1, nr.
2193) are necessary:
There were 5 parts, not 4, and the dates previously cited were incorrect (correct information
here provided by Marshall R. Crosby):
<em>Pt. 1</em>: [1]-86 is dated on cover Jun 1903 (not Sep 1903).
<em>Pt. 2</em>: 87-[166] is dated on cover Mai 1904 (not Jul 1904).
<em>Pt. 3</em>: 167-[246] is dated on cover Jun 1906 (not Mar 1907).
<em>Pt. 4</em>: 247-318 is dated on cover Apr 1908 (not Jul 1910).
<em>Pt. 5</em>: [319]-416 is dated on cover Jul 1910.
In addition, there was a second printing of the 1965 reprint: 1972, ... No. Bennington, Ver-
mont (John Johnson). <em>Copies</em>: MO (n.v.), NY, US (n.v.).
(2) <em>Moss fl. New York</em> ... 1916 (TL-2/1, nr. 2194) has been issued in microform:
<em>Microfiche</em>: Westport, Conn. (Meckler/Chadwyck-Healey Pub.), [1987?] 2 microfiche (Plant
	taxonomic lit. microfiche coll., "2151A3-2152E2"). <em>Copy</em>: MO (n.v.).
(3) The William C. Steere collection cited in TL-2/1 was purchased by MO in 1977.

*Grove, William Bywater (1848-1938), British mycologist, born 24 Oct 1848 in Birming-
ham (Warks.), B.A. 1871 Cambridge, headmaster, Birmingham School for Boys at Queen's
College 1887-1900, lecturer in botany, Studley Horticultural College (Warks.) 1900-1908

PAGE: 420
HEADING: GROVE

and then Birmingham Municipal Technical School, 1905-1927, hon. Curator, Fungus Herb.,
Univ. of Birmingham, president Birmingham Natural History Society, M.Sc. (h.c.) 1936,
died 6 Jan 1938 in Birmingham. (<em>Grove</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: K (3500), duplicates BIRM, BPI, CGE, RGY (now WARMS),
WARMS. – Mss. in BMNH (incl. orig. col. and pencil drawings of micro-fungi, mostly
British), Merseyside Museums (i.e. National Museums Liverpool) (corr.), NY (William
Bywater Grove papers 1924-1928) and Royal Entomological Society (corr. with Colbran
Joseph Wainwright (1867-1949), entomologist).

Groves, Enrico (b. Henry) (1835-1891), English pharmacist and botanist, born in Wey-
mouth (Dorset), settled in Florence, Italy 1862 where he came to own a pharmacy, collected
vigorously during the summers when business was at a stand-still, F.L.S. 1884, died 1 Mar
1891 in Florence. (<em>E. Groves</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BM, BP, CGE, E, F, FI (main set), G, GB, GOET, K, L, MANCH,
OXF, P.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 92; BB p. 132-133; Bossert p. 154; CSP 3: 33,
7: 847, 10: 71, 15: 487; Desmond p. 273, ed. 2: 302; Hist. Coll. BMNH p. 152 (as "Henry");
IH 2: 242; Kew List p. 28 (as "Henry (of Florence)"); Morren ed. 10: 84; Portr. 3: 510;
Rehder 5(index): 346; Saccardo 1: 86; Tucker 1: 304; Wagenitz p. 67.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., J. Bot. 29: 191-192. 1891; Pharm. J. Trans., ser. 3, 21: 894-895. 1891; Proc.

*Groves, Henry (1855-1912), British botanist interested in Characeae and nomenclature,
born 15 Oct 1855 in London, employed as a stockbroker until 1879, then by Queen Anne's
Bounty Office until his death, F.L.S. 1892, died 2 Nov 1912 in London (Clapham). (<em>H.
Groves</em>).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Older brother of James Groves (1858-1933) (see below), with whom he published.

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BM (orig.), duplicates E, EBH, GL, K, MANCH, NMW, NOT, OXF,
SLBI, etc. – <em>Exsiccatae</em> (with his brother James Groves): <em>Characeae Britannicae exsiccatae</em>
(fasc. i-iii, nos. 1-60, 1892-1900), sets at e.g. BM, CGE, DBN, E, FH, JE, K, LD, PC.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 244; Backer p. 651; Barnhart 2: 92; BB p. 133; BL
2: 268, 662; BM 6: 413; BN p. 175; Clokie p. 175; CSP 10: 71, 12: 294, 15: 487; Desmond
p. 273, ed. 2: 302; De Toni 1: lv, 4: xxv; Hist. Coll. BMNH p. 152; IH 2: 242-243; Kent p.
58, ed. 2: 156; Kew List p. 28 (as "Henry (of Clapham)"); Lenley p. 190; NAF 7(15): 1067;
Morren ed. 10: 73; Portr. 3: 510; SO p. 26 (index); TL-2/1: 1016; Zander ed. 17: 950.

*Groves, James (1858-1933), British algologist and paleontologist interested in Characeae,
born 19 Jan 1858 in London, worked in Army and Navy Stores until retirement in 1918, F.L.S.
1885, died 20 Mar 1933 in Trevarthian (or Freshwater Bay), Isle of Wight. (<em>J. Groves</em>).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: The youngest of three brothers, incl. Henry Groves (1855-1912) (see above) with
whom he often published.

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BM. – <em>Exsiccatae</em> (see also under Henry Groves, his older brother):
<em>British and Irish Charophyta</em> (with Rev. George Russell Bullock-Webster, 1858-1934) (fasc.
i-ii, nos. 1-42, 1924), sets at B, BM, DBN, E, K, OXF. – Mss. at BM (James Groves papers).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Andrews p. 272; APN p. 244; Barnhart 2: 92; BL 2: 268,
662; BM 6: 413; Clokie p. 175; CSP 10: 71, 15: 487; De Toni 4: xxv; Desmond p. 273, ed.
2: 302; Hist. Coll. BMNH p. 152; IH 2: 242-243; Kent p. 58, ed. 2: 156; Kew 2: 521; Kew
List p. 28; MW p. 146, suppl. p. 80; NI 2: 72; Portr. 3: 510; SO p. 26 (index); TL-2/1: 1016,
2/6 (index); Zander ed. 17: 950.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) Editor, with his brother Henry, of C.C. Babington, <em>Man. Brit. bot.</em>
... ed. 9, 1904 (see TL-2/1, nr. 216).
(2) Characeae, with his brother Henry, <em>in</em> I. Urban, <em>Symb. antill.</em> ... vol. 7(1), 15 Dec 1911
(see TL-2/6, nr. 15.687).
(3) J. Groves &amp; G.R. Bullock-Webster, <em>Brit. Charoph.</em> ... 1920-1924, 2 vols., was treated
earlier (TL-2/1, nr. 2199) but can be amended as follows:
<em>Microfiche</em>: (a) Westport, Conn. (Meckler/Chadwyck-Healey Publishing), [1987 ?], 6 mi-
	crofiches (Plant taxonomic lit. microfiche coll., "8277A1-8282B6"). <em>Copy</em>: MO. (b)
	Wakefield, Yorkshire, U.K. (EP Group of Companies, Microform Division), [19–]. <em>Copy</em>:
	LC – NRMM (Printing master microform) (n.v.).
<em>Reprint</em>: New York (Johnson Reprint), 2 vols., 1971. <em>Copy</em>: UC-Santa Barbara (n.v.).
(4) Contributed a section on fossil Charophyta to E.M. Reid &amp; M.E.J. Chandler, <em>Bembridge
fl</em>. ... 1926 (TL-2/1, nr. 8905).
(5) Specimens obtained by Clement Reid (1853-1916) and J. Groves, bequeathed to the
BMNH by the latter in 1933, formed the basis of Thomas Maxwell Harris (1903-x), <em>British
Purbeck Charophyta</em>, London (British Museum (Natural History)), ix, 83 p., <em>17 pl</em>. 1939.
Reid and Groves published a preliminary report on the Characeae of the Purbeck formation
in <em>Proc. Roy. Soc. London, Ser. B, Biol. Sci.</em>, 89: 252-256. 1916.

Groves, J[ames]. Walton (1906-1970), Canadian mycologist, born 18 Oct 1906 in Kin-
burn, Ontario, graduated from Ottawa Normal School, taught public school in Ottawa 1926-
1928, B.A. 1930 Queens' Univ., Kingston, Ontario, M.A. 1932 and Ph.D. 1935 Univ. of
Toronto, mycologist, Dept. of Agriculture, Ottawa 1936-1970, incl. chief, Mycology Sect.
1951-1967, Fellow Royal Soc. Canada 1951, founding member I.A.P.T. and served on
special committee on Fungi and Lichens 1950-1970, died 6 Mai 1970 in Ottawa. (<em>J.W.
Groves</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Canada (1931-1952, Fungi): BPI, CUP, DAOM, OTB, PC,
TRTC.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Ainsworth &amp; Bisby's Dict. p. 218; APN p. 245; Barnhart
2: 92; Bossert p. 154; Hawksworth p. 183; IH 2: 243; Kew 2: 521; Portr. 1: 64 (index).

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Taxon 20: 394. 1971.
Boivin, B., 1980. Provancheria nr. 10: 34, 45. (herb.)

	Ser. 28: 37-38 (English), 38 (French).

Shoemaker, R.A., 1971. Mycologia 63: 1-4. (portr.)
Thomson, S.C., 1972. Canad. Field-Naturalist 86: 177-180. (bibl., portr.)

*Grummann, Vitus Johannes (1899-1967), German teacher and amateur lichenologist,
born 3 Mar 1899 in Jacobsdorf (Oberschlesien), military service 1917-1918 (i.e. W.W.-I),
teacher in Berlin 1920-1942 and again after W.W.-II, Ph.D. 1941 Berlin, retired 1963, died
9 [12?] Dec 1967 in Berlin. (<em>Grumm</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: B, GFW, LD.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Ainsworth p. 308, 337; APN p. 245; Barnhart 2: 94; Biol.-
Dokum. 7: 87.737-87.743; Bossert p. 154; GR p. 16-17; GR cat. p. 64; Hawksworth p. 183;
Portr. 1: 64 (index), 3: 511; Roon p. 46; SBC p. 121; TL-2/1: 1017.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bryologist 71: 159. 1968. (d. "9 Dec")
Klement, O., 1968. Ber. Deutsch. Bot. Ges. 81(3/4): 81-84. (d. "12 Dec") (bibl., portr.)
Perlick, A., 1970. Beuthener Abhandl. Oberschlesischen Heimatforschung 31: 6 p. (n.v.)

<sm>OUTSIDE OUR PERIOD</sm>: (1) <em>Morphologische, anatomische und entwicklungsgeschichtliche
Studien</em> über <em>Bildungsabweichungen</em> bei <em>Flechten</em>: unter kritischer Einbeziehung der bis-
herigen Literatur ... Gräfenhainichen (Druck von A. Heine G.m.b.H.) 1941; his doctoral
thesis. Also issued as ... Dahlem bei Berlin (Im Selbstverlag) 1941.
(2) Co-author with Johannes Hillmann (1881-1943), <em>Flechten</em> ... Berlin (Gebrüder Born-
traeger) 1957.
(3) <em>Catalogus lichenum Germaniae</em>; ein systematisch-floristischer Katalog der Flechten
Deutschlands ... Stuttgart (G. Fischer) 1963.
(4) <em>Biographisch-bibiographisches Handbuch der Lichenologie</em> [von] V. Grummann: Nach
dem Tode des Verfassers für die Herausgabe durchgesehen von O[scar]. Klement ... Lehre
(J. Cramer), ix, 839 p., <em>41 pl</em>. (facsims., portrs.) 1974. – <em>Note</em>: This is a standard reference
for TL-2, abbreviated as "GR".

37.364. Die <em>Flechtenflora</em> der Insel Rügen mit Hiddensee, etc. ... 1934. Oct.

	Lichenologische Berichte II.

Gruner, Leopold Fedorovich (1839-x), Russian-born German field botanist, born 2/14
Oct 1839 in Livland (then a Russian province), collected plants with Eduard Lehmann. (<em>L.
Gruner</em>).

*Grunow [Grunov], Albert (1826-1914), German chemist and amateur but important di-
atomologist, born 3 Nov 1826 in Berlin, removed to Berndorf, Austria in 1857 where he
worked, died 19 [17?] Mar 1914 in Berndorf. (<em>Grunow</em>).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Treated earlier as "Grunov" (see TL-2/1: 1017).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: W (diat. and other alg.), WU (diat. <em>fide</em> Wornardt, 1968), B (other
collections), duplicates AWH (diat.), B, BR, BRM, E, HBG, KIEL, L, PH. – <em>Exsiccatae</em>:
(1) See William Ferguson (1820-1887), <em>Algae ceylonicae</em> ... 1850-1887, or later. (2) See
Henri Ferdinand Van Heurck (1838-1909), <em>Types du synopsis de diatomées de Belgique</em>
(ser. i-xxii, nrs. 1-550) 1882-1885.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 245 (as "Grunov"); Barnhart 2: 94 (as "Grunow");
BM 2: 744 (as "Grunow"), 6: 414 (as "Grunow"); BN p. 26, 175; Bossert p. 152 (as "Grunow");
CSP 3: 53, 7: 859, 10: 78, 12: 295, 15: 498; De Toni 2: lv-lvi (as "Grunow"); DTS 1: 97
(as "Grunow"); Frahm&amp;E. p. 153 (as "Grunow" with image on medal); Herder p. 453 (as

"Grunow"); Kew 2: 523 (as "Grunow"); Kleppa p. 92; KR p. 248-249; Moebius p. 78; Morren
ed. 10: 31 (as "Grunow"); MW p. 147; Nordstedt p. 16 (as "Grunow"); ÖBL 2: 94; Portr. 3:
511; PR ed. 2: 3619 (as "Grunow"); Quenstedt p. 176; Saccardo 1: 86 (as "Grunow"); Sarjeant
p. 1155, Suppl. 1: 461; TL-1: 518 (index); TL-2/1: 1016, indices 2/4, 2/5, 2/6 (as "Grunov" but
in text nr.15.915 as "Grunow"!), 2/7, Suppl. 2, 4; Urban-Berl. p. 264, 301, 351.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: The earlier entry for <em>Österr. Diatom.</em> ... (TL-2/1, nr. 2201) analyzed the serial public-
cation and a facsimile of the same. Having since examined a reprint of the "Zweite Folge",
the entry can be amended as follows:
Die <em>österreichischen Diatomaceen</em> nebst Anschluss einiger <em>neuen Arten</em> von andern Loka-
litäten und einer kritischen Uebersicht der bisher bekannten Gattungen und Arten ... (Aus
den Verhandlungen ...Wien) 1862. Oct. (<em>Österr. Diatom.</em>).
<em>Publ</em>. ["Erste Folge"]: 1862 (read 5 Mar 1862), ... p. [1]-158, [alternate pagination, p.
	[315]-472], <em>pl. III</em>(<em>6</em>)-<em>VII(10), XIII(11)</em>. <em>Copies</em>: BM, FH (detached), NY (detached),
	WU. – Extracted from Verh. K.K. Zool.-Bot. Ges. Wien 12: 315-472, <em>pl. 6-11.</em> 1862.
["Zweite Folge"]: 1862 (read 7 Mai 1862), ... p. [1]-44, [alternate pagination, p. [545]-588],<em>
	pl. XVIII</em>(<em>XII</em>). <em>Copies</em>: BKL, BM, FH (detached), NY (detached), WU. – Id. 12, Abt. 2:
	545-588, <em>pl. XII</em> (uncol. lith.).
<em>Note</em>: (1) In both the reprint and the journal the plates are numbered twice; Roman numerals
	(in sequence for the volume) and Arabic ones (for Grunow's article alone) in the "Erste
	Folge" and different Roman ones in the "Zweite Folge". (2) Plate VIII is misnumbered
	as "XIII".
<em>Ref</em>.: Stafleu, F.A., Taxon 21: 195-196. Feb 1972 (rev. of facsimile ed.).

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) Contributed to part 2 <em>in</em> L. Rabenhorst, <em>Beitr. Kenntn. Alg.</em> ... 1865
(TL-2/4, nr. 8443).
(2) <em>Algen und Diatomaceen aus dem Kaspischen Meere in</em> O. Schneider, <em>Naturw. Beitr.
Kaukasusländ.</em> ... 1878 (TL-2/5, nr. 10.961 and nr. 37.373 below).
(3) Contributed to <em>Rabenh. Krypt.-Fl. ed. 2</em> ... vol. 1(1), 1880-1885 (TL-2/4, nr. 8450).
(4) Collaborated with H.F. Van Heurck, <em>Syn. diatom. Belgique</em> ... Part I, fascs. 4-5,
1881-1882 (TL-2/6, nr. 15.915).
(5) Co-author with É. Bornet, <em>Mazaea</em> ... 1882 (TL-2/Suppl. 2, nr. 22.170). – <em>Note: Mazaea</em>
is dedicated to Mazé, Hippolyte Pierre (1818-1892), see TL-2/3: 391-392.
(6) Co-author with A. Zahlbruckner, <em>Beitr. Fl. Neu-Caled.</em> ... 1888 (TL-2/7, nr. 18.489).
(7) Algae <em>in</em> K. Schumann, <em>Fl. Kais. Wilh. Land</em> ... 1889 (TL-2/5, nr. 11.368).
(8) Assisted with the text accompanying <em>pl. 145-212 in</em> A. Schmidt, <em>Atlas Diatom.-Kunde</em>
... 1890-1895 (see TL-2/5, nr. 10.871).
(9) Co-author with P.T. Cleve, <em>Beitr. arct. Diat.</em> ... 1880 (TL-2/Suppl. 4, nr. 26.638).

Guadagno, Michele (1878-1930), Italian botanist, born 16 Oct 1878 in Naples, titled him-
self as "Ing." in early papers, esp. interested in the flora of the isl. of Capri, died 10 Sep
1930 in Naples. (<em>Guadagno</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: PI-GUAD (orig.; transfered from Naples in Dec 1939), duplicates
BP, E, GB, GZU, K, L, NH, US, W. – Some mss. materials in the Univ. of Pisa.

2: xviii.

HEADING: GUBA

Guba, Emil Frederick (1897-1999), American mycologist and plant pathologist, born 13
Mai 1897 in New Bedford, Mass., B.Sc. 1919 Mass. Agricultural College (now Univ. of
Mass.), Amherst, Ph.D. 1923 Univ. of Illinois, plant pathologist, Cornell Univ., Ithaca, New
York 1923-1925, asst. prof. 1925 and prof. 1939, Mass. Agricultural College Field Station
(a.k.a. Market Garden Field Station), Waltham, Mass., retired 1962, died 16 Mar 1999 in
Kingston, Mass. (buried in Waltham). (<em>Guba</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Nantucket (Fungi): MASS, duplicates BPI, ILL, NMMA. – <em>Ex-
siccatae</em>: <em>Plants of Nantucket County, Mass</em>. (<em>Pl. Nantucket</em>) (Cent. 1-3, nos. 1-300, 1937-
1942; viz. Cent. 1, nos. 1-100. 1937, Cent. 2: 101-200. 1939 and Cent. 3: 201-300. 1942).
Sets: BPI, FH, PC.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Amer. Men Sci. 8: 978; APN p. 246; Barnhart 2: 95; Ewan
Pap. p. 84; Hirsch p. 106; IH 2: 243; LS suppl. 10.200-10.209; Portr. 3: 512; Rhodora, index
p. 333; RUS 3: 275, 4: 277; Tucker 3: 128.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Cornell Alumni News 25(26): 326. 1923 ("Emile"); Intl. address book
	botanists: 476. 1931.
Palm, M., [Mar-Apr] 2000. Inoculum (Newslett. Mycol. Soc. Amer.) 51(2): electronic
	copy only.
Pfister, D.H., 1985. Mycotaxon 23: 105.
Stevenson, J.A., 1971. Beih. Nova Hedwigia 36: 178-179.
Wyatt, G., 1937. Ann. Rept. Maria Mitchell Assoc. 35: 22. (herb.)

<sm>OUTSIDE OUR PERIOD</sm>: (1) <em>Monograph</em> of <em>Monochaetia</em> and <em>Pestalotia</em>, Cambridge, Mass.
(Harvard Univ. Press) 1961.
(2) <em>Wild mushrooms – food and poison</em> ... Waltham, Mass. (Published by the author) 1970;
ed. 2, ... Kingston, Mass. (Pilgrim Publishers) 1977.

Gubb, Alfred Samuel (M.D.) (1857-x), British doctor (gynecologist and/or obstetrician)
and amateur botanist, resided in London (1889) and then Paris (1892), at least, doctorate
1893 Faculty of Medicine, Paris. (<em>Gubb</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

Gubler, [Nicolas] Adolphe Marie (1821-1879), French physician, pharmacologist and
botanist, born 4 Apr 1821 in Metz (Moselle), studied medicine in Paris 1841, traveled in
Italy, returned to Paris and obtained his doctorate 1849, Prof., Faculty of Medicine, Paris
1858-1879, Académie de médecine 1865, published extensively on human anatomy, physi-
cology and clinical medicine, vice-president, Société Botanique de France, died 20 Apr 1879
in Val Margue nr. Toulon (Var). (<em>Gubler</em>).

PAGE: 435
HEADING: GUBLER

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Baillon 2: 751; Barnhart 2: 95; BM 2: 745; CSP 3: 54-55,
7: 859, 10: 80-81, 12: 295, 15: 502; DBF 16: 1406-1408; Jackson p. 208; Kew 2: 523-524;
LS 10.707-10.508; Rehder 5(index): 347-348; Tucker 1: 305.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Cavillier, [Frère], 1941. Boissiera 5: 51.
Charpin, A. &amp; J. Timbal, 2007. Acta Bot. Gallica 154: 454.
Gubler, A., 1876. Notice sur les titres et travaux scientifiques du Dr A. Gubler, Paris (P.
	Dupont): 76 p. (n.v.)

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: In medicine, "Gubler's line", "Gubler's tumour" and "Millard-Gubler syndrome".

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: Scientific editor, <em>Journal de thérapeutique</em> (1874-1878).

Guebhard, Ch. (fl. 1829-1850), Romanian botanist. (<em>Guebhard</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: CN, FI, G, P, W.

37.399. <em>Notice géographique</em> et <em>botanique</em> sur La <em>Moldavie</em>, pour servir d'introduction à la

*Gümbel, [Wilhelm] Theodor (von) (1812-1858), German bryologist, born 19 Mar 1812
in Dannenfels (Palatinate), older brother of Carl Wilhelm Gümbel (1823-1898, who became
a geologist and also studied mosses), dir. of a secondary school in Landau (Palatinate), died
10 Feb 1858 in Landau. (<em>W. Gümbel</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown; some mosses at BR, TUB. – Gümbel's extensive moss
herb. was offered for sale by his brother, C. Wilhelm Gümbel, in Flora 45(15): 240. 8 Mai
1862. It contained many of the originals on which the illus. of P. Bruch, <em>Bryol. europ.</em> ...
(1836-1855) were based.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: ADB 10: 188-119; APN p. 248; Baillon 2: 755; Barnhart 2:
95; BM 2: 745-746; CSP 3: 85-86, 6: 679; DTS 1: 99; Frahm&amp;E. p. 153-154; Herder p. 453
(index); IH 2: 245; Jackson p. 308; Lasègue p. 545; Moebius p. 119; NDB 7: 258-259; NI
2: 72; PR ed. 2: 3622; Rehder 5(index): 348; SBC p. 121; TL-1: 57-63; TL-2/1: 1019-1020,

Günthart, [Emil] August (1879-1957), Swiss botanist, born 8 Jul 1879 in Frauenfeld (Kt. Thur-
gau), Ph.D. 1902 Zürich, teacher in girls' schools in Barmen 1902-1905 and Zürich 1905-1912,
leader of the mathematics/natural history division of the Teubner Press in Leipzig 1912-1917,
Dir., Botanical Garden, Frauenfeld from 1920, died 22 Apr 1957 in Frauenfeld. (<em>Günthart</em>).

PAGE: 437
HEADING: GÜRKE

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

*Gürke [Guerke], Robert Louis August Maximilian [Max] (1854-1911), German (Sile-
sian) botanist, born 17 Nov 1854 in Beuthen an der Oder (Oberschlesien) (now Poland),
studied natural history and mathematics 1873-1880, taught in Görliz 1880-1884, asst. at
Berlin 1886, Ph.D. 1892 Göttingen, asst. curator ("Hilfkustos") 1892, curator ("Kustos")
1893-1911 and Prof. 1904, all Botanical Garden and Museum, Berlin, studied at Kew 1895,
died 16 Mar 1911 in Berlin (Steglitz). (<em>Gürke</em>).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Although cited as "Guerke" in TL-2/1, he invariably published as "M[ax].
Gürke".

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown, some material at K. – B had a set of 154 drawings of
Cactaceae by Mrs. Toni Gürke, the wife of Max Gürke. The Cactaceae drawings are al-
most certainly connected to K. Schumann &amp; M. Gürke, <em>Bl. Kakt.</em> ... [1900-1921] (TL-2/5,
nr. 11.388), Mrs. Gürke also contributed some plates to C.F. Schmidt, <em>Atlas off. Pfl.</em> ...
vols. 3 &amp; 4, 1896-1902 (TL-2/5, nr. 10.874).

PAGE: 438
HEADING: GÜRKE

... Part 40, 1894, see TL-2/7, nr. 16.709.

33.029); and
(c) A. Zahlbruckner, <em>Plantae Pentherianae</em> ... Part 3, 1905, see TL-2/7, nr. 18.507.

(7) Pref. <em>in</em> K. Schumann, <em>Prakt. Morph. syst. Bot.</em> ... 1904 (TL-2/5, nr. 11.392).

(1905, see nr. 36.408 above).

Güssow [Gussow], Hans Theodor (1879-1961), German-born Canadian mycologist and
plant pathologist, born 24 Aug 1879 in Breslau, studied applied botany and subsequently
plant pathology and bacteriology in Breslau, Leipzig and Berlin, worked in England from

PAGE: 440
HEADING: GÜSSOW

1901-1909 and as asst. to William Carruthers from 1903 to 1909, Dominion Botanist and
head of the Botany Division of the Experimental Farms Branch, Ottawa, Canada 1909-1944,
Assoc. Dir., Science Service of the Dept. of Agriculture 1938-x, LL.D. 1931 Queen's Univ.,
Kingston, Ontario, Fellow, Royal Society of Canada 1931, died 15 Jun 1961 in Victoria,
British Columbia, Canada. (<em>Güssow</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Fungi: DAOM, duplicates in BPI. Vascular plants: DAO (pos-
sibly).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Amer. Men Sci. ed. 8: 873; APN p. 250; Barnhart 2: 96;
Bossert p. 156; Ewan ed. 2: p. 92; Kelly p. 97; LS suppl. 10.333-10.371; NW p. 47 (index);
Portr. 1: 64 (index), 3: 517.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Intl. address book botanists: 45. 1931.
Boivin, B., 1980. Provancheria nr. 10: 34, 35.

Guest, Evan Rhuvon (1902-1992), British agronomist and botanist, born 24 Jan 1902 in
London, educated at Eton, B.Sc. 1924 Imperial College, London, Southeastern Agricultural
College, Wye (Kent) ca. 1925, Imperial College of Tropical Agriculture, Trinidad ca. 1926,
followed by two years in the Anglo-Egyptian Sudan, held various agricultural postings in
Iraq through 1933, agricultural advisor, I.C.I. (Malaya) in London 1934-1937, botanist,
Rubber Inst., Kuala Lumpur 1937-1940, B.B.C. Foreign Service in London and Cairo dur-
ing W.W.-II, again in Iraq 1953-1958, returned to London and worked at Kew on the <em>Flora
of Iraq</em> until 1987, died 4 Mar 1992. (<em>Guest</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BAG, BUH, E, K, duplicates (now lost?) in local Iraqi herbaria in
Rustam and Abu Ghraib.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 247; BFM p. 287 (index); Bossert p. 155; Frodin
ed. 2: 1029 (index); IH 2: 244; LS suppl. 10.237; Strid p. 141, ed. 2: 195.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Daily Telegraph [newspaper]: 3 Apr 1992. (portr.)
Blakelock, R.A., 1948. Kew Bull. 1948: 375. [Rustam Herb.]
Blakelock, R.A. &amp; E.R. Guest, 1966. <em>In</em>, E.R. Guest (ed.), Fl. Iraq 1: 113; Id.: 186-187,
	193. (bibl.)

*Guettard, Jean-Étienne (1715-1786), French physician, geologist and naturalist, born
22 Sep 1715 in Étampes (Île de France), studied botany under Bernard de Jussieu, Fac-
ulty of Medicine, Paris 1742, from 1747 "médecin botaniste" to and keeper of the Duc
d'Orléans's natural history collection, he was the first to survey and geologically map
France and to observe the exposed bedrock of the Paris Basin, died 6 [7?] Jan 1786 in Paris.
(<em>Guett</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Académie p. 227; AG 12(3): 269; APN p. 247; Baillon 2:
751; Barnhart 2: 97; BM 2: 749, 6: 417; DBF 17: 19-21; De Toni 1: lvi; Dryander 5: 256
(index); DSB 5: 577-579; GR p. 325; LS 10.563-10.564; Moebius p. 450 (index); PR ed.
1: 3953-3954, ed. 2: 3630-3631; Quenstedt p. 176-177; Rehder 5(index): 349; RS p. 86;
Saccardo 1: 87; Sarjeant p. 1157-1158, Suppl. 1: 461-462, Suppl. 2: 679; SO p. 26 (index);
Sotheby 1: 250; TL-1: 186; TL-2/1: 1020-1021, 2/4: 1173 (index); Tucker 1: 306; Zander
ed. 10: 665, 17: 951.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Carpenter, M.M., 1953. Amer. Midl. Naturalist 50: 293.
Condorcet, N.C. de, 1788. Hist. Acad. Sci. Paris 1786: 47-62. (n.v.)
Daszkiewicz, P., 1998. Arch. Nat. Hist. 25: 281-282. [travel in Poland &amp; n. Europe,
	1760-1762]
Geikie, A., 1901. The founders of geology .... ed. 2, Baltimore (The Johns Hopkins Press):
	478-479. (index)
Gibson, J.A. &amp; E.C. Nelson, 2001. Cumulative index Archives Nat. Hist.: 60.
Guettard, J.E., 1786. Catalogue des livres de la bibliothèque de feu M. Guettard ... Paris
	(Chez Pissot, Saugrain): [2], 99, [3] p. (n.v.)
Hahn, R., 1971. The anatomy of a scientific institution: 69, 114, 132 note, 347 (biogr.).
Rappaport, R., 1964. Guettard, Lavoisier, and Monnet: geologists in the service of the
	French monarchy, Ph.D. Thesis, Cornell Univ., Ithaca, New York. (n.v.)
Rappaport, R., 1968. Isis 58: 375-384. [geological activities]
Soland, A. de, 1873. Étude sur Guettard, Angers (impr. de Lainé frères): 57 p. [Also in Ann.

Stafleu, F.A., 1971. Linnaeus and the Linnaeans: 87, 275.
Tarkowski, R., 2004. Comptes rendus, Géoscience 336(13): 1227-1232. [travel in Poland,
	1760-1762] (n.v.)

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: (additional) <em>Guettardidites</em> A.M. Khan (1976), derived from from <em>Guettarda</em> L.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: (1) <em>Observations sur les plantes</em> ... 1747 (TL-2/1, nr. 2207) is now available in
microform:
(a) <em>Micro-opaque</em>: New York (Readex Microprint), 1974, 10 cards, 23×15 cm (In series,
	Landmarks of science). <em>Copy</em>: (n.v.). (b) <em>Microfiche</em>: Westport, Conn. (Meckler/Chad-
	wyck-Healey Publishing), 1987, 10 microfiches (Plant taxonomic lit. microfiche coll.,
	"2171D6-2180F4"). <em>Copy</em>: MO (n.v.).

PAGE: 443
HEADING: GUFFROY

(2) His <em>Cinquième</em> [i.e. Sixième] <em>mémoire</em> ... 1753 (TL-2/1, nr. 2208) is now listed in Ap-
pendix V "<em>Opera Utique Oppressa</em>" of the 2006 Vienna <em>Code</em>. Names appearing in these
works in the ranks specified at the end of each listing (all ranks in this case) are not to be ac-
cepted as validly published. This list was established by action of the Tokyo Congr. (1993)
and first appeared in the 1994 Tokyo <em>Code</em>.

Guffroy, Charles Émile (1875-1954), French botanist and mycologist, Lic. ès-sciences,
Ingénieur-agronome, Paris. (<em>Guffroy</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 247; Barnhart 2: 96; BFM p. 287 (index); BL

TL-2/2: 955 (index).

Gugelberg von Moos, Maria [Marie] (Barbara Flandrina) (1836-1918), Swiss bryologist
and hepaticologist, born 6 Feb 1836 in Schloss Salenegg bei Maienfeld (Kt. Graubünden),
studied in Maienfeld and Neuchâtel, evidently also collaborated with Christian Gregor
Brügger, died 29 Oct 1918 in Maienfeld. (<em>Gugelb</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Z.

	nerischen Monatsblatt 1919]

Guilfoyle, William Robert (1840-1912), British-born Australian landscape gardener, bota-
nist and civil servant, born 8 Dec 1840 in Chelsea (London), emigrated to Sydney, Australia
1853 with his family where his father, Michael Guilfoyle (1809-1884), established an active
nursery business, attended Lyndhurst College, Glebe (Sydney), sailed (as "tourist") aboard
H.M.S. <em>Challenger</em> in Pacific Ocean Mai-Oct 1868, farmed sugar cane and tobacco, Tweed
River, n.e. New South Wales, appointed curator (i.e. Dir.), Royal Botanic Gardens, Mel-
bourne 1873, and concentrated on transforming the gardens rather than on science as did
his predecessor F. von Mueller, visited England and Europe 1890-1891 and 1896, retired
because of ill health 1909, F.L.S., died 25 Jun 1912 in East Melbourne. (<em>Guilfoyle</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: MEL, duplicates E; two albums of fern specimens also are in the
Natl. Library of Australia. – Mss. materials in Univ. of Melbourne Archives.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: ADB(2) 4: 307-308; APN p. 247; Backer p. 246; Barnhart
2: 98; BB p. 133; BL 1: 64, 299; BM 2: 750, 6: 417; BN p. 175; Bossert p. 155; CSP 7: 863,
15: 521; Desmond p. 274, ed. 2: 303; Herder p. 164: HR; Kew 2: 528; Lenley p. 190; Mor-
ren ed. 2: 14, ed. 10: 149; Portr. 3: 513; Rehder 5(index): 350; Tucker 1: 306, 3: 128.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bull. Misc. Inform. Kew 1912: 350-351. 1912. [resigned as Dir., Royal
	Botanic Gardens Sep 1909]
Dörfler, I., 1896. Botaniker-Adressbuch: 230; 1902. Id., ed. 2: 293; 1909. Id., ed. 3: 400.
[Engelmann, W.], 1891. Botanisches Adressbuch: 151.

	(n.v.)

	Univ. of New England. Vol. 3: 7.

	of Australian Science Database]

37.434. <em>Australian plants</em> suitable for gardens, parks, timber reserves, etc. ... Melbourne

<em>Publ</em>.: [1909?] (USDA copy rec'd. 1 Mai 1911), p. [1]-478, <em>214 pl</em>. (unnumb. phot.). <em>Copies</em>:

Anon., Nature 87(2176): 37-38. 13 Jul 1911.
<em>Note</em>: There is controversy about the publication date (none on the t.p.), e.g. Blake &amp;
	Atwood state "[1911?]" and the BM library cat. has it as "[1911]". The t.p. copied at
	NSW has a handwritten note at the bottom: "Published in 1909 according to information
	received from the Public Library Sydney". This note is initialed, possibly reading "N.W."
	[but apparently involving three letters since there are three periods] and dated "10/4/41"
	[i.e. 10 Apr 1941].

Guillaud, Jean-Alexandre (1849-1923), French botanist, born 12 Feb 1849 in Aumagne
(Charente-Inférieure), Prof., Faculty of Medicine and Pharmacy, Bordeaux, Dr. ès-sciences
naturelles 1878 Paris, collected fungi in s.w. France 1883-1884, died 18 Nov 1923 in Saintes
(Charente-Maritime). (<em>Guillaud</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 98 (as "Alexander"); BL 2: 111, 663; BM 2:
750; CSP 10: 85, 15: 522; DBF 17: 136; Kelly p. 94; Kew 2: 528; LS 10.572; Morren ed. 2:
19 (in Montpellier), ed. 10: 60 (in Bordeaux); Rehder 5(index): 350 (as "A.-J. Guillaud");
Tucker 1: 306-307.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Charpin, A. &amp; G.G. Aymonin, 2003. J. Bot. Soc. Bot. France 21: 80.
Charpin, A. &amp; J. Timbal, 2007. Acta Bot. Gallica 154: 454. (as "Alexandre")
Davy de Virville, A., 1954. Hist. bot. France: 137, 264.
Dörfler, I., 1896. Botaniker-Adressbuch: 60 (as "Alex."); 1902. Id., ed. 2: 77 (as "Alexan-
	dre"); 1909. Id., ed. 3: 112. (as "Alexandre")
[Engelmann, W.], 1891. Botanisches Adressbuch: 85. (as "Dr. A.")
Maire, A., 1892. Cat. Thèses Sciences soutenues en France de 1810 à 1890: 81.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: Founded and published in the short-lived <em>Journal d'Histoire Naturelle
de Bordeaux et du Sud-Ouest</em> (1882-1888).

*Guillaumin, André [Louis Joseph Edmond Armand] (1885-1974), French botanist

PAGE: 448
HEADING: GUILLAUMIN

and explorer, born 21 Jun 1885 in Arrou (Eure-et-Loir), Lic. ès-sciences 1906, "prepara-
teur", Lab. de Phanérogamie, Muséum natl. d'Histoire naturelle, Paris 1909 (under Henri
Lecomte), Dr. ès-sciences 1910 Paris, sub-dir. 1927-1950 and prof. 1932-1956, Lab. de
Culture (i.e. horticulture), Muséum natl. d'Histoire naturelle, Paris, President, Société
Botanique de France 1935, retired Oct 1956, died 24 Mai 1974 in Athis-Mons (Essonne).
(<em>Guillaumin</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: P (orig.), duplicates A, US, Z.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 247; Barnhart 2: 98; BFM p. 287 (index); BL 1:
115, 118-119, 125, 299, 2: 103, 663; BM 6: 418; Bossert p. 155; DBF 17: 198-199; Frank
3(Anh.): 39; Frodin ed. 2: 1029 (index); GR p. 325; Hirsch p. 107; Hortus 3: 1194; IF
suppl. 4: 322, 355; IH 2: 244; Kew 2: 528-529; Langman p. 341; MW p. 147-148, suppl.
p. 81; Plesch p. 245-246; Portr. 1: 64 (index), 3: 513; TL-2/1: 1021, indices 2/4, 2/5, 2/7,
Suppl. 2, 5; Tucker 1: 307, 3: 128; Zander ed. 10: 665-666, ed. 11: 758, ed. 17: 951.

<sm>OUTSIDE OUR PERIOD</sm>: (1) <em>Les plantes cultivées</em> ... 1946.
(2) <em>Flore analytique</em> et <em>synoptique</em> de la <em>Nouvelle-Calédonie</em>; phanérogames ... 1948.
(3) <em>Les plantes sauvages</em>: biologie et utilisation ... 1948.

graphics ... 1949; Id. (English transl.) ... <em>Cacti</em> ... 1952.
(5) Co-author with Fernand &amp; Claude Moreau, <em>La vie des plantes</em> ... 1955.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) Co-editor for botany with H. Schinz of F. Sarasin &amp; J. Roux, <em>Nova
Caledonia, Bot</em>. ... 1914-1921 [i.e. 1922] (TL-2/5, nr. 10.288).
(2) Edited <em>Cactac. utiles Mex.</em> ... 1928 (TL-2/Suppl. 5, nr. 30.678), which was posthu-
mously published by L. Diguet.
(3) Co-author with L. Blaringhem et al., <em>Hybrides sexuels et mosaïques</em> ... 1937 (TL-2/
Suppl. 2, nr. 21.510).

*Guillemin, [Jean Baptiste] Antoine (1796-1842), French botanist and traveler, born 20 Jan
1796 in Pouilly-sur-Saône (Côtes-d'Or), apprenticed to a pharmacy in Dijon 1812, moved to
Geneva 1814 where he studied under Jean Pierre Vaucher and then A.P. de Candolle, moved to
Paris 1820 where eventually he succeeded Achille Richard as curator of Benjamin Delessert's
herb. and library 1827-1842, simultaneously "aide-préparateur" 1827 and "aide naturaliste"

PAGE: 453
HEADING: GUILLEMIN

to the botany chair (succeeding Adolphe T. Brongniart) 1834, Muséum natl. d'Histoire na-
turelle, Paris, Dr. en médecine 1832 Paris, sent on a government sponsored mission to Brazil
1838-1839, died 13 [15?] Jan 1842 shortly after moving to Montpellier. (<em>Guillem</em>.).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Guillemin and Joseph-Henri Leveillé (1796-1870) jointly are credited with coining
the term "baside" (i.e. basidium) for the spore-bearing structure in Basidiomycetes.

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: The first set of Guillemin's own Brazilian collections is at MJSD
(not DI, as stated in TL-2/1) with the rest of his herb. His types are mainly at P, but also in
G (G-DC and Delessert Herb.); some duplicate material also is found in DBN, DS, E-GL
and K. – Corr. with A.P. de Candolle in G (Archives).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 247; Backer p. 651; Baillon 2: 754; Barnhart 2: 98;
BL 1: 53, 128, 299; BM 2: 751, 6: 418; BN p. 175; Bossert p. 155; CSP 3: 80, 6: 679; DBF
17: 220; GFB ed. 2: 97; GR p. 281; GR cat. p. 64; Herder p. 453 (index); Hortus 3: 1194;
IF p. 700, IF suppl. 4: 355; IH 2: 244; Jackson p. 554 (index); Kelly p. 96; Kew 2: 529-530;
Kew List p. 28; Lasègue p. 570 (index) (d. "15 Jan"); LS 4140, 10.576; Moebius p. 233; NI
2: 73; NI suppl. p. 36; Portr. 3: 514; PR ed. 1: 3973-3978, ed. 2: 3645-3650; Rehder 5(in-
dex): 351; RS p. 86; TL-1: 518 (index); TL-2/1: 1021-1023, indices 2/1, 2/3, 2/4; Tucker 1:
307; Urban-Berl. p. 351; Zander ed. 11: 758, ed. 17: 951.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Flora 25: 256. 1842.
Candolle, A.L., 1880. Phytographie: 417.
Candolle, A.P., 1862. Mémoires et Souvenirs: 143, 332-334.
Davy de Virville, A., 1954. Hist. bot. France: 222, 345, 350, 351, 367, 372.
Dayrat, B., 2003. Botanistes fl. France: 649. (index)
Hedge, I.C. &amp; J.M. Lamond (eds.), 1970. Index collectors Edinburgh Herb.: 86.
Hepper, N. &amp; F. Neate, 1971. Pl. collectors W. Afr.: 34.
Jaussaud, Ph. &amp; Éd. Brygoo, 2004. Du Jardin au Muséum en 516 biographies: 271-272. (as
	"Jacques, Antoine")
Lasègue, A., 1842. Ann. Sci. Nat., Bot., sér. 2, 17: 287-296. (bibl., handwr., portr.) [reprint,
	repaginated, p. [1]-14, [i]. <em>Copies</em>: HH, K]
Lasègue, A., 1842. London J. Bot. 1: 411-418. (d. "15 Jan")
Maiden, J.H., 1910. J. &amp; Proc. Roy. Soc. New South Wales 44: 150-151.

Pritzel, G., 1847. Linnaea 19: 454. (d. "15 Jan"; also said to be "Antoine" not "J.B.A.")
Urban, I., 1906. <em>In</em>, C. Martius, Fl. Bras. 1(1): 30-31. (itin.)
Wittrock, V.B., 1903. Acta Horti Berg. 3(2): 113; 1905. Id. 3(3): 103.

HEADING: GUILLEMIN

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) The entry for A. Delile, <em>Joliffia africana</em> ... 1827 (TL-2/Suppl. 5,
nr. 29.632) can be corrected to indicate that Guillemin contributed a "<em>Note supplémentaire</em>
à la description du <em>Joliffia Africana</em> ...", which comprises p. 7-10 of the reprint (and p.
[320]-323 of the serial) and which was previously attributed solely to Delile and also that
it was Guillemin's (not Delile's) article that was signed 10 Jul 1827.
(2) Editor, <em>Bulletin des sciences naturelles et de géologie</em> ... vol. 5 (1825) and vols. 16-27
(1829-1831).
(3) Co-author with Alphonse Chevallier (1793-1879) and Achille Richard (1794-1852) of
vols. 3-5 of the 5 vol. <em>Dictionnaire des drogues simples et composées</em> ... 1827-1829 by
Chevallier &amp; Richard.
(4) Contributed a "Table alphabétique et explicative des plantes ..." (p. [1]-17) to the last
part of P.J. Redouté, <em>Choix plus belles fleurs</em> ... 1833 (see TL-2/4, nr. 8750, where other
editions with text by Guillemin also are noted).
(5) Prepared texts signed "J.A.G." <em>in</em> A.P. de Candolle, <em>Pl. hist. succ.</em> ... 1798-1837 (TL-2/1,
nr. 983, the entire work being "... one of the nightmares of botanical bibliography").
(6) Contributed to C.H.D. d'Orbigny, <em>Dict. univ. hist. nat.</em> ... 1841-1849 (TL-2/3, nr.
	7096).

HEADING: GUILLIERMOND

37.474. <em>Rapport</em> de M. <em>Guillemin</em>, D.-M., aide de Botanique au Muséum d'Histoire Natu-
relle, à M. le Ministre de l'Agriculture et du Commerce. Sur sa <em>mission au Brésil</em>, ayant
pour objet principal des <em>recherches</em> sur les <em>cultures</em> et la <em>préparation du thé</em>, et le transport
de cet arbuste en France ... [Paris] (Imprimerie de Maulde et Renou) 1839. Oct. (<em>Rapport
Brésil thé</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1839, p. [1]-38. <em>Copies</em>: G, HH (n.v.), K, MO (n.v.).
<em>Note</em>: (1) Footnote at end of title: "Inséré dans la Revue agricole, 16e livraison". (2) This
	report (and the materials brought back from Brazil) led to the award of the Légion
	d'Honneur to Guillemin; the report also was abridged and transl. by W.J. Hooker (see
	J. Bot. (Hooker) 3: 1-16. Oct 1840).

Guilliermond, [Marie Antoine] Alexandre (1876-1945), French mycologist (specializing
in yeasts) and cytologist, born 19 Aug 1876 in Lyon, doctorate 1902 Lyon, Faculty of Sci-
ences, Lyon, then from 1921 in Paris where he became prof., Faculty of Sciences at the
Sorbonne, Académie des Sciences 1935, president, Société Botanique de France, died 1 Apr
1945 in Lyon. (<em>Guillierm</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Académie p. 229; Ainsworth p. 213, 325; Ainsworth &amp;
Bisby's Dict. p. 219; APN p. 247; Barnhart 2: 99; Biol.-Dokum. 7: 88.514-88.525; CSP 15:
526; DBF 17: 245; DSB 5: 584-585; Hawksworth p. 183; Hirsch p. 107; Kelly p. 96-97; Kew
2: 530; LS 10.582-10.606, 33.923-33.940; LS suppl. 10.253-10.308; Moebius p. 450 (index);
Nordstedt suppl. p. 7; Portr. 3: 514; Tucker 3: 128.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Intl. address book botanists: 109. 1931; Chron. Bot. 2: 128. 1936 (portr.);
	Rev. Cytol. Cytophysiol. Vég. 9: 5-47. 1946-1947. (bibl., portr.)
Charpin, A. &amp; J. Timbal, 2007. Acta Bot. Gallica 154: 455.

	(Impr. éditeur A. Rey): x, 107 p. Qu. (n.v.); 1928. Id. ... (1900-1928) de M. Alexandre

	1928 à 1934), Paris (impr. Jouve): 96 p. Qu. (n.v.)

Guinet, [Jean Étienne] Auguste (1846-1928), Swiss businessman and botanist, born 23
Mai 1846 in Carouge (Geneva), he botanized during his free time and became a member
of the Bot. Soc. Geneva in 1877 (when founded), built a considerable herb. that was incor-
porated into the Delessert Herb., after 1879 he began microscope studies of cryptogams,
particularly lich., then mosses and hepatics, from 1908 asst. curator of mosses at Geneva
(under J.I. Briquet), retired 1925, died 3 Aug 1928 in Geneva. (<em>Guinet</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: G (European Herb.), BR, DBN, GB, MPU, PC (France).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 248; Barnhart 2: 99; Briquet p. 245-248; CSP 15:
529; GR p. 325; IH 2: 245; LS 10.619; Morren ed. 10: 110; Portr. 1: 64 (index), 3: 514;
Tucker 1: 307.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Briquet, J., 1929. Candollea 3: 481-489. (bibl., portr.)
Burgisser, L. &amp; M.J. Price, 2005. Candollea 60: 513-562.
Dörfler, I., 1896. Botaniker-Adressbuch: 144; 1902. Id., ed. 2: 195; 1909. Id., ed. 3: 276.
[Engelmann, W.], 1891. Botanisches Adressbuch: 53.
Nelson, E.C., 1980. Glasra 4: 48. (specimens at DBN)
Sayre, G., 1977. Bryologist 80: 509.

PAGE: 457
HEADING: GUINIER

Guinier, [Marie Joseph Jean Baptiste] Philibert ('la bique' to his students) (1876-1962),
French forester, ecologist and administrator, born 21 Jun 1876 in Grenoble, studied
at the National Inst. of Agronomy 1895-1897, then at the École Nationale des Eaux et
Forêts, Nancy 1897-1899, asst., forestry research station 1901, instructor of forest botany
1904-1921 and dir. 1921-1941, all at the École Nationale des Eaux et Forêts, retired 1941,

PAGE: 458
HEADING: GUINIER

Académie d'agriculture de France 1936, president, Société Botanique de France 1946, Lé-
gion d'honneur 1948, Académie des Sciences 1953, died 3 Apr 1962 in Paris. (<em>Guinier</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: P, duplicates in "Nancy (Chaire de Botanique et Écologie forestiè-
res de l'actuelle E.N.G.R.E.F.)".

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Académie p. 229; APN p. 248; Barnhart 2: 99; BL 2: 103,
142, 663; Bossert p. 155; DBF 17: 296-297; Kelly p. 97; Kew 2: 531; LS 33.948-33.951; LS
suppl. 10.313-10.315; Portr. 1: 64 (index), 3: 514; Tucker 1: 307, 775; Zander ed. 17: 951.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Intl. address book botanists: 138. 1931; Jubilé de M. Guinier, 24 juin 1950,
	Nancy (École nationale des eaux et forêts): 47 p. 1950 [i.e. 1951]. (bibl.) (n.v.)
Aymonin, G.G. et al., 1987. Bull. Soc. Bot. France, Lett. Bot. 134: 39-50. (herb.)
Charpin, A. &amp; G.G. Aymonin, 1999. J. Bot. Soc. Bot. France 10: 76. (index)
Charpin, A. &amp; G.G. Aymonin, 2003. J. Bot. Soc. Bot. France 21: 81.
Charpin, A. &amp; J. Timbal, 2007. Acta Bot. Gallica 154: 455.
Dörfler, I., 1909. Botaniker-Adressbuch, ed. 3: 112.

HEADING: GUINOCHET

<em>Note</em>: (1) This was projected to include 28 fascicles (=Séries) with 900 pages of text and 280
	plates, but as of 1912 only 9 fascicles were published and distributed (320 pages, 93 plates
	of which 45 were in color). (2) There is indirect evidence that additional fascicules were
	issued in 1913 but we have not seen them. A notice of this same title by Guinier appeared in
	Bot. Centralbl. 124(14): 219. 14 Oct 1913. It states "Paris, 1913. 8o. Fasc. 2 et 3. 20 pl. (10
	col) avec 20 pp. texte", these details not agreeing with Série 2 and 3 in the 1912 edition.

	Louis Mangin ... Paris (see TL-2/3: 276).
