Guinochet, [Jean-Étienne] Marcel (1909-1997), French phycologist and botanist with in-
terests and influence in phytosociology and biosystematics, born 21 Dec 1909 in Lyon,
Lic. ès-sciences naturelles 1931, asst.-"préparateur", Centre de Recherches Agronomiques
de Provence (Villa Thuret) in Antibes (Alpes-Maritimes), Dr. ès-sciences 1938 Grenoble,
taught in Montpellier 1939-1943, during and after W.W-II held a number of university
positions in quick succession, incl. Besançon 1943-1945, Nancy 1945-1946 and Stras-
bourg 1946, succeeded René Maire as prof., Faculty of Sciences, Univ. of Alger, Alge-
ria 1950-1957, returned to France and joined the Faculty of Sciences, Paris (Orsay) from
1958 until retirement in 1977, president, Société Botanique de France, died 22 Aug 1997
in Fayence (Var). (<em>Guin</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: JBVN, VIL.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 248; Barnhart 2: 99; Bossert p. 155; Frodin ed. 2:
593; Kew 2: 531-532; Portr. 3: 514; TL-2/6: 898 (index); Zander ed. 17: 951.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Intl. address book botanists: 109. 1931.
Blaise, S., 1999. J. Bot. Soc. Bot. France 11: 83-88. (bibl., portr.) (n.v.)
Cavillier, [Frère], 1941. Boissiera 5: 51-52.
Charpin, A. &amp; G.G. Aymonin, 2003. J. Bot. Soc. Bot. France 21: 81.
Charpin, A. &amp; J. Timbal, 2007. Acta Bot. Gallica 154: 455.
Gorenflot, R., 2000. Rev. Cytol. Biol. Veg. Bot. 23: 3-11. (portrs.) (n.v.)
Lacoste, A., 1999. Acta Bot. Gallica 146: 179-184. (portr.)

<sm>OUTSIDE OUR PERIOD</sm>: (1) Supervised the posthumous publication of the first vols. of
R. Maire, <em>Fl. Afrique du Nord</em> ... 1952-[1987], see TL-2/3: 257-260.
(2) Co-author with R. de Vilmorin, <em>Fl. France</em> ... 1973-1984, 5 vols.; see also TL-2/6:
747-748.

	to be cited from Rev. Gén. Bot. 51(610): 600-614. Oct 1939; (611): 671-688. Nov 1939;
	(612): 723-747. Dec 1939; 52(613): 18-39. Jan 1940.

Guppy, Henry Brougham (1854-1926), English geologist interested in isls. and seed and
plant dispersal by water, born 23 Dec 1854 in Falmouth (Cornwall), educated at King's
School, Sherborne, Queen's College, Birmingham, Medical School of St. Bartholomew's
Hospital, M.B. 1876 and C.M., Edinburgh Univ., surgeon in Royal Navy 1876-1885, served
on the China Station 1877-1880 and on the Australian Station 1881-1884, F.R.S.E. 1888,
F.L.S. (Gold Medal) and F.R.S. 1918, died 23 Apr 1926 on board <em>El Kantara</em> in Martinique
(remains interred at Seaton). (<em>Guppy</em>).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Not to be confused with Henry Guppy (1861-1948), librarian of the John Rylands
Library, Manchester.

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BM (chiefly ferns), BO, K, MEL. – Corr. at BM, K and Univ. of
Edinburgh; mss. also at BM.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 247; Barnhart 2: 101; BB p. 134; BL 1: 95, 115,

PAGE: 462
HEADING: GUPPY

124, 299; BM 2: 753, 6: 418-419; CSP 10: 94, 15: 537; Desmond p. 276, ed. 2: 305; IH 2:
245; Kew List p. 28; Lenley p. 191; Plesch p. 246; Rehder 5(index): 352; SK 1: 205-206, 5:
cclxxxii; TL-2/7: 634 (index); Tucker 1: 308, 3: 129.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Science, ser. 2, 63: 543. 1926; Bot. Soc. &amp; Exch. Club Brit. Isl. 8: 92-93.

*Gussone, Giovanni (1787-1866), Italian botanist, born 18 Feb 1787 in Villamina (Avel-
lino), studied medicine, Univ. of Naples 1811, began collaborating with Michele Tenore in
1810 while still a student, dir., botanical gardens in Boccadifalco nr. Palermo and Caserta
nr. Naples, succeeded Tenore as dir., botanical gardens in Naples 1861, died 14 Jan 1866
in Naples. (<em>Guss</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Mainly at NAP (14,000 species), partly at FI; other material B,
BM, BP, C, CGE, E, G, G-DC, GOET, K, KIEL, LY, M, MANCH, P, TC, W. The part
of the K.P.J. Sprengel herb. that was acquired by B in 1890 contained material from Gus-
sone.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 2(l): 462, 6(2): 936; APN p. 250; Backer p. 247; Bail-
lon 2: 757; Barnhart 2: 101; BL 2: 347, 391, 663; BM 2: 754; Bossert p. 156; CSP 3: 94;
DBI 61: 575-578 (d. "8 Feb"); Ewan Pap. p. 85; Frank 3(Anh.): 39; GFB ed. 2: 97; GR p.
532; Herder p. 454 (index); Hist. Coll. BMNH p. 152; Hortus 3: 1194; IF p. 700; IF suppl.
4: 355; IH 2: 246; Jackson: 554 (index); Kew 2: 536; Kew List p. 28; Lasègue: 570 (index);
NI 2: 73; Plesch p. 246-247; Portr. 3: 517; PR ed. 1: 3987-3995, ed. 2: 3658-3663; Rehder
5(index): 353; RS p. 86; Saccardo 1: 87; SO p. 26 (index); Sotheby 1: 250-251; Strid p. 143,
ed. 2: 197; TL-1: 188; TL-2/1: 1025, indices 2/5, Suppl. 3; Tucker 1: 146, 308; Urban-Berl.
p. 351; Wagenitz p. 67; Zander ed. 10: 666, ed. 11: 758, ed. 17: 951.

HEADING: GUSSONE

*Guşuleac, Mihail [Michail] (1887-1960), Ukrainian (Soviet) morphologist and botanist,
born 12 Oct 1887 in Csernovic (then Austro-Hungarian Empire, now Chernivtsi, Ukraine),
graduated 1911 and awarded doctorate 1917, both Franz-Josefs Universität (later Univer-
sitatea Regele Carol I din Cernăuţi), Dir., Univ. of Cernăuţi Botanic Garden 1919 (from
1918-1940 Cernăuţi (Chernivtsi) was part of the Kingdom of Romania), died 11 Sep 1960
in Chernivtsi, Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic. (<em>Guşuleac</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: B, BUC, C, CHER, GH, W.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 250; Barnhart 2: 102; BFM p. 287 (index); Biol.-
Dokum. 7: 88.826-88.830; Hirsch p. 108; IH 2: 246; Kew 2: 537; MW p. 148; Portr. 3:
517; Strid p. 144, ed. 2: 197; TL-2/1: 1026, 2/6: 898 (index, as "Guşileac" but Guşuleac
in text).

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Intl. address book botanists: 301. 1931; Natura (Rumania) 30(1): 41-43.
	1979. (portr.)

Gutner, Lidia Solomonovna (1903-1942), Russian mycologist, born 13 Jun 1903 in Mogi-
lev oblast, Belarus, graduated 1925 Leningrad State Univ., trainee and lab. assist. 1925-
1930, Leningrad Agricultural Inst., lab. assist. and ultimately assist. dir. 1930-1932, 1935-
1942, Lab. of Systematics, All-Union Inst. of Plant Protection, plant pathologist 1933-1934,
All-Union State Association of Pest Control &amp; Agricultural Diseases, died 4 Feb 1942 in
Kotlas, U.S.S.R. (now Russia). (<em>Gutner</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: LE?

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 250; Kew 2: 538; Lipschitz 3: 96; LS suppl.
10.382-10.383.

<sm>OUTSIDE OUR PERIOD</sm>: <em>Golovnevye griby</em> (po materialam A.A. Iachevskogo) [=The <em>smut-
fungi</em> [of the U.S.S.R.] (after the materials of the late A.A. Iachevskogo)], Moskva (Ogiz.
Selkhozgiz) ... 383 p. 1941.

<em>Publ</em>.: 1935, p. 411-484. <em>Copies</em>: FH, USDA-Mycol. (copy rec'd. 20 Nov 1935). – Re-

Gutwiński [Gutwinski], Roman (1860-1932), Polish phycologist, born 4 Jun 1860 in
Pagorzyne (Gorlice District), studied at Jaslo College 1871-1878 and then Krakow Univ.
1878-1882, assisted J.T. Rostafińsky until 1885, taught at various secondary schools incl.
schools in Podgorze nr. Krakow 1892-1900 and finally Krakow 1900-1924, where he died
27 Oct 1932. (<em>Gutw</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: KRA ?, KRAM ?

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 250; Barnhart 2: 103; Bossert p. 157; CSP 15:
543-544; De Toni 1: lvii, 4: xxv-xxvi; LS 10.646; Morren ed. 10: 35; MW p. 148; Nordstedt
p. 16-17; Nordstedt suppl. p. 7-8; Portr. 3: 518; TL-2/Suppl. 6: 515 (index).

	3: 216.

Guyot, Alain Lucien (1901-1987), French mycologist, prof. of botany and phytopathol-
ogy, École Nationale Supérieure d'Agriculture de Grignon (Seine-et-Oise), and from 1932
dir. of the Jardin Botanique there, studied rust fungi of s. France and n. Africa (Morocco,
Tunisia). (<em>A.L. Guyot</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Some rust fungi at BPI.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 250; BL 2: 123, 663; Kew 2: 538; LS suppl.
10.385-10.415; MW suppl. p. 82; Plesch p. 247.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Charpin, A. &amp; J. Timbal, 2007. Acta Bot. Gallica 154: 455. (as "Guyot, Lucien")

<sm>OUTSIDE OUR PERIOD</sm>: (1) <em>Origine des plantes cultivées</em>, ... Paris (Presses universitaires de
France) 1942; Ed. 2, ... (© 1948) 1949; Ed. 3, ... 1964.
(2) <em>Catalogue raisonné des micromycètes de Tunisie</em> ... 1952.
(3) A.L. Guyot &amp; Georges Jean Louis Malençon, <em>Urédinées du Maroc</em>, Trav. Inst. Sci. Chérifien,
Sér. Bot., 11: [i]-v, 1-184, <em>pl. 1-4.</em> 17 Mai 1957; Id., 28: [i]-vii, [1]-161, <em>pl. 1-5.</em> 12 Jun 1963.
(4) <em>Histoire des plantes cultivées</em> ... Paris (A. Colin) 1963.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: Edited the serial <em>Uredineana, recueil d'études systématiques et bi-
ologiques sur les urédinées du globe</em>, vols. 1-6, (1938-1967) (also numbered separately in
the series Encyclopédie mycologique).

PAGE: 469
HEADING: GUYOT

37.536. <em>Les Urédinées</em> (ou rouilles des végétaux). Étude morphologique et biologique des
champignons de ce groupe, qui vivent en Europe, Asie occidentale, Afrique septentrionale,
et révision des espèces connues dans les autres parties du monde ... Tome 1. Genre <em>Uromy-
ces</em>. a) espèces parasites des plantes appartenant aux familles des Graminées, Cyperacées,
Juncacées, Renonculacées, Polygonacées, Ombelliféres, Campanulacées ... Paris (VIe)
(Paul Lechevalier, ...) 1938-1957. Oct. (<em>Urédinées, Uromyces</em>).

<em>1</em>: Feb-Mar 1939 (t.p. dated 1938, p. 3 pref. dated 25 Feb 1838, p. [440] printing finished
	25 Feb 1939, insert dated Feb 1939), p. [i-iii], [1]-438, [439-440], insert between p.
	[iii] and 1 (i.e. "corrections, additions et observations"). [<em>Note</em>: as announced, the cor-
	rections, additions and observations appear in Uredineana 1: 161-177. 1939]. <em>Copies</em>:
	BM (n.v.), HH (n.v.), K (n.v.), LC (n.v.), NY, U, USDA. – In series, Encyclopédie
	mycologique 8.
<em>2</em>: Jun 1951 (p. [332], printing finished 1 Jun 1951), Genre <em>Uromyces</em>. (b) espèces parasites
	des plantes appartenant aux familles des Liliacées, Amaryllidacées, Iridacées, Chénopo-
	diacées, Plombaginées, Composées, Rosacées, Géraniacées, Primulacées, Scrophula-
	riacées, Valérianacées, ... p. [1]-331, [332, colophon]. <em>Copies</em>: HH (n.v.), K (n.v.), LC
	(n.v.), NY, U. – In series, Encyclopédie mycologique 15.
<em>3</em>: Apr 1957 (p. [648], printing finished 4 Apr 1957), Genre <em>Uromyces</em>. (c) espèces parasites
	des plantes appartenant à la famille des legumineuses ... p. [1]-647, [648]. <em>Copies</em>: BM
	(n.v.), HH (n.v.), K (n.v.), LC (n.v.), NY. – In series, Encyclopédie mycologique 29.
<em>Note</em>: (1) Vols. 1-5 of the serial <em>Uredineana</em> include "Corrections, additions et observations"
	to <em>Les Urédinées</em> ... (1938-1957). (2) The monograph (3 vols.) and the serial (6 vols.) are
	confused because both also are numbered in the Encyclopédie mycologique series.

Guyot, Arnaud [Arnold] Henri [Henry] (1807-1884), Swiss-born American geographer,
paleontologist, meteorologist and naturalist, born 28 Sep 1807 in Boudevilliers nr. Neuchâ-
tel, attended Neuchâtel Univ. where he was a classmate of Leo Lesquereaux, Ph.D. Berlin
1835, went to America at instigation of Louis Agassiz in 1848 and became prof. of geology
and geography, Princeton Univ., Princeton, New Jersey 1854-1884, L.L.D., died 8 Feb 1884
in Princeton. (<em>A.H. Guyot</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: NY (ex Princeton Univ.). – Mss. materials held by the Amer.
Philos. Soc. (Arnold Guyot Collection, 1857-1882) and the Historical Society of Princeton
(Papers 1836-1888).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 103; BM 2: 755; CSP 3: 98, 6: 679, 7: 878,
10: 99, 15: 547; DSB 5: 599-600; Ewan ed. 1: 220-221, ed. 2: 92; Ewan Pap. p. 85; IH 2:
246; Lenley p. 458; ME 1: 190, 3: 587 (index); Quenstedt p. 179; Sarjeant p. 1167, Suppl.
1: 463-464; Tucker 1: 308, 3: 129.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Proc. Amer. Acad. Arts. 19: 522-526. 1884; Science 3(55): 218-220. 1884.
	(portr.); Trans. New York Acad. Sci. 3: 66-69. 1886. (n.v.); Exercises at the unveiling of
	a memorial tablet to Arnold Guyot, Ph.D., LL.D., in Marquand Chapel, Princeton, N.J.
	... (C.S. Robinson and Co.): 16 p. 1890. (n.v.)
Dana, J.D., 1886. Biogr. Mem. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 2: 309-348. (bibl.) [reprinted Rep.
	(Annual) Board Regents Smithsonian Inst. 1887, pt. 1, p. 693-722. 1889]
Faure, C., 1884. Vie et travaux d'Arnold Guyot. Le Globe (Société de Géographie de Ge-
	nève) 23: 3-72. (n.v.)
Favre, L., 1884. La Suisse Libérale [newspaper?] [article nécrologique]
Favre, L., 1885. Musée Neuchâtelois: 7-31, 33-41, 65-75. (n.v.)
Ferrell, E.H., 1981. Geographers Biobibl. Stud. 5: 63-71. (portr.) (n.v.)
Jones, L.C., 1929. Arnold Guyot et Princeton, Neuchâtel (Secrétariat de l'université): 125
	p. (bibl.) (n.v.)
Libbey, W., Jr., 1884. J. Amer. Geogr. Soc. 16: 194-221.

PAGE: 470
HEADING: GUYOT

Raymond-Le Brun, G., 1885. Jahrb. Geogr. Ges. Bern 7: 1-21. (n.v.)
Scott, W.B., 1884. Pop. Sci. Monthly 25: 261-265. (portr.)
Youmans, W.J., 1896. Pioneers Sci. America: 493-499. (portr.)

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: The term "guyot", used in geology, is named for him, as are at least three moun-
tains in the U.S.A., a glacier in Alaska and a crater on the earth's moon.

Guyot, Henry (1891-1950), Swiss pharmaceutical researcher and botanist with a keen in-
terest in floristic botany and geology, born 26 Mai 1891 in Saint Imier (Ct. Berne), studied
at the Collège de Porrentruy, passed his pharmacy examination 1915, Dr. ès-sciences na-
turelles 1917 Univ. of Geneva, taught school nr. Geneva 1918-1921, asst. to R.-H. Chodat
1918-1922, employed as a research scientist at Hoffmann-La Roche (pharmaceutical firm),
Basel 1922-1950, died 12 Apr 1950 nr. Montreux. (<em>H. Guyot</em>).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Guyot's first wife, Marie Chirtoiu (1892-1937), was born in Romania and she stud-
ied, as did her husband, under R.-H. Chodat at the Univ. of Geneva (see TL-2/Suppl. 4:
111).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Switzerland, Italy, Turkey, Egypt, etc.: BAS (orig.).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 2: 103 (as "Henri"); BL 2: 382, 663; Hirsch p.
108; Kew 2: 538; TL-2/Suppl. 4: 609 (index).

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Intl. address book botanists: 329. 1971. (as "Henri")
Fuchs, H.P., 1991. Bull. Murith. Soc. Valais. Sci. Nat. 109: 152-153.
Thommen, Ed., 1940. Bull. Soc. Bot. Genève, sér. 2, 30: [266]. 1937-1938. (d. of Mme.
	Guyot-Chirtoiu)
Vischer, W., 1950. Actes Soc. Helv. Sci. Nat. 130: 405-409. (bibl., portr.)
Vischer, W., 1952. Bull. Soc. Bot. Genève, sér. 2, 42-43: v-vii.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: One of several co-authors with R.-H. Chodat, <em>Jardin alpin Linnaea</em> ...
1915 (TL-2/Suppl. 4, nr. 26.064).

Gwynne-Vaughan, Helen Charlotte Isabelle (Dame) (née Fraser) (1879-1967), English
cytologist and mycologist, born 21 Jan 1879 in London, B.Sc. 1904 and D.Sc. 1907 Univ. of
London, lecturer in botany, Royal Holloway College, head, Dept. of Botany 1909-1917 and
Prof. of Botany 1921-1939, 1941-1944, Birbeck College (Univ. of London), Queen Mary's
Army Auxiliary Corps (W.W.-I) in France 1917, president British Mycological Society
1928, Commandant Women's Royal Air Force (W.W.-II) 1939-1941, on 7 Dec 1911 mar-
ried David Thomas Gwynne-Vaughan (1871-1915), also a botanist, and generally thereafter
published under her married surname, C.B.E. 1918, D.B.E. 1919, Linnean Society Medal
1920, died 26 Aug 1967. (<em>H.C.I. Gwynne-Vaughan</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown. – Corr. in Glasgow Univ. Archives (Frederick Orpen
Bower papers).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Ainsworth p. 273, 301, 327 (as "Gwynne-Vaughan");
Barnhart 2: 4, 104 (as "Gwynne-Vaughan"); Desmond p. 237 (as "Fraser"), p. 277 (as
"Gwynne-Vaughan"), ed. 2: 306 (as "Gwynne-Vaughan"); DNB 56: 167-169. 2004 (as
"Vaughan"); Hirsch p. 108; Kelly p. 84 (as "Fraser"), 97 (as "Gwynne-Vaughn"); Kew 2:
539-540; LS 3034-3036, 33.406-33.414 (as "Fraser"); LS suppl. 8802, 10.419-10.423 (as
"Gwynne-Vaughan"); Portr. 1: 64 (index), 3: 518 (as "Gwynne-Vaughan"); TL-2/Suppl.
1: 448 (index).

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Intl. address book botanists: 184. 1931; The Times (London) [newspaper]:
	22 Jan 1962 (portr.), Id.: 30 Aug 1967 (portr.).
Carlile, M.J., 2005. Mycologist 19: 129-131. (n.v.)
Dörfler, I., 1909. Botaniker-Adressbuch, ed. 3: 156. (as "Fraser, Miss Helen Charlotte Isa-
	bella")
Izzard, M., 1969. A heroine in her time: a life of Dame Helen Gwynne-Vaughan, 1879-1967,
	London (Macmillan)/New York (St. Martins Press): 368 p., <em>8 pl</em>. (n.v.)

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: Senior author of <em>Struct. Develop. fungi</em> ... 1927 (TL-2/Suppl. 1, nr.
20.227), treated earlier under B.F. Barnes, her co-author.

<em>Co-author</em>: Williamson, H.S. (fl. 1920s).
<em>Publ</em>.: Apr 1931, p. 355-371, <em>pl. 12-14. Copies</em>: HH (n.v.), NY, USDA-Mycol. – Reprinted
	and to be cited from Ann. Bot. (Oxford) 45(178): 355-371, <em>pl. 12-14.</em> 1931.

*Gyelnik, Vilmos (Wilhelm) (1906-1945), Hungarian lichenologist, born 30 Mar 1906 in
Budapest, studied botany, Univ. of Pázmány Péter, Budapest 1924-1928, asst., Dept. of Bot-
any, Veterinary College, researcher, Seed Research Station 1928 and visited Agricultural
Museum, Cairo, Egypt for eight months, Dr. Phil. 1929 Budapest, "Privatdozent" 1930,
curator, Natural History Museum, Budapest 1930, asst. lecturer, Univ. of Debrecen 1934,
visited Finland to work with E.A. Vainio, died (along with his family) 15 Mar 1945 in an
air-raid at the Amstetten, Austria, railroad station. (<em>Gyeln</em>.).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: In 1934, Gyelnik changed his surname to Köfaragó-Gyelnik.

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BP, addititonal material H (lich.), HAL, M. – <em>Exsiccatae</em>: (1)
Gyelnik, ... <em>Lichenotheca</em> ... ([Budapest], Fasc. 1, nrs. 1-20. 1933; Fasc. 2, nrs. 21-40. 1
Mai 1935; Fasc. 3, nrs. 41-60. 1 Jun 1935; Fasc. 4, nrs. 61-80. 1 Jul 1935; Fasc. 5-10, nrs.
91-200. 1937): FH. <em>Note</em>: There is a [39] p. Schedae ... at FH (Fascs. 2-10); and 3 separate
[4] p. Schedae for Fasc. 2-4 at US-Stevenson. (2) Köfaragó-Gyelnik, ... <em>Lichenotheca
parva</em> ... (Budapest, Fasc. 1, nrs. 1-20. 1 Mar 1937; Fasc. 2, nrs. 21-40. 1 Oct 1937): FH,
UPS. <em>Note</em>: There are two [4] p. Schedae ... at FH.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Ainsworth &amp; Bisby's Dict. p. 220; APN p. 251; Barnhart
2: 104; Biol.-Dokum. 7: 89.069-89.081; Bossert (as "Köfargo Gyelnik, Vilmos"); Col-
lander p. 131; GR p. 651-652; GR cat. p. 35-36, 64; Hawksworth p. 183 (as "Gyelnik");
Hirsch p. 108; IH 2: 376 (as "Kofarago-Gyelnik"); Kew 3: 289 (as "Köfaragó-Gyelnik"
in 1939); Kleppa p. 323 (index); LS suppl. 10.424-10.439 (as "Gyelnik, V."); MW p. 148,
suppl. p. 82; SBC p. 121 (as "Gyelnik"); TL-2/1: 1027, index 2/4.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Intl. address book botanists: 219. 1931.
Hillmann, J., 1939. Repert. Spec. Nov. Regni Veg. 46: 132-134.
Kárpáti, Z., 1940. Borbásia Nova 2: 13-14. 1940. (caricature of Köfaragó-Gyelnik)
Kuŝan, F., 1939. Ann. Mycol. 32: 57.
Sayre, G., 1969. Mem. New York Bot. Gard. 19: 137. (exsiccatae)
Sjödin, Å., 1954. Acta Horti Gothob. 19: 113-156. (bibl. [100 publ.], cat. of new names)
Verseghy, K., 1963. Feddes Repert. Spec. Nov. Regni Veg. 68: 113-114.

nr. 8450). <em>Reprint</em>: 1971 ... New York [etc.] (Johnson). <em>Copy</em>: (n.v.).

<em>2</em>: 1937, ... <em>Peltigera nova</em> e <em>Transbaikalia</em>, p. [1, unnumb.]. <em>Copy</em>: FH. – Id. 2: 167. 1937.
<em>Note</em>: (1) Here his name appears as "V. Köfaragó-Gyelnik". (2) Stated to consist of three
	parts, but part 3 not seen nor cataloged in the bibliography by Sjödin (1954).

37.595. <em>Species nova</em> lichenum generis <em>Placidiopsis</em> ex Argentina ... Budapest ... Annales
Musei Nationalis Hungarici ... 1939. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 1939, p. [1, unnumb.]. <em>Copy</em>: FH. – Reprinted and to be cited from Ann. Hist.-Nat.
	Mus. Natl. Hung. 32(Pars Botanica): 62. 1939.
<em>Note</em>: Here his name appears as "V. Köfaragó-Gyelnik".

*Győrffy, István (latter often abbreviated "J.") (1880-1959), Hungarian bryologist, born
19 Dec 1880 in Hidasnémeti, studied in Makó, lived in Löcsén and collected mosses in the
Tatra Mts., habilitation 1913 Franz-Joseph Univ. in Cluj (then Kolozsvár in Hungary, now
Romania) and became prof. there from 1915 until Transylvania became Romanian and the
Univ. moved to Szeged (1919-1940) where he founded a new inst., a botanical garden and
a botanical journal (<em>Folia Cryptogamica</em>), returned to Cluj (Kolozsvár) 1940-1945, after
W.W.-II took refuge in Salzburg, Austria but moved again, died 19 Apr 1959 in Csákvár (or
Székesfehévár?). (<em>Győrffy</em>).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: (1) His wife, Irma Győrffy (née Greisiger) (1882-1947), was also a botanist but pub-
lished outside the period of our concern. (2) With the first name initialed, both Győrffy and
his wife could be confused with the Hungarian ethnologist István Győrffy (1884-1939).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BP, DBN, E, H-BR, K, L, W. – <em>Exsiccatae</em> (with M. Péterfi) widely
distributed (see Rev. Bryol. Lichénol. 31(3-4): 283. 1962, for what happened after 1919;
and TL-2/4: 192). <em>Bryophyta Regni Hungariae Exsiccata</em>, for an index, see: A "Bryophyta
regni Hungariae exsiccata" részére begyűtött és Klozsvárott rekedt fajok jegyzéke, Folia
Crypt. 1: 25-40. 7 Mai 1924. <em>Copy</em>: NY.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: APN p. 251; Barnhart 2: 104; Biol.-Dokum. 89.089-89.095;
BM 6: 420; Bossert p. 157 (as "Istvón"); Collander p. 131; Futak-Domin p. 226-229;
GR p. 658; Hirsch p. 108; IH 2: 247; KR p. 251; Lenley p. 191; LS 33.963; LS suppl.
10.440-10.444; Portr. 3: 518; SBC p. 121; TL-2/1: 1027, indices 2/3, 2/4 (as "Györfy");
Tucker 3: 129; Urban-Berl. p. 301.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Intl. address book botanists: 219. 1931.
Boros, A., 1959. Rev. Bryol. Lichénol. 28: 400-408. (bibl., portr.)
Charpin, A. &amp; J. Timbal, 2007. Acta Bot. Gallica 154: 455. (as "Györffy, Itsvan")
Dörfler, I., 1909. Botaniker-Adressbuch, ed. 3: 216.
Hedge, I.C. &amp; J.M. Lamond (eds.), 1970. Index collectors Edinburgh Herb.: 87.
Kenyeres, Á. (ed.), 1967. Magyar Életrajzi Lexikon 1: 641-642. (d. "Csákvár")
Nelson, E.C., 1980. Glasra 4: 49. (specimens at DBN)
Sayre, G., 1971. Mem. New York Bot. Gard. 19: 208-209.

4941).

(3) Editor, <em>Acta Univ. Szeged., Sect. Sci. Nat., Pars Bot.</em>, n.s., vol. 5 (1939).
